DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE FM SAYS DISAGREEMENT OVER IRAQ HAS NOT DAMAGED U.N.

TEXT.P: Singapore's Foreign Minister S. Jayakumar said he does not think the disagreement over Iraq Has damaged the United Nations.
Addressing the annual U.N. General Assembly, he said this is not an occasion to revisit old debates over whether the war in Iraq was authorized.
So Jayakumar said it has underscored the fact that only the Security Council can authorize intervention when the Permanent Members are in agreement.

And that all states, big and small, will do what they must to protect their vital interests, he said, adding that it would be sometime before consensus could be reached on the U.N. role in post-war Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANGUAGES OF EACH ETHNIC GROUP SHOULD BE RESPECTED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said on Wednesday that the government will not obstruct the linguistic development of any specific ethnic group based on the principle of ethnic diversity and equality.
Yu said in a Cabinet meeting that the government will take concrete steps to show its determination to pursue ethnic diversity and the equal development of languages.
Yu stressed that the government will not allow the language of any specific ethnic group to dominate the country's resources.

The premier cited the example of the establishment of a Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs by the Chen Shui-bian administration to repair the biased cultural development caused over the last several decades.
Yu reaffirmed that the government will guarantee the fair usage of each language in the education, academic research, examination system, and culture conservation in the future.
Furthermore, Yu said he has instructed the Council for Cultural Affairs to draw up a bill on the development of national languages to implement fair linguistic development of each ethnic group.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE REMAINS NORMAL: VIRTUALLY NOTHING ACCOMPLISHED

TEXT.P: Political gridlock remained the operative word in the new session of the Legislative Yuan Wednesday as lawmakers accomplished nothing but to acknowledge the high-profile free trade agreement between Taiwan and Panama.
The accord was signed by President Chen Shui-bian and his Panamanian counterpart, Mireya Moscoso, Aug. 21 in Taipei.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng was forced to call off Wednesday's session in the early evening after party caucuses failed to reach a consensus over the legislation of six controversial bills.
The session was scheduled to run past midnight to deal with the six key draft bills that need to be approved soon.
Wang said that he will convene a coordination meeting among party caucuses again next Thursday to facilitating the passage of the legislation.

Notable among the controversial bills are revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, revisions to the Organic Law of the Judicial Yuan and revisions to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CLOSER ASIA-PACIFIC TIES TO STRENGTHEN SECURITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Asia-Pacific countries should continue to strengthen their ties to prevent crises in regional security or in the region's financial situation.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with a group of Japanese specialists who are participating in an international seminar on Asia-Pacific political and economic security in Taipei.
The Japanese guests were lead by Yoshio Okawara, chairman of the World Peace Research Institute of Japan.

Chen urged Asia-Pacific countries to strengthen their anti-terrorist cooperation, be aware of the possibility of nuclear weapons proliferation on the Korean Peninsula, help maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, and prevent the growth of weapons of mass destruction in the region.
The president also asked that people understand the "magnetic effect" that mainland China has on foreign investment and reflect on whether the renminbi should appreciate.
Chen also called for economic integration in the region to promote better trade ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FORM CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM PANEL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will form a special panel to flesh out President Chen Shui-bian's appeal to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006, a party official said Wednesday.

DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung told a news conference that the decision to form a constitutional reform panel was reached at a meeting of senior officials from the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and DPP headquarters a day earlier.
Chang said the new panel, to be jointly headed by himself and Chiou I-jen, President Chen's chief of staff, will be composed of scholars, experts, and DPP heavyweights.

The panel will study 11 major topics concerning Taiwan's constitutional reform, including a 50 percent cut of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, the legislative electoral system, the central government system -- a parliamentary system or an outright presidential system -- and a three-level or two-level administrative system, Chang said.

Addressing a Sunday rally in Taichung marking the Democratic Progressive Party's 17th founding anniversary, President Chen said in his capacity as the ruling party's chairman that in 2006, when the DPP turns 20 years old, he hopes all of the 23 million people of Taiwan will push for a new constitution.

Chen's remarks have drawn broadsides from opposition parties at home and caused concern among U.S. authorities about whether the "new constitution" call is a move to promote Taiwan's de jure independence which could provoke a military attack from mainland China.
Chang said Chen's call for a new constitution was mainly aimed at spearheading a process of constitutional reform to craft a political framework that would fit Taiwan's present realities.

Later in the day, Chang paid a visit to the DPP's legislative caucus to brief its members on the party headquarters' new decision. He said after meeting with DPP legislative whips that the party headquarters and the legislative caucus shared views on constitutional reform issues. He said the DPP legislative caucus will also form a nine-member task force to push for constitutional reform.

Meanwhile, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said the "pan-blue alliance's" presidential and vice presidential candidates for next year's election -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- should present their views on three major constitutional reform issues for public discussion.

The three issues are whether they support a presidential system or a dual-leadership system, whether they would resurrect the already marginalized Taiwan provincial government should they win the 2004 election, and whether they think that the vice president should be allowed to concurrently serve as premier.

"Constitutional reform is by no means 'boring' as claimed by the 'pan-blue' leaders. They should face up to all relevant issues squarely because these topics are critical to our nation's future development," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HAS PLAN FOR NEW CONSTITUTION, BUT ECONOMY IS REAL ISSUE: LIEN

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is not opposed to revising the ROC Constitution; however, it has its own proposals which will be put forward after listening to public opinion and consulting with other political parties, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday.

Three days after President Chen Shui-bian sending shockwaves through political circles by pledging to draw up a new constitution for the country by 2006, Lien said the key to revising the constitution lies in negotiations rather than a unilateral declaration.

However, the KMT chief, who will run for president in the 2004 election, said his party wants to address the problem that the public is most concerned about, which is not if the country should unite with the mainland, but how to boost the nation's sagging economy and improve the lives of its people.

Many of the current economic problems result from the fact that the government's economic policy was dictated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's political preferences and its desire to win the 2004 presidential election, Lien claimed.

As a way to win support for his presidential bid, Lien said the KMT and its political ally in the presidential election, the People First Party, will come up with a program to better the country's investment environment, sharpen its competitiveness, reform the financial system and protect the interests of farmers and laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN APPROVES TAIWAN-PANAMA FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved a free trade agreement (FTA) Wednesday signed by Taiwan and Panama, making the accord the first of its kind for Taiwan after the country entered the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Jan. 2002.

However, a resolution was attached to the passage because of its "flawed signing process" despite praise and encouragement by lawmakers from various political parties who expressed the hope that the pact would boost bilateral trade and economic exchanges between the two countries and help lay a sound foundation for similar agreements between Taiwan and other friendly nations.

The resolution requires that all agencies under the Executive Yuan must first gain legislative approval from now on in compliance with a constitutional requirement before they clinch bilateral or multilateral accords with other countries. The Executive Yuan also is required to make reports to legislative committees when encountering contradictory cases.

Lawmaker Shu Yuan-kuo of the opposition People First Party said the legislature was forced to accept the pact previously inked by President Chen Shui-bian and Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso on Aug. 21 in Taipei, while Chiang Yi-wen claimed that she also felt the Legislative Yuan was "looked down upon, " despite her happiness about the agreement.

Legislator Sun Kuo-hua of the major opposition Kuomintang hailed the Taiwan-Panama FTA as an encouraging breakthrough, and said he deeply hoped that the pact will set a framework for Taiwan to obtain such accords with other states.
The Taiwan-Panama FTA, which is to become effective on Jan. 1, 2004, is composed of 21 chapters, focusing on market access, service, investment and technical cooperation.

During the next 10-year period from the beginning of the next year, 97 percent of Taiwan-made industrial product items will be available to enter the Panamanian market on a zero-tariff basis, while 95 percent from Panama will be allowed to be imported into Taiwan under the same treatment.

At the same time, Taiwan's shipping, telecommunications and financial service industries will be given a boost to explore the Panamanian market, which is an ideal springboard to make inroad into American and international markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES TO BE FINED IF THEIR NOMINEES ARE CONVICTED

TEXT.P: Political parties will be fined if their nominees for public elections are convicted of vote-buying, organized crime or other felonies, according to a draft package of amendments to the existing election and recall law.

The package, drafted by the Ministry of the Interior, stipulates that parties will be slapped with a fine of between NT$500,000 and NT$5 million if any of their candidates is convicted of vote-buying, use of violence in the campaign process, candidacy fixing, organized crime or other felonies subject to a minimum 10-year prison term.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said after the Cabinet approved the basket of amendments to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law at its weekly meeting that the new penal regulation is aimed at pushing political parties to be more prudent in nominating their standard-bearers in public elections and thereby allowing the establishment of clean politics.

Yu said that although the election and recall law has undergone several small rounds of revisions since its enactment in 1980, it is still insufficient to cope with changing political and economic conditions.

"The newly drafted package marks the largest-ever amendments to the law, " Yu said. "The package will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and I hope the legislature can complete screening as soon as possible to help speed up political reform."
In addition to strengthening the mechanism to prevent those with links to organized crime from entering politics, the package also proposes penalties for vote-buying in intraparty primary elections.

Moreover, those involved in vote-buying in the elections of speakers and deputy speakers of legislative councils at central and local levels could be given prison terms ranging between three and 10 years plus fines ranging between NT$1 million and NT$10 million.

The draft package also lifts a controversial ban that prohibits police officers and students from becoming candidates for public elections. Once the package clears the legislature, police officers and adult students will be eligible to run for public office.
In addition, the package clearly forbids political parties or individuals from publishing, reporting or quoting the results of election public opinion polls within 10 days of a political election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE TO COVER HEPATITIS B, C PATIENTS

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) started a new program Wednesday to cover the treatment of hepatitis B and C.
BNHI officials said that both new and existing sufferers will be covered under the new program.

The officials said an annual budget of NT$1.2 billion (US$ 5.5 million) has been appropriated for the new program, but as there are only three months left of this year, the budget for the remainder of the year will be NT$400 million.

Liver disease is sometimes called Taiwan's "national disease" because of the large number of people with liver afflictions. It is estimated that the number of hepatitis B carriers in Taiwan is between 2.5 million and 3 million, and that the number of hepatitis C carriers is around 300,000.

As the medicines are expensive and the national health insurance previously has refused to provide coverage for treatment, few people receive treatment and the hepatitis usually deteriorates into cirrhosis and eventually liver cancer.
At the repeated urging of the medical profession, the BNHI has finally decided to cover the cost of the medicine, including expensive drugs such as lamivudine and ribavirin.
BNHI officials said that after a three-month trial period, the program will be reviewed to decide if the scale needs to be further expanded.
The officials said that the bureau will also set up a registration system to monitor the condition of patients receiving medication.

The officials said that at present, 84 hospitals are eligible to join the new program, all of which are regional-level or higher. Patients will be able to receive a one-month supply of medication at a time.

Doctors have said that the combination of the drug interferon with ribavirin has shown dramatic effects in curing hepatitis C, although the medication is less effective in the treatment of hepatitis B.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GENERATION OF FAST ATTACK BOATS INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A new generation fast attack boat developed by the navy was inaugurated Wednesday in a ceremony held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Navy Commander-in-Chief Miao Yung-ching presided over the inauguration held at the Tsoying naval base and said that the addition to the fleet of the new generation fast attack boat, designed to defend Taiwan's coastline and conduct blitz attacks, will enhance the navy's combat capability.

The prototype of the vessel completed its sea trials last September and the first of the craft was delivered to the navy in April. The boat, equipped with Hsiungfeng II missiles also developed in Taiwan, was demonstrated during the Hankuang 19 live-fire combined forces exercise in early September.
Miao noted that the time required to build the new boats is short and they are relatively inexpensive, but they can form a credible deterrent force.

The Navy's older Seagull fast attack boats have been in service for more than 20 years. The Seagull, at just over 50 tons, can be equipped with only two Hsiungfeng missiles, but the new generation fast boat is more than 170 tons and can be equipped with four of the missiles.
The new generation fast attack boat, is 34.2 meters long, 7.6 meters wide, four meters high and has a maximum speed of 33 knots. The hull is specially designed to evade radar detection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH JAPANESE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Wednesday with Katsuhiko Shirai, president of Japan's Waseda University, and expressed the hope that the university's baseball team can hold more friendship tournaments with teams from Taiwan universities.

Chen hailed Shirai as an outstanding educator and praised Waseda University, a prestigious school established more than 120 years ago, for having nurtured talent that has excelled both in Japan and in Taiwan.
He pointed out that in the Japanese Diet alone, more than 80 members are graduates of Waseda University, which has also produced many of Taiwan's political, media and sport high-fliers.
Hsieh Kuo-cheng, who has been hailed as Taiwan's "father of baseball," also graduated from Waseda University, Chen said.
The president said he hopes Shirai can further exchange views with Taiwan's educational sector during his stay.
Shirai for his part talked about higher education, saying that talent cultivation should have no boundaries and should also be a benign competition among universities.
Saying that universities should focus more on the humanities, Shirai also urged students to develop an understanding of Asian history to enlarge their outlook.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS EXPECTED AFTER NEXT COLD FRONT

TEXT.P: Bird conservationists said Wednesday that they might have to wait for the arrival of the next cold front to see alarge number of black-faced spoonbills coming to their main wintering habitat in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
The first of the endangered birds arrived at the Chiku wetlands Sept. 26, to the excitement of bird watchers, but no others have been spotted as yet.
Experts said that the lone bird came to Chiku early and suspect that the seven-year-old adult might not have found a partner and had therefore migrated earlier.

Although the black-faced spoonbills have yet to arrive en masse, the Tainan county government has made preparations for the winter guests in an effort to prevent the mass die-offs from botulism that occurred last winter.
In addition to a "save the black-faced spoonbill" drill over the weekend, the government is also mapping out plans for various agencies to save the endangered birds in case of emergency.

The Tainan County Livestock Disease Control Center has stepped up monitoring of the Chiku habitat for traces of botulism. As tests between June and August showed four feeding sites to be contaminated, the center sent workers to turn the soil in order to letting the sun kill off the botulin pathogen. The results of testing at 16 sites in September have yet to be released.

Each year, a large proportion of the world's remaining black-faced spoonbills migrate from the Korean peninsula and northeastern mainland China to the Chiku wetlands to spend the winter. More than 700 arrived last year, and the die-off of 71 last year was the first of its kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 30 PERCENT OF INTERNET USERS SEEK JOBS ONLINE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Over 30 percent of Taiwan's Internet users look for work online each month, with female job-seekers outnumbering males, according to the results of a recent survey.

The poll conducted by Insight Xplorer, a market consulting company based in Taipei, found that each executive search Web site received more than 30 percent of Internet users per month during the June-August period.
For instance in August, some 3.47 million users -- or 36 percent of the Taiwan's total 10 million cyber population -- logged on to the Internet to seek jobs, according to the survey results.

Since the beginning of this year's summer vacation, over 3 million Internet users sought jobs per month on line, with school students and graduates accounting for the largest portion of 34 percent of the total. Online female job seekers outnumbered their male counterparts by around 10 percent, an Insight Xplorer official said.
Each online job seeker visited executive search Web sites nine times per month, spending an average 38 minutes during each visit and browsing 52 pages, he went on.

Men and women aged between 20 and 30 accounted for the largest age group of nearly 40 percent of the online job seekers, followed by 24 percent made up of visitors aged between 30 and 40, the survey discovered.
In terms of occupation, school students and this year's graduates accounted for about 34 percent, while white-collar workers came in second with 22 percent.

104.com.tw was the most visited executive search site in August, luring 2.58 million online visitors -- more than 70 percent of the total job seekers that month in the domestic employment market. 1111. com.tw, career.com.tw and a site run by the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs were also popular, according to the survey.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported that the number of Taiwan's jobless workers totaled 529,000 in August, representing an unemployment rate of 5.21 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN PASSES BILL FURTHER LOWERING LAND INCREMENT TAX

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved an amendment to the land laws Wednesday, allowing the increment tax on land value to be further lowered in a bid to rekindle the domestic real estate and housing market.

In view of the fact that the existing implementation of halved land value increment taxes is scheduled to expire Jan. 31, 2004, the Cabinet passed the amendment to lower the increment taxes on land value to 40 percent, 30 percent and 20 percent, respectively, from the current levels of 60 percent, 50 percent and 40 percent.
The amendment is expected to be implemented after it is submitted to the Legislative Yuan and approved.

In the first year of the implementation of halved land value increment taxation, between Feb. 1, 2002 and Jan. 31, 2003, more than 330,000 pieces of land changed hands in transactions, up 40 percent -- or some 90,000 cases -- over the year-earlier levels, according to Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials.

During this period, revenues generated from those transactions reached NT$50.2 billion (US$14.76 billion), representing an increase of 26 percent, or NT$10.4 billion, over the year-earlier levels, the officials added.
MOF officials said that the halved land value increase taxation design has had a noticeable effect in rejuvenating Taiwan's real estate and housing business over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX REBATE SYSTEM FOR FOREIGN TOURISTS LAUNCHED TO BOOST TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taiwan launched a tax rebate system for foreign tourists Wednesday as part of its efforts to rev up its tourism industry.

Customs official said that foreign tourists who make one-stop purchases totalling NT$3,000 (US$88.75) or more at selected shops during their stay can apply for a 5-percent tax rebate upon their departure from Taiwan.

Foreign tourists who spend NT$3,000 or more in a shop displaying the "tax return shopping (TRS) " logo and take the goods out of the country within 30 days will be eligible to apply for the tax rebate at the airport upon departure.
More than 20 department stores around the island have been selected as TRS shops so far.
Customs authorities said the new tax rebate measure will cost the national coffers an estimated NT$700 million (US$20.6 million) in business tax revenues annually.
The tax rebate scheme is part of an ambitious tourism promotion project aimed at doubling the number of tourist arrivals by 2008, government officials said.

Meanwhile, Tourism Bureau Director Su Chen-tien said the government has decided to designate 2004 as Taiwan's "tourism year, " during which a series of cultural activities, street carnivals and folk arts exhibitions will be held to attract foreign and overseas Chinese visitors.

The programs will include an expanded lantern festival, carnival-style trade fairs and traditional operatic performances, Su said, adding that many new tour packages, including ecotours and trips to new tourist farms, will be presented.

Su said that although the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks between March and June this year dealt a severe blow to the local tourism industry, the number of tourist arrivals has rebounded since July.
"In July, more than 154,000 foreign tourists visited Taiwan, increasing to 206,000 in August. We believe that tourist arrivals will continue rise in the months ahead," Su said confidently.

He said the Tourism Bureau will send a delegation of local chefs to various U.S. cities later this month to demonstrate their culinary arts and introduce newly developed Chinese cuisine menus as part the bureau's efforts to attract visitors looking for a taste of delicious Chinese food.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE BATTERIES POISONING TAIWAN: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Substandard batteries from mainland China are increasingly poisoning Taiwan with mercury and other hazardous mineral waste, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung claimed Wednesday.

Speaking at a press conference that he organized in conjunction with the non-profit Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, Hsu said the mainland dumps about 20,000 tons of substandard batteries in Taiwan annually without attracting notice from the Taiwan authorities.

The batteries, with an average mercury content that is 360 times larger than those of legally controlled batteries, are posing an appalling threat to Taiwan's environment and the people's lives, according to Hsu.

Hsu called for the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to step up the inspection and interception of the mainland batteries while raising the retrieval rate of all batteries disposed of in Taiwan by at least 10 percent.
The mainland batteries -- many of which are produced in underground factories and illegally smuggled into Taiwan -- are easily available on the shelves of NT$10-per-item stores, Hsu said.
He added that most of them have also been dumped in the Taiwan market at lower-than-normal prices and carry fake EPA quality certification marks.
Hsu also called for the EPA to accelerate the retrieval of disposed batteries of all kinds, particularly those that are poisonous or hazardous to the environment.

Hsu said the disposed battery retrieval rate was about 6.3 percent two years ago. Although the rate had been raised to 10.5 percent in the first four months of this year, the retrieval rate is still relatively low in comparison with the rates in most industrially advanced countries.

He suggested that the EPA set forth and publicize a clear battery retrieval policy and set a retrieval goal of 30 percent in the first year of implementation, gradually increasing to 60 percent in three years.

Hsu said one tiny button battery can pollute 6,000 tons of water, equivalent to the amount that a single person consumes in 60 years, while a lead-acid car battery is capable of causing one square foot of land to become too toxic to farm forever.

He warned that some 10,000 tons of used batteries are thrown into Taiwan's incinerators or landfills each year, polluting an immeasurable volume of water and air with mercury, lead, chromium and other depleting elements.
Meanwhile, Liu Ming-long, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, said mainland batteries are commonly dumped in Taiwan packed together with cheap toys and games.

Liu urged the government to strengthen controls on these products, charging that they not only constitute a hazard to Taiwan's environment, they also adversely affect the interests of Taiwan's traders and consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 29.75 points to close at 5,581.66.
The bourse opened at 5,599.1 and then fluctuated between 5,613.18 and 5,560.55 during trading.

A total of 2.27 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$49.69 billion (US$1.47 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.42 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$50.54 billion (US$1.5 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.3 percent, pulp and paper issues and foodstuff shares, both at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, electrical shares at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 585 to 169, with 116 stocks remaining unchanged.

Market turnover amounted to NT$49.69 billion (US$1.47 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER RETURNS AFTER U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien has returned to Taipei after a visit to the United States, diplomatic sources said Wednesday.

"Chien returned home earlier in the day after presiding over a working meeting in Baltimore, Maryland, of Taiwan officials stationed in the United States, " said a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official who asked to remain anonymous.
According to the official, Chien took advantage of his visit to brief U.S. officials on President Chen Shui-bian's idea to push for the introduction of a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

Addressing a Sunday rally in Taichung marking the Democratic Progressive Party's 17th founding anniversary, President Chen said in his capacity as the ruling party's chairman that in 2006, when the DPP turns 20 years old, he hopes all of the 23 million people of Taiwan will push for a new constitution.

Chen's remarks have drawn broadsides from opposition parties at home and caused concern among U.S. authorities about whether the "new constitution" call is a move to promote Taiwan's de jure independence which could provoke a military attack from mainland China.
The MOFA official said Chien explained to U.S. authorities the main reasons behind Chen's call for a new constitution.

"Chien told relevant U.S. officials that Taiwan needs to largely amend its current constitution or enact a new one in order to fit the island's present realities and facilitate its reforms on various fronts, including a conscription system overhaul and a reduction in the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan, " the official said.
He added that after hearing Chien's explanations, the U.S. authorities have a better understanding of President Chen's stance.
The official further said that Taiwan has consistently maintained smooth communications with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 1, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

The National University Hospital (NUH) of Singapore will lower some charges for Class B1 wards by year-end, after its rates were found to be way out of line compared to other public hospitals.
In 10 out of 15 medical procedures in B1 wards, NUH charges the highest rates, some as much as 70 percent more than the hospital offering the lowest price.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN HALF AMERICAN PEOPLE DO NOT CONSIDER CHINA AN ALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: More than a half of the American people do not consider mainland China an ally, according to the results of a poll conducted by Zogby International Sept. 5-9.

The survey commissioned by New York-based Foreign Policy Association (FPA) shows that 51 percent of the respondents do not consider China an ally, 38 percent view it as a "so-so" ally, 8 percent describe it as a good ally and 3 percent are unsure.

When asked to identify the greatest challenge facing the relationship between China and the United States, 28 percent of respondents chose human rights from a list of issues, 22 percent cited differences in political views, 21 percent mentioned the issue of North Korea, 17 percent picked trade issues and 7 percent cited military competition.
The results show that Americans now view China more as an economic competitor in the era of globalization than the stark threat from the Cold War era, analysts said.
The poll also shows that Americans most often view the United Kingdom (90 percent), Canada (73 percent) , Israel (57 percent) and Mexico (56 percent) as good allies of the United States.

Founded in 1918, the FPA is a national, nonprofit, nonpartisan, nongovernmental, educational organization set up to educate Americans about the significant international issues that influence their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD FAULTED BY U.S. WATCHDOG GROUP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's human rights record has not improved in the last year, according to a group set up by Congress to monitor Chinese human rights.

In its annual report, the Congressional-Executive Commission on China said both the Congress and the Executive branch should step up their diplomatic efforts to prod Beijing into honoring its promises about improving its human rights record, including the release of people illegally detained.

The commission also recommended that the Congress and the Bush administration should ask Beijing to arrange trips to the mainland by the U.S. International Religion Freedom Committee and United Nations religious groups to inspect its human rights practices.

The Congressional-Executive Commission on China was created by Congress in October 2000 with the legislative mandate to monitor human rights and the development of the rule of law in China, and to submit an annual report to the president and Congress.

It consists of nine senators, nine members of the House of Representatives, and five senior administration officials appointed by the president. The current chairman is Congressman Jim Leach and the co-chair is Senator Chuck Hagel.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO BRIEF LEGISLATURE ON BUDGET

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will brief the Legislative Yuan on the government's 2004 budget Friday.
According to a budget plan already presented to the legislature, the government's total outlay will be NT$1.61 trillion (US$48.07 billion), NT$61 billion more than the previous year.
Meanwhile, the total revenue is estimated at NT$1.35 trillion, which means there will be a shortfall of NT$257.4 billion that will have to be raised through borrowing, according to the budget plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIMING TO ATTRACT 1.8 M. TOURISTS IN FOURTH QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's tourism industry is getting back on track following the recent severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak, and the Tourism Board hopes to woo 1.8 million visitors during this quarter to reach its target of 6 million visitors for the year.

Hotels, shopping centers and tourist attractions in Singapore were deserted during the SARS outbreak. Visitor numbers plunged more than 70 percent for May compared to the year-earlier level. However, five months later, tourist numbers are almost back to normal.

The Tourism Board is confident that upcoming events, like powerboat racing and wrestling events, will be able to draw 1.8 million more visitors to the city-state over the final three months of this year.
The Tourism Board said regional markets are fueling the recovery in Singapore's tourism industry, particularly tourists from mainland China, the Philippines and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR CLAIMS ORCHID ISLAND ABORIGINES MIGHT HAIL FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A local archaeologist said Thursday that the theory that the Tao aborigines residing on Orchid Island hail from the Philippines island of Bataan is questionable.

Tsang Chen-hua, curator of the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, said the available archaeological evidence shows that the Tao people are more likely to have originated from Taiwan rather than Bataan.

Tsang said that although the possibility of the Tao people immigrating from Bataan to Orchid Island -- located some 42 kilometers off the coast of Taitung -- cannot be completely ruled out, the facts reflected by the evidence should also not be ignored.
Quoting archaeological documents, Tsang said, people from Taiwan began traveling to Orchid Island during what is known as the Fine Corded-Pottery Culture Period more than 4,000 years ago.
Artifacts unearthed on Orchid Island and Taitung also show that people from Taiwan continued traveling to Orchid Island during the Peinan Culture Period some 2,500 years ago, Tsang said.

Moreover, he went on, the Tao people's jar burial tradition more likely originated in Taiwan. Relics of jars containing human remains have been excavated at the site for the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan and at several areas in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung.

According to Tsang, the Tao culture emerged after the Fine Corded-Pottery Culture Period and the Peinan Culture Period and he said he has completed an academic paper suggesting that the ancestors of Tao aborigines came from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRWOMAN HOPES FOR PASSAGE OF DRAFT AMENDMENTS TO KEY LAW

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday that she hopes revisions to a key law governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China will clear the legislature next week.

Tsai's remarks came one day after negotiations among legislators on the draft amendments to seven key laws, including the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law and the Organic Law of the Judicial Yuan collapsed.

Attributing the break-up of the negotiations to the lack of consensus, the MAC chairwoman said she will do her best to assert her stance in favor of the passage of the amendments in order to gain support from opponents, mainly lawmakers of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Following a discussion of more than an hour with the opponents after the negotiations broke up Wednesday, Tsai told a conference later the same day that lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accepted her explanation and agreed to her plan to maintain the eight-year threshold, which will be imposed in the future with complementary measures based on control quotas.

Tsai promised to adopt a quota-based control system in conjunction with her plan to continue allowing mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan residents to receive ID cards after having lived in Taiwan for eight years -- one of the major disputes in which TSU lawmakers have demanded prolonging the wait period to 11 years out of their concern over national security and social order.

These quotas will be decided in compliance with the government's demographic policy, she explained, adding that she will continue negotiations with the TSU legislators to seek their backing on the issue.

TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen claimed that his party insists that the wait period be prolonged to 11 years and added that the TSU is also firmly opposed to amendments that would permit mainland-based colleges to recruit students in Taiwan and allow the opening of direct cross-strait transport links.
Earlier Thursday, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced that legislators had agreed to resume negotiations and screening on these disputed amendments Oct. 9.

Chen Chung-hsin, director of the DPP's mainland affairs department, called for quick passage of the long-awaited law revisions, especially those to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, despite the fact that sharp differences remain in the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF TWO ALLIES TO ATTEND ROC NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: The president of Gambia, Yahya Jammeh and the president of Malawi, Bakili Muluzi, have confirmed that they will attend Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) sources said Thursday.

To celebrate the gradually recovering economy, the government has decided to increase the scale of this year's celebration. In addition to the heads of state of Gambia and Malawi, many high-ranking officials from other diplomatic allies, including Palau, Grenada and Dominica, will also come to Taiwan to participate in the event.
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission will invite second-generation of overseas Chinese to visit Taiwan to experience the nation's progress and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH DANISH PARLIAMENTARIANS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that it will not be in Taiwan's interest if mainland China's economy is developed to pay for military expansion.

Chen made the remarks in a meeting with Poul Nodgaard, deputy speaker of Denmark's parliament, who is making his second visit to Taiwan since 2000 at the head of a pro-Taiwan group of Danish parliamentarians.

In addition to expressing gratitude to the parliamentarians for what they have done for Taiwan, Chen said he also hopes that the Danish Parliament can pass a resolution demanding that Beijing dismantle the more than 500 missiles along its southeastern coast targeting Taiwan.

Nodgaard and Chen also talked about issues of mutual concern, including human rights, the impact of mainland China's economic development on Taiwan, the prevention of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Chen said the impact of SARS on Taiwan would have been less if the island had been a WHO member and he urged the Danish Parliament to show its support for Taiwan's WHO bid as did the European Parliament.

Meanwhile, Chen added that he feels it ironic that due to pressure from Beijing, Denmark, a democratic country, did not allow him to receive the 2001 Prize for Freedom of the Liberal International at a ceremony held in Copenhagen.
Instead, Chen's wife had to travel to Strasbourg, France, to receive the award on Chen's behalf.

Despite the unpleasant past, Chen said, Taiwan and Denmark have maintained close economic and trade relations, with bilateral trade reaching US$457 million last year, leaving a trade surplus of US$83 million in Taiwan's favor.
Chen hailed Denmark's achievements in high technology, design and biotechnology and expressed the hope that the two countries can have more exchanges in these areas in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION TRYING TO RETAIN EPA CHIEF: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his administration is doing all it can to dissuade Hau Lung-bin, chief of Environmental Protection Administration, from resigning.

Meeting with a group of officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, of which he is chairman, in Taichung City, the president said his administration cannot afford to lose a Cabinet member as popular as Hau, who tendered his resignation Wednesday when Premier Yu Shyi-kun refused to exclude environmental protection issues already decided through environmental impact assessments from problems that could be put to referendum.

The premier called on Hau at his residence Thursday evening to urge the environmental chief to remain in the Cabinet despite their differences, but Hau seemed unmoved by the premier's persuasions. When the premier left, Hau told journalists camping outside his house that his continued presence in the Cabinet would only become a political burden for Yu's Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: OB-GYN CLINICS CLOSING DUE TO DECLINING BIRTH RATE

TEXT.P: About one-third of Taiwan's private obstetric clinics have been forced to change their service fields or close altogether because of the ever-declining birth rate, medical sources said Thursday.

Lee Mao-sheng, president of the Society of Obstetrics and Gynecology (SOG) in Taiwan, said the birth rate has been declining by 10 percent annually in recent decades, forcing many ob-gyn clinics to scale down or suspend operations.

According to Lee, more than 410,000 babies were born in 1981, but the number dropped to slightly more than 320,000 in 1991 and plunging further to about 260,000 in 2001 and 247,000 in 2002. The number of infants to be born this year is estimated at 210,000.

Lee said major local associations of obstetricians and gynecologists have discussed this downward trend many times. Rising tuition fees and the sluggish economy might be discouraging people from having babies, Lee said, adding that the SOG is watching to see whether the trend will continue deteriorating.

A few years ago, Lee said, Taiwan still had 1,800 private obstetric clinics. "Nowadays, only about 1,200 of them are still operating, marking a 33 percent decline, " he said, adding that some 600 professional obstetricians or gynecologists have transferred to family medicine or other medical fields, or have simply retired.
To the best of his understanding, Lee said, many clinics now focus on treating women's diseases or disorders related to the reproductive system or menopause.

Of the clinics in the four cities and counties of central Taiwan, fewer than 15 can deliver more than 10 babies a month, Lee said. With the number of pregnant women declining, he said, SOG members are treating only 27 outpatients per day. "Ob-Gyn doctors can hardly make a living on such a small number of patients," he noted.
As a result, many local ob-gyn clinics have adopted promotional strategies to attract customers, including offering gifts to newborns or free specially prepared meals for new mothers.

According to government tallies, each Taiwan woman now gives birth to an average of just 1.3 children. The Ministry of the Interior has proposed a package of 12 measures to encourage marriage and birth, with a view to raising the number of children born to each local woman to 1.6 in 30 years.

Later this year, the ministry will also come up with a report on problems that might arise from an aging population and declining birth rate. Ministry officials said they will push the Cabinet to offer more incentives or subsidies to encourage childbirth.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG STEPS UP PATROLS AROUND TUNGSHA, NANSHA ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau is cooperating with the Coast Guard Administration to protect fishery resources around the Tungsha and Nansha islands in the South China Sea, bureau officials said Thursday.
Tungsha, also known as the Pratas, and Nansha, also known as the Spratlys, are claimed in whole or in part by a number of countries.
The Republic of China claims sovereignty over the two archipelagoes and they are under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung city government.
The officials said coast guard patrols have driven away more than 170 fishing boats from the areas since the beginning of this year.
Most of the boats belong to neighboring countries and mainland China, said the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT TRADE ON INCREASE: BOFT

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait trade amounted to US$24.55 billion in the first seven months of this year, an increase of 22.2 percent over the previous year's level, according to statistics released Thursday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

During the January-July period, the statistics show, Taiwan exported goods worth US$18.82 billion to and imported US$5.73 billion-worth of goods from mainland China, up 18.7 percent and 35.3 percent, respectively, on a year-to-year basis.

In July alone, exports to the mainland registered a year-on-year growth of 15.9 percent, while imports from the mainland increased by 23.4 percent, making the mainland Taiwan's third largest supplier, surpassing South Korea.
At the same time, Taiwan received orders worth US$3.42 billion from the mainland, including Hong Kong, setting a new monthly record.

BOFT officials attributed the growth of cross-strait trade to the world economic recovery and the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome. They predicted that two-way trade will continue to grow in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TOURISM BOARD BLACKLISTS 9 STORES

TEXT.P: Nine stores in Singapore, some with more than one outlet, have been blacklisted by the Tourism Board of Singapore.

The Tourism Board had earlier warned that any store that received three or more complaints from tourists would be blacklisted. The nine stores, which received three or more such complaints between July and September, have been blacklisted for six months.
One of the shops that was blacklisted is Budget Electronics at the Mandarin Shopping Arcade. Just three weeks earlier, it had been nominated for a Singapore Tourism Board award by tourist shoppers.
The president of the retailers association said he is upset with the blacklist. The retailers association is worried that a few black sheep could tarnish the entire sector.
Many tourists, however, have applauded the move, and the shopping malls where some of these errant shops are located are already taking steps to improve their image.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEGINS TRAINING SEEING EYE DOGS

TEXT.P: A local welfare organization began training a seeing eye dog Thursday as part of its efforts to enhance the independence, dignity and self-confidence of Taiwan's blind people.
The Institute for the Blind of Taiwan said the country's first internationally licensed seeing eye dog trainer has begun to train an eight-month-old Labrador from New Zealand.
The institute was the first Taiwan welfare organization to introduce specially bred and trained seeing eye dogs to help people who are blind or visually impaired to travel safely and independently.
Since 1993, the institute has imported 10 professionally trained seeing eye dogs from Japan, Australia and New Zealand. The oldest one retired earlier this year after 10 years of service.

Because of significant differences in the general living environment in Taiwan and the three advanced countries from which the animals come, the foreign-trained dogs have had difficulty adapting to life in Taiwan. In some cases, an institute spokesman said, they are scared by the undisciplined swarms of motorcycles on local streets, resulting in injuries to their blind masters.

The institute therefore decided to send local pet training experts to New Zealand to study advanced seeing eye training skills and gaining expertise in preparation for training professional guide dogs in Taiwan.
Chen Ya-fang is the first to obtain an international license to enter the guide dog training profession.

Chen said she has endured many daunting challenges and tests during her three-and-a-half years of study in New Zealand. "My love of dogs has helped me overcome all the difficulties and complete my studies," she said.
According to Chen, Labradors make the best guide dogs as they are docile and interact well with their masters.

In advanced countries, Chen said, there is one seeing eye dog for every 100 blind people. "In terms of this ratio, Taiwan should have 500 guide dogs, as the nation has about 50,000 blind or visually impaired persons. At the moment, we have only 10 dogs, so we still have a long way to go," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK ANALYSTS AWAIT IMPACT OF QFII MECHANISM ABOLITION

TEXT.P: The qualified foreign institutional investor (QFII) mechanism that has regulated foreign investments in Taiwan's securities and future market for 13 years was abolished Thursday, according to Wu Tang-chieh, vice chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC).
Wu said that a foreign investor needs to state in the registration document whether the nature of the investment is for the purpose of actual investment or hedging.

If the investor is not a fund, the declaration shall state that the investment capital in Taiwan is not, and shall not, be funded from mainland China or Taiwan and that the investor shall not use unjust methods to manipulate the financial market.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced in July that the foreign investment regulations would be amended and the QFII registration replaced by a single registration with the Central Bank and the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE), with no investment quota for new foreign institutional investors.

While Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) is expected to elevate the weightings of the Taiwan index constituents in November, the SFC has anticipated that the timing for suspending the QFII mechanism will have some effect on the MSCI decision, according to Wu.

Norman Villamin, Asia-Pacific strategist at Morgan Stanley, said that as the announcement in July has induced a capital flow into Taiwan's stock market over the past few months and has stimulated stock prices, the suspension of the QFII mechanism might not have much impact on Taiwan's stock market.

On the other hand, some market observers have suggested that anticipation that the Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) would elevate the current Limited Investability Factor (LIF) applied to the MSCI Taiwan Index constituent might induce another US$30 billion to US$35 billion foreign capital into the Taiwan stock market.

The MSCI has applied the LIF in Taiwan as an instrument to reflect market restrictions and obstacles to foreign investment. At present, the MSCI applies to LIF of 0.55 to the free float-adjusted market capitalization of all constituents in the MSCI Taiwan index.

Statistics released by the MOF indicate that foreign capital inflows into Taiwan's stock market reached a single-month height in August, totaling US$4.218 billion. Between January 2000 and Sept. 5, 2003, foreign capital inflows amounted to US$57.324 billion.

Since the government allowed qualified foreign institutional investors to invest in Taiwan stocks in 1991, a total of 719 QFIIs have operated in the Taiwan Stock Exchange, according to MOF statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL LANGUAGE CHOICE SHOULD TRANSCEND POLITICS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the establishment of official languages should be based on the respect of differences among various ethnic groups and cultures, and should transcend stereotypes and political ideology.
Chen made the remarks in an essay on the beauty and diversity of Taiwan's languages in his electronic newspaper.

Chen noted that when he was small, he talked with his parents in Taiwanese and it was not until he entered school that he started to learn mandarin Chinese. In Junior high school, he studied English and heard a lot of classmates speaking Hakka and aboriginal languages.

"Although my wife Wu Shu-chen often laughs at me for speaking `Taiwanese mandarin,'" the president said, the purpose of talk is to communicate and although his is not standard usage, the listener can understand and the purpose of communication is served.
The president also said that he speaks Hakka and aboriginal languages now on occasion and even though he is far from fluent, it helps to "bridge the gap between him and his audiences."

Chen said that "everyone" knows that the languages spoken in Taiwan are the result of historical development and social structure, adding that the Japanese colonists and later the Kuomintang regime invariably used high-handed methods to impose their languages on the people, which he said seriously damaged the development of other cultures.

Chen said that there are 29 languages spoken in Taiwan, including Taiwanese, mandarin, Hakka and more than a dozen aboriginal languages. According to UNESCO statistics, however, there are only 22 languages left in Taiwan and the other seven have disappeared.
Chen said: "We should pay more attention to ensure the continued passing on of the languages of minor ethnic groups."
The president also said that the establishment of official languages should be based on the principles of respect, linguistics, education and ethnic relations.
The establishment of official languages should serve as a tool for communication and that priority should be given to the convenience of the majority, the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA CHIEF SAYS HE IS STILL DETERMINED TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: The administrator of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration, Hau Lung-bin, who tendered his resignation Wednesday, said Thursday that he is determined to quit despite pleas from Premier Yu Shyi-kun.
Hau made the statement during a visit to an environmental protection supervisory unit in Taichung, central Taiwan. He said he went to say goodbye to his colleagues.

Hau is the only Cabinet member who belongs to an opposition party -- the New Party. He is also a popular figure among high-ranking government officials. Hau decided to resign after his suggestion that environmental issues should not be subject to a vote in referendums was not accepted by Premier Yu, who maintained that the views of experts should not prevail over democracy.

Hau made his suggestion after residents of Pinglin, a rural township in Taipei County, held a non-binding referendum last month to urge the central government to open a ramp linking the town to a freeway, despite a decision made by Hau's specialists on the issue that such a move would damage the environment of Pinglin, located near a catchment for a reservoir that supplies drinking water to the metropolitan Taipei area.
Hau said he was afraid that accepting these sorts of referendums would trigger a domino effect in other areas of Taiwan that would seriously damage the island's environment.

Not to Hau's surprise, several non-binding referendums are planned for other townships around the island, with the subjects focusing on whether the residents should have an incinerator or crematorium in the area.
On Thursday, Hau encouraged his colleagues to continue their fight for the protection of the environment of the island.
Stressing that he will not be involved in political affairs in the short term, Hau said he may serve as a volunteer worker in the future for the welfare of the country.

Meanwhile, the Democratic Progressive Party government is still trying to convince Hau to stay, with Premier Yu going to Hau's residence Thursday to make one final attempt to dissuade Hau from stepping down.
Hau, who assumed his post in March 2001, grabbed the spotlight by his successful implementation of a policy limiting the use of plastic bags around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES NOT TO PHASE OUT VOCATIONAL HIGH SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian promised Thursday that his administration will not phase out vocational high schools, saying that students should have a wider range of options in Taiwan's diversified and pluralistic society.
Chen made the remarks at the opening of a two-day national conference being held in central Taichung, which brought the heads of vocational high schools across Taiwan together.

In an effort to allay their concern over the issue, Chen said vocational high schools are not affiliated with normal high schools and stressed that the government in turn will devote more energy and resources to develop vocational education facilities instead of abolishing them.

The government should build a good environment in which Taiwan's children and youth should be provided with more options and channels to develop their interests, potential and dispositions, the president said, expressing the hope that the current meeting will help create more favorable conditions for the normal development of elementary school and junior high school education.

"Taiwan's education environment must be more flexible and multitudinous, and a sound and high-quality vocational high school system plays a key role in the nation's educational spectrum, " he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE IN TWO AREAS IN CENTRAL TAIWAN WANT TO HOLD REFERENDUMS

TEXT.P: People living in two small areas in central Taiwan said Thursday that they will hold referendums to highlight their opposition to their local governments' plans to build an incinerator and a crematorium in their neighborhoods.
They made the statements after high-ranking government officials said recently that it is legitimate for local governments to hold referendums on local and autonomous affairs.

People living in Chichi, a small town in Nantou County, will vote in a referendum Saturday to show their strong opposition to a government plan to build an incinerator near their town, said Huang Yen-min, president of the Chichi Environmental Protection Association.
After the referendum, they will go to Taipei to present a petition to the Executive Yuan, to ensure that their voice is heard by the central government, organizers said.

People living near a cemetery in suburban Touliou, a city in Yunlin County, said they will also vote in a referendum to dramatize their opposition to a plan to build a crematorium in their neighborhood, because it will send the prices of real estate in the area into a tailspin and cause their living environment to deteriorate.

DOC.HEADLINE: 99.99-METER RICE NOODLE TO BE MADE AT HSINCHU NOODLE FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The sponsor of a rice noodle festival said Thursday that the feature this year will be the creation of the world's longest rice noodle - all 99.99 meters of it.

Chou Tsou-huei, chairman of the Hsinchu branch of the Kuomintang, noted that rice noodles are one of the most famous delicacies of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan, and the Fourth Hsinchu International Rice Noodle Festival will kick off Oct. 18.
Chou said that last year, the festival unveiled an 88.88-meter rice noodle to the amazement of spectators, and this year, an even longer one will steal the show.
But he said that in the past years, the long rice noodle was made in silver and white, and because the display space was large enough, a "huge straight line" was formed.
But his year, the record rice noodle will be in white (rice), red (tomato) and purple (taro) and its arrangement will be in a meandering manner according to the terrain.
A series of fun-oriented activities related to rice noodles will also be held between Oct. 18-26, Chou said. (By Lilian Wu) ENDTIEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO DELIVER CHILDREN BOOKS IN ENGLISH TO REMOTE AREAS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) will transport 100,000 children's books in English for free to remote areas for school children between November and Christmas Eve this year, a CAL spokesman said Thursday.

The spokesman noted that a lot of children in Taiwan start to learn English at an early age, but many children in remote areas can't afford to buy English books. CAL started the campaign last year to collect children's books in English and distributed 70,000 books.

This year, overseas Chinese in San Francisco, Los Angles, New York and Hawaii donated around 100,000 children's books, and CAL will transport the books in three flights to school children in remote areas.
The spokesman said that in addition to English books, the air carrier is recruiting volunteers this year to teach students how to
read.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHECKING REPORTED REJECTION OF NEW TAIWAN PASSPORT IN BOSNIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed the hope Thursday that Bosnia would respect the new version of Republic of China passports as effective travel documents for the people of Taiwan.
MOFA spokesman Richard Shih made the remarks after reports from travel agents said the East European country had refused to issue visas to Taiwan citizens holding the new version of the passport.
Chu Chien-sung, deputy director of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said that the ministry is checking on the matter through appropriate channels.
Chu said that the ministry was surprised when travel agents alerted them to the matter, since Taiwan tourists seldom travel to Bosnia, and the government has no missions stationed there.

The ministry further learned that a particular travel agent had applied for visas through the Bosnia embassy in Slovenia. As the ROC government also has no missions stationed in Slovenia, it has to check on the matter through other channels.
Chu said the ministry is trying to learn whether the rejection was because of the new version of the passport or because of the Taiwan tourists themselves.

But Chu said that before the launch of the new version of the passport last month, the ministry had asked all missions overseas to communicate with governments of their hosting countries, and Bosnia falls under the jurisdiction of Taipei's representative office in Hungary.
Chu noted that Rock Leng, ROC representative to Hungary, has notified the Bosnian embassy in Hungary about the new version of the passport, and did not receive an unfavorable response.
The MOFA launched the new version of passport Sept. 1, with the word "Taiwan" in capitalized Roman script added to the official name of the Republic of China to the cover.
The MOFA said the new ROC passport will make it more distinguishable from the one issued by the People's Republic of China (PRC) -- mainland China's official name.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Outside Probe of Leaks Is Favored. Poll Findings Come As White House Softens Denials.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT READY TO GO ALL OUT TO ATTRACT PRIVATE SECTOR INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The government is prepared to pull out all the stops to stimulate investment from the private sector, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Thursday.

Lin, who also serves as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks at the opening of a two-day seminar sponsored by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BOTC) on the private-government partnership on public works construction in the United Kingdom.

The Executive Yuan hopes to receive NT$313.9 billion (US$9.2 billion) in private sector investment for 167 public construction projects during the 2003-2005 period, and it has succeeded in courting NT$57.3 billion worth of such capital for 16 projects during the first nine months of this year, Lin noted.

The Executive Yuan also set up an ad hoc group under its auspices late last year to push all related government agencies to devote themselves to promoting private sector investment in public construction projects, Lin said, adding that the Cabinet also appointed 16 categories, with concrete programs and measures, as the top options for the private sector to take part in.
Public Construction Commission Chairwoman Kuo Yao-chi and BOTC Director-General Derek Marsh also gave speeches on the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, giving up NT$0.042 to close at NT$33.768.
A total of US$445 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.789, and was traded between NT$33.763 and NT$33.795.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG HANDLED SARS MOSTLY EFFECTIVELY: INDEPENDANT REPORT

TEXT.P: An independent report says that the Hong Kong government handled the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) effectively overall.

The report released Thursday by a committee investigating the SARS outbreaks in Hong Kong earlier in the year said that there were significant shortcomings in the government's initial response to the crisis.
But it noted that overall, the epidemic was handled well. No one has been singled out for blame.
The committee consisting of 11 doctors and medical professors said it had not found any individuals culpable of negligence or maladministration.
It also came out with several recommendations, including the establishment of a center for health protection.
The committee said that strengthening disease monitoring is an urgent priority.
The committee was earlier set up by Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa to investigate the SARS outbreaks, which claimed nearly 300 lives.
Its 11 members consist of seven from overseas, two from mainland China and two from Hong Kong.
Meanwhile, Tung welcomed the report, reiterating that the government handled the outbreaks well and is willing to improve in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO RISE

TEXT.P: The private sector's participation in public construction projects amounted to NT$57.3 billion (US$1.7 billion) in the first nine months of this year, and is forecast to reach NT$90 billion for the whole of 2003 and NT$120.9 billion in 2004, a high-ranking official said Thursday.

Kuo Yao-chi, chairperson of the Public Construction Commission of the Executive Yuan, said in a seminar that the government plans to budget NT$500 billion for public construction projects from 2004 to 2008, hoping that the private sector will invest the same amount of money in public construction projects during the five-year period.
The government will make good use of foreign technology and capital in public construction projects, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE POP CULTURE CHIC TO TAIPEI YOUTH

TEXT.P: In terms of chic, Taiwan youths are attracted by things Japanese, with 40 percent who responded to a survey released Thursday saying that they like Japanese pop culture most.
Twenty-three percent of Taipei youths said they like European and American pop culture, followed by local pop culture at 19 percent.
Though Korean TV series's are popular in Taiwan, only 6 percent of the youths polled said they like Korean pop culture.

The survey, conducted by the Taipei Youth Activity Center under the Taipei City Government, investigated the current developments and trends on four aspects -- the Internet, music and dance, dress, and idols.

The results showed that youths look most to the Internet for pop culture information, or 58 percent, followed by music and dance performance (42 percent), dress and info on idols accounted for 37 percent and 33 percent respectively.

Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, commenting on the survey, said that with the powerful economic might of Europe, the United States and Japan, the tentacles of their pop cultures also reach the youth in Taiwan, although she said that with the promotion of local education, some youths have begun gravitate toward local pop culture.
The council is planning to set up pop culture centers in northern, central and southern Taiwan, Tchen said, so that Taiwan youths will be able to access local pop culture with deeper substance.

The survey also found that more than 70 percent of the youths will go on the Net for either pure entertainment or various other aspects. Nearly 67 percent said they use the Internet to make friends and chat with others; 44 percent said they use the Net for homework.

Commenting on the result, Legislator Tuan Yi-kan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that an addiction to the Net could result in relationship alienation, with the youths only concerned about their own enjoyment without any enthusiasm for the outside world.
On which music and dance will best represent the chic culture of the youths, 46 percent cited hip-hop; 26 percent said performance by entertainers.

Fifty-four percent of the youths polled said that their parents don't understand the chic culture, but 82 percent also said that the pursuit of pop culture has not created a confrontation with their parents.
The survey was conducted between Sept. 19-24 on youths between 15 and 18 in the greater Taipei area. A total of 1,003 effective samples were collected, with a margin of error of 3.16 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 90 points to close at 5,720, with 37,651 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 96 points to finish at 5,716, with 270 contract transactions, while December futures gained 38 points to close at 5,690, with 3 contracts traded.
June futures surged 100 points to finish at 5,700, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,630 for October, 5,620 for November, 5,652 for December, 5,600 for March, and 5,600 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
October TE futures gained 5 points to close at 256.7, with 5,199 contract transactions, while November TE futures rose 4.45 points to finish at 256.6, with 135 contracts traded.
December TE futures moved up 6.95 points to close at 255.5, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures increased 11.4 points to finish at 784.2, with 3,761 contract transactions, while November TF futures rose 6.4 points to close at 781.6, with 128 contracts traded.
December TF futures gained 9 points to finish at 782, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 18 KG OF KETAMINE, ARREST FIVE SUSPECTS

TEXT.P: Police raided an apartment in a high-rise building in Kaohsiung Wednesday night, seizing 18 kilograms of Ketamine and arresting five individuals.

A police officer said that, according to preliminary investigations, two of the suspects manufactured Ketamine, a sedative drug known as "rape pills, " in the apartment for two of the other suspects to sell in pubs. The materials they used to manufacture the drug were allegedly supplied by the fifth suspect.
The officer said evidence shows that the suspects have sold an unknown quantity of the drug in Taiwan.

The Kinocenter movie theater on Wednesday refused to screen hard-hitting documentaries about Chechnya for a film festival, saying the 18 films from six countries were "unacceptable" and "too much politically charged." [By Vlogya chang]
