The New York Times: Officials Say Bush Seeks $600 Million to Hunt Iraq Arms.
The Bush administration is seeking more than $600 million from Congress to continue the hunt for conclusive evidence that Saddam Hussein's government had an illegal weapons program, officials said Wednesday. The money comes on top of at least $300 million that has already been spent on the weapons search, officials said.
The Wall Stree Journal: Filtering Process: Longer Dialysis Raises Hopes, but Poses Dilemma. Who Gets Costly Treatment? Personality, Persistence and Housekeeping Count.
In 2001, New York's Rogosin Institute was about to start an unusual new program for dialysis patients. It would give them a blood-cleansing machine to use at home for six nights a week, eight hours each night. The "intensive" treatment had shown excellent results elsewhere. But because both Medicare and private insurers wouldn't pay for it, the nonprofit dialysis center could only afford to make it available to a handful of patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-PURPLE ALLIANCE URGES LAWMAKERS TO FOCUS ON LEGISLATIVE WORK

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice issued an open letter to the ruling and opposition parties Thursday urging them to focus on legislative work in order to craft a comprehensive social security net.

The alliance, also known as the pan-purple alliance, said the opposition parties should not drag their feet while advising the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to refrain from adopting radical, extremist strategies or spurring a meaningless debate on whether Taiwan should declare independence or unify with mainland China.
"We hope both the ruling and opposition parties will push their lawmakers to devote their full energies to legislative work, " Chien Hsi-chieh, the alliance's convener, said at a news conference.

If the ruling and opposition parties fail to respond to the alliance's appeal, Chien said, the alliance will launch a campaign against those parties or individual politicians during next year's legislative election.

According to Chien, the alliance has sent duplicate copies of the letter to Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Premier Yu Shyi-kun as well as the headquarters and legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties.

Chien said the alliance has outlined a series of priorities in its letter. "We hope the Legislative Yuan can complete law revisions or new legislation in four areas during its current session to strengthen social security benefits and eliminate unfairness and injustices in our current taxation system," he explained.

The four areas of legislation singled out by the alliance include those related to overhauling the taxation system, introducing a national pension system, bettering the healthcare system, and establishing an immigration administration and revising immigration regulations.

Chien said the alliance looks forward to seeing a quick passage of amendments to immigration rules to give full civil rights to mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens equal to those offered to spouses from other countries.
The pan-purple alliance is composed of nine major local social welfare groups that promote fair and just welfare services and speak for the underprivileged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 118.2 points to close at 5,699.86.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,644.5 and continued to go up later due to good performances of both electrical shares and bank and insurance stocks. The index fluctuated between 5,703.38 and 5,639.98 during trading.

A total of 3.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.8 billion (US$2.28 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.27 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$49.69 billion (US$1.47 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 2.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, pulp and paper issues, and foodstuff shares, both at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, and textile issues at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 631 to 115, with 122 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 118.2 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving up 118.2 points to close at 5,699.86.
Market turnover amounted to NT$76.8 billion (US$2.28 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY PRESENT TRADE PACKAGE TO U.S.: FAR EASTERN ECONOMIC REVIEW

TEXT.P: Mainland China could present a trade package addressing U.S. concerns during a planned visit to the United States by Premier Wen Jiabao towards the end of the year, the Far Eastern Economic Review has reported.

In its latest issue published Thursday, the magazine quoted a high-level U.S. official as saying that the package would respond to U.S. concerns about whether mainland China is implementing market-opening and other pledges it made on joining the World Trade Organization in late 2001.

U.S. officials, the report said, also hope that Beijing will make some gesture to lower its trade surplus with the United States when U.S. Commerce Secretary Don Evans visits Beijing later this month, such as purchasing more passenger jets from Boeing.

The high-level U.S. official reportedly said that after weeks of pressuring Beijing to revalue its currency, the Bush administration is turning instead to mainland China's trade practices as the main focus of its efforts to cut the United States' huge trade deficit with the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 2, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2000: Premier Tang Fei points out during a meeting on Taiwan's energy needs that he does not think nuclear power is "absolutely safe" or the "only option," but says he is choosing the "lesser evil."
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2001: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vows in a party resolution to build a knowledge-based economy and an efficient and clean government for the people of Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT SMOKING A SERIOUS PROBLEM AT TAIPEI SCHOOLS: CITY COUNCILOR

TEXT.P: A Taipei city councilman on Friday called attention to the serious problem of junior and senior high school student smoking and urged the city government to adopt necessary measures to deal with the problem.
Taipei Councilor Wang Shih-chien of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party pointed out that school authorities have caught more than 6,500 students smoking over the past 30 months.
Wang noted that even more shocking is the fact that elementary school students down to Grade 4 have been caught smoking.

Noting that there are currently more than 234,600 students at Taipei junior and senior high schools, Wang said that on average, there are over seven students under the age of 18 discovered smoking on school grounds each day.

"This figure could very well be just the tip of the iceberg, " Wang pointed out. He said that judging from the fact that schools have not reported all cases of students caught smoking and that many students may be smoking off school grounds after having been caught doing so on campus, the actual figure could be more staggering.

Wang asked the Education Department of Taipei City Government to work out feasible measures within two months to solve the problem. He also asked that the total ban on smoking on campus be rigorously enforced to prevent students from imitating teachers that smoke.

He said that between the start of 2001 and June 2003, nearly 70 percent of the 127 public and private schools in Taipei had reported students smoking alone or with their fellow classmates in restrooms, stadiums or other sites on school grounds.

He also noted that more than 90 percent of the students who smoke get their cigarettes from convenience stores, grocery stores, or even betel nut vendors, and that only a few get their cigarettes from their friends or from home.

Noting that only a total of NT$470,000 (US$13,905) in fines have been issued to only 157 shops over the past 30 months for selling cigarettes to youths under 18, Wang lashed out at the relevant government agencies for failing to rigorously enforce the tobacco control law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER FORECASTS GROWTH OF 3.8 PERCENT FOR 2004

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun forecast Friday that Taiwan's economy will grow by 3.8 percent for 2004 in his report at the Legislative Yuan on the government's 2004 general budget plan.

Briefing the Legislature, Yu said growth of 3.8 percent for next year is likely in view of the expanded public investment projects, both in scale and scope, at home, and the steady recovery of economies worldwide.

According to the budget plan already presented to the Legislature, the government's total outlay will be NT$1.61 trillion (US$48.07 billion) for 2004, representing an increase of NT$61 billion over that for 2003.

Meanwhile, total government revenue for next year has been estimated at NT$1.35 trillion, which means there will be a shortfall of NT$257.4 billion that will have to be raised through borrowing, according to the budget plan.

Yu said the NT$1.6l trillion outlay is primarily designed for the financing of public investment projects which are part of the 2008 National Development Plan. Of the total outlay, NT$78.4 billion has been allocated exclusively to science and technology development, marking an increase of 11.3 percent over the level for 2003, he noted.
Other major expenditures listed in the budget are for education, at NT$200.9 billion, defense and weaponry systems procurement, and subsidies to senior citizens and farmers, according to Yu.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 GRAND JUSTICES SWORN IN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the swearing in of 15 grand justices, including Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng and Vice President Cheng Chung-mo, at the Presidential Office Friday.
The 15 new grand justices, led by Judicial Yuan president, took their oaths of office in front of a Republic of China flag and a portrait of ROC founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
President Chen congratulated the new grand justices and shook hands with each of them after the swearing-in ceremony.

In addition to Weng and Cheng, also sworn in were Wang Ho-hsiung, Yu Hsue-ming, Lin Young-mo, Tseng You-tien, Yang Jen-shou, Liao Yi-nan, Lin Tzu-yi, Hsu Pi-hu, Hsu Yu-hsiu, Hsu Tsung-li, Peng Feng-chi, Lai In-jaw and Hsieh Tsai-chuan.

Others witnessing the ceremony included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chiou I-jen and National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang.

The Judicial Yuan is the highest judicial organization in Taiwan, with the Council of Grand Justices as its main body. There are currently 15 grand justices, including the president and the vice president of the Judicial Yuan to be selected from among the members.
The grand justices are nominated and appointed by the president of the nation, with the consent of the Legislative Yuan.

The Council of Grand Justices interprets the ROC Constitution as well as unifies the interpretation of the nation's laws and ordinances. The Council meets three times a week and holds additional meetings when necessary. Oral proceedings may be held whenever the need arises. After an interpretation of the Constitution or unified interpretation of a law is made, the Judicial Yuan publishes the text of the interpretation, the reasons supporting it, and any dissenting opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMPLOYERS SAY TOP GRADES NO GUARANTEE OF CAREER SUCCESS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The next big challenge for Singapore's education system is to turn out young people geared to succeed in a changing work environment, employers have told Acting Education Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam.
Shanmugaratnam, delivering his first major speech on education Thursday, polled several employers and industry leaders for a sense of the challenges facing schools in Singapore.

Employers told him that straight As alone are no guarantee of career success. They said they want employees who speak well, think on their feet, ask good questions, and have stretched themselves through co-curricular activities (CCA) or community work.

Speaking to about 1,200 school principals, teachers and education specialists at Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Shanmugaratnam said that there are important gaps to be plugged but that there is no need to overhaul the system.

According to the employers, Singaporean students emerge from the rigorous, competitive system with top grades, but still lack critical skills that are valued in the workplace. The system needs to produce people who have more than outstanding academic results, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SIGN OF WAR DRILL BY MAINLAND CHINESE TROOPS: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Contrary to a newspaper report, there is no sign that the mainland Chinese military is planing to conduct exercises in the southern province of Fujian, according to the Ministry of National Defense Friday.

In spite of a story published in Friday's Straits Times in Singapore, the ministry said in a statement that it has kept a close watch on Beijing's military movements and has not seen any evidence that the military is preparing to hold drills in Fujian.
The Straits Times said Beijing will stage a rapid-strike military exercise on Oct. 10, the Republic of China's National Day, in an attempt to jangle the nerves of the people of Taiwan.
The paper said the exercise is meant as a show of Beijing's anger over Taiwan leader Chen Shui-bian's recently revealed plan to write a new constitution.
Beijing's Xinhua news agency, however, reported from Hong Kong earlier in the day that there was no exercise planned for Oct. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL ETHNOGRAPHIC FILM FESTIVAL OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The second Taiwan International Ethnographic Film Festival (TIEFF) opened Friday in Taipei with 11 Taiwan films and 17 foreign works selected from more than 200 overseas films and nearly 100 local works to be screened in the five-day event.
The opening films screened at a theater in downtown Taipei were "Moi, un Noir (Me, a Black) " by Jean Rouch of France and "Experimental Taiwanese Moon Academy" by Wu Mi-sen of Taiwan.
The theme of this year's TIEFF is "Migration Story" which aims to focus on various experiences in migration, Hu Tai-li, chairwoman of the film festival said.

In addition to films from the host country Taiwan, films selected for screening during the festival are from mainland China, France, the United States, Australia, the Czech Republic, Serbia and Montenegro, Sweden, Finland, the United Kingdom and Japan.
The TIEFF is a biannual festival whose aim is to spotlight the many extraordinary documentary films that have been made about culture and ethnography.

The film festival is organized by the Taiwan Association of Visual Ethnography, a non-profit organization which aims to promote ethnographic knowledge. There is no competition category in the festival, and the most important criterion for participating films is a respect for other cultures.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS COMMISSION TO OFFER ONLINE COURSES

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) is planning to offer online courses in commerce and trade to worldwide ethnic Chinese, Chang Fu-mei, chief of the commission, said Friday.

Speaking to an annual conference of the World Federation of Chinese Traders Alumni in Taipei, Chang said her commission is trying to recruit well-known scholars in Taiwan to offer courses in international trade, business administration, and finance on the OCAC Web site, which caters to Chinese worldwide.
The World Federation of Chinese Traders Alumni, founded in 1999, is an association of Chinese traders who have enrolled in training programs opened by the OCAC.

The short-term training programs, including business administration, international trade, electronic trade, cooking, bakery, hotel operations and management, have been attended by more than 4,000 overseas Chinese.
The alumni held their annual gathering Friday, which brought together some 100 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PERSISTENCE IN EDUCATION REFORM

TEXT.P: Modernizing Taiwan's outdated education system will not be easy, but the government must not shy away from its responsibilities simply because of the challenge, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.

Speaking to a group of students who had won awards in various international academic competitions, the president affirmed his commitment to the 10-year-old education reforms, which have encountered strong opposition because of the problems in making substantial changes.

Chen said Taiwan's education system used to be a tool of the rulers who used it to turn out loyal followers. Although it produced some worthy persons in the past, the system has dampened -- even smothered -- students' creativity and blunted the country's competitiveness, the president said.
Along with the changing atmosphere in Taiwan, the country needs an education system which is more open, more liberal, and more likely to meet the needs of society, the president said.
"The process of transformation is not trouble-free, but we can't retreat and give up our efforts to attain our goals because of the difficulty of the tasks," Chen said.

Taiwan students' excellent performance in international academic competitions remind the government of its duty to provide an excellent education system, which can bring out the best in all students, the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL AND MEDIUM BUSINESS CREDIT GUARANTEE FUND TO BE INCREASED: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Friday that the government will donate an additional NT$50 billion (US$1.38 billion) to the Small and Medium Business Credit Guarantee Fund (SMBCGF) over the next five years.

Addressing the award presentation ceremony of the 12th National Awards of Small and Medium Enterprises and the fifth National Awards of Overseas Taiwanese Businesses, Chen said that small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) form the main force in creating the so-called Taiwan economic miracle. They account for 97.72 percent of Taiwan enterprises in terms of numbers and offer 78 percent of the country's job opportunities, he explained.
The government will donate NT$10 billion each year in the next five years to the SMBCGF to increase the capital supply for SMEs and to further consolidate their development, Chen noted.

Chen encouraged the SMEs to join government efforts in improving the country's economy. More than one year after the government launched its six-year national development plan, "Challenge 2008," he said, more than 10 multinational enterprises have decided to establish their research and development centers in Taiwan.
It is expected that some 250 Taiwan businesses will set up their operational hubs in Taiwan by the end of this year, Chen added.

Founded in 1974 with donations from central and local governments, contracted financial institutions and other agencies, the SMBCGF provides credit guarantees to SMEs which are promising but short of collateral necessary to obtain financing from contracted financial institutions. The amount of the fund's net worth was NT$13.049 billion at the end of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN NEGOTIABLE:MAC

TEXT.P: Issues relating to the opening of charter flight services for homeward-bound Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China during the coming lunar new year holiday are negotiable, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Friday.

Claiming that the MAC is awaiting instructions from President Chen Shui-bian on the matter, Chen said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can conduct negotiations as long as the mainland authorities express willingness to do so.
The MAC vice chairman said that the council will deal with the matter in a practical manner in order to meet the needs of the many Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland.

The institutionalized channels between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait will be the top option for holding the negotiations, he went on, adding that the private sector might be allowed to play a role in such talks after relevant law amendments clear the Legislative Yuan.

Taiwan was able to unilaterally launch historic charter flight services earlier this year for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen returning home for the lunar new year holiday after having obtained agreement from the mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MUTUAL RECOGNITION OF CREDITS AWARDED BY CROSS-STRAIT SCHOOLS: MAC

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) denied reports Friday that mainland China's Peking University and Taiwan's National Chengchi University will each recognize academic credits awarded by the other.

Chen Ming-tong pointed out that the government at present allows Taiwan universities to open classes on the mainland, but only recognizes the credits awarded if the teachers and the students are from Taiwan.
Chen said that this is tantamount merely to using mainland facilities as classrooms, which he said is different from recognizing credits awarded by the universities on each side of the Taiwan Strait.
Referring to the reports, Chen said: "These are only media reports, " and he added that the MAC will take steps to learn more about the matter.

He said that according to the regulations governing cultural and educational exchanges between professors and students on the mainland and in Taiwan, mainland scholars can teach in Taiwan and mainland students can study here, although Taiwan does not give them any credit certification. Whether or not the mainland would recognize credits even if Taiwan were to award them, "would be their business," he said.
The issue does not involve the recognition of credits awarded by the mainland, or mutual recognition of the credits awarded by universities on either side of the Taiwan Strait, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING BOAT CAPTAIN RETURNS FROM DETENTION IN PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The captain of a Taiwan fishing boat detained by the Philippines for 18 months returned to Taiwan Friday.

Upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Huang Chi-huang, captain of the Pingtung-registered Man Chi Tsai No. 2, headed straight for Tungkang in Pingtung County to be reunited with his wife and four children, whom he had not seen for more than 500 days.

On the way to Tungkang, Huang said that on April 15, 2002, he sailed to the Philippines to pick up a Filipino crew to fish for black tuna in the Pacific, but was detained by the Philippine authorities when he was navigating through Philippines' waters.
Huang dismissed as "rubbish" reports that he was poaching in the Philippines' waters.
He expressed his gratitude toward all those who had assisted him over the past 18 months in securing his release, especially the Republic of China mission in Manila.

Huang said that one Taiwanese and three mainland Chinese crewmen were detained along with him, but the Taiwanese and two of the mainlanders were able to escape after they boarded another detained Taiwanese ship that was swept out of Abali Port in northern Luzon Province during a typhoon earlier this year.

Huang said that he will try to secure the release of the remaining mainland Chinese fisherman and added that Captain Hung Hsin-san and Chief Engineer Peng Fei-lung of another Taiwan fishing ship, Chin Sheng Ta, are still detained in the Philippines and awaiting their chance to return to Taiwan.
Earlier in Manila, the ROC representative to the Philippines saw Huang off at the airport.

Wu Hsin-hsing, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines, said that from the experiences of Huang and other detained fishermen, it is evident that the lives, property and human rights of Taiwan fishermen must be ensured.

Wu said that his office will do everything possible to promote fishery cooperation between Taiwan and the Philippines, and will seek to find a lasting solution to fishery disputes between the two countries.

Many Pingtung fishing boats have cooperated with the private Philippine fishing sector through brokerage house to allow them to operate in waters overlapping the economic zones of Taiwan and the Philippines. Should a Taiwanese vessel be detained by the Philippine authorities, the Taiwan shipowner and the brokerage house should each pay half the fine for the ship's release. Those who do not join the cooperative project have to pay the fines on their own.

The period from mid-April through mid-July is a peak season for black tuna, whose firm, meaty flesh is a costly delicacy. During the season, hundreds of Taiwan fishing vessels, mostly from Pingtung and Kaohsiung, operate in fishing grounds that overlap the economic zones of Taiwan and the Philippines near the Bashi Channel and the Philippine Sea to catch black tuna.
Philippine fishery authorities began to pay close attention to Taiwan fishing boats in 2002 after some Pingtung fishermen made a fortune from black tuna sales the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INCREASE SURCHARGE ON CIGARETTES

TEXT.P: Legislators of the ruling and opposition parties reached a preliminary decision Friday to increase the surcharge on cigarettes, beginning Jan. 1, 2004.

If enacted, the law will make Taiwan cigarettes more expensive, because the surcharge will rise from NT$5.00 to NT$8.00 per pack. The increase in the cigarette tax will be used to improve health care.

The legislators also preliminarily decided to adopt a resolution, asking the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Finance to continue to negotiate in the World Trade Organization for the exemption of rice wine from taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER NOT BE PUNISHED APART FROM REPRIMAND

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien was reprimanded by Premier Yu Shyi-kun Thursday for hiring two masseuses at the expense of a business friend, but will not receive any further punishment, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Friday.

Lin said an investigation by the Executive Yuan found that Yu did not behave appropriately in receiving a massage from the two women, who are not blind and are therefore unlicensed masseuses. However, the investigation determined that the massage did not count as asexual service and the minister did not return the favor from his business friend, so the premier decided not to punish him other than by warning him to mend his ways. There is no question that he will be asked to resign, Lin added.
The spokesman quoted the premier as telling Yu Cheng-hsien that public officials are government workers and should be held to higher standards of behavior than members of the public.
The incident was reported by a local newspaper and triggered an uproar in political circles, as local massage parlors are often thinly veiled fronts for the sex industry.
Yu apologized for accepting the massage, but claimed not to know that massage is a profession reserved for the blind.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREATER CHINA, SINGAPORE ECONOMIES MOST AFFECTED BY SARS: U.N. REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The economies of mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore have been the ones most affected by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), according to a report by the United Nations.

The 2003 trade and development report released by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) said that mainland China's first-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) was stagnate, while the Q1 GDP growth of Taiwan and Hong Kong fell noticeably. Singapore's Q1 GDP growth was even in red, according to the report.

SARS might have a greater economic impact in the second quarter on these badly affected areas, with their transportation and tourism industries suffering bigger losses, in addition to the foreign trade sector, the report said.
The transportation and tourism industries in these countries and areas account for 10 percent of their GDP, according to the report.

Citing an assessment by the Asian Development Bank, the report said the negative effects of SARS on these East Asian economies' Q2 GDP growth could drop to a range between 0.2 percent and 2 percent, affecting Hong Kong and Singapore the most and mainland China and South Korea the least, at a time when the epidemic had been effectively contained.
The report claimed that SARS might bring down the GDP by 0.5 percent for the whole region in 2003 and it estimated that Taiwan will post 3.2 percent economic growth for the whole of this year.

Meanwhile, the UNCTAD listed Taiwan and South Korea as first-grade newly industrialized economies (NIEs) , or industrializers, in the report because of their successful advances into the hi-tech field under the model set up by developed countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO MEET WITH BUSINESS LEADERS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun will meet with six business heavyweights over the weekend at a seminar designed as a warm up to a large-scale business solicitation extravaganza later this month.

The seminar on Sunday will kick off the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference to be held Oct. 19-21 at the Taipei International Convention Center, with more than 1,000 business leaders expected to attend.

Participating in the seminar, which will be sponsored by the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will be Leslie Lok, president of Siemens Limited Taiwan; Walt Cheng, chairman of Du Pont Taiwan; Y.T. Du, Citigroup Global Markets Taiwan Limited; Douglas Hsu, chairman of The Far Eastern Group; Day Sheng-tong, chairman of San Sun Hat & Cap Co.; and Paul Lo, CEO of SinoPac Holdings.

Trade officials said the purpose of the seminar is to explore the present situation of Taiwan's high-tech industry, traditional industry, financial and service sectors, with special focus on how to attract more foreign investment.
The officials said that they hope to demonstrate Taiwan's confidence in developing its economy through in-depth talks between the premier and the six business leaders.
Central News Agency President Hu Yuan-hui will be invited to serve as a coordinator to explore trade and financial issues through the angle of the news media, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREX RESERVES TOP US$190 BILLION: CBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$190.57 billion as of the end of September, an increase of US$4.907 billion over the figure recorded at the end of August, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Friday.
The September figure also represented an increase of US$28.92 billion over the end of 2002, CBC authorities said.
The CBC attributed the increase to an influx of foreign capital and earnings from its accounts in foreign commercial banks.
The foreign exchange reserves are the third-largest in the world, behind only those of Japan and mainland China, CBC officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 22 points to close at 5,742, with 26,731 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 24 points to finish at 5,740, with 208 contract transactions, while December futures gained 39 points to close at 5,740, with two contracts traded.
March futures surged 79 points to finish at 5,769, with two contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,720 for October, 5,716 for November, 5,701 for December, 5,690 for March and 5,690 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

October TE futures gained 0.3 points to close at 257.0, with 3,184 contract transactions, while November TE futures dropped 0.4 points to finish at 256.2, with 27 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures increased 10.4 points to finish at 794.6, with 4,844 contract transactions, while November TF futures rose 11.4 points to close at 793, with 97 contracts traded.
December TF futures gained 10 points to finish at 790.4, with eight contracts traded. March TF futures rose 10.4 points to finish at 787, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAGISTRATE WARNS AGAINST MAINLAND CHINESE VEGETABLES

TEXT.P: The county magistrate of the Republic of China-controlled island of Kinmen called Friday for attention to be paid to mainland Chinese vegetables and fruit that he said might have been polluted with excessive amounts of pesticide.

Lee Chu-feng said that since the opening of the "mini three links, " large amounts of mainland-originating vegetables and fruit have found their way to Kinmen, mainly through the illegal "beach trade."
However, Lee claimed that most of the mainland produce that arrives in Kinmen via the "beach trade" is found by customs and health authorities to contain excessive amounts of agricultural chemicals.
Lee said consumption of the polluted produce on a long term basis would be harmful to the health of Kinmen residents.
Meanwhile, Lee also called for Kinmen farmers to refrain from using excessive amounts of pesticide on their farms.

Citing his own personal experiences as an example, Lee said that when he was a child, he used to see many palang turtle and huashen fish -- common endemic species in Kinmen -- which are found no longer, most likely as a result of excessive use of pesticide.

Lee made the remarks during a workshop on the safe use of agricultural chemicals sponsored by the Kinmen county government, with the participation of academics from National Chung Hsing University and about 150 Kinmen farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PROPOSE REGULATION OF FORMER MILITARY, SECURITY PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Friday that it will propose an amendment to suspend pension payments to former military and security personnel who violate regulations that prohibit them from traveling to mainland China without permission.
The TSU legislative caucus expressed the views after listening to a report delivered by the National Security Bureau (NSB).

TSU legislators were very upset that Pan Hsi-hsien -- a former head of the NSB's personnel department who went to work at a friend's factory in Shenzhen, mainland China, three days after his retirement in June 2000 -- is still claiming his pension through his wife and that more than 100 retired army generals have settled on the mainland.
NSB Vice Director Huang Lei reported that Pan has been detained by the mainland security authorities and has been forbidden to leave the mainland.

Another NSB official, former Chief Accountant Liu Kuan-chun, is still at large after embezzling more than NT$192 million (US$5.68 million) and sneaking out of Taiwan in September 2000, Huang reported.

Liao Ben-yan, TSU caucus whip, said that according to Huang's report, the government has no way to regulate retired military and security officials who travel to the mainland. He added that Pan's continued claiming of his pension is "incredible."

He said that many retired generals have not followed the regulations that state that if their work involved national security, they should obtain approval from the Ministry of the Interior and other related government agencies if they want to travel to the mainland within three years of their retirement.
He said regulations for former military and security officials should be more strict and that those who ignore the regulations should be severely punished.

TSU Legislator Lo Jhih-ming said that based on a calculation of more than 100 retired generals traveling to the mainland, the money Taiwan remits each year to the mainland in pensions amounts to more than NT$1 billion.
In addition, Lo said, those people might reveal national secrets or expose intelligence networks.

The TSU will motion an amendment to a revised draft of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area next week to regulate retired military and security officials.
If they are found to have violated the regulations by traveling to the mainland, they should be fined, sentenced to two years of imprisonment and have their pensions suspended, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taipei Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.93 points to close at 5,747.79.
The bourse opened at 5,716.79 points and fluctuated between 5,759.0 and 5,701.87 during the trading session.

A total of 3.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.6 billion (US$2.59 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 3.35 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$76.8 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 4.0 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, electrical and foodstuff stocks both at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, and textile shares at 0.1 percent. Plastics and chemical stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 444 to 274, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE DISCOVER A SMALL MAKESHIFT ARSENAL IN TAITUNG

TEXT.P: Police raided a small makeshift factory of firearms Friday morning on Kunmin Street in Taitung City in eastern Taiwan and arrested two suspects.
A police spokesman said five shotguns, some shotgun bullets, 2.3 kilograms of black gun powder, and a set of tools were seized from the factory.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INFLUENCE PEDDLING INVOLVED IN TAIPEI BANK-FUBON MERGER: MA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he guaranteed with his personal reputation that there was no influence peddling nor "insiders' deal" involved in the merger of the private Fubon Holding Co. and the city-run Taipei Bank.

He vowed to step down from his post as mayor if he were found to have been involved in interest-peddling or collusion with the Fubon Group as claimed by some ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) city councilors.
Ma said he has felt "depressed and stressed" over the accusations that the DPP councilors have made against him over the past two days.

He said he had visited Fubon's private club several times, but that these visits all occurred after the merger deal was completed. He said he went there primarily to socialize with the Fubon Group members in the hopes that the "daughter" Taipei Bank would fare well after its "marriage."

Denying accusations that he had visited Fubon's private club seven times, Ma said he only went there three times, with one visit being hosted by an investment and securities firm while the Fubon executives were also present.
He said he had met with Fubon executives for a fourth and fifth time for casual talks, but that neither of these meetings were at the Fubon club.
Ma offered his apology for the confusion caused by the city government not initially releasing accurate information regarding how many times he had met the Fubon people.
"I have also directed all city government employees, including myself, to stop going to private companies' clubs in the future for business socializing purposes," he said.

Ma pointed out Friday, however, that it is unfair to accuse the Taipei City Government of committing collusion simply because its personnel met with private business groups. "This runs counter to the spirit of the development of a modern society," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 3, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OUTLINES QUALIFICATIONS FOR NEW EPA ADMINISTRATOR

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday he hopes to pick a thoughtful, capable and experienced person to head the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

Yu made the remarks while attending the inauguration of a new highway linking the northeastern city of Ilan to other parts of Taiwan a day after he accepted the resignation of EPA Administrator Hau Lung-pin.
Praising Hau as an outstanding EPA chief, Yu said he wants to name an equally qualified person to assume the post left vacant by Hau.

Yu also outlined the terms for selecting Hau's successor. "The new environmental chief must have contributed to Taiwan's environmental protection drive in the past years and have experience, ideas and the capability to implement the government's environmental protection policies and all relevant projects, " he explained, adding that it may take a few more days for him to select a suitable replacement.

According to media reports, Legislator Chao Yung-ching of the Democratic Progressive Party is a likely candidate for the top EPA post. But Chao, who has been active in promoting environmental protection programs in recent years, said nobody has talked about he issue with him.
Meanwhile, Yu said the Peiyi Expressway, which will link Ilan to metropolitan Taipei, will be completed by the end of 2005 as scheduled.

Noting that the Peiyi project's most challenging section -- the Shueishan (Mount Snow) tunnel -- is now 80 percent complete, Yu said he is confident that construction of the remaining part of the expressway will proceed smoothly. When the new expressway opens to traffic, it will take only 40 minutes to travel from Ilan to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA TO INSTALL SURVEILLANCE CAMERAS OUTSIDE COCKPIT

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) says that by Nov. 1all its planes will have surveillance cameras installed to allow the pilot to view the cabin area just outside the cockpit.
This is just one of the stepped up security measures which the airline has undertaken.
Speaking at a media briefing on Friday, SIA spokesperson Rick Clements said other security measures include random physical checks on baggage and improved plane surveillance on the ground.
Since April 1, all SIA planes have had bullet-proof reinforced cockpit doors installed.
Only pilots and where necessary, cabin crew, are allowed into the cockpit.
Air marshals are on board some SIA flights.

Since the SQ006 crash in Taipei, the SilkAir crash in Palembang in December 1997 and the terrorist attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001, SIA's insurance premiums have rocketed from SIN$12 million (about US$6.8 million) a year to around SIN$100 million.
On a separate matter, SIA says there is a hiring freeze at the moment.
But its compulsory no-pay leave for both pilots and cabin crew, introduced to help cut costs in the wake of the SARS outbreak, has now been lifted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR STEP TAKEN TO PAVE WAY FOR NEW SINGAPORE CARRIERS

TEXT.P: The Singapore government has set up a committee to allocate the country's air traffic rights among local carriers.
Singapore has taken a major step to pave the way for the potential entry of new carriers like the proposed budget airlines ValuAir.
Singapore has an air services agreement with over 90 countries, and so far, all air traffic rights are used only by its national carrier -- Singapore Airlines (SIA).
But with potential new local carriers taking to the skies next year, that won't be the case anymore.
SIA will be able to keep its existing air traffic rights for 10 years, before it has to renew them for up to five years.
New carriers won't be at a disadvantage when competing with SIA for air traffic rights.
The Ministry of Transport says there are ample rights for the new carriers to countries like Australia, Hong Kong, and Thailand.
To apply for the rights, airlines will first need to obtain a valid Air Operators Certificate, fulfill the conditions under the Air Services Agreement and must have sufficient financial resources.
If there are competing requests, the airlines will be judged according to how their services can contribute to Singapore's air hub and consumer benefits.
All new rights are valid for a maximum of five years.
If any right isn't used for more than six months, it will be suspended. SIA isn't exempted on this.
The fee for each city is SIN$2,000 (US$1,142) a year.
But in light of the weak global aviation industry, these charges will be waived till the end of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALL FOR NEW CONSTITUTION AIMED AT MAKING TAIWAN GREAT COUNTRY: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday promoting introduction of a new constitution is a necessary step to build Taiwan into a normal, complete and great country.
Addressing a meeting of Taiwanese Christians, Chen said his appeal to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006 is by no means "boring" campaign rhetoric as claimed by opposition parties.

"The call touches on an important topic worthy of study and discussion," Chen said, adding that he hopes that the call can spur a process of constitutional reform to craft a political framework that would fit Taiwan's realities and deepen its democratic system.

Speaking on the same occasion, former President Lee Teng-hui seconded Chen's view, saying that his efforts to push for a "Call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement is aimed at reminding local people to make Taiwan a normal country through legislating a new constitution.

More than 3,000 Taiwanese Christian followers, including those residing abroad, attended the conference at the Taipei International Convention Center. They joined Chen and Lee in praying for Taiwan's well-being during the conference.

Chen brought up the idea of introducing a new constitution for Taiwan for the first time at a rally last Sunday marking the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) 17th founding anniversary in his capacity as the ruling party's chairman. He said that in 2006, when the DPP turns 20 years old, he hopes all of the 23 million people of Taiwan will push for a new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN PROMISES TO IMPROVE ECONOMY IF ELECTED PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Presidential Candidate Lien Chan promised to bring the jobless rate down to four percent, raise the economic growth rate to five percent, and eliminate government budget deficits, if he is elected president in the Presidential election in March.
Speaking to a training class for party officials in Hsinchu, Lien said these promises may be called his "four-five-six policy."

He said, if elected President, his administration will lower the jobless rate from the current 5.21 percent to under four percent by improving the investment climate, making good use of foreign capital, and improving the living and business conditions so that Taiwanese entrepreneurs will keep the root of their businesses in Taiwan.

Lien said that under the rule of the Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's economic growth rate has dropped from 8.1 percent in 2000 to minus 2.08 percent in 2002. If elected, Lien's administration will raise the economic growth rate over five percent. The per capita income will also increase from the current US$11,600 to US$16,000.

Lien also said he will see to it that everybody in the country has equal opportunity to receive education, because education is the last line for the defense of social justice and equality. To ensure that poor people have equal right to receive education, he put forth his "three nos" policy, meaning "no" interest on student loans, "no" tuition and miscellaneous fees for disabled students or disabled person's children to pay, and "no" miscellaneous fees for students of middle- and low- income families to pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHICHI TOWNSHIP RESIDENTS VOTE AGAINST INCINERATOR CONSTRUCTION PLAN

TEXT.P: Residents in Nantou County's Chichi township in central Taiwan overwhelmingly voted Saturday against construction of a garbage incinerator in their neighborhood.
The mountainous township has 9,419 eligible voters and 68 percent of them, including many senior citizens, turned out to vote.

With firecrackers exploding in the background, Chichi township Chief Lee Chung-ching said 97.88 percent of those who voted in his town rejected the incinerator in a non-binding referendum. He said he would relay the results to the Nantou County Government. As the nation has not yet enacted a referendum law, the Chichi vote was consultative in nature. But Lee said he hopes the county government and the central government should not ignore Chichi residents' mainstream opinions.
Some residents said they may travel to Taipei to file an appeal if the county government disregards the referendum result and goes ahead with the project.

Nantou County Magistrate Lin Chung-nan said he respects the result of the Chichi referendum, but he added that the plan to build an incinerator in the mountainous township will be carried out as scheduled.

Lin said the county government has passed an environmental impact assessment on the proposed incinerator construction site and will hold an open tender before the end of this month to pick a qualified contractor.

Lin said prospective bidders must present detailed water and soil conservation plans. "The county government will closely monitor the proceedings to allay public misgivings about the incinerator's possible adverse impact on the environment and water resources, " he added.

Nantou is Taiwan's only county that doesn't border seas and 80 percent of its area is slopelands or valleys. "It's no easy task to select a piece of land to accommodate an incinerator, " Lin said, adding that more than half of the county's 13 townships and villages have been plagued by garbage issues.

If the new incinerator, which will be able to handle 500 tons of garbage a day, cannot be built as scheduled, Lin said, Chichi township and its nearby areas will be faced with serious garbage disposal problems.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration said its respect for the Nantou County Government's environmental impact evaluation will not be affected by the nonbinding Chichi referendum results.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EPA HEAD TO BE DECIDED NEXT WEEK AT EARLIEST: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The government will decide on who to replace Hau Lung-bin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), next week at the earliest, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Saturday.
Spokesman Lin Chia-lung also said that Premier Yu Shyi-kun is "still making an overall assessment, " and has yet to begun the inquiry process for possible candidates.
"Professionalism, personal image and substantial working experience" will be the major considerations for the future head of the EPA, Lin said.

Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, and Yeh Chun-jung, minister without portfolio, have been tipped to be the two top choices to succeed Hau, but there are also reports that the premier relies greatly on them in their present capacities and is unwilling to let them move to other posts.
Lin said that the reports are "only speculations," as the premier has yet to begin the process of narrowing down or ruling out any possible candidates.

Lin said that DPP Legislator Jao Yung-ching, who was recommended by ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers, is a very qualified candidate for his long-term concern for various environmental issues.
He said the premier will definitely include Jao for consideration, although he will need some time to make a final decision.

The premier accepted the resignation of Hau Friday night after last-ditch efforts failed to persuade him to change his mind, and EPA Vice Administrator Chang Juu-en is now acting on Hau's behalf, whose resignation will take effect Oct. 6.
Hau tendered his resignation on Wednesday because he didn't see eye to eye with the premier on referendum issues.
Hau said the premier rejected his suggestion to exclude environment related issues which had already passed environmental impact assessments from issues which could be put to a referendum.
Hau, a scholar-turn-legislator, was recruited by former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the helm of the EPA in March 2001 and has become one of the most popular Cabinet members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO DEVELOP KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to develop a knowledge-based economy so that it is not easily outpaced in global economic competition, the head of a local think tank said Saturday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of Taiwan Thinktank, made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Economic Association on the effects of cross-strait trade on the development of Taiwan's economy and industrial structure.

Chen said that because of increased cross-Taiwan Strait trade and investment, Taiwan's wages and prices have drifted down towards the level of that of mainland China, adding that the effect is especially evident in the labor wages of the manufacturing sector.
"Taiwan needs to develop a knowledge-based economy which mainland China could not match, and reverse the adverse situation, " Chen said.

Chen noted that Taiwan and other three Asian dragons, meaning Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea, were able to achieve rapid economic growth and enjoy prosperity in the 1980s because then the world economy and its main international trade were made up of high-income countries and a few small countries in Asia.

But then Vietnam, India and other East Asian countries joined the same development pattern. Using only one-tenth the wages offered by the four Asian dragons, they took away business and then labor wages in the manufacturing sectors of the four dragons began to drift downwards.

Chen said that as the drifting lower of labor wages is inevitable, if Taiwan wants to maintain its high income, it will have to develop non-trade properties, such as service, a more ideal living environment, and hardware and software facilities, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian continued soliciting public support for his initiative Saturday to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

While visiting a nursing home for the elderly in Taipei County, Chen encouraged senior citizens to join the campaign for a new constitution to allow for establishment of a political framework that would fit Taiwan's present realities.

Chen made the visit as part of celebrations of the Chung Yang Festival -- the ninth day of the ninth moon on the lunar calendar -- that has been observed since 1966 to honor senior citizens. The festival fell on Saturday this year.

In addition to wishing all senior citizens a happy holiday, Chen took advantage of the occasion to enlist their support for his appeal for a new constitution, which he broached first at a rally last Sunday marking the 17th founding anniversary of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen said many much-anticipated reforms, such as changes in the conscription system and lowering of the suffrage age, require constitutional amendments.
"I hope all of the 23 million Taiwan people, regardless of their age, will contribute to the campaign to introduce a new constitution to facilitate national rejuvenation," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALASKA TRADE MISSION ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An Alaskan trade mission, led by governor Frank H. Murkowski, arrived in Taipei Saturday for a four-day visit.

Murkowski and members of the trade mission were greeted at the airport by Joseph J. Wu, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, and Victor J. Chin, director-general of the Department of North American Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

According to a press release from the Alaska State Government, Murkowski will receive an honor in Taipei on Monday afternoon. President Chen Shui-bian will present Murkowski with the "Order of Propitious Clouds with Grand Cordon" for his many years of support and contributions to Taiwan. Murkowski was a U. S. senator before he was elected governor of Alaska.
Murkowski and members of the trade mission will discuss Alaska's resources with Taiwan's business and government leaders before leaving on Tuesday to continue their trip in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN RETURNS FROM SOUTH KOREAN VISIT

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) , said Saturday that he has witnessed the efforts and progress of South Korea over that past decade, and feels that Taiwan must catch up quickly.

Soong made the remarks upon returning to CKS International Airport after a five-day visit during which he met with South Korean political heavyweights and influential business executives as part of the "pan-blue alliance's" presidential campaign activities.
Soong, who will serve as the the running mate of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in the 2004 presidential election, also received an honorary doctoral degree from Sookmyune Women's University.

Soong said that he exchanged views on a wide range of issues with friends, political party leaders, and leaders from the private and business sectors in South Korea, and felt acutely the progress made by South Koreans.
In addition, Soong noted that South Korea has its definite views and stance on participating in situations in East Asia and the development of nuclear weapons by North Korea.
Soong also said that he would report to Lien on what he observed in South Korea to serve as a reference in mapping out their campaign platform.

Soong also said that he was not familiar with the controversy surrounding President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Sunday that he would push for a new constitution by 2006, believing that this is no time to join the "war of words."
"Faced with the progress of other countries, Taiwan should be alert and prepare itself in every possible way, " Soong said, adding that he would not let himself be lured into criticizing others.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH TRADE OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Sir Stephen Brown KCVO, group chief executive of British Trade International, will arrive in Taiwan Sunday for a three-day visit.

The British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei said that this will be Brown's first visit to Taiwan. Brown will stress the importance of bilateral trade relations between Britain and Taiwan and demonstrate his country's sincerity in establishing a partnership relationship with Taiwan.

Brown is scheduled to call on related government agencies and businesses during his stay in Taiwan, and could talk about issues related to the World Trade Organization (WTO) , the British office said.

The office also said that the task of British Trade International is to promote British products to other countries, and Brown hopes that his brief visit will help him understand further the business and trade relations between Taiwan and Britain.

On questions whether Brown will talk about the row over Taiwan's largest air carrier China Airlines' decision to procure engines from the United States-based General Electric for its newly ordered 18 aircraft instead of from British-based Rolls Royce, the British Economic and Cultural Office only said that as Taiwan is already a WTO member, it is natural to talk about matters related to the world trade regulatory body.
Recent media reports have said that Britain may seek a settlement through the WTO's trade dispute arbitration mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 4, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: RAILWAY ACCIDENTS DECREASING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of railway accidents in Taiwan has reduced substantially in recent years after the installation of "emergency knobs" at more than 400 crossings, a spokesman for the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) said Sunday.

Citing TRA statistics, the spokesman said the number of accidents at railway crossings reduced from 129 in 1998 and 116 in 1999 to 77 in 2001 and 82 in 2002. The TRA spent NT$400 million (US$11.85 million) for the installation of the emergency warning device.

He said railway accidents could be further reduced in Taiwan, because the TRA has asked the Taipei-based China Traffic Signal Association to develop an optoelectronic monitoring system to detect dangerous conditions along the railroad and at railway crossings. The monitoring system could provide video information to alert locomotive drivers to dangerous conditions in ample time to avoid accidents.
