DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL PIANO COMPETITION CONCLUDES

TEXT.P: The 2003 Taiwan International Piano Competition (TIPC) concluded Sunday after 10-day contest.

Chang Chiao-yin of Taiwan was the biggest winner of the competition by capturing the second prize. There was no first prize winner because none of the contestants won approval by the simple majority of jury members.
Mariya Kim of Ukraine, Rufus Choi of the United States and Yuan Wei-jen of Taiwan won the third, fourth and fifth prizes, respectively, as the order.
Republic of China first lady Wu Shu-chen was invited to award the prizewinners at the closing ceremony.

A total of 32 pianists, including seven from Taiwan, who made it to the final in Taipei after going through initial selections in Vienna, Paris, New York and Taipei among a group of more than 60 contestants from 21 countries, competed in the first TIPC.

The event, sponsored by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , was designed to allow Taiwan to play a role on the world stage and make the world gain an understanding of Taiwan's development of classical music, according to CCA Chairwoman Chen Yu-chiou.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT REMAINS ATTRACTIVE: BUSINESS LEADERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment environment remains attractive, a group of business leaders said Sunday at a symposium.

Speaking at the symposium titled "Invest in Taiwan, Access the World" sponsored by the Executive Yuan, Leslie Lok, president of Siemens Ltd. Taiwan, said that Taiwan has a free, convenient, comfortable and beautiful living environment that is attractive to the talented individuals who are the core value of an enterprise's competitiveness.

Citing the results of a survey carried out among his company's employees as example, he said that 87 percent of the respondents would choose to stay in Taiwan given the option of working in Taiwan, Mainland China, Hong Kong or Malaysia.

Lok said his company is expected to have an annual revenue of 946.9 million euros (US$1.106 billion) this year, enjoying a growth rate of 110 percent over that of five years ago, when it registered 450 million euros.
The figures show that Taiwan remains a place worthwhile to do business, he said.

For his part, Y.T. Du, chairman of Citigroup Global Markets Taiwan Ltd., said that Taiwan is more attractive to international capital markets every day and that international capital inflow to the country is increasing.
Foreign capital accounted for more than 22 percent of the total value of stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange at the end of September, up from 16 percent registered in May 2000, Du noted.

Based on the fact that the total value of stocks listed on Taiwan's bourse increased from between NT$8 trillion and NT$9 trillion to NT$11.1 trillion during the period between 2000 and September 2003, foreign capital in Taiwan has increased by 60 percent in less than three years, he went on.

Furthermore, he went on, Taiwan's enterprises had lured a total of US$11.1 billion-worth of foreign capital through issuing deposit receipts or bonds overseas as of the end of September, up 60 percent on a year-to-year basis. The capital channeled into Taiwan using these methods reached only US$4.8 billion in 2000, he added.
Apart from Japan, Du noted, Taiwan is the largest absorber of foreign capital of all the Asian nations.

For his part, Day Sheng-tong, president of the Republic of China Small and Medium Business Association and chairman of San Sun Hat and Cap Co., said that the creativity and fast delivery of products ordered are two advantages that Taiwan businesses have in the international market.
He said that Taiwan is becoming a stronger option for manufacturers, as the profits in the mainland China manufacturing sector are falling due to an increasing volume of production.
The government should make use of the advantages that Taiwan businesses have for soliciting foreign investment, he suggested.
Walt Cheng, chairman of DuPont Taiwan, said that his company has confidence in Taiwan in light of the fact that it has been in Taiwan for 35 years.
Taiwan is now the third-largest country in terms of the value of DuPont investment, which now amounts to US$1 billion, he said.
Taiwan has a good geographic position to be a regional operation hub, he added.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun also attended the symposium, which was jointly organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the China External Trade Development Council and Central News Agency and was presided over by CNA President Hu Yuan-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOW IS RIGHT TIME TO INVEST IN TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Now is the right time to invest in Taiwan, Premier Yu Shyi-kung said at a symposium with business leaders Sunday.

Exchanging views with chief executives and officials of a group of leading companies in Taiwan, the premier said the country's economy is recovering strongly in the second half of this year, citing a 5.4 percent expansion forecast for next year by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) , part of the organization that publishes the Economist magazine in Britain.

In order to prompt a worldwide wave of investment in Taiwan, Yu said the Executive Yuan is pushing forward with various projects to improve infrastructure and increase the country's investment incentives.

The symposium, sponsored by the Executive Yuan, and organized jointly by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the China External Trade Development Council and the Central News Agency, is a prelude to a high-profile investment promotion conference -- the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference -- slated to take place from Oct. 19-22.

Noting that the international economy is turning the corner in the second half of this year and is predicted to grow by 3.2 percent this year and 4.1 percent next year, compared to 2 percent in 2002, the premier said that now is the right time to invest in Taiwan, which he claimed is leading the world in terms of economic recovery.

The government predicted 3.06 percent economic growth for this year and 3.81 percent, or even more than 4 percent for 2004, while the EIU forecasts an even more optimistic 5.4 percent for 2004, Yu said.

Furthermore, the premier said, the risk of investment in Taiwan has been reduced significantly thanks to the country's increasing globalization and integration with the regional economy, as well as the increasing transparency of business operations.

As a result, various international consultancy companies, such as the Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development, World Economic Forum and Business Environment Risk Intelligence, and the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd., are giving Taiwan high ranks in surveys about worldwide investment environments.

Pointing to a survey issued by the International Institute for Management Development in May, the premier said Taiwan has moved from seventh place in the world last year to sixth this year in terms of competitiveness, because of its "marvelous economic performance and government efficiency."
The Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan's investment environment at 1A -- representing a country with low risk and therefore suitable for investment.

Meanwhile, the World Economic Forum, which rates countries worldwide according to their economic potential for the next five to eight years, advanced Taiwan from 10th place in the world in 2000 to third place in the world this year. All these surveys show that Taiwan is an ideal place for investment, the premier said.

He said the Executive Yuan is pressing ahead with plans to boost investment by reducing the rent for land used by industry, offering tax credits to investors, lifting the ceiling on foreign investment in local stock markets, and streamlining finance regulations.

The government's efforts have borne fruit, Yu went on, pointing out that 159 companies had chosen Taiwan as their business operation centers as of September and saying that the number is estimated to hit 1,000 within 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSAGE OF KEY LAW REVISIONS REMAINS UNCERTAIN

TEXT.P: The passage of various major revisions to a key law governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China remains uncertain, despite a lawmakers' decision to negotiate and screen them in the Legislative Yuan again Thursday after party-to-party talks broke up last week.

Cheng Chen-long, legislative whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said Sunday that his party will never give way to the draft amendments to the seven key laws, especially those relating to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Cheng said the TSU lawmakers are determined to voice their opposition to the passage of the revisions that would keep in place an eight-year waiting period for mainland spouses of Taiwan residents to apply for ID cards, would allow the recruitment of students in Taiwan by mainland-based colleges and would permit the opening of direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait.

Cheng, who claimed that approving the amendments would be tantamount to "surrender, " said the TSU is resolved to seeking a vote to decide the issues and make clear the party's firm stance, despite the fact that its lawmakers already know what the result will be -- the TSU controls only 12 seats in the 223-seat legislature.

In the face of the many difficulties over the much-delayed passage of the disputed draft amendments to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area due to boycotts by the TSU and some members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said she was disappointed but by no means desperate.

Claiming that Thursday's extra session might be the last chance for legislators to reach a final agreement over the law revisions prior to the next presidential election in March 2004, she said the timing for making the amendments will become increasingly sensitive in the run-up to the presidential race.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, however, was a little more positive, saying that "the revisions might smoothly clear the Legislative Yuan on Thursday. " He based his optimism on planned negotiation efforts to bridge the differences between the various political parties.
He urged the ruling and opposition forces to repair their year-long divisions over the legislation with wisdom and rationality in order not to damage the public's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY OFFICIAL DENIES WRONGDOING IN SELLING CITY BANK

TEXT.P: A financial official in the Taipei city government denied any wrongdoing in incorporating the Taipei Bank, a bank virtually controlled by the city government, into the private Fubon Financial in August 2002.

Lee Sush-der, director of the Financial Bureau, told a news conference that Fubon was chosen by a panel of experts out of five private financial companies that were interested in taking over Taipei Bank.
The process was carried out under the vigilant eyes of the Ministry of Finance and the board of directors of the Taipei Bank, and the regulations were followed to the letter, Lee said.

Prosecutors from the Taipei District Court have investigated the process twice -- in August of last year and again in March this year -- and the Control Yuan opened an investigation into the process in October of last year, but none of these investigations have turned up any evidence of wrongdoing, Lee said.

He made the statement after former Taipei Bank Chairman Liao Cheng-ching claimed the city government committed serious mistakes by letting Fubon, which has assets of only NT$100 billion (US$2.97 billion), take over Taipei Bank, which has assets of more than NT$600 billion.

The city government suffered losses of tens of billions of new Taiwan dollars in the process, said Liao, who was forced to leave his post at the bank by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in 2001 after he became embroiled in a public quarrel with Taipei Bank General Manager Ting Yu-kang at the city council.

Liao's accusation came at the time when many Taipei city councilors were accusing Ma of favoring Fubon by trying to sell back to Fubon the city government's stock in the company at unreasonably low prices. The city government got Fubon's stock through the incorporation of Taipei Bank into Fubon Finance.

Lee dismissed as "a layman's view" Liao's claims that Taipei Bank is bigger than Fubon in terms of assets, saying that Taipei Bank's gross assets were NT$658.7 billion before the acquisition took place in August 2002, but most of its assets were deposits belonging to depositors, so that its net assets were NT$45.8 billion.

On the other hand, Fubon Finance, which acquired the Taipei Bank, is the parent company of Fubon Bank and others. It has gross assets of NT$1.15 trillion and net assets of NT$138.8 billion, which is almost three time larger than that of Taipei Bank.

Furthermore, Taipei Bank is facing the problem of shrinking profits, which have decreased from NT$1.5 billion before it was privatized in 1991 to less than NT$1 billion in the last two years because its relatively small business scale has seriously limited its competitiveness. The problem would not be solved unless it merged with a bigger financial group that could complement its ability to make a profit, Lee said.

Measured by stock prices as of Thursday, the combined value of Taipei Bank's stock has increased by NT$13.64 billion since it entered into an incorporation agreement with Fubon Aug. 8, 2002. This is the best proof that Taipei Bank has benefited from the incorporation, Lee argued.

Meanwhile, Chen Ching-hsiou, director of the city government's Rules and Regulations Commission, said Liao's "false accusation" has seriously hurt the city government's image and those of the related officials, and that he should be held accountable for libel and damage prompted by his "groundless" accusation.
Liao could not be reached for comment Sunday.

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese living in southern California Saturday jubilantly celebrated the Double-Tenth national day by taking part in two flag-raising ceremonies and a gala parade.

Jointly sponsored by more than 40 overseas Chinese organizations, a flag-raising ceremony was held in the city of Monterey Park in suburban Los Angeles in celebration of the Republic of China's national day, which falls on Oct. 10 each year.

Many overseas Chinese also attended a flag-raising ceremony sponsored by the Overseas Chinese Benevolent Association in Los Angeles' China Town. After the ceremony, they took part in a parade led by five floral floats and traditional Chinese dragon and lion dancing teams.
They marched to a city park and laid a wreath before a statue of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEIYI RAILWAY BOT PROJECT TO BE FINALIZED BY YEAR-END: MOTC

TEXT.P: Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials said Sunday that they will know later this year whether a direct railway line can be built linking Taipei City with the northeastern county of Ilan.

The MOTC Railway Engineering Bureau has contracted a private engineering consultation firm to carry out a comprehensive assessment of the feasibility of building a direct line through the mountainous Peiyi area and of the development's impact on the environment, MOTC officials said.

The feasibility and environmental impact assessment of the BOT (build-operate-transfer) project in which private investors will be allowed to construct and operate the railway for a given period before handing it over to the government -- is expected to be available by the end of the year, the officials noted.

In addition to the environmental impact, other factors, including geological conditions, drilling capacity and protection of water conservation are also major points to be included in the assessment report, they added.

The Peiyi railway, which will be about 42 kilometers long, could be developed in two ways -- either from Taipei City's Nankang District to Chiaohsi Township of Ilan County, or from Nankang to Chiaohsi via Toucheng, another Ilan township located nearer to the coast.
The railway would be built in 10 years with a budget of around NT$26.5 billion (US$0.79 billion), the officials noted.

The MOTC began planning the project after residents of Ilan appealed to the government that a direct line is needed to help the northeastern county prosper, even though the highly publicized Peiyi Freeway is 85 percent complete and scheduled to open to traffic by the end of 2005.
The Peiyi Freeway -- which links Taipei City and Ilan County -- has been called one of the most challenging road construction projects in the world and was 85 percent complete as of mid-September.
Construction had been delayed because of the special geological formation of Shueishan, the mountain through which the 12.9-km Shueishan Tunnel will pass.

More than a decade has passed since construction of the freeway began in 1991. Boring work has often been halted due to the frequent welling up of water at the construction site, as well as frequent mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS KEEN ON INVESTMENT PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Foreign companies willing to invest in Taiwan have promised in the run-up to the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference slated for Oct. 19-21 in Taipei to channel about NT$136.79 billion (US$ 4.06 billion) -worth of capital into the country, according to an official of a conference task force.

As of last Friday, a total of 1,441 company executives -- 563 from foreign companies, 385 from Taiwan-based foreign enterprises and 493 from domestic firms -- had applied to take part in the conference designed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to lure foreign capital to sharpen Taiwan's competitiveness, the task force official said.

Noting that the number of attendees has exceeded the target set previously, the official said foreign companies have given their assurance that they will inject NT$66.21 billion into 110 investment projects, and have also promised to channel NT$70.57 billion into another 73 investment projects --bringing the total to around NT$136.79 billion.
The official forecast that the total foreign investment level is expected to continue growing with the approach of the invest-promotion conference.

In addition, Ray Boushie, president of the U.S.-based Crane Aerospace, has met Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu and has expressed his company's hope of setting up an Asia-Pacific business operations center in Taiwan, an official with the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center said. He added that the U.S. company has already opened a production line at the Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone.

The Germany-based Bayer Group and Infineon Technologies AG are among the many world-class foreign concerns that are weighing investment in Taiwan. The Bayer Group has decided to send officials to take part in the business alliance conference, while Infineon is pondering increasing its investment in a Taiwan-based semiconductor company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AMERICAN ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION CONFERENCE OPENS IN L.A.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 4 (CNA) (by L. Chu and EH)

TEXT.P: More than 100 American and Taiwanese scholars and experts participated in the Taiwan-American Natural Disaster and Environmental Protection Conference Saturday in suburban Los Angeles.

The topics of discussion at the conference included the various problems of pollution and land sinking, how to resolve these problems, how to make good use of water resources, and how to improve the living environment.
Among the participants in the conference were Taiwanese experts from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, National Science Council, and the Environment Protection Administration.
The participants in the conference also visited a waste water processing plant, a trash yard, and an air quality control bureau in the greater Los Angeles area.
The conference was aimed at helping Taiwan resolve problems of natural disasters and environmental pollution, an official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES ASSURANCES FOR SECOND TERM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian gave seven assurances Sunday should he win a second term from 2004 through 2008, saying that he will do his utmost to achieve the objectives if he is re-elected in March next year.
Chen gave the assurances at a gathering in Taipei County to mark the establishment of one of his re-election support clubs.

Chen said he hopes to make Taiwan into a country that boasts "the world's largest number of high-quality products" and enjoys doubled tourist arrivals, 3 percent growth in gross domestic product, an unemployment rate lower than 4 percent and an economic growth rate of more than 5 percent, as well as the creation of 6 million broadband Internet users and 700,000 new jobs by 2008.

In addition, the president appealed for stronger public support for his call for a new constitution in 2006. Stating that it is an irreversible path for Taiwan to continue with its democratization, he claimed that the worst hardship for the government is over and that the public should have confidence in the government.
He also hailed the high efficiency of the administration led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which he said is hard evidence of the government's efforts to push for economic reforms.

For instance, construction of the Taipei-Ilan expressway is slated for completion by the end of 2005, while the quality of the tap water in the greater Kaohsiung area will be greatly improved by the end of this month, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU PROMOTING TAIWAN IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan mission featuring top-notch cooks from high-end international tourist hotels in Taipei and artistic performance groups has arrived in San Francisco to help promote Taiwan tourism.

A culinary demonstration of Chinese gourmet foods with an emphasis on Taiwanese cuisine, accompanied by music played by the Han Tang Ensemble -- a group of Taiwan musicians of classical Chinese music who gave a concert at New York's Lincoln Center this year -- and an aboriginal group playing songs that include Kuo Ying-nan's best-known work, which was part of the theme song of the 1996 Olympic Games, was met with warm enthusiasm by the audience, which included representatives from the U.S. travel and dining businesses and Chinese community leaders.
The five chefs who gave the culinary demonstrations were from the Hyatt, Grand and Ritz Landis hotels in Taipei, according to Stanley Yen, chairman emeritus of the Taiwan Visitors Association.
Yen said it was a great challenge simply to enable the Taiwan chefs to cook in the kitchen of the San Francisco Regency hotel using Western utensils and ingredients.
San Francisco is the first stop of the U.S. circuit tour of the Taiwan tourism promotion mission authorized by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF: TAIWAN SHOULD TRY TO JOIN U.N.-SPONSORED ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: Instead of joining the United Nations, Taiwan should first try to join working organizations sponsored by the United Nations, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has said in an interview with the Washington Post.

A statement issued Sunday by the KMT quoted Lien, who has served in the past as foreign minister, as saying that Taiwan has had difficulty returning to the United Nations because of its feud with mainland China, which strongly opposes the country's access to the world body, membership of which requires statehood.
However, Lien pointed out, there are many U.N.-sponsored working organizations which do not require statehood and therefore should be easier for Taiwan to join.

As a country with an advanced economy, Taiwan would be a valuable member of such organizations, most of which are formed for the purposes of improving weather forecasting, medical care, crime fighting, the environment and coordinating monetary policies.

Citing Taiwan's exclusion from the World Health Organization, Lien noted that the island had to fight the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks alone earlier this year and became an loophole in the worldwide defenses against the epidemic.
Lien said the example serves as evidence that the absence of Taiwan from these United Nations-sponsored working groups is a loss not only to Taiwan but also to the whole world.
The KMT statement did not say when and where the interview was conducted, or whether it has been published or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: STANFORD LECTURER ELECTED PRESIDENT OF HONG KONG CHINESE UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A professor of economic development at Stanford University has been elected president of the Chinese University of Hong Kong.

Lau, 59, a grandson of the late Kuomintang official Yu You-jen, is currently a K.T. Li professor of economic development at Stanford University, where he obtained his B.S. degree in physics and economics in 1964.

With M.A. and Ph.D degrees in economics from the University of California, Berkeley in 1966 and 1969, respectively, Lau is also currently a fellow researcher with Stanford University's Center for International Development and Center for Economic Policy Research, and a senior fellow with the Hoover Institution of Stanford University.
His specialized fields are economic theory, economic development and growth, and the economies of East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 5, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES CENTRAL AMERICAN PARLIAMENT SPEAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian bestowed Monday the Order of Brilliant Star With Special Grand Cordon upon Central American Parliament Speaker Augusto Vela Mena in recognition of his outstanding contributions to promoting ties between the Republic of China and the countries of Central America.

The ceremony, which took place at the Presidential Office, was witnessed by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco Hwang, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Joseph Wu and various members of Vela's entourage.
Chen welcomed the Central American parliamentarians to Taiwan and thanked them for a resolution they adopted to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
Chen also voiced his appreciation for various recent activities held jointly by the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America, as well as for Vela's second visit to the country.
The Pacific, rather than being a barrier, serves as a bridge linking the two sides as they move toward their shared aspiration for democracy, peace and freedom, the president said.

In response, Vela said he was deeply touched to receive the honor, which represents praise of peace and democracy long advocated by the Central American Parliament and by democratic Caribbean countries. Vela promised to devote more energy to helping strengthen two-way relations between the ROC and Central America.

Vela also expressed great admiration for Chen's long-term efforts to promote Taiwan's freedom and democratization and said he strongly believes that a wider range of cooperation between the two sides lies ahead, as the Legislative Yuan enjoys observer status at the Central American Parliament.
Traveling at the head of a seven-member delegation, Vela arrived Saturday in Taipei and is slated to depart for home Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ADMINISTRATION SIGNIFICANTLY BETTER THAN PREVIOUS ONE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed pride in the performance of his administration since the political transfer in 2000, claiming that its capacity to implement various projects was several times better than that of the previous administration under the Kuomintang (KMT).

Legislator Lee Chun-yi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said in a general interpellation session at the legislature that the DPP administration "is not afraid to make comparisons with the previous one."
Yu also expressed confidence in his administration when he spoke of its performance over the past three years.

The premier said that a 25-year contract for the Tatan power plant in Taoyuan will lead to savings of NT$150 billion (US$4.437 billion) , while the government saved NT$250 billion on the construction of the second north-south freeway.
"The DPP government has make the best use of each penny, " Yu claimed.

He also said that state-owned enterprises have started to operate in the black because of the efforts of the government. Between 1995 and 2001, China Shipbuilding Corp. and Tang Eng Iron Works Co. lost NT$35 billion, but both began to make money last year, he said.
The government also has helped the Kaohsiung region improve its tap water system and residents will have clean piped water from the end of this month, he added.
He also cited the Taichung Science-based Industrial Park, at 304 hectares and with manufacturers having built plants there within just one year, as a victory for his administration.

The annual progress of the Beiyi Freeway was 3.8 percent on average during the previous administration, but the ratio has jumped to 21 percent since the DPP came to power, Yu said, adding that he is confident the project can be completed as scheduled in 2005.

He described the DPP's performance as "excellent" and said the Cabinet is doing a good job in implementing various projects. He also claimed that the difference before and after the 2000 political transfer "is not double, but several fold."

On the government's debts, the premier said that when President Chen Shui-bian assumed office, the government was already NT$2,400 billion in debt, thanks to the KMT. As of the end of 2004, it will have incurred interest payments of NT$500 billion, which will have to be shouldered by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES ATTEMPTS AT FRAMEUP

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun denied Monday that his Cabinet has a scheme to "frame" opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong in the run-up to the March 2004 presidential election.

In an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, the premier dismissed as "groundless" an accusation made a day earlier by PFP official Chang Hsien-yao that the Executive Yuan is brewing a scheme codenamed "August 18" to set Lien and Soong up by delving into their past government service in the hope of finding material with which to smear them.
Lien is set to pair up with Soong in the election, with Lien running for president and Soong running for the vice presidency.
Chang also accused the Democratic Progressive Party administration of setting aside NT$100 billion for pork barrel politics in an attempt to court DPP followers.
Yu also denied these allegations.
Also Monday, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung condemned whoever spread the allegations, blasting them as irresponsible.

"Anyone who claims the Executive Yuan is trying to tarnish their image should come up with evidence rather than making unsubstantiated accusations that only suggest that they made the accusations for political purposes," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIXTH ASIA-PACIFIC ITS FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Sixth Asia-Pacific Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) Forum opened Monday at the Taipei International Convention Center, with Vice President Annette Lu addressing the opening.

Billing ITS as the leading and core technology in the current service- and knowledge-based society that allows people to easily navigate through intelligent transportation infrastructures, Lu said the innovative technology is expected to trigger a social revolution in the same way that IC technology led to the birth of the information industry.

Lu described ITS as a seamless entity that integrates transportation and management information systems, saves time and lives and reduces all types of resource-wasting, as well as helping strike a balance in regional development and upgrading social competitiveness and living standards.

ITS will become the most essential infrastructure in terms of national security and persistent development, she said, adding that this is the reason behind the U.S. government's efforts to initiate the National Intelligent Transportation Infrastructure (NITI) as far back as the 1990s to seek to continue the country's economic progress.
The vice president expressed her hope that Taiwan and other countries in the Asia-Pacific region will closely cooperate in promoting ITS to secure the region's security and prosperity.
It is the first time that Taiwan has hosted an international conference on ITS.

Experts from 16 countries and executives sent by many leading foreign-based and domestic information-related companies are taking part in the conference, which will run through Wednesday under the sponsorship of the Chinese ITS Association.

Association Chairman Lo Shang-jung said the Asia-Pacific region is set to become the world's largest ITS market within 10 years and that a wide range of commercial ITS applications are already in use, such as global positioning systems and real-time traffic broadcasts.

Many of the foreign officials at the conference were there mainly to gain more information about bidding for a highway toll machine system offered by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX UP IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) has a chance of returning to positive growth in the fourth quarter of this year and the pressure of deflation could ease, Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) officials said Monday.
The officials noted that the annual CPI growth was down 0.22 percent in September, marking a fall for the third consecutive quarter.
The officials said that the positive forecast is based on the economic recovery and a brisk stock market coupled with a lower base for comparison last year.

Asked whether the new Taiwan dollar's appreciation against the U.S. dollar -- and the consequent lower import costs -- will trigger more deflation, the officials said that although the domestic currency has appreciated against the greenback, it has depreciated against the yen and the euro, so that the prices of some imported electronics have risen and therefore deflation will not necessarily occur.
The CPI was 99.46 in September, up 0.30 percent from the previous month, the officials added.

They attributed the increase largely to price rises for fresh vegetables, fruit and meat in the run-up to the Sept. 11 Mid-Autumn Festival, parents buying presents for babysitters, and tuition hikes and other fees for the new academic year.
The CPI in September was down 0.22 percent from the same month of last year and the average CPI in the first nine months of this year was 0.3 percent lower than the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO ORDER PROBE INTO WATER SHORTAGES IN ABORIGINAL VILLAGES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said he will order the Cabinet's ethics division to investigate whether there have been any irregularities involved in water supply construction projects in several aboriginal villages in central Taiwan.
Yu was responding to complaints by independent Legislator May Chin's that a number of mountainous tribal villages in Nantou County have been plagued by serious water shortages.

Chin said at a Legislative Yuan plenary session that over the past two months she headed a team of aboriginal culture researchers to survey the living conditions of indigenous people in Nantou's several aboriginal townships, including Lona, Nanao, Tatung and Fuhsing.
"We were saddened when we found that many of the residents of these villages did not have any piped water," Chin said.

Chin said the village of Lona used to be Taiwan's largest aboriginal village. During its heyday, the village had a population of more than 2,700 people. Their ancestors built a dam more than 50 years ago to resolve their water supply problems but this was destroyed in 1996 when Typhoon Herb swept through central Taiwan. The government then spent NT$18 million and five years rebuilding a water supply system.

"The costly project only allowed Lona residents to enjoy piped water for seven months. The system was destroyed again in 2001 when Typhoon Toraj hit the area. Although the Nantou county government spent NT$8.5 million building a new water supply system, Lona residents still have no tap water," Chin claimed.
She said the government should conduct a comprehensive review to determine whether there have been any flaws or irregularities in carrying out the reconstruction projects.

In response, Yu admitted that there might have been some drawbacks in implementing the projects. "I will ask the ethics department to look into the cases and will also make an overall review of water supply problems in mountainous aboriginal villages, " he added.

Meanwhile, the Council of Aboriginal Affairs said natural disasters have damaged water supply systems in the tribal villages and that the council has launched a four-year plan to improve water supplies for aboriginal people.

"When the project is completed next year, the tap water supply rate will reach 70 percent in those areas, " a council spokesman claimed, adding that the council will draw up another improvement project after the first plan is completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDGET FOR REFERENDUM WILL BE APPROPRIATED ACCORDING TO LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that the budget for a national consultative referendum will be appropriated according to law, although the operation of such a referendum have not been finalized.
The premier made the remarks in the Legislative Yuan when he was addressing the concerns of an opposition legislator about the budget for the proposed referendum.

Legislator Kuo Chun-tsai of the opposition Kuomintang said that by his estimate, the budget for a consultative referendum would be between NT$400 million and NT$500 million (US$11.83 million and US$14.79 million) . He wondered if this issue deserved the high priority that the administration has given it.
The premier replied that the Executive Yuan has yet to flesh out the details of the referendum.

Liu San-chi, director of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, concurred by saying that government agencies had not included a budget for the consultative referendum in their 2004 proposed budget.
But the premier reaffirmed that the related budget will be appropriated "within legal bounds and will be according to law."

The administration has said that it will push for a national consultative referendum by next year's presidential election March 20, 2004, although Central Election Commission Chairman Huang Hsih-cheng said last week that the commission has no money and personnel to conduct such a referendum.
Huang also said that the Executive Yuan must create a legal basis for the referendum; otherwise, it will be hard for the commission to carry out the decisions of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FARM, AGRICULTURAL GOODS GAINING POPULARITY IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports of farm and agricultural products to Japan have gained an upper hand over those from mainland China, thanks to their high quality and safety, according to an official of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

Chen Chia-lin, a session chief of the COA's International Cooperation Department, said Taiwan-produced vegetable and fruits have enjoyed increasing popularity among Japanese consumers because of their high quality.

Chen said that Japan's purchases of Taiwan farm and agricultural products began to increase this year, a situation which he said might have something to do with the high level of pesticides and chemical residues found in green soy beans and spinach imports from mainland China since last year.

Japan's customs officials have now further heightened their scrutiny and control of mainland Chinese farm and dairy imports by lifting their inspection rate from 5 percent to 20 percent, which has resulted in a large decline in mainland exports to Japan, Chen explained.

Japanese consumers' grave concerns about the safety of mainland Chinese produce has created a big advantage for similar Taiwan products in the Japanese market and has led to greater Taiwan exports to Japan, Chen pointed out.

Chao Yung-chuan, secretary-general of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) , said the good image of Taiwan-made agricultural and farm products in Japan, although more expensive by 20 percent than mainland China's goods, have cleared the way for them to tap the international market.

In a bid to sell Taiwan's safe, healthy and fine-quality farm and agricultural produce, CETRA will help invite local farmers and companies to take part in international food festivals and invite foreign experts to strengthen bilateral exchanges, Chao added.

According to tallies compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan exports of farm and agricultural products were worth US$2.51 billion during the first eight months of this year, up by 4.3 percent over the year-earlier level.
Taiwan exports to Japan grew by 13.4 percent during the same eight-month period, while those to Hong Kong and the United States dropped by 14 percent and 8.7 percent, respectively, the tallies show.
Japan, Hong Kong and the United States are Taiwan's prime overseas markets for such products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIAL CONSENSUS BUILD ON TWO OF SEVEN BILLS PENDING AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A consensus among different political parties has been forged concerning many sections of two of seven bills which will be voted on in the Legislative Yuan Thursday, Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, said Monday.

Various parties have agreed with each other on most parts of the revised Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, and a revision to the 1995 Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union, which disagreed with the other parties on several articles of each bill, insisted to vote on them individually rather than enact them as a package.
There is no consensus on the other five bills, and the chances that they will pass Thursday are slim, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS ON ENTREPRENEURS TO KEEP BUSINESS ROOTS AT HOME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Taiwan manufacturers Monday to keep their business roots at home and to support his administration's push for further constitutional reforms to consolidate the island's young democracy.

Chen made the appeal in a speech delivered at the joint opening of the ninth annual conference of the World Federation of Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce and the 10th annual conference of the Council of Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce in Asia.

Noting that a prosperous Taiwan will contribute to individual business groups' global expansion plans, Chen said he is hopeful that all local business people will give priority to investing in Taiwan and retaining their business roots at home while making forays into the world market.

Chen said his administration has made strenuous efforts to revitalize the domestic economy and attract foreign investments. "All those efforts have paid off, " Chen said, adding that several world-renowned market research firms, including the Swiss Business Environment Risk Intelligence, have given high marks to Taiwan's investment climate and overall national competitiveness.

Since the government launched its six-year "Challenge 2008" national development plan, Chen said, more than 10 famous multinational business groups have set up research and development centers in Taiwan.
In addition, Chen said, more than 250 overseas Taiwan companies have also decided to establish their global operational headquarters on the island by the end of this year.
While corporate Taiwan epitomizes Taiwan's economic strength, Chen said, Taiwan is the root of all Taiwan companies. "And all business people will benefit from a stronger Taiwan."

Chen also said Taiwan's democratic reforms have yet to be completed. "We still have a lot of work to do, ranging from education, judicial and financial overhauls to constitutional reforms, " he stressed, adding that Taiwan must craft a constitutional framework that fits its present realities.

As overseas Taiwan business people have been a pivotal force supporting the nation's economic development and political reform, Chen said he is hopeful that they will support his call to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan.

Chen made the "new constitution" appeal for the first time on Sep. 28 at a rally marking the 17th founding anniversary of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in his capacity as the ruling party's chairman. He said he hopes that in 2006, when the DPP turns 20 years old, all of the 23 million people of Taiwan will push for a new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING TYCOON PREDICTS WORLD ECONOMY WILL GAIN STRENGTH AFTER 2005

TEXT.P: A shipping tycoon in Taiwan predicted Monday that barring any unexpected circumstances, the global economy will gradually rebound after 2005.
Chang Jung-fa, chairman of the Evergreen Group, made the remarks in a speech given at National Taiwan Ocean University to mark the school's 50th anniversary.
Chang said that based on an analysis of container cargo loads and his experience over the years, he said that the world economy will slowly regain strength after 2005.

Unless something out of the ordinary happens, Chang said, such as the United States-led military campaign against Iraq, or the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks against the United States, the world economy will be solid by 2015.
During the one-hour speech, Chang said shipping exchanges will increase progress in civilization and technology development. Mainland Chinese are more aware of this than those on Taiwan, he said.
He lamented that though Taiwan calls itself an ocean country, it has no ocean policy.

He noted that mainland China, after opening its markets, has seen its coastal cities such as Dalien, Shanghai and Guangdong enjoy rapid development, and the people there are even more affluent than people in Taiwan.
In contrast, the hinterlands of mainland China, because of its lack of stimulus and trade exchanges with the outside world, is comparatively rather backwards, he said.
He said that shipping can be a gauge of the direction of economic development and cited the recent growth of cargo volume of container vessels as an example.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2003 VLSI-TSA SYMPOSIUM OPENS IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: The 2003 International Symposium on VLSI Technology, System and Applications (2003 VLSI-TSA) opened at the Ambassador Hotel in Hsinchu Monday with the participation of top scientists and engineers in semiconductor industries from home and abroad.

The Taiwan VLSI-TSA symposium, considered one of the three leading conferences of its kind in the world along with the ones held biennually in Japan and the United States, is jointly sponsored by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , the International Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) and the Taiwan Semiconductor Industy Association.

The 2003 VLSI-TSA symposium in Taiwan, also a biennial event, is bringing together scientists and engineers actively engaged in research and development on VLSI technology, system and applications to discuss current progress in the field.

This symposium is also serving as a bridge ushering overseas Taiwanese or foreign scientists and specialists into Taiwan to actually join the lines of semiconductor research and development and manufacturing industry, said an ITRI official who is co-sponsoring the conference.

Among distinguished keynote speakers of the symposium will be H. Hakatsuna, vice chairman of Applied Materials Japan, who will speak on new 0.1 micron technology and its business prospects; B. Ackland of Agere Systems from the United States, who will introduce the applications of SOC technology in IC markets; and T. Claasen of Philips Semiconductor of the Netherlands, who will speak on platform-based designs and beyond, according to the ITRI official.

On Tuesday, United Microelectronics Corp. Chairman Tsao Hsing-cheng, MediaTek Inc. Chairman Tsai Ming-chieh and Chiang Shang-yi, a senior vice president in R & D of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. will each give a speech at the conference to share their experiences in the industry and its prospects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS GRADUAL SHIFT TO VOLUNTEER MILITARY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday the government will promote a volunteer military to replace the current mandatory conscription system insofar as the nation's financial resources will accommodate.

Yu was responding to questions from opposition lawmakers about his views on President Chen Shui-bian's recent call for further constitutional reforms to pave the way for government restructuring, including an overhaul of the military service system.
Because of the development of electronic warfare and other advanced defense strategies, Yu said, an all-volunteer military has become a prevailing trend.
Yu said that a conscription system under which draftees usually leave the military after a relatively short period of service could hinder accumulation of manpower training results.
"As modern warfare technology requires long-term training, we need more career soldiers. Therefore, an all-volunteer military is the wave of future," Yu told lawmakers.

As a matter of fact, Yu said, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has begun experiments with attracting individuals to join the services voluntarily. "We'll promote the all-volunteer military in a gradual manner according to the nation's financial condition, " he added.
Nevertheless, opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang questioned the appropriateness of trying to introduce a volunteer military in Taiwan, which would invariably be costly.
Lin said the government cannot afford to adopt such a system under which 80 percent of the military budget will be spent on personnel costs.
According to the MND's military restructuring plan, the total number of military personnel will be cut from the current 380,000 to 340,000 by the end of 2006 and further lowered to 300,000 by 2011.

"If we adopt a volunteer military system in 2006, the annual personnel maintenance cost will increase by an estimated NT$95.4 billion from the current level. Even when the number of military servicemen is trimmed to 300,000, the personnel cost will still increase by NT$89 billion annually," Lin claimed.
The exorbitant personnel cost will in turn hinder renovation of weaponry systems and manpower training and eventually undermine Taiwan's overall combat capability, Lin said.
Worse still, Lin said the local social environment is not yet ripe for creating a volunteer military.

According to Lin, the MND originally planned to receive three battalions of volunteer, non-commissioned officers this year. But so far, it has only managed to bring in 217 volunteers, Lin said, adding that 139 of them are incumbent marine corpsmen who opted to change to the new units.

"Only 78 were civilians who volunteered to join the military. The small number points to local youths' reluctance to pursue a military career. This should serve as a warning to the government while mulling an all-volunteer military," Lin noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY SUPPORT IMPORTANT FACTOR IN HELPING DEPRESSED YOUTHS

TEXT.P: The amount of family support that a depressed youth receives is a major factor influencing the level of severity of the youth's depression, a psychology expert said Monday.
Huang Kuo-yen, a psychology professor at National Chengchi University, said that the higher the level of family support the depressed juvenile receives, the less severe his or her depression will be.
Huang said that youths are just as likely to suffer from depression or other emotional problems as adults are.

Although most youths are inclined to share their feelings with their peers, those who suffer mental or physical health problems will fare much better if they seek and obtain support from their own families, Huang noted.

He urged the nation's youths to be on alert against the following symptoms -- mood swings, difficulty concentrating, dizziness, the sudden onset of feelings of sadness, and loss of appetite. Persons who suffer most of these symptoms continuously for three weeks should seek professional assistance immediately, Huang said, pointing out that depression is treatable and curable so long as it is discovered and tackled in time.

The John Tung Foundation, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting public health, which completed an islandwide survey last month about the mood climate of Taiwan adults, has made a short film, titled "The Next Smile, " to call the Taiwan public's attention to the problem of depression among youths.

The foundation has also made handy printed charts available at convenience stores islandwide to help youths to examine themselves constantly so as to prevent themselves from falling into the quagmire of depression or other mental or physical problems.
The results of the foundation's survey last month revealed that many Taiwan adults are not happy, with roughly 44 percent admitting that they are troubled by depression.

According to the survey, 43.9 percent of the Taiwan adult respondents confessed to having problems with depression, with 11.7 percent saying they feel they need medical treatment, 8.7 percent saying they feel their stress has reached the "saturation point," and 23.5 percent saying they often experience mood swings.

The survey also found that while 52 percent of the respondents said they can distinguish between clinical depression and feelings of depression, only 7.6 percent said they would consider seeking professional assistance for a mental disease or emotional problems.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPANIES IN SILICON VALLEY URGED TO SET UP FACTORIES IN S. TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 5 (CNA) (by Y. Chiang and EH)

TEXT.P: A reception was held Sunday in Silicon Valley to encourage American high-tech companies to set up production lines in the Tainan Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

Several hundred American entrepreneurs and high-tech experts attended the reception sponsored by the Tainan Industrial Park, the Taiwan Trade Center, and the science division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco.

Tai Chien, director of the Tainan Industrial Park Administration, said at the reception that many semiconductor, optoelectronics, biotechnology, communications and precision machinery companies have established their production facilities in the industrial park.
For example, he said, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp.(UMC) of Taiwan have established fabs in the industrial park to produce 12-inch chips.
He said all companies of advanced new technologies are welcome to set up factories in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PREDICTS GROWTH COULD REACH 4.67% FOR 4TH QUARTER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun predicted optimistically Monday that Taiwan's economic growth could reach 4.67 percent for the final quarter of this year.

Yu made the forecast at a Legislative Yuan plenary session to refute a claim by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kuo Tien-tsai that the Democratic Progressive Party administration is not competent enough to rev up Taiwan's sluggish economy.

Dismissing Kuo's criticism as unfair, Yu cited concrete figures, including growth in exports and foreign exchange reserves, to prove that the domestic economy has rebounded from its recent sluggishness and is now on a steady upward streak.

Yu further said preliminary tallies show that Taiwan could post a 3.9 percent economic growth rate for the third quarter of this year. "And the GDP (gross domestic product) growth rate may even hit 4.67 percent for the final quarter of the year," he added.

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau forecast heavy rains in Ilan, Hualien, Taitung, Hengchun, and the mountainous areas in southern Taiwan on Monday.
Weather forecasters said strong seasonal northeastern winds began to bring rains to eastern Taiwan early Monday morning.
A tropical low pressure system is expected to bring heavy rains to the mountainous areas of southern Taiwan Monday, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 6, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SAYS TAIWAN WILL WALK ITS OWN ROAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday ruled out the possibility of talks with mainland China as long as Beijing continues to impose conditions regarding such talks.
In an interview by the Asian Wall Street Journal, Chen declared that "we will walk our own road, our own Taiwan road."
"Taiwan is not a province of any country, nor is it a state of another," the president said, indirectly referring to mainland China and the United States, respectively.
"Any kind of democratic reform is our own internal affair. I don't think any democratic country can oppose our democratic ideals," he was quoted as saying.

The newspaper said that the Bush administration has watched with some alarm as President Chen has launched a series of initiatives - including pushing for referendum legislation and vowing to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan.

In the interview, Chen said the "one-China principle " should not exist. He also ruled out the possibility of accepting the 1992 consensus in which mainland China and Taiwan had agreed to allow for their own respective interpretations of the "one-China principle, " the paper said.
"The so-called 1992 consensus is still a "one-China principle, " Chen was quoted as saying.

"It's a way to make Taiwan a region; it belittles Taiwan; it marginalizes Taiwan, " Chen reportedly said, adding that "the people of Taiwan firmly believe that there is one country on each side of the straits, one China and one Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION KEY TO GREAT COUNTRY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A brand-new constitution is the key for Taiwan becoming a normal, fully developed and great country, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

In a defense of his call for a new constitution by 2006, the president told a meeting of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , of which he is chairman, that he made the call out of his concerns over the people's well-being because an economic system on its own cannot work unless it operates under a well political framework defined by the constitution.
If a government cannot work efficiently and a legislature cannot work properly because of partisan bickering, it will inevitably dampen private sector interest in investment, Chen said.
Therefore, he said, the DPP wants to reach its goal of economic recovery through political reform that should start with rewriting the constitution.
The current political system, which enables a few lawmakers to block legislation vital to the country and paralyze the entire legislature, has to be overhauled from inside out, Chen said.
The country cannot resort to dictatorship as a way to improve its efficiency. However, it can rewrite a constitution to make it easier and faster to formulate, review and implement policy, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DEBTS INCREASE BY NT$248.8 BILLION IN FOUR YEARS

TEXT.P: A government spokesman said Tuesday that the government's debts will increase by NT$243.8 billion (US$7.21 billion) from fiscal 2000 to fiscal 2004 after unusual and disaster relief expenditures have been deducted.

Lin Chia-lung made the remarks after various legislators expressed concern about the government's unpaid debts, which are expected to reach NT$3.4 trillion in fiscal 2004, accounting for 33 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP).

Lin explained that after deducting the reconstruction fund for the 1999 earthquake, the relief budget for the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , the fund to compensate farmers' losses due to agricultural imports, the budget for the reconstruction of the Keelung River, and other unusual disaster expenditures, government debts will see a net increase of only NT$243.8 billion from fiscal 2000 to fiscal 2004, by which time the Democratic Progressive Party will have governed the country for four years.

Meanwhile, in response to criticism that the government has not streamlined the personnel of public agencies as it has promised to do, Lin quoted statistics compiled by the Central Personnel Administration showing that the government plans to hire 229,644 workers for its administrative sector in fiscal 2004, in comparison with the 235,459 hired in fiscal 2003 and 248,519 hired in fiscal 2002.
The government is also expected to hire 173,751 people in its state-run enterprises in fiscal 2004, in comparison with the 180,610 hired in fiscal 2003 and the 193,570 employed in fiscal 2002.
Lin added that although the government has increased the number of public agencies, the real number of personnel hired by the government agencies has fallen every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MORE EFFECTIVE IN CRACKDOWN ON PIRATED COMPACT DISKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's efforts to clamp down on pirated CDs, VCDs and DVDs have noticeably paid off in recent months since the Copyright Law was amended in July requiring prosecution of manufacturers and sellers of fake discs, a government official said Tuesday.

Tsai Lien-sheng, director-general of the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , made the remarks at a news conference in which he also denied a media report that claimed Taiwan is one of the world's three largest sources of pirated discs, calling the figures cited in the report "groundless" and "unfounded."

According to Tsai, the law amendment has effectively reduced commercial piracy, while a police task force set up by the Criminal Investigation Bureau has also been a useful weapon in the crackdown on intellectual property rights violations.

Tsai said the police ad hoc group seized a total of 5,906 pirated CDs and 8,001 counterfeit DVDs and VCDs during the second half of August at night markets across Taiwan. In September, a total of 11,411 fake CDs and 22,098 DVDs and VCDs were nabbed, he added, noting that the amounts represent a large fall from the previous levels, which easily hit 90,000 per month.

Tsai said that the sale of pirated discs has markedly fallen in Taiwan and noted that the U.S.-based Music Publishers' Association has also echoed this viewpoint after repeated fact-finding missions to Taiwan's night markets.

In addition, he added, an MOEA special committee made a total of 807 inspections on 76 disc manufacturing factories across the country during the first nine months of this year, a large increase from the year-earlier level of 144.

Tsai reiterated the government's resolve to fully protect intellectual property rights and urged what he described as "discredited organizations" not to tarnish Taiwan's image in this regard by issuing "groundless information."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING SHIPS NOT TAKING SHARKS IN COSTA RICAN WATERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan fishing ships do not catch sharks or collect shark fins in Costa Rican waters, an official of the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Tuesday.

Denying reports by a Costa Rican ecological and environmental protection group that Taiwan fishermen have been catching sharks to collect shark fins in the Central American nation's waters, Chen Yu-cherng said that the vessels involved in the illegal operations are not Taiwanese, according to information compiled by the Republic of China's governmental agencies stationed in Costa Rica.
Chen said there are only a small number of Taiwanese fishing boats operating in Costa Rican waters and they are not commissioned to catch sharks.

The agency has investigated similar reports issued by other ecological and environmental protection organizations in the past and found in each case that the ships involved were not from Taiwan, Chen noted.
Chen said the ecological and environmental organizations might be mistaking foreign fishing vessels that employ Asian fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS REACH RECORD HIGH IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Exports in September reached US$12.56 billion, a record high since April, and foreign trade will grow in the fourth quarter, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Tuesday.

According to MOF statistics, exports in September represented an increase of 11.6 percent over the same month of last year, while imports totaled US$10.98 billion, an anual growth of 4.1 percent, giving a trade surplus of US$1.58 billion, up 125 percent over the same period of 2002.

Exports in the first nine months of this year totaled US$103.3 billion, up 8.1 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports reached US$90.79 billion, an annual growth of 9.2 percent giving a trade surplus of US$12.51 billion, an increase of 0.4 percent over the same period of last year.
Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Department of Statistics, said exports in the fourth quarter are expected to grow by 8 percent over the same period of last year.
With the recovering global economic prospects and the consequent growth in exports, as well as the prosperous stock and real estate markets, Hsu expressed optimism about Taiwan's economic prospects.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO MOBILIZE 100,000 PARTY MEMBERS TO JOIN MARCH FOR REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will mobilize 100,000 party members to participate in a march for referendum slated for Oct. 25 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, a DPP official said Tuesday.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Yin-yuan said at a press conference following the party's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting that President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as DPP chairman, instructed party officials at the meeting to mobilize the DPP members.

Chen expressed the hope that at least 100,000 DPP members will take part in the demonstration in order to demonstrate that the party is pulling all the stops to drum up support for referendum and a new constitution, said Lee.
Chen also instructed party officials to form an ad hoc task force to promote the Oct. 25 demonstration, Lee continued, adding that the group will be headed by DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-GROWN FLAMINGO FLOWERS CONQUER JAPAN

TEXT.P: Flamingo flowers grown in a small southern Taiwan village have conquered Japan, agricultural sources said Tuesday.

Chuang Chun-chin, head of a floral production cooperative in Tainan County's Chungshe village in southern Taiwan, said that since he took the initiative to plant flamingo flowers, also known as anthurium, in styrofoam containers a few years ago, the imported floral species has grown well in his village.

"The success rate is almost 100 percent, " Chuang said, adding that forcing the flowers in styrofoam containers cuts the growth period by two to three months compared to time they need to reach maturity using regular planting methods.

According to Chuang, it takes only six to seven months for a styrofoam container-grown flamingo plant to blossom. "The shortened growth period gives us great leverage to compete with other countries in the world market," he explained.
Hawaii and the African state of Mauritius are Taiwan's strongest competitors in this field, Chuang said. "We have competed fiercely to make inroads into Japan, a major export market," he noted.

Chuang said Taiwan is now Japan's largest flamingo flower supplier, accounting for a 39 percent market share. "Chungsha village alone accounts for 17 percent of Taiwan's annual flamingo flower exports to Japan, or about 1.4 million stems worth more than NT$150 million, " he said, adding that the village is thriving on its flowers.
In the past, Chuang said, the annual income of a horticulturalist in Chungsha was about NT$300,000. "Nowadays, each of them can make two or three times that amount," he added.
