DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Japan Highway chief refuses to step down; Long process needed to remove Fujii. Japan Highway Public Corp. President Haruha Fujii on Monday defied an order by transport minister Nobuteru Ishihara to begin the formal process of sacking him.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFERENT AGE GROUPS HAVE DIFFERENT INTERNET PREFERENCES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Users of different age groups have different purposes for the Internet, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

According to the poll conducted by Insight Xplorer, a market consulting company headquartered in Taipei, Internet users who were born during the decade from 1971 to 1980 -- the so-called "sixth-graders" -- accounted for the largest portion of Taiwan's total cyber population in August at around 3.17 million.

Those users who were born during the 1981-1990 period -- the "seventh-graders" -- made up the second-largest age group at about 3.04 million, the survey found, while the "fourth-grade" age group -- users who were burn during the 1951-1960 period -- formed the smallest ratio of less than 950,000.

The seventh-graders, though fewer in number compared to the sixth graders, spent the longest time per month -- an average 28 hours -- browsing on the Internet. These "heavy Internet users" were also the most frequent online visitors browsing the largest number of Web sites.
According to the survey results, the seventh-graders were entertainment-oriented, surfing the Internet in search of their favorite music, personal pages and games.
However, the sixth-graders went online largely to meet their personal needs in August, mainly to find jobs, followed by online banking and shopping.

Meanwhile, the fourth- and fifth-graders were knowledge-based Internet users, preferring to visit sites on financial, stock, securities investment and news services. Tourism-related websites were most popular among the fifth-graders.

Internet users of different age groups vary a great deal in their behavior patterns and value judgments, and Web site operators should know very precisely which segment of the public they aim to attract, an Insight Xplorer executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT FINANCES STILL HEALTHY: MOF

TEXT.P: Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials claimed Tuesday that the government's financial situation can be considered healthy, with unpaid debts accounting for 32.22 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP).

The officials noted that although the central government's financial situation is still healthy and the ratio of its debt is reasonable, government agencies are still trying hard to increase revenues and reduce expenditures.

They made the remarks in the wake of news reports saying that the government's outstanding debts have reached NT$3.4 trillion (US$97.84 billion) , or 33 percent of the GDP. Quoting the statistics compiled by the International Monetary Fund, the reports added that if efforts are not made, the country might undergo a financial collapse.

The officials said that as of the end of September, the government's unpaid public debts had reached NT$3.18 trillion, accounting for 32.22 percent of the GDP, a figure that is expected to reach NT$3.43 trillion by next year, which is still within the ceiling of 40 percent allowed under the public debt law.

The officials said that the unpaid public debts of the U.S. government accounted for 34.6 percent of its GDP in 2000, Japan's public debts accounted for 106.5 percent of its GDP in 2002, while United Kingdom's public debts were 49.9 percent of its GDP in 1997.

Government debts accumulated rapidly in the last 10 years due largely to the implementation of various construction projects designed to stimulate economic development, expenditures in social welfare, and extensive reconstruction work following the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan in 1999.

In addition, the officials added, the corporate tax reduction policy and the global economic recession have made the country's stable income account for between 12.61 percent and 14.17 percent of the GDP, while its expenditures since 2001 have accounted for between 77.65 percent and 86.38 percent of the GDP.

The officials said the government has worked hard to increase its revenues by avoiding inappropriate tax reduction programs and reducing its expenditures with the aim of achieving financial balance in five to 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LEGISLATURE TO EXAMINE BUDGET PLAN SOON

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan should not turn back the government's budget plan, but should examine it as soon as possible to avoid giving the people the impression that lawmakers are indulging in partisan struggles while ignoring the public interest, Premier Yu Shyi-kun warned Tuesday.

Answering a question from a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Yu said the operation of the Executive Yuan has been affected in the past two years because its budget was not approved by the legislature by the time set by law.
Saying that the budgets of some government-owned enterprises had been passed eight months later than required by law, the premier said this had disrupted the running of these companies.

Meanwhile, lawmakers of the opposition People First Party (PFP) pointed out 23 instances of what they called irregularities in the budget plan, and urged the government organizations that prepared the budget to correct them.
Citing as examples, Chou Hsi-wei, PFP convener at the legislature, said the Judicial Yuan prepared its budget on the basis of a new organic law that has not yet been enacted by the Legislative Yuan,
Furthermore, Chou said, the budget illegally financed at least 65 government organizations, such as the National Human Rights Exhibition Hall and the Higher Education Examination Committee.
The lawmaker said his party won't return the budget plan to those who drafted it; rather, the organizations that submitted the budget should correct the errors themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTISTS FLOCK TO TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL CERAMICS FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan International Ceramics Festival has attracted 692 entries from 47 countries in the competition to be held next January, the Council for Cultural Affairs said Tuesday.
Council Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou said 125 local and overseas artists have been selected as qualifiers to vie for the top prize of NT$1.3 million (US$38,460).
Among the qualifiers, 25 are from Taiwan and the largest among all nations, and the rest hail from 26 different countries.

She noted that Taiwan has hosted other international arts events, including a lithography exhibition, a documentary film festival and a piano playing contest since she assumed office, hoping to make the achievement of Taiwan in arts more visible to the world.

Many well-known ceramics artists are competing in the upcoming festival, such as the modern pottery master Rudy Autio from the United States and Steven Montgomery, who just won a gold medal at a competition in South Korea.

She said that the complete list of qualifiers can be found online at www. ceramics.tpc.gov.tw. An international panel of judges will arrive in Taipei next January to screen the works for the final competition.
The award ceremony will be held Feb. 13 next year and there will be a three-day international ceramics seminar to promote exchanges between artists.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, giving up NT$0.017 to close at NT$33.793.
A total of US$742.5 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.850 and dipped to a low of NT$33.780.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX MILITARY ACADEMIES TO BE INTEGRATED INTO ONE SCHOOL: MND

TEXT.P: The six existing core military academies will be integrated into a single university in 10 years, the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday.

Defense ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a regular news conference that the military academies integration is part of the nation's military restructuring and modernization plan aimed at forging an elite deterrent force in the face of mainland China's persistent military threats.

According to the defense ministry's reform agenda, the Chinese Military Academy, the Chinese Naval Academy, the Chinese Air Force Academy, Fu Hsing Kang College, the National Defense Management School and the Chung-cheng Institute of Science and Technology will be integrated into one university to train career military officers by 2012.

The integration project will be carried out in two stages, Huang said, adding that in the first phase from 2003 through 2006, departments at the six academies will be merged or cut and their staff will be trimmed. In the second stage from 2007 through 2012, their campuses will be concentrated in one area or several areas.

Touching on Premier Yu Shyi-kun's recent announcement that the government will promote a volunteer military to replace the current mandatory conscription system, Huang said an all-volunteer military is truly the wave of future because of the development of electronic warfare and other advanced defense strategies.

Nevertheless, Huang said the defense ministry will carry out the transformation project insofar as the nation's finances will allow for the adjustment. The speed will also depend on the acquisition of advanced weapons and the response of local youths to voluntary military services, he added.

Meanwhile, Minister of Defense Tang Yiau-min said recently that the ROC armed forces will be transformed into defense forces, with the combined services brigade as the main operational unit to cope with the nation's defense demands.

The transformation, which will be carried out in a gradual manner, is expected to be completed in 10 years, Tang said, adding that in the first four years, various existing military academies will be downsized and integrated. Several professional defense research institutes will then be set up in tandem with the nation's military buildup policy.
From 2004 through 2006, Tang said, 45,000 servicemen will be axed. In the second stage, he went on, the number of servicemen on active duty will be cut to 270,000.

The New York Times: Officials Warn of Absentee Vote Factor in Recall Election.
About 3.2 million Californians have requested absentee ballots for Tuesday's recall election, and election officials are growing worried that counting this record number of absentee ballots could drag out the results of an already unwieldy election.
The Wall Street Journal: Air Force Ex-Official Had Ties To Boeing During Contract Talks.
A former Air Force official who now works for Boeing Co. had several personal ties to the aerospace giant while she was negotiating on behalf of the government a controversial plan valued at over $20 billion to lease Boeing jetliners as airborne refueling tankers.
Darleen Druyun, during her tenure as deputy acquisitions chief for the Air Force, agreed to sell her Virginia home to a Boeing attorney working on the tanker-lease arrangement, according to information compiled by a conservative nonprofit research group in Washington. In addition, her daughter and her son-in-law were and still are employed by the Chicago-based company.

It was a few minutes past 8 a.m. on Saturday when Hanadi Jaradat's parents last saw her.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCKS PERFORMANCE, REAL ESTATE SHOW ECONOMY HAS RECOVERED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that judging from the stock market and real estate market, Taiwan's economy has indeed recovered and he urged the public to have confidence in the government.
The president made the remarks when he spoke at the ground-breaking ceremony of the second 12-inch fab of Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.
The president said that steady growth in the stock market and the rejuvenation of the real estate market have shown that the economy has rebounded.
He noted that since the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome in June, Taiwan's economy has been brisker.

The stock market has grown by more than 30 percent since the beginning of the year, and the government's incentive to halve the land price increment tax as well as low interest rates for housing loans have helped the house purchase rate to hit a new 16-year high. The rate grew 23 percent this year from last year.

The president said that judging from the fact that the public has gradually pumped money into the stock market and real estate market, Taiwan's economy is gradually rebounding and the situation is not just a temporary recovery.

The president also cited the words of Franklin D. Roosevelt: "We have nothing to fear but fear itself, " to highlight his point that "We must believe in ourselves, believe in Taiwan and in its economy."

He also said that the government will continue to push for deregulation, an open policy, improve the investment environment, and solicit more enterprises to take part in major investment projects to build momentum in the economic recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN PRIME MINISTER REITERATES NEED FOR ASEAN SINGLE MARKET

TEXT.P: Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said Tuesday that Association of South East Asia Nations (ASEAN) economies stand to grow by as much as 10 percent, but only if they work faster towards forming a single market to stay competitive.

Speaking at an investment summit ahead of the annual ASEAN leaders summit to be held Oct. 7-8 in Bali, Indonesia, Goh said that the collapse of last month's World Trade Organization talks in Cancun, Mexico doesn't mean that ASEAN should take its foot off the pedal when it comes to economic integration.
Goh, regarded as the architect of the notion of the ASEAN Economic Community, reiterated the urgency for realizing the vision of a single market.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT CONSIDERING CHANGING POLICY ON LEGAL MASSEUSES

TEXT.P: Allowing people who are not visually impaired to give massages legally is not being considered by the government, officials of the Ministry of the Interior said Tuesday.
The officials made the announcement after receiving protests by eight associations of blind people who strongly oppose opening the massage industry to people with normal eyesight.

The complaints stem from an incident late last month where Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien received massage services from two unlicensed woman masseuses, which were paid for by business associates of the minister.
Taiwan's media highlighted the situation, speculating whether Yu would retain his job. The issue ended with Yu apologizing and Premier Yu Shyi-kun giving out a verbal warning.
Interior ministry officials said on Friday that it is inappropriate to open the massage market to ordinary people before the blind citizens' jobs are fully protected.

DOC.HEADLINE: SRI INTERNATIONAL TO SET UP R&D HUB IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. research institute SRI International is planning to set up a research and development hub in Taiwan, in the belief that Taiwan is a country with vast global potential and competitiveness in biotechnological industrial development, an industrial leader said Tuesday.

Tai Chien, administrator of the Southern Taiwan Science Park, who has just returned from a trade and investment promotion tour of the United States, said SRI International authorities have given great credit to Taiwan's potential to be developed into an international biotech R&D stronghold.

Tai said he met with some of SRI International's officers and was told that if SRI International decides to relocate part of its R&D operations to Taiwan, the Southern Taiwan Science Park will be one of the partners in Taiwan for cooperation.

According to Tai, a mission from the Southern Taiwan Science Park, a new "Silicon Valley" in Taiwan, visited the United States in September, successfully soliciting 32 American companies to invest in Taiwan. The prospective investments, including those in semiconductor manufacturing, precision instruments, telecommunications and biotech industries, are expected to be finalized in two to three years, he said.

SRI International, an independent, non-profit research institute formerly known as Stanford Research Institute, provides high-value solutions to a wide range of government, business and foundation clients in information, communications and engineering technologies; pharmaceuticals and biotechnology; chemicals and physics; and the public policy areas of education, health and economic development, according to Tai.

DOC.HEADLINE: 32 U. S. COMPANIES COURTED TO INVEST IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Thirty-two U.S. hi-tech companies are willing to invest in two science-based industrial parks in southern Taiwan over the next three years, with two of them already having signed cooperation accords with Taiwan authorities, an official said Tuesday.

Tai Chien, director of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration, made the report at a news conference after having returned a day earlier from a tour of Los Angeles, Houston, Chicago and San Francisco, which was aimed at attracting U.S. capital for the two science-based industrial parks -- one in Tainan and the other in Luchu, Kaohsiung.

Tai said it was the fourth such trip organized by the administration to the United States and that the response has been far warmer than in the past as a result of an ongoing economic recovery across the globe and a better understanding of Taiwan's investment climate by U. S. businesses.

The 32 prospective U.S. corporate investors are mainly from the semiconductor, biotechnology, telecommunications and precision machinery industries, Tai said, adding that two of them already have agreed upon a memorandum of understanding with the administration, while three will soon send officials on fact-finding missions to the industrial park in Tainan.

Over the past seven years, 116 companies have been allowed to set up shop in the two southern science-based industrial parks and have employed more than 16,700 workers, creating business revenue of over NT$100 billion last year. The level is expected to top NT$150 billion (US$4.438 billion) in 2003. (By Flor Wang) ENDTIEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Ruling Opens Cable Lines; Internet Access Choices May Grow.
Cable companies would be required to open their networks to rival high-speed Internet service providers under a federal appeals court ruling yesterday that could lead to more choices for consumers and subject the industry to the same competitive pressures roiling the telephone market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIATHLON ATTRACTS OVER 600 TO TAITUNG COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fittest men and women will challenge their physical limits Oct. 11 in Taiwan's 12th annual triathlon in Taitung County.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, known as an avid jogger, said Tuesday that he has "summed up his courage" and will participate in the grueling competition this Saturday in eastern Taiwan.
Participants in the triathlon will swim 1.5 kilometers, ride a bicycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers.

Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan has invited anyone interested in the event to take part. Already more than 600 have registered to participate, including Mayor Ma and his bodyguards, a Taipei City Government team comprised of bureau chiefs from the Taipei City police department, as well as Ma's old friend and former Taipei City Government Information Department Director King Pu-tsung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO VISIT PANAMA IN EARLY NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to pay a state visit to Panama in early November to attend a ceremony marking the Republic of Panama's centennial slated for Nov. 3, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Tuesday.
Panama will be the only ally country of the Republic of China that President Chen will visit in his upcoming overseas trip scheduled for Oct. 30-Nov. 6, Chien said.
On his way to Panama, President Chen will make a transit stop in New York where he will be honored at an annual meeting of the International League for Human Rights (ILHR), Chien said.
ILHR Chairman Scott Horton will bestow the prestigious Human Right Award on President Chen in recognition of his extraordinary contributions to protecting human rights in Taiwan.
President Chen is scheduled to make another transit stop on his way home from Panama in the state of Alaska, Chien said.
The president will pay a visit to Anchorage, Alaska's largest city, at the invitation of Governor Frank H. Murkowski, who has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan, Chien said.

During the visit, Murkowski will confer a medal representing the highest honor of Alaska on Chen to show his admiration for the ROC president, according to Wu Li-pei, a senior adviser at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTBOUND TOURISTS URGED TO STAY VIGILANT AGAINST ROBBERY

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau on Tuesday urged Taiwan tourists traveling abroad to be aware of the possible dangers of robbery after a stabbing incident in Spain.
The bureau made the appeal after two members of a Taiwan tour group sustained injuries in a street robbery in the Spanish capital of Madrid Monday.

According to reports from Madrid, a female member of the tour group organized by a Taipei travel agency was stabbed by a man who tried to snatch her handbag. The leader of the tour group also sustained a knife wound to his hand while struggling to rescue the injured group member. The robber made away with a few hundred euros. The two victims are in stable condition after receiving medical treatment.
The 27-member tour group continued its travel itinerary after the incident, local travel sources said. The group will return to Taipei Oct. 12.

Tourism Bureau officials said that due to a steady influx of illegal immigrants in Spain, public order in that country has been deteriorating and foreign tourists are primary targets of criminals. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO SURRENDER CONTROL OF ISLETS TO KINMEN GOVERNMENT: MND

TEXT.P: The military will surrender administrative control of the six offshore isles near the frontline island of Kinmen to the Kinmen County government in the near future and open them up to tourism, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Tuesday.

However, troops will not be withdrawn from the two major frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu as long as the Communist Chinese refuse to renounce the option of military force against Taiwan, said Chao Ching-ho, a spokesman for the MND Office of Deputy Chief of General Staff for Operations and Planning.

As long as Beijing holds to the option of the use of force against Taiwan, the MND will not talk about abolishing the Kinmen and Matsu defense commands as has been alleged in recent local media reports, Chao said.

He said the MND has decided to surrender administrative control of the six isles -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tongting, Peiting, Menghuyu and Shihyu -- in line with the will of local residents as expressed in a series of meetings held with the residents since 1999.

After the gradual removal of the military presence on the six isles is completed, the Kinmen police and coast guard forces will take over the responsibilities of maintaining law and order there, Chao said.

In the event of an outbreak of war in the Taiwan Strait, Chao said, the MND is confident that these Kinmen isles will be in good defensive hands authorized by the MND, which in recent years has strived to upgrade the armed forces' surveillance, mobilization and combat capabilities on a comprehensive basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted index for October moved up 26 points to close at 5,855, with 20,659 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 18 points to finish at 5,850, with 596 contract transactions, while December futures gained 23 points to close at 5,850, with 6 contracts traded.
March futures decreased 4 points to finish at 5,859, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,829 for October, 5,832 for November, 5,827 for December, 5,863 for March, and 5,799 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
October TE futures gained 0.2 points to close at 259.5, with 3,343 contract transactions, while November TE futures remained unchanged at 259.6, with 226 contracts traded.
December TE futures rose 2.9 points to finish at 259.3, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures increased 8.6 points to close at 831.6, with 6,480 contract transactions, while November TF futures gained 5 points to finish at 825, with 495 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 11.8 points to close at 828, with 4 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 5.48 points to close at 5,856.68.
The bourse opened at 5,873.33 and then fluctuated between 5,879.68 and 5,828.05 during trading.

A total of 4.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$106.42 billion (US$3.15 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 5.81 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$125.2 billion (US$3.71 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.4 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by cement stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 1.1 percent, construction stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 0.7 percent, electrical stocks at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 437 to 268, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ACHIEVE BALANCED BUDGET IN 5 TO 10 YEARS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the administration has set the goal of achieving a balanced budget in five to 10 years.
The premier made the remarks in a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan during which lawmakers expressed concern about the worsening financial state of the nation.

Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao of the opposition Kuomintang said that the government registered a deficit of NT$800 billion (US$23.66 billion) between 2001 and 2003, asking whether there is any possibility at all that it will be able to achieve a balanced budget.
Finance Minister Lin Chuan replied that the government cannot achieve such a goal in a short period of time, saying that it is now trying to carry out a plan to achieve the goal in five to 10 years.
KMT Legislator Huang Ming-hui cited news reports to point out that the government's total outstanding debt has reached 3.4 trillion, or 33 percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
The mass-circulation China Times reported that the government's stable income, such as from taxes, as a ratio of the nation's GDP is only 13.5 percent.

If the government continues to run deficits every year, coupled with the fact that the island's population continues to gray, meaning fewer and fewer people paying taxes and more and more people receiving social welfare benefits, the government could face financial collapse if the island is struck by a natural disaster or an economic crisis, the report said.
The premier said that a financial reform committee under the Ministry of Finance submitted a plan on achieving financial balance in five to 10 years and that the Cabinet has accepted the plan.
Minister Lin said that the plan has been implemented and that it would be reviewed every two years, adding that "the chances are that financial balance can be achieved in eight or nine years."

The premier also said that the increases in the government deficit are not as serious as reports have claimed, noting that the deficit was a little more than NT$2.3 trillion for 2000 and that it only rose about NT$1 trillion over the period of four years.

If the interest payment of NT$500 billion and other unforeseen expenditures such as those for the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak between March and June of this year are excluded, then the public deficit only amounts to about NT$40 billion a year, the premier said.

On the same occasion, the premier said that the government's NT$20 billion public works project to stimulate employment has paid off, noting that the unemployment rate for August was 5.21 percent, down from 5.35 percent for the same month a year earlier.
By the year's end, the jobless rate should be cut even further to 4.5 percent, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 7, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSETS OF OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS REACH RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: According to statistics compiled by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC), as of the end of August, there were 71 offshore banking units (OBU) in the island, with their assets reaching US$56.63 billion, an historical high.
The figure represents an increase of 19.62 percent over the same month of last year, according to a CBC official.

Yu Ming-nan, deputy director of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, said most of the capital of the OBUs came largely from deposits from financial institutions and Taiwan investors with operations abroad.
The statistics also showed that the OBU's trade in foreign exchange totaled US$5.31 billion in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR MEETS WITH HIS ASUNCION CITY COUNTERPART
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that his city and Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, should strengthen cooperation in matters relating to economic processing zones as well as in cultural exchanges.

During a meeting with Enrique Riera Escudero, the mayor of Asuncion, Hsieh also expressed his gratitude to Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos for his strong support to Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations.

Hsieh noted that although Taiwan is economically strong, it is weak in global political circles. He said he hopes that both countries can strengthen city government information exchanges, and that he can have the opportunity to visit Paraguay next year.
Riera invited Hsieh to visit Paraguay and to sign a cooperation agreement for further exchanges between Kaohsiung and Asuncion.

Riera added that Paraguay, located in the center of the Southern Cone Common Market (Mercosur) , is geographically close to other member countries, including Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil. He said he hopes that Taiwan manufacturers can use Paraguay as a transshipping center to promote their products in the whole Southern Cone Common Market.
Noting that Paraguay is Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in South America, Hsieh stressed that both countries should further strengthen cooperation and exchanges.
Hsieh added that the government is helping enterprises in the Kaohsiung Economic Processing Zone to invest in Central and South America.

DOC.TEXT:
Times: England strike caps day of football shame.
The England football squad last night voted unanimously to strike unless Rio Ferdinand was reinstated to the squad.
Financial Times: Granada-Carlton merger approved.
One of the biggest deals in UK broadcasting history was cleared yesterday as the government approved the 4.5bn pound merger of Granada and Carlton to help the ITV companies compete against the BBC and British Sky Broadcasting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TAIWAN-AUSTRALIAN TRADE TIES STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met an Australian trade delegation Wednesday and expressed the hope that economic and trade relations between the two countries can be further strengthened.

Ian Sinclair, chairman of Australia-Taiwan Business Council (ATBC), who is leading the Australian trade delegation, extended an invitation to Taiwan's business leaders and government officials to visit Australia to promote bilateral economic and trade ties.

President Chen expressed his gratitude to the Australian government for its support for Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), and he said that the ATBC has played a vital role in the efforts. Taiwan joined the WTO in early 2002, becoming the 144th member of the world organization.
Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Australia reached US$4.4 billion last year, with a trade surplus of US$1.2 billion in Australia's favor.

Taiwan, Australia's eighth-largest trading partner, is also Australia's 10th-largest source of both tourists and foreign students. Last year, Taiwan people made 97,400 visits to Australia for sightseeing, while more than 6,300 Taiwan students were studying there.
Sinclair, on his third visit to Taiwan, also hailed the island's capability in dealing with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , which hit Taiwan earlier this year.
Although SARS had a tremendous impact, Taiwan's ability to recover and the efficiency in its anti-SARS measures were also impressive, Sinclair said.
Sinclair added that next year will be the 20th anniversary of the ATBC's founding, and that he hopes that Taiwan's business leaders and government officials can attend the celebration in Canberra.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN TO ARRIVE OCT. 11 FOR WEEK-LONG VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Oct. 11 for a week-long visit.

This will be Shaheen's first visit to Taiwan since assuming the AIT post late last year to serve as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

In addition to inspecting the AIT operations in Taiwan, Shaheen will travel to the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien to meet with the respected Buddhist Master Cheng Yen who heads Taiwan's largest charity -- the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.

Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative to the United States, said Shaheen has a keen interest in the Tzu Chi operations as she was once involved in Indochinese and Afghan refugees relief work in the late 1970s and the early 1980s.

Shaheen was Asia regional director for the Tokyo-based Refugee International during that period. Her main missions were raising funds for refugees in the then-Soviet-occupied Afghanistan and for displaced Vietnamese and Cambodian people during border conflicts between their two countries. Her work also included helping improve living conditions in refugee camps in those countries as well as repatriation of refugees.

Shaheen was originally scheduled to visit Taipei in May of this year, but her travel plan was postponed to this month due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in Taiwan between March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 PROPOSED R&D CENTERS SHOW THAT WORST IS OVER FOR ECONOMY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the worst is passed for Taiwan's economy as evidenced by the fact that 30 world-class companies plan to open research and development (R&D) hubs in the country by 2006.

Chen made the remarks while taking part in a ceremony at the Presidential Office marking the publication of a new book picturing his journeys to 319 villages and townships across Taiwan over the past three years since he came to power in May 2000.

Saying that only actions will make dreams come true, Chen said that the hard days for Taiwan are already over, as the domestic economy has shown strong signs of recovery at a time when Taiwan is facing a historic juncture.

In view of the dramatically changing situations in the international community, Chen stressed that the government is determined to continue with reforms on all fronts to make Taiwan into a competitive country.

Citing the newest report made public in August by the Switzerland-based Business Environmental Risk Intelligence, he said Taiwan still was rated as one of the world's best countries in terms of investment climate - tied for fourth with Japan among the major 50 countries cited.

Chen said Sony and HP, two of the 24 foreign-based multinationals wishing to establish R&D centers in Taiwan, have been granted approval. He forecast that by 2006, an additional 30 international business groups will also open such facilities in the country, proof that the government's trade and monetary liberalization and market opening efforts have paid off.
He said he strongly believes that more world-class enterprises will be willing to invest in Taiwan after the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference slated for Oct. 19-22 in Taipei has been held.

Stressing that building Taiwan into a "green Silicon Valley" has long been his commitment to the people of Taiwan, who are deeply concerned about humanitarian values and environmental protection, he said Taiwan must become a progressive society and a full-fledged democracy in which human and cultural interests and physical infrastructure are paid equal attention.
The president also attended later the same day the inauguration of an exhibition hall inside the presidential building which features Taiwan's top international products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REAFFIRMS STANCE ON CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States have the same stance on maintaining stability across the Taiwan Strait and on pushing for an early resumption of cross-strait dialogues, a Presidential Office spokesman said Wednesday.

James Huang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, was refuting opposition parties' claim that President Chen Shui-bian's recent appeal to rewrite the ROC Constitution and to amend laws so that islandwide referendums can be held would undermine Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Huang said Chen had made it clear in a recent interview in Taipei with John Pomfret, Beijing bureau chief of the Washington Post, that the political reforms he wants to make would not touch on sensitive issues that might provoke mainland China.

Stressing that Chen's call to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan is mainly aimed at consolidating Taiwan's young democracy and upgrading its overall competitiveness, Huang said it was opposition parties' misinterpretation of Chen's appeal as moves to instigate ethnic disharmony and provoke mainland China that could adversely affect Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Huang said Chen had emphasized in his interview with the Washington Post that pushing for these democratic reforms has nothing to do with the issues of independence or unification. "So the things that America is concerned about won't happen."
Huang acknowledged that Washington has expressed concern about the proposed political reforms, but he denied that America is pressuring Taiwan to back away from the changes.
"Concern is not the same thing as pressure, " Huang said. "Being concerned doesn't mean that you're going to get involved in another nation's domestic affairs."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTS SWISS DESIGNATION CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has lodged a protest with Switzerland over an arbitrary change of Taiwan's designation on the Alien Resident Certificates it issues to Republic of China nationals living there, an official said Wednesday.

For the last month, the official said, the Swiss government has identified the nationality of ROC passport holders as "Chinese Taipei" on their residence certificates. Prior to that, the Swiss government identified the nationality of ROC citizens as "Taiwanese" in those documents.

"We have lodged protests with the Swiss government through our representative office in Bern and Switzerland's representative office in Taipei," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
According to the official, the Swiss authorities have responded to the ROC's protest by claiming that they were pressured by mainland China to change Taiwan's designation.
"We have informed the Swiss government that the arbitrary designation change is unacceptable, " the official said, adding that the MOFA is still negotiating the issue with the Swiss authorities.

Because of Beijing's pressure, Taiwan cannot join major international organizations under its official title of the Republic of China. For example, it is designated as "Chinese Taipei" in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and as the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" in the World Trade Organization.

However, reports from Geneva quoted Swiss officials as having said that the designation change was not adopted as a result of Beijing's pressure, nor has it had anything to do with Taiwan's recent issue of a new version of its passport bearing the word Taiwan on its cover to distinguish it from that of the People's Republic of China.

The unnamed Swiss officials claimed that the designation change is mainly an "internal administrative technical matter" aimed at differentiating Taiwan and mainland Chinese citizens residing in Switzerland, the reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND PANAMA TO STRENGTHEN COOPERATION ON OMBUDSMAN OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The president of Republic of China's Control Yuan, Fredrick Chien, and Panama's ombudsman, Juan Antonio Tejada, signed an agreement Wednesday on the ombudsman cooperation.

Tejada, who is on a six-day visit at the invitation of the Control Yuan, is an important figure in the International Ombudsman Institute and has spared no effort in supporting Taiwan's bid to enter world organizations.

Chien said the agreement between the ROC's Control Yuan and Panama's Office of the Ombudsman will help bilateral cooperation in ombudsman documents, information, technology, and training programs. He expressed the hope that the cooperation will strengthen the protection of civil rights and human rights in both countries.
Chien also decorated Tejada in recognition of his long-term support of Taiwan, and expressed hope that Tejada will continue rendering help to Taiwan in the world community.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER ADDRESSES OPENING OF ASIA-PACIFIC NGO FORUM

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Kau Ying-mao said Wednesday that Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) have played a key role in Taiwan's democratization.
Kao made the remarks at the opening of the two-day 2003 Asia-Pacific NGO Forum sponsored by the Foreign Ministry -- Taiwan's first-ever such gathering.

In a bid to further promote democracy and human rights in Taiwan, the Foreign Ministry and the Legislative Yuan jointly set up the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy to advocate and monitor the country's human rights development.

In addition, Kao said, the foundation will also conduct long-term impartial research on human rights both at home and abroad, and he invited the experts attending the forum to put forward research cooperation projects.

Among the foreign guests are Gordon Feller, an advisor to the World Bank and chief executive officer of Urban Age; Beth Rivin, a professor at University of Washington; and other experts from Hong Kong, South Korea and Indonesia.
They will discuss and exchange views on issues related to NGO cooperation and assistance mechanisms and the development of civic societies in the region.
Feller gave a keynote speech during the first day of the gathering, in which he put forward his viewpoint on self-sufficiency and professional management measures of NGOs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIES STRONG: DPP

TEXT.P: The deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that relations between Taipei and Washington are close and that the two countries have smooth channels of communication.

Lee Ying-yuan made the remarks after concern was raised about U.S-Taiwan ties following President Chen Shui-bian's unusually strong words toward the United States and mainland China pronounced in an interview with the Washington Post.

Chen said in the interview that he will not bow to U.S. pressure to modify recent moves -- including his proposal to hold a referendum on rewriting the constitution and the decision to add the name Taiwan to Republic of China passports -- which Bush administration officials fear will heighten tension with Beijing, according to Washington Post.

Referring to Chen's remarks, Lee noted that Taiwan and the United States pursue democracy and liberty and have long-term cordial relations. Both sides have common interests but it is normal that they sometimes have different views on some issues.
The channels of communication between Taiwan and the United States are smooth and both sides have many goals and ideas in common, Lee added.

Lee said there are no problems with Taiwan-U.S. ties. Noting that Taiwan's arms purchases are fully supported by the United States and that Chen will have a high-profile transit stay in the United States en route to and from Central America in the near future, Lee said these factors are evidence of the benign bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COFFEE FESTIVAL SCHEDULED TO BEGIN OCT. 10

TEXT.P: Taiwan Coffee Festival Day will be established Oct. 10 this year, making it an annual event to celebrate coffee production in Taiwan, officials from the Cultural Affairs Department under the Yunlin county government reported Wednesday.

In line with the establishment of Taiwan Coffee Festival Day, the Yunlin county government will also sponsor a coffee tasting event in Taipei, allowing 12 local coffee planters from Yunlin's Kukeng township to show off their produce in Taiwan's largest city, which boasts the biggest number of coffee drinkers in Taiwan.
According to the Yunlin officials, Kukeng township is where coffee was first planted in Taiwan at the beginning of the 20th Century, when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule.
Now the major coffee-producing area in Taiwan, Kukeng growers cultivate the arabica and robusta. Arabica dominates about 70 percent-80 percent of the world's coffee production, the officials said.
The Taiwan Coffee Festival Day will be marked at the Chienhushan Recreational World and the Tahuashan Area in Yunlin County Oct. 10-12 with a wide variety of activities, the officials noted.

The Japan Times: ASEAN signs historic pledge on democracy.
The Assocication of Southeast Asian Nations-which includes communist Vietnam and Laos, the sultanate of Brunei and army-ruled Myanmar-signed a historic pact Tuesday pledging support for democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED-MARRIAGE CHILDREN STRUGGLE TO ADAPT AT SCHOOL: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 2,000 mixed-marriage children have enrolled in elementary schools in Taipei and about 40 percent of them have a hard time adapting to school life, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The Education Department of the Taipei city government conducted the survey in mid-September.
The survey discovered that 2,199 schoolchildren from mixed-marriage families have enrolled into primary schools around the city, accounting for 1.14 percent of the total enrollment.
Most of them are from families with foreign parents and about 900 are from families with one or both parents from mainland China, according to the survey.

According to the results, 732 of these children have difficulty with their studies and 458 are struggling to adapt to campus life. As these two groups of students partially overlap, the total number of mixed-marriage children with adaptability problems is 838, or 38.11 percent of all the mixed-marriage schoolchildren studied.

Education Department officials said adaptability problems shown by mixed-marriage children include poor motivation or interest in study, reluctance to abide by etiquette and rules, difficulty speaking Mandarin Chinese, poor social skills, emotional instability, untidiness, inclination to lie or steal, and failure to get along with classmates of the opposite sex.
The problems mainly result from their parents' language barriers, disadvantageous economic status, cultural differences and a lack of parenthood education, the officials claimed.

Wu Ching-chi, director of the Education Department, said the city government will join forces with community colleges and adult education organizations to open language and parenthood classes for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens.
"The Education Department will also ask elementary school authorities to offer more counseling to help mixed-marriage children adapt to school life and academic study," Wu added.

According to the survey, Wenshan, Shihlin and Hsinyi top the various Taipei districts in terms of the number of mixed-marriage schoolchildren, while Chungshan and Neihu have the largest ratios of students with adaptability problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC AMBASSADOR TO VATICAN NAMED

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Eugene Chien confirmed Wednesday that Ambassador to the Vatican Raymond Tai has resigned and that Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Tou Chou-seng will succeed him.

Tou, 61, holds a doctoral degree in law from the University of Paris II. He has served in the ministry's departments of European Affairs, Treaty and Legal Affairs, Protocol, and North American Affairs. He was also the ambassador to Senegal before serving as vice foreign minister.

The 69-year-old Tai tendered his resignation shortly after first lady Wu Shu-chen concluded a visit to the Holy See in July, citing his age and a feeling that his mission was over as reasons. He remained adamant in his decision, despite repeated appeals for him to remain in his post.
The Vatican is the Republic of China's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: US$3.27 BILLION IN FOREIGN CAPITAL FUNNELED INTO TAIWAN IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: A total of US$3.247 billion in foreign capital was channeled into the Taiwan Stock Exchange in September, the second-highest level following the record monthly high of US$4.218 billion posted in August, an official of the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) reported Wednesday.

According to the SFC official, qualified foreign institutional investors (QFII) and non-QFII investors poured US$60.121 billion into Taiwan during the first nine months of this year -- US$51.465 billion by QFII and US$8.656 billion by non-QFII -- representing a growth of US$3.247 billion over the US$56.874 billion as of Aug. 31.
However, US$44 million in foreign capital was remitted during the first three days of October, bringing down the September total to US$60.077 billion, the official noted.

Since the QFII mechanism was adopted in 1991 to regulate foreign investment in the domestic securities and stock markets, foreign institutional investors had made a total of 2,539 investment applications -- including 732 first applications -- as of Oct. 2, when the QFII system was abolished.
Since non-QFII investment began in Taiwan in April 1996, a total of 6,078 such investment applications had been granted through Oct. 2.

According to statistics compiled by the SFC, net investment by QFII, NON-QFII and overseas investment funds in the Taiwan stock market totaled NT$435.7 billion from the beginning of this year until Oct. 2 -- the gap between NT$1.7026 trillion-worth of shares bought and NT$$1.2669 trillion-worth of stocks sold.

During the same period, all types of foreign investors purchased a total of NT$54.9 billion-worth of shares listed in the over-the-counter market and sold NT$41.1 billion-worth, leaving a net buy of NT$13.5 billion, according to SFC statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURKINA FASO ISSUES STAMPS TO MARK AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Burkina Faso will issue a set of postage stamps on the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day Friday to commemorate successful agricultural cooperation between the two countries, a Chunghwa Post Co. spokesman said Wednesday.

The state-owned postal firm will hold a ceremony at the Postal Museum in Taipei Oct. 10 to mark the issue of the commemorative stamps. The 10-stamp collection will be sold both in Burkina Faso and Taiwan. Each set will be sold for NT$180, the spokesman said.

The new stamps feature images of two major agricultural facilities in the West African state built with the assistance of the ROC technical mission stationed there -- the Bagre Farm and the Riziere de la vallee du Kou, the spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, ROC-Burkina Faso agricultural cooperation has been very successful. During the 2002 Earth Summit held in South Africa, a French news media report lauded the Bagre Farm as a model for sustainable agricultural development.
The 1,200-hectare Riziere de la vallee du Kou rice farm was completed in 1973 with the assistance of the Taiwan agricultural mission.

To help local people better understand Burkina Faso's culture and postal history, Chunghwa Post Co. will sponsor a three-day exhibition of Burkina Faso stamps at the Postal Museum starting Oct. 10. The company will open a service counter at the museum during the exhibition period to sell stamps issued by several of the ROC's diplomatic allies, including Burkina Faso, the Solomon Islands, Sao Tome and Principe, Nicaragua, and Paraguay.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL-VOLUNTEER MILITARY UNFEASIBLE BEFORE 2112: MND

TEXT.P: Taiwan is unlikely to adopt an all-volunteer military service system before 2112, according to an armed forces restructuring plan mapped out by the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, Tang said an all-volunteer military will be feasible only when smaller numbers of servicemen are required, the defense budget reaches certain levels and all the necessary advanced weaponry systems are acquired -- all of which have been forecast to be achieved by 2112 or later.

The issue of a voluntary military service system was made part of the conversation at the committee's meeting Wednesday in response to President Chen Shui-bian's recent moves to promote a new constitution for Taiwan, under which efforts will be made to facilitate an all-professional military to replace the current mandatory conscription system.

Legislators Chiang Chi-wen, Lin Yu-fang and Liao Wan-ju together asked Tang's opinion on the scenario of the MND not being able to recruit any young Taiwan men once the all-voluntary military system is adopted since, as they said, not a single soul in Taiwan wants to serve in the military.
Tang said it is an irreversible trend that the military is becoming "lean and mean, " with the number of men and women in uniform gradually decreasing and the forces increasingly becoming high-tech.
Meanwhile, Tang said that the ROC armed forces will be transformed into defense forces, with the combined services brigade as the main operational unit to cope with the nation's defense demands.

The transformation, which will be carried out in a gradual manner, is expected to be completed in 10 years, Tang said, adding that in the first four years, various existing military academies will be downsized and integrated. Several professional defense research institutes will then be set up in tandem with the nation's military buildup policy, he added.
From 2004 through 2006, the number of servicemen will be cut by 45,000, he said. In the second stage, he continued, the number of servicemen on active duty will be reduced to 270,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 34.88 points to close at 5,821.8.
The bourse opened at 5,860.4 and then fluctuated between 5,867.09 and 5,808.19 during trading.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, textile issues at 0.8 percent, and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 374 to 346, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya Alphonse Jamus Jebulai Jammeh arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a four-day state visit.
During his stay, Jammeh will attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, including a National Day rally and a dazzling fireworks show.
Before concluding his visit Oct. 11, Jammeh will sign a joint communique with President Chen Shui-bian reaffirming their commitment to further promoting relations between the two countries.

Chen will host a state dinner in honor of Jammeh Wednesday evening. On Thursday, Jammeh is scheduled to travel to Taoyuan, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei, to visit major construction projects there, including the Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s new facilities.
Jammeh will also meet with senior ROC officials during his visit to discuss measures to boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AND SOUTH KOREA TO LAUNCH FORMAL FREE TRADE TALKS SOON

TEXT.P: Singapore and South Korea are set to soon begin formal negotiations on a free trade agreement after wrapping up joint feasibility studies.
The two sides released a joint report on Tuesday calling for the freeing up of trade in goods and services, and of investment.
Singapore wants to become South Korea's gateway into Southeast Asia, while South Korea could be another base for Singaporean firms in their push into Northeast Asia.
Separately, South Korea is also seeking a free trade accord with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , of which Singapore is a member.
It hopes to join the likes of mainland China, India and Japan which have already started work on similar pacts with ASEAN.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 8, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULTS OF STUDY ON ORGANIZATION LEADERSHIP IN SINGAPORE RELEASED

TEXT.P: The first-ever statewide study of organizational leadership in Singapore found that the city-state's workforce rates its leaders highest in the areas of financial stewardship, integrity and respect for workers.

The first phase of the study, jointly sponsored by the Gallup Organization, the Singapore Institute of Management, and the Gallup Leadership Institute, looked at a series of attributes associated with leadership that have been used in validated indexes in Europe, the United States, Australia and New Zealand.

The first phase included findings from the general working population in Singapore. The second phase will involve establishing a representative sample of organizations from the public and private sector where employees from those organizations evaluate the leadership style of their immediate supervisor or the top leadership within their organization.

Dr. Bruce Avolio, director of the Gallup Leadership Institute, said "the results reflect some of the core strengths associated with Singapore's culture, including organizational financial strength, trust in the integrity of leadership, and treating individuals with respect."
The study also found that Singaporean corporate leaders scored appreciably lower on the key dimensions that drive workforce innovation, engagement and performance.

Specifically, Singaporean leaders were rated as less visionary than their U.S., Australian, New Zealand and European counterparts, as well as less optimistic, less willing to challenge old ways of doing things, less likely to sacrifice their self-interests, and less likely to pay attention to the moral and ethical consequences of their decisions.

Comparing across industries and government, government leaders were generally rated highest on all scales except in encouraging employees to be creative and entrepreneurial at work. Information-technology industry leaders received the highest ratings in this category.

The general pattern of findings in the first phase of the study indicated that leaders in Singaporean organizations could place more emphasis with their workers on the importance of learning new ways of doing their work, developing each other, being entrepreneurial, working creatively and encouraging more ownership of their jobs, especially in the manufacturing, service and business services industries.
More specific data focusing on the relationship between the leader and his or her workers is currently being collected in the second phase of the study.

Malaysia has failed in its bid to persuade an international court to order Singapore to suspend its reclamation works in Pulau Tekong and Tuas immediately. DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN APPEALS FOR MORE ASSISTANCE FOR MALAWI
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT) urged the people of Taiwan Thursday to provide more help for poverty-stricken children in Malawi, which is in the grip of a famine.
Chen Wei-chih, director of WVT's eastern office, said Malawi suffered serious inundations in 1992 and 1996, of which the famine is a result.

WVT launched a campaign in 1996 to help some 2,500 children in Malawi and in the last seven years, Taiwan people have helped construct schools and clinics for the people of Malawi, as well as offering agricultural equipment and training.
According to statistics compiled by the United Nations, 54 percent of Malawi's population lives in poverty.

Noting that the average life expectancy in Malawi is 40.7 and the mortality of its children under five is 18.8 percent, Chen urged the people of Taiwan to demonstrate their love and make generous donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM TO BE HELD OCT. 12

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy will hold a seminar on initiative and referendum Oct. 12 in Taipei, with the participation of prominent specialists in the initiative and referendum process from around the world.

Vice Foreign Minister Kau Ying-mao, who is also chief executive of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, said the foundation has invited five specialists in the initiative and referendum process, including Dane Waters, founder of the U.S. Initiative and Referendum Institute, Bruno Kaufmann, president of the Initiative and Referendum Institute Europe, and the Swiss parliamentarian Andreas Gross, to attend the seminar.
The experts will also have talks with officials of the Executive Yuan and various legislators.

The government is planning to conduct a referendum on or before the next presidential election slated for March 20, 2004, on several issues, including whether Taiwan should join the World Health Organization and on the fate of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.
After the seminar, the foundation will also invite former U.S. President Bill Clinton to visit Taiwan and will hold a seminar focused on Myanmar's opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC CORPORATE TRAVEL ALMOST FULLY RECOVERED POST-SARS

TEXT.P: The corporate travel trade has almost fully recovered in the Asia-Pacific region, according to an American Express post-SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) travel analysis for the region released recently.

Corporate Travel in SARS-impacted markets such as Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan took only three weeks to hit rock bottom, with trading down 90% as of the end of May. Nine weeks later, however, corporate travel trade had recovered almost fully to the previous year's levels, according to the analysis.

The analysis also reveals that corporate travel in non-SARS-impacted markets such as Australia, India and New Zealand dropped over a three week period to a trading low down 50% on 2002 but had almost recovered within five weeks, much faster than the SARS-impacted markets.

The negative impact of SARS was quick and deep, beginning in early April and peaking in late April. Recovery was slower with SARS-impacted markets recovering by mid-July and non-SARS-impacted markets recovering through late June. Both markets, however, had stabilized by late August at levels somewhat below those of 2002, it notes.
The travel activities of more than 800 corporations trading in the region were analyzed for the year-on-year, revenue passenger kilometers comparison.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNCIL SPEAKER KICKED OUT OF COUNCIL

TEXT.P: The disgraced speaker of the Kaohsiung city council has lost his membership of the council, retroactive to Sept. 25, when the Supreme Court convicted him of buying his way into the city legislature, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang said Thursday.

Liu said the Executive Yuan informed the Ministry of the Interior and the Kaohsiung city council Thursday that Chu is no longer a member of the council and will therefore not be able to chair the council.
The council can decide whether to pick a new speaker or have Vice Speaker Tsai Shung-hsiung act as speaker, said Liu.
Chu was found guilty of election-fixing in the city council election of Dec. 7, 2002, and was sentenced to an 18-month prison term.
He is also charged with bribing his colleagues in the council to elect him speaker on Dec. 25. That case is still pending in the Kaohsiung District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES LAW REVISIONS ON CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Thursday various controversial amendments to a key law governing exchanges between the people of Taiwan and mainland China, creating a new page in cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.

The long-disputed revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which cleared the legislature through a vote, include maintaining the eight-year waiting period for mainland spouses of Taiwan residents before they can receive ID cards, allowing recruitment by mainland-based colleges in Taiwan and the opening of direct cross-strait transport links.

Another critical amendment allowing the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to commission accredited and professional privately run organizations to handle civic exchanges between the two sides and permitting those MAC-commissioned private agencies to commission other institutional bodies to deal with related affairs was also approved.

In addition, all levels of local governments, public opinion organizations and institutional groups are prohibited from conducting negotiations or signing agreements in any shape or form with the mainland authorities on law-enforcement and political issues without having first obtained permission from the MAC or relevant government agencies, according to the revision.

One amendment allows Taiwan people to carry an amount of mainland currency -- to be set by the Ministry of Finance -- to and from the mainland, while another revision permits mainland-based companies to open branches or offices in Taiwan on a case-by-case basis, as long as they obtain permission to do so from the relevant Taiwan authorities.

In future, Taiwan people heading for the mainland will be treated at immigration in compliance with foreign-bound standard procedures without having to gain a travel permit from the government. However, government officials, the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung and public servants charged with secret state information are still banned from traveling across the strait.

The passage of the critical amendments after a year-long postponement because of sharp divisions among the various political parties are expected to facilitate two-way exchanges in trade, traffic and academic research and give a boost to a wide range of activities, according to observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL ELECTRONICS SHOW KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The five-day Taipei international electronics show -- TAITRONICS-Components and Equipment 2003 -- opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming, China External Trade Development Council Chairman Hsu Chih-jen and president of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association Hsu Sheng-hsiung jointly presided over the opening ceremony.
Yiin noted that 707 enterprises from nine countries are exhibiting the cream of their electronic components and equipment, offering a wide variety of options to buyers.
Hsu said that in the face of the fierce global competition, Taiwan electronics companies should keep on top of the rapidly changing industrial trends so that they can receive orders more easily.
Citing the field of notebook computers as an example, Hsu said most Taiwan manufacturers are trying to reach the goal of delivering ordered goods in two days.

He pointed out that the production volume of Taiwan's electronics components totaled NT$839.7 billion (US$24.91 billion) last year, with IC products and monitors the biggest sellers. Production is expected to reach NT$939.7 billion this year, an increase of 11.8 percent over last year.

Hsu said that in order to maintain high competitiveness, many domestic electronics manufacturers have shifted their production of low-level items overseas and are concentrating on research and development, marketing and high-end production at home.
In addition, Taiwan firms should also accelerate the establishment of logistic systems worldwide to sustain their competitiveness, Hsu said.

More than 12,000 buyers visited the exhibition last year, bringing orders worth US$2 billion for domestic firms. The organizer estimated that this year's exhibition will attract some 15,000 visitors, with estimated orders worth US$3 billion.
