DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES AMENDMENTS TO ELECTION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a package of amendments to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law Thursday that allows different political parties to field a joint ticket in the presidential election.

The amended law provides a legal basis for the teaming-up of the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year.

The revised law also raises the ceilings for campaign funding for various kinds of public elections. According to the new act, the campaign fund for next year's presidential election can reach a maximum of NT$400 million.
However, lawmakers rejected a proposal that would have barred citizens born outside of Taiwan from running for president or vice president.

The proposal had been dubbed "the Arnold clause" because it was similar to a U.S. ban on foreign-born citizens -- such as Austrian-born California Governor-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger -- running for president.

The measure was proposed by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which is worried that one of the growing number of immigrants from mainland China might one day become president and unify the island with its communist neighbor.
"Now that so many Chinese have entered Taiwan as immigrants, we have to draw up some clauses to protect the rights of the natives, " TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming said.
But opponents argued that the ban would be unfair. "People who have no way of choosing where their mothers gave birth would be politically isolated for a long time," said one PFP lawmaker.
Meanwhile, an "absentee vote" proposal broached by the opposition Kuomintang was also rejected by lawmakers.

It stipulates that parties will be slapped with a fine of between NT$5 million and NT$50 million if any of their candidates are convicted of vote-buying, use of violence in the campaign process, candidacy fixing, organized crime or other felonies subject to a minimum 10-year prison term.
The new regulation is aimed at pushing political parties to be more prudent in nominating their standard-bearers in public elections and thereby allowing the establishment of clean politics.
In addition to strengthening the mechanism to prevent those with links to organized crime from entering politics, the package also proposes penalties for vote-buying in intraparty primary elections.

Moreover, those involved in vote-buying in the elections of speakers and deputy speakers of legislative councils at central and local levels could be given prison terms ranging between three and 10 years plus fines ranging between NT$1 million and NT$10 million.
In addition, the package clearly forbids political parties or individuals from publishing, reporting or quoting the results of election public opinion polls within 10 days of a political election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE FISHING BOAT INTERCEPTED NEAR TIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: A fishing boat carrying people from mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan was intercepted by a Japanese Coast Guard patrol boat Thursday near the Senkaku Islands, known as the Tiaoyutais in Chinese, according to a Japanese Coast Guard officer in Naha, Okinawa.
The fishing boat carrying 15 people was spotted some 45 km west of the Tiaoyutais by the patrol boat and intercepted when it was some 22 km from the islands, the officer said.

The people aboard the fishing boat protested against the interception through loudspeakers, waved People's Republic of China flags and unfurled a banner claiming that the Tiaoyutais belong to China, said the officer.
One of the men on the fishing boat also used a video camera to film the confrontation, said the officer.
The boat managed to sail as close as one kilometer from the islands before being turned away by the patrol boat.

Meanwhile, a member of a Hong Kong group organized to press for China's claim over the Tiaoyutais said earlier in the day in Hong Kong that two members of his group, including David Chu Yu-lin, a member of the Hong Kong Legislative Council, joined six others from mainland China for the voyage to the Tiaoyutais on the fishing boat out of Xiamen, in mainland China's Fujian Province.

They were joined by two other protesters from Taiwan at sea off Taiwan Thursday and then tried to land on the islands and raise the flags of Taiwan and mainland China to underpin their countries' territorial claims to the islands.
They timed the landing to mark a similar action taken by members of the same group Oct. 7, 1996.

Located some 240 nautical miles southwest of Okinawa, the five tiny uninhabited islands with a combined size of 6.3 square kilometers, are claimed by Japan, mainland China and Taiwan. It rarely makes headlines except when extremists from the three countries make high-profile landfalls to highlight their country's territorial claims to the islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DEVELOPS PRECISION GUIDED MISSILES

TEXT.P: The military will focus on developing precision guided missiles, unmanned aircraft, superconductivity and nanotechnology, according to a five-year military buildup plan unveiled Thursday by the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

The MND outlined its five-year military buildup plan in a report delivered to the Legislative Yuan, as required by an amendment to the defense law that requires the ministry to present to the legislature a report on mainland China's military development and a report on Taiwan's five-year military buildup plan annually. The ministry presented its mainland military buildup report earlier this year.

According to the MND's five-year plan, the military will step up research and development of various types of guided missiles, anti-tank weapons and gunships, as well as unmanned aircraft and cutting-edge nanotechnology and superconductivity defense technology.
The report said the military will also strive to maintain supremacy in electronic warfare technology and to build up a comprehensive C4ISR architecture.
Another priority is the establishment of an anti-submarine combat command system and a coastal anti-submarine command center, the report said.
Quoting the MND report, opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang noted that the MND will need NT$1.59 trillion to finance its plan.

Meanwhile, unconfirmed press reports said that the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology -- the military's research arm -- is concentrating efforts on developing anti-ship and surface-to-surface missiles, including cruise missiles that can hit targets in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST RECTIFY ITS NAME: LEE TENG-HUI

TEXT.P: Taiwan must rectify its name because all the difficulties it has encountered are linked to its impractical name "the Republic of China", former ROC president Lee Teng-hui said in an article published Thursday in the Far Eastern Economic Review.
Taiwan must begin to correct its name, making the nation and its official name consistent with reality, Lee stressed in his article.
In early September, over 150,000 people gathered in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei to support a proposal for what is called the "rectification" of Taiwan's name, he continued.

"As I worked to advance the cause of freedom and democracy in Taiwan during my 12 years as president, I met with many difficulties and obstacles that brought me to the conclusion that Taiwan is not a 'normal country'," he noted.

A normal country's path towards development is influenced by its history and by its geography. People seek the most advantageous course by reflecting upon their past and considering where they are situated in the physical world.

But over the past two centuries, Taiwan has been ruled by external powers. Its goals and political system, in particular, have been imposed by outside regimes, without any influence by the people of Taiwan, without any heed of their views and needs. For a very long time, outside powers dictated the way life was lived by Taiwan's people.

Even now-three years after the democratic transfer of political power-we suffer from the debilitating effect of this historical burden. The people of Taiwan still are unable to muster the determination to be their own masters, to shoulder the responsibilities they alone ought to bear, to deliberate on the nation's future goals, to bravely face challenges and pursue ideals. This is a cause for regret, and it must be remedied.
While, admittedly, the establishment and progress of a nation cannot be shackled by history, it cannot completely dissociate itself from the past.

History cannot be changed, but the future is for us to define. How we define our identity is an exercise made against the backdrop of our antecedents. One reason Taiwan is not a normal country is because it has not been able to come to terms with its own history and to establish a Taiwan-centric frame of thinking. Creating a Taiwan-centred environment and realizing the ideals of a normal country are the goals towards which Taiwan should strive.
Lee said that he recently claimned "The Republic of China no longer exists" based on three reasons:
First, when the Republic of China was established in 1912, it by no means encompassed Taiwan;

Next, after World War II, the Republic of China was a military occupier of Taiwan, and Taiwan's actual status ought to be deemed a land belonging to no country, whose international status has yet to be defined-not as a part of the Republic of China's already-existing territory;

Lastly, after 1949-when Chinese communists took the mainland territory of the Republic of China-the Republic of China in fact no longer possessed any territory, with only its name continuing to exist. Although the name "Republic of China" was hung on Taiwan, ever since the People's Republic of China supplanted the Republic of China in the United Nations in 1971, the Republic of China vanished from the international community. People should realize that the "Republic of China" is just an official name, not a nation.

Through democratization, Taiwan has finally established a native, Taiwan-rooted democratic regime. Such a native government ought to plan for the well-being of all Taiwan's inhabitants, serve the people and work hard to act on the public's demand for rectification of Taiwan's name.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CONSIDERING STIFF PUNISHMENT FOR DRUNKEN PILOTS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) admitted Thursday that the captain of a China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane was over the alcohol limit while on duty and said the CAA is considering a stiff punishment for the man.

The captain was prohibited from boarding an Anchorage-to-New York flight after a screener at Anchorage airport smelled alcohol and found an open container of alcohol on the pilot's person, whereupon he was breathalyzed, according to wire reports.
CAA officials said they had questioned the breath test and had contacted U.S. Federal Aviation Administration for a renewed investigation.
The officials said that when Anchorage officials tested the pilot, he was found to have a blood-alcohol level of.087 percent, almost double the FAA's permitted level for pilots of .04 percent.

However, the Taiwan authorities originally had doubts about the calculation of the figures because in Taiwan, the limit for a breath test is 0.2 milligrams per liter. They had asked therefore for a re-investigation, which confirmed that the pilot was at fault, the officials said.

The officials said that although the pilot attempted to defend himself by claiming that he had refrained from drinking alcohol 12 hours prior to going on duty, the result of the breath test showed that he was over the limit, which is a serious problem of professional ethics that is subject to punishment ranging from a fine of just NT$60,000 (US$1,775) to revocation of the pilot's license.

CAL officials said that they had yet to receive a formal report, and declined to comment on the matter, although they stressed that the pilot, who has been suspended from duty, will be punished severely if he is found to have breached flight rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DONATES FIRE TRUCKS TO ASUNCION

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government on Thursday donated two recommissioned fire trucks and one pumper with an aerial ladder to the mayor of its sister city, Asuncion, in Paraguay.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hosted a luncheon for Asuncion Mayor Enrique Riera Escudero and his wife, who came to Taiwan to take part in the celebration activities of the National Day of the Republic of China on Oct. 10. Afterwards, the Taipei mayor donated the vehicles to his counterpart on behalf of the city government and its residents.

Mayor Ma first greeted his guests in Spanish, and said that though the fire trucks have been in service for 15 or 16 years, they are in good condition after maintenance and he believes the trucks will be very useful to Asuncion.
Mayor Riera expressed his appreciation for the goodwill of Taipei city and its people, saying that this was his first time to visit Taiwan and was quite impressed.
Ma and Riera later signed a joint statement, opening a new page of cooperation between the Taipei Zoo and the Asuncion Zoo.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN SOLAR ENERGY EXPERT HOPES FOR ENHANCED EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A visiting German solar energy expert hailed Taiwan Thursday as a springboard for enhanced exchanges and cooperation between Germany and Asia in the development of alternative energy sources.

Dr. Uwe Hartmann, chief executive officer (CEO) of the Institute for Elektroniske Systemer (IES) and a professor at the University of Sarrbruecken, said he hopes to meet Taiwan business representatives from the opto-electronic industry and visit related research and education establishments in an effort to forge technology and research cooperation agreements.

Hartmann said he hopes to gain a full understanding of Taiwan's development in the solar energy field and he voiced his hope that Taiwan can serve as a springboard in Asia for Germany to conduct technology and cooperation exchanges with countries in the region.

The issue of how Taiwan explores, develops and exploits alternative energy sources will be a key element in the government's efforts to build the country into a "green Silicon Valley" free from nuclear power. Germany has been promoting solar energy since the 1970s and has rich experience from which Taiwan can learn.
At the invitation of the Ministry of Education, Hartmann arrived in Taipei earlier the same day for a six-day visit. The trip is his first to an Asian country in his capacity as IES CEO.

While here, Hartmann will visit and give speeches at the Sustainable Development Committee under the Executive Yuan, science-based industrial parks and various natural science museums and academic establishments around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKERS, FAMOUS BRAND OWNERS TO TEAM UP IN ALLIANCES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 8 (CNA) (by Y. Chiang and EH)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council will introduce owners of world-renowned brand names to outstanding Taiwan manufacturers for business alliances under its international brand alliance program.

Tsai Wen-kai, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in San Francisco, said Wednesday that the program is aimed at promoting the cooperation between Taiwan manufacturers and foreign brand owners in developing the world market through brand authorization and through good use of their distribution channels.
He urged all those American brand owners who are interested in the program to contact his office in San Francisco.

The Kinloch Anderson Company of the United Kingdom and a hat producer in Taiwan were scheduled to enter into an agreement, under which the Taiwan company would be authorized to use the brand names of the British company, he said.

The figure represents an expansion of 3.2 percent over the August level and a 48.3 percent increase as compared to the year-earlier level, the TSMC official said, attributing the rise to greater demand last month from foreign buyers.

Business revenues of the world's largest and most successful dedicated independent semiconductor foundry during the first nine months totaled NT$144.1 billion (US$4.28 billion), up by 20.3 percent over the level posted for the same period of a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TESTS FOR BOTULISM PATHOGEN AT BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL HABITAT CONTINUE

TEXT.P: Testing in the black-faced spoonbill's habitat in southern Taiwan has revealed the presence of the botulism pathogen in two out of the 16 sites tested, the Tainan County Livestock Disease Control Center said Thursday.

Following the death of 71 of the rare birds last year due to food poisoning, the center began testing this June in the bird's main habitat -- the Chiku wetlands at the mouth of Tsenwen River in Tainan County -- for traces of the botulism pathogen.
The center chose 10 sites at which to conduct tests every month between June and August. Four of the black-faced spoonbill feeding sites tested positive for the presence of the botulism pathogen.

In September, the center increased the number of testing sites to 16. Among them, two tested positive, but the sites were near the original four sites where the botulism pathogen was found to be present.

The officials said that after a site tests positive, the center's countermeasures are usually to clear away the dead fish, shells and shrimp in the area and turn the soil in order to let the sun kill off the botulism pathogen.

Each year, a large proportion of the world's remaining black-faced spoonbills migrate from the Korean Peninsula and northeastern mainland China to the Chiku wetlands to spend the winter. Last year's mass die-off, despite strenuous efforts to save the birds, was the first of its kind in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF CROSS-STRAIT MARRIAGES REACHES 190,000

TEXT.P: The number of cross-Taiwan Strait marriages had reached 190,000 as of Oct. 8, according to tallies released by the Immigration Bureau Thursday.

Among these cross-strait couples, 171,582 mainland Chinese spouses of Republic of China citizens had applied to visit Taiwan. Of the applicants, 95,338 have been allowed to come to Taiwan for brief visits; 13,149 have obtained residence permits; and 10,063 have secured ROC citizenship.

Meanwhile, the bureau received 2,963 applications between January 1992 and September 2003 for mainland Chinese spouses' next of kin to come to Taiwan for family reunions. Among these, 1,579 applications were approved, 782 were rejected, while the remaining 602 are still awaiting approval based on quotas.

To stave off an influx of mainland Chinese immigrants through marriages of convenience, the National Police Administration (NPA) implemented on Sept. 1 of this year a personal interview system for incoming mainland Chinese spouses.

As of Wednesday, 903 mainland Chinese spouses had been interviewed either at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- the main gateway to Taiwan -- or on the ROC-held frontline island of Kinmen which lies closer to mainland China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan.
Thirteen of these, including 11 women and two men, were determined to be in bogus marriages with ROC citizens and were immediately repatriated, an NPA official said.
Moreover, the official said, 10 other mainland Chinese spouses were determined, following a second round of interviewing after their entry into Taiwan, to be in bogus marriages with ROC citizens.
"We have invalidated their entry permits and ordered them to leave the island within 10 days," he added.
In the first nine months of this year, police authorities checked into 1,079 cross-strait marriages and determined that 52 of them were bogus.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

The bourse opened at 5,817.72 and then fluctuated between 5,872.98 and 5,800.82 during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA FINDS SIGNIFICANT PERCENTAGE OF CR0SS-STRAIT MARRIAGES ARE BOGUS

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) reported Thursday that a significant percentage of marriages between mainland Chinese citizens and Taiwan residents have been discovered to be bogus.

NPA officials said that since they implemented on Sept. 1 the new measure of conducting interviews with mainland Chinese coming to Taiwan to visit their spouses, 903 spouses had been interviewed as of Oct. 8, with 2.5 percent of the marriages having been found to be bogus.

The officials said 13 of the mainland spouses were determined to be in bogus marriages with Taiwan citizens during the interviews conducted at CKS International Airport or on the outlying island of Kinmen, adding that the 13 were immediately repatriated.

The officials have also conducted interviews with mainland spouses already in Taiwan, concluding that 10 were in bogus marriages. Their entry visas were revoked immediately, and they were allowed 10 days to leave the island.

The officials said that there are 190,000 Taiwan-mainland Chinese married couples to date and that the number of mainland spouses who have applied to come to Taiwan for visits and reunion has reached 95,338. Among them, 13,149 have obtained resident status, and 10,063 have received citizenship.
Meanwhile, legislators of the tiny opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) visited the NPA's Bureau of Immigration to observe the interviewing process.

Noting that there are only six immigration officials charged with conducting the interviews, TSU Legislator Lo Jhih-ming urged the government to establish an immigration agency with 500 staff and proceed with full-scale interviews of all mainland Chinese spouses in Taiwan. TSU Legislator Chien Lin Hue-jyun also urged Taiwan women not to get into bogus marriages with mainland Chinese men to help them come to Taiwan to work legally, saying this is having a harmful effect on Taiwan's system. She called for the women to think over their actions and exercise self-restraint.

Chien Lin further added that there have been many cases of citizens from mainland China or other countries divorcing their Taiwan spouses upon obtaining their Taiwan IDs and then finding another spouse to bring to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 5,000 OVERSEAS CHINESE TO VISIT TAINAN, KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Some 5,000 overseas Chinese, who are visiting Taiwan for celebration of the Double-Tenth National Day of the Republic of China, will visit Tainan and Kaohsiung next week.
An official of the Tainan County Government said Thursday that, under the sponsorship of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, they will arrive in Tainan on Tuesday.

They will spend the whole day in visiting the Wushantou Reservoir and Choumalai Farm, where they will see several places of scenic beauty and enjoy a variety of traditional Chinese songs, dancing, drum-beating and other performing arts.
From Tainan, they will proceed to Kaohsiung for sightseeing and visiting economic and cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 48.08 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving up 48.08 points to close at 5,869.88.
Market turnover amounted to NT$115.6 billion (US$2.43 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS-TAIWAN WORKSHOP ON NANO SCIENCE TO OPEN SUNDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 8 (CNA) (by N. Lu an EH)

TEXT.P: Some 30 scientists from Switzerland and Taiwan will participate in a workshop on challenges and advanced method in nano science Sunday at Zermatt, Switzerland.

Jointly sponsored by the Academia Sinica in Taipei and a Swiss university, the workshop is expected to help promote cooperation in scientific researches between the two countries. One Singaporean and one South Korean scientist will also take part in the workshop.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIAN PRESIDENT INVITES CPC HEAD TO VISIT HIS COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Visiting Gambian President Yahya Jammeh on Thursday invited Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai to lead a delegation to visit his country to explore cooperation possibilities.

Noting that Gambia is rich in oil, Jammeh expressed the hope that the CPC can use its expertise to assist in relocating or building oil tanks for the West African country. If possible, both countries could also cooperate in building refineries, he added.

Kuo said that the CPC is now seeking opportunities to cooperate with other countries to prospect for oil. Noting that the CPC has excellent and experienced technical talent, he said his company and Gambia could cooperate in oil exploration.
Kuo also said that his older brother once worked as part of a Taiwan agricultural mission to Africa to provide technical assistance and that his brother told him about his life in Africa.
Jammeh expressed a great interest in Kuo's words and invited him to lead a delegation to visit his country at the end of this month.
The Gambian president, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a four-day visit, later traveled to Taoyuan, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei, to visit a CPC plant there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 9, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HOSTS NATIONAL DAY RECEPTION FOR FOREIGN DIGNITIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Eugene Chien and his wife jointly hosted a National Day reception Friday night for a group of foreign dignities who were either visiting Taiwan or are posted in the country.

Speaking at the reception, the minister touted the long way his country has come in combating the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome, boosting the economy and cementing friendships with other countries.

Notable among the country's diplomatic achievements were a summit in Taipei with its allies in central America and the Caribbean on August 21 and a free trade agreement with Panama concluded on that day, Chien said.
Although the country is recognized by only 27 countries, Taiwan has gone out its way to aid other countries, and is forming a foundation to campaign for democracy around the world, said Chien.
The minister thanked the dignitaries for their support in bids for entrance to the World Health Organization.
Government leaders from President Chen Shui-bian on down as well as visiting Gambia President Yahya Jammeh and Malawi President Bakili Muluzi were among the foreign dignities.

Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi compromised with his Liberal Democratic Party on Thursday a- nd agreed to leave the timing of the privatizat- ion of the nation's postal services ambiguous in the party's campaign policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI FIRST LADY THANKS TAIWAN FUND FOR AIDE TO CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Malawi first lady Shanil Muluzi thanked the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (CCF Taiwan) Friday for the assistance it has extended to needy children in her country.
Muluzi spoke when visiting CCF Taiwan's offices. She said she is trying to learn of the experiences of CCF Taiwan for reference in operating similar organizations in her country.

Muluzi, who is accompanying her husband -- Malawi President Bakili Muluzi -- on a visit to Taiwan, said that many children in southern Africa have contracted AIDS and urgently need international assistance in education and medical services.

CCF Taiwan has sponsored 100 AIDS-infected Malawi children, donated cash and 30,000 pieces of clothing since February 2001 when Shanil Muluzi was soliciting international help for needy Malawi children.

CCF Taiwan started to sponsor needy foreign children in cooperation with the Network of Christian Children's Fund since July 1987. It now sponsors more than 17,000 needy children in 26 developing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE ACROSS WORLD MARK ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese living around the world got together in their host countries Friday to celebrate the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
More than 1,000 overseas Chinese from the San Francisco Bay Area celebrated the ROC national day at the San Francis Hotel with a traditional lion dance.

In line with the government's efforts to promote Taiwan after the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier in the year, huge cloth banners printed with Taiwan landscapes were hung at the entrance of the hotel, coupled with films showing Taiwan's everyday street and country life.

Lee Shih-ming, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, addressed the occasion. He said Taiwan has overcome many difficulties following the outbreaks of SARS with assistance from Taiwan people both at home and abroad.

Despite the problems, the government has been relentless in promoting national development by encouraging foreign investors and tourists to come to Taiwan. He said Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 3.2 percent this year, while outbound shipments in August increased by 12.98 percent from the same month last year.
Lee urged Taiwan people living in the United States to make trips back to Taiwan to gain a better understanding of their homeland.
In addition to House representatives from California, governors of Utah and Nevada also sent envoys to take part in the celebrations.
Meanwhile, ROC Ambassador Raymond Tai hosted a banquet in the Vatican on Double Ten Day, attracting more than 200 guests from the Vatican government and the Chinese community.
During the two-hour feast, a Taiwan folk dance was performed by a women's group from Panchiao City of Taipei County, while posters featuring landscapes of the offshore Penghu Island were given away.

In Madrid, over 300 figures from the local political, cultural, media and law enforcement, as well as envoys of the ROC's diplomatic partners based in Spain and Chinese community leaders participated in a Double Ten Day banquet held at a downtown hotel.
The foreign dignities were received by two Taiwan female students dressed up in ancient Chinese dress, adding an exotic flavor to the party.

Sun Shi-chung, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Prague, sponsored an ROC national day celebration at a famous hotel in the Czech capital, in which nearly 500 Czech and Taiwan guests took part, among them a group of pro-Taiwan Czech parliamentarians, Czech government officials and foreign envoys.

Addressing the party, Sun said Taiwan, under the capable leadership of President Chen Shui-bian, overcame the impact of SARS and continued moving toward becoming a full democracy and a knowledge-based economy.
Despite long distances and cultural differences between the two countries, Sun called for closer ties between the two countries based on their common aspiration for human rights, peace and democracy.
Newsletters and leaflets in English and Czech about Taiwan's politics, culture and lifestyle were given away at the event.
At the same time, similar activities were also held prominently by overseas Chinese in Bangkok, Yokohama, Singapore and Buenos Aires to observe the birthday of their mother country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PETROLEUM DENIES REPORT IT WILL BECOME TAIWAN PETROLEUM CORP

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) denied a newspaper report Friday that said the 67-year-old company was considering changing its name to Taiwan Petroleum Corp.
CPC officials said that the company has "so far no intention to change its name, and the media report is purely speculation."

The officials were referring to a report in the mass circulation China Times Friday that pointed out that the name Chinese Petroleum is currently being used by a mainland Chinese petroleum and natural gas group.
The report said that the CPC was considering changing its name to avoid conflict and confusion with the company in the mainland.

In addition, it noted that Vice President Annette Lu openly expressed the hope that all state-owned enterprises that contain the word China would change their names as soon as possible, so that it is very likely that the CPC will change its name, the reports added.
CPC officials said that since the founding of the company in 1936, it has continued to develop and its operations now span the globe. It has also become one of the top 500 companies in the world.
"The reputation and the credit the company enjoys in the world have been built through long-term strenuous efforts, and the company will not change its name overnight," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOOR TO CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION, PEACE ALWAYS OPEN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the door to cooperation and peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is always open.
Chen made the remarks in an address delivered at a rally at the Presidential Office plaza marking the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day.
With a view to opening the door to cross-strait cooperation, Chen said mainland China should put aside its "one China" and "one country, two systems" political conditions.
And in order to achieve cross-strait peace, Chen said, mainland China should renounce its threat to resort to the use of force and halt its strategic attempts to isolate Taiwan from the world.

Chen said his administration has consistently adopted a firm and pragmatic manner in promoting cross-strait relations. Even though mainland China has not made an immediate goodwill response to his three-phase plan for opening direct cross-strait transportation links, Chen said he is convinced that trade and economic relations between the two sides will enter a new stage after the next presidential election in March 2004.
As a national leader, Chen said, he must defend national sovereignty, security and dignity as well as sustain Taiwan's development.

"The people of Taiwan must have confidence in their own strength and their motherland, " Chen said, adding that only those who lack self-confidence would compromise or even surrender to the other side's barbaric demand to accept the "one China" principle as a precondition for resumption of cross-strait dialogue. Beijing's "one China" principle downgrades Taiwan to the status of a province under mainland China's jurisdiction.

Noting that Taiwan has managed to play an active role in the international community not only because of its economic strength but also due to its democratic reforms, Chen dismissed the claims by some local politicians that Taiwan could have "greater room" on the international stage should it accept the "one China" principle.

As a matter of fact, Chen said, Taiwan would lose its qualifications to join any international organization and would have no place in global society should it give up its sovereign status and democratic political system.
Chen said Taiwan has endured many setbacks in its pursuit of freedom, democracy and prosperity and may face even more daunting challenges in the future.
Nevertheless, Chen said he firmly believes that freedom and democracy will prevail and that the people of Taiwan will enjoy lasting peace and prosperity.
While celebrating the ROC's birthday, Chen said he most wants to appeal for "faith in democracy, faith in reform and faith in Taiwan."

Chen further said signs of domestic economic recovery have become ever more evident and stronger. Quoting concrete economic indicators and evaluations by noted international market research firms, Chen said the worst of the economic recession is over and that local people will be able to experience the results of economic recovery in the near future.

Chen's speech kicked off the ROC's National Day celebrations in front of the Presidential Office that included soldiers in shiny chrome helmets, high school marching bands and dancers from the African allies of Gambia and Malawi.

Over 80,000 people attended the Double Ten Day rally, including the presidents of Gambia and Malawi, other foreign dignitaries, overseas Chinese community leaders and representatives from all walks of life.
The celebrations will continue in the evening with a "Faith in Taiwan" party featuring multimedia and rock music performances, a reception for foreign dignitaries and a dazzling fireworks display.

Last year General Motors Corp. set out to update its electronic company phone book, so that with a few keystrokes its engineers in, say, Taiwan could look up colleagues in Germany. But an unanticipated problem came in the way: Europe's strict privacy laws. While the U.S. has opposed comprehensive regulations to protect citizens' privacy, Europe has plowed ahead with the world's toughest set of rules governing how companies and governments may deal with personal data, such as one's age, marital status, buying patterns -- even the information on a standard business card. And as GM's experience shows, those rules are increasingly shaping the way businesses operate around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: HON HAI SEPTEMBER REVENUE HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd., the largest company in Taiwan's manufacturing sector, posted a historic high of NT$36.585 billion (US$1.085 billion) in its monthly business revenue in September, a 9 percent growth from its August level of NT$33.567 billion.

The figure helps Hon Hai maintain its leading position in the private manufacturing sector, leaving behind other companies such as Quanta Computer in second spot with NT$30.7 billion and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. in third with NT$18.911 billion.

Hon Hai's business revenue totaled NT$220.073 billion for the first nine months of this year, up by 33.9 percent from the year-earlier level of NT$164.404 billion, thanks to the company's fast response to a global economic recovery, which led to stronger demand for motherboards and components for mobile phones and video games.
For the third quarter alone, Hon Hai also posted a record quarterly high of NT$98.19 billion, up by 60 percent from the second quarter's NT$61.32 billion.

Industry sources forecast that Hon Hai's business revenue for the fourth quarter is expected to top NT$100 billion and reach NT$$320 billion for the whole of the year, making it Taiwan's first privately run manufacturing company to register annual business revenue of more than NT$300 billion.
Stock market analysts said the Hon Hai's EPS (earning per share) may top NT$9 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PUSHES FOR WRITING OF NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made clear in his National Day message Friday his determination to push for a new constitution for Taiwan and solicited support and concerted efforts from all walks of life to achieve this goal.

Addressing a Double Ten National Day ceremony held at the Presidential Office and attended by all major members of the administration and legislative branches, Chen said that as the tenth-term president of the Republic of China, he has a responsibility to history.

"I have an obligation to confront the important issue of constitutional reform and unite our nation's 23 million people in hastening the birth of a new constitution, so as to make Taiwan a normal, full-fledged and great democracy," Chen said.

"For constitutional reform to succeed, we must have the integrated will of the people, a consensus among political parties, and the participation of constitutional experts, " he said, adding that all three factors are indispensable.
He said his government shall not repeat the mistakes of past administrations by allowing a single political party to dominate the constitution amendment process.
"In the end, the new constitution must be submitted as a national referendum for the people of Taiwan to decide," he stressed.

"I firmly believe that so long as we are unswerving in our resolve to implement democratic reforms, and have confidence in the people of Taiwan, the history of the 21st Century will show that our future constitutional reforms will have been yet another major triumph for Taiwan's democracy," Chen said.

In his speech, titled "Faith in Democracy, Faith in Reform and Faith in Taiwan, " Chen said that Taiwan in the new century is now stepping across one invisible threshold after another. With the passing of each arduous test, he said, Taiwan moves closer to the final door of hope that leads to democracy, freedom, progress and prosperity.
"We have faith in Taiwan, because we have faith in the 23 million people of Taiwan, because we have faith in democracy and faith in reform," he said.

"The power of a single person may not be able to change fate, but the collective strength of all can necessarily rewrite history. So long as every one of us has faith, I know we can do it, " he continued.

Chen said that if economic revitalization and comprehensive reform -- two top priorities of the Administration that he proposed at the beginning of this year -- are "the two sets of wheels propelling Taiwan forward, then the re-engineering of Taiwan's constitutional system is undoubtedly the body of the vehicle."

Over the past few years, he said, the ruling and opposition parties and the general public have repeatedly pointed out that the current constitutional framework and the government system it mandates are insufficient to meet Taiwan's practical needs. He pointed out that past constitutional amendments were restricted by special circumstances of time and environment, and were only able to address specific issues through partial adjustments. Not only was it impossible to realize a complete plan for a constitutional government, but even more so, they left many problems unresolved, thus seriously undermining the quality of Taiwan's democracy and the efficiency of the government, he added.

He said the goal of initiating economic revitalization and comprehensive reform is to change Taiwan for the better and hence provide better lives for the people. "Democratic reforms are like the branches and trunk of a tree, while the leaves are the economy. We must have both if Taiwan is to grow stout of limb and full of foliage, and have prosperity and a better life for our people, " he said.

"From the perspective of economic revitalization, " he went on, "the country has already seen a gradual series of exciting achievements thanks to the concerted efforts of the government and the people."

"Since the beginning of this year," he continued, "both the stock and real estate markets have grown steadily. Consumer spending grows stronger by the day, while recent economic indicators have shown `green light' growth for Taiwan's economy for two consecutive months, and experts predict that the indicator will continue to show a green light or better for the next half-year," he said.

"Furthermore, Taiwan set two new records in terms of value for overseas orders in July and August. All of these signs indicate that Taiwan's economic recovery is gaining strength and momentum, " he said, adding that in August of this year, "overseas investment in Taiwan reached US$350 million, a new 10-month high, and many international investment and evaluation institutions have also recognized Taiwan's efforts and are optimistic about Taiwan's potential.

Rejuvenation of Taiwan's economy and international acclaim are not mere coincidence. Rather, they are the achievements of the coordinated and unheralded efforts of the government and people, " he noted.

"The government has worked hard to promote financial reforms and deregulation, so as to further liberalize the economy, improve the transparency of industry, and lower structural risks of industrial operations, " he said, adding that "the goal is to strengthen the infrastructure for economic development and create conditions conducive to sustainable development in Taiwan.
From the perspective of structural reforms, the deepening of democracy is naturally the most important of the basic pursuits," the president said.

Over the past three years, he said, outstanding achievements have been made in the establishment of truly nationalized armed forces, the institutionalization of intelligence work, the protection of fundamental human rights, the eradication of "black gold" politics, and many other areas. "We firmly believe that the only way to ensure an enhanced foundation for democracy is to completely sever the intricate ties that sustain "black gold" politics, he pointed out.

The president said that "the people have long pinned their highest hopes on major reforms in areas such as education, the judiciary, politics, finance and the media. These arena have now been freed from the old fetters and constraints imposed by political parties. The latitude of freedom and room for public discussion that reforms ought to have has been restored.

The government has proposed policies and launched actions in response to public demands. We are confident that so long as political parties can set aside selfish interests, accommodate the diversity of public opinion and remain committed to democracy and reform, then we can find the ideal path for carrying out all reforms," Chen vowed.

"I would like to re-emphasize that economic revitalization and comprehensive reform represent two sides of the same coin. Only steady and continuing implementation of reforms can sweep away the accumulated ills of the past and allow us to quickly and effectively promote the transformation and upgrade of Taiwan's political and economic environment," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RECEIVES FOREIGN GUESTS ON NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu received 265 foreign guests and accepted their congratulations on the Republic of China's National Day Thursday at the Presidential Office.

The well-wishers included 65 members of congratulatory missions, 33 members of the diplomatic corps in Taipei, 67 representatives of other foreign missions in Taipei, 59 parliamentarians from various countries, and 35 foreign journalists invited by the Government Information Office.
Among them were President Alhaji Yahya Jammeh of Gambia, President Bakili Muluzi of Malawi, and Douglas H. Paal, Taipei Office Chief of the American Institute in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOUBLE TEN DAY CELEBRATIONS HELD IN NEW YORK AND WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By James Kuo, S.C. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C. hosted a National Day party Thursday night, bringing a series of Double Ten Day celebrations in the U.S. capital to a climax.

The National Day party was presided over by Chen Chien-jen, the ROC's representative to the United States, and his wife. Nearly 3,000 people, including U.S. officials, the ambassadors of the ROC's diplomatic allies in the United States, as well as overseas Chinese took part in the National Day Party.
Eighteen U.S. members of Congress issued statements or felicitations to honor the ROC's National Day, with several others phoning Chen Chien-jen to express congratulations.

Celebrations for the Double Ten Day kicked off in the U.S. capital last week with a flag-raising ceremony held in Chinatown on Oct. 5. Four Taiwanese students who are currently studying at a military academy in Virginia were invited to raise the ROC and U.S. national flags during the ceremony.
After the flag-raising ceremony, there was a colorful parade of flags, a Kung fu performance, dragon dancing, Asian song and dance performances, as well as fireworks.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York also held a National Day party in Manhattan Thursday night, with nearly 1,000 guests participating, including the representatives of the ROC's diplomatic allies stationed at the United Nations.
Four New York City council members also read a declaration offering felicitations for the ROC's National Day.

Andrew Hsia, the TECO's New York director, in addressing the party, urged the international community to shed its "ostrich mentality" and address the fact that the ROC is an independent sovereign state so as to give it reasonable representation on the world stage.
Hsia also stressed that Taiwan-U.S. relations are in their best shape since 1979 when the two nations severed diplomatic ties.

He noted that President Chen will make a transit stop in New York and accept an award from the International Human Rights Alliance on his way to visit Panama later this month, highlighting the friendship between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE LEADERS CELEBRATE ROC NATIONAL DAY IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 10 (CNA) (by Stanley Cheung and EH)

TEXT.P: Some 300 overseas Chinese leaders and guests celebrated the Double-Tenth National Day of the Republic of China Thursday at a Dr. Sun Yat-sen memorial house in Hong Kong.

The Republic of China was established in 1911 under the leadership of Dr. Sun, who lived in that house around that time. To pay homage to him, overseas Chinese leaders celebrate the national day in that house on Oct. 10 every year.
Among the guests participating in the celebration was Chang Liang-jen, general manager of Chung Hwa Travel Service, which represents Taiwan's interests in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 10, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announced on Sept. 28 that Oct. 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chungkuo Kuomintang (KMT), also known as the Nationalist Party.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extra-territoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC air force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by U.S. President Richard Nixon to be vice president, resigns before appearing at a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.
1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the ROC armed forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries joining in the celebration.
1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniversary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F-5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.
1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urges his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.
2001: A Republic of China Double Ten National Day parade is held at Yokohama's Chinatown, with more than 300 pro-Republic of China overseas Chinese residents and friendly Japanese people participating.
2001: Steven Newman, the Guinness world record holder for the most number of countries traversed on foot completes his 27th conquest when he arrives at the southern-most tip of Taiwan.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says in his National Day message that the ROC government has not only strongly condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man never upholds a man because of what he says, nor does he discard what a man says because of the speaker's character."

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER UNIONIZED WORKERS IN SINGAPORE LAID OFF IN THIRD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Relatively fewer workers in unionized companies in Singapore were laid off in the third quarter of this year compared to the second quarter.
This fact and the positive gross domestic product (GDP) growth seen in the third quarter seem to signal that the economy has bottomed out, the National Trades Union Congress has said.
The Ministry of Trade and Industry has said flash estimates show GDP for the third quarter increasing by one percent over the year-earlier figure.
This marks a sharp rebound from the previous quarter, when GDP contracted by a revised 4.1 percent over the figure for the same period a year earlier.

The worst is over for the economy as new figures show it is climbing out of the trough during the disastrous Sars months. One per cent growth for the July-to-September quarter compared to a year ago may not sound that wonderful, but it means the economy has stopped shrinking.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore economy rebounds but economists cautious on outlook.
Singapore's economy rebounded in the third quarter after a sharp SARS-led contraction in the second, according to new figures, but analysts were cautious that the recovery is not broad-based. Quarter-on-quarter growth of 15 per cent reversed an 11 per cent downturn in the second quarter, the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said, citing preliminary figures based on the economy's performance in July and August.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SWEDEN BUSINESS COUNCIL MEETING TO OPEN MONDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 11 (CNA) (by M.T. Liu and EH)

TEXT.P: The 19th Taiwan-Sweden Business Council meeting will be held Monday in Stockholm.
The meeting is aimed at promoting the economic relations and technological exchanges between the two countries, an official of the Taipei Mission in Sweden said Saturday.

He said Lin Ling-san, minister of transportation and communications of Taiwan, and Lars-Olof Lindgren, director of the Foreign Trade Department of the Sweden Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will deliver speeches at the meeting.
Lin and members of the Taiwan mission to the meeting will visit Sweden companies and meet with a number of business leaders on Tuesday and Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP TO OFFER VOLUNTEER SERVICE IN PHILIPPINES, LIBERIA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Roots Medial Peace Corps (TRMPC) will send a team of medical professionals to offer volunteer service in the Philippines later this month, the group's founder said Saturday.

Liu Chi-chun, a dentist who founded the TRMPC eight years ago to offer volunteer medical services in Taiwan's aboriginal communities or other developing countries, said a 16-member medical delegation will offer volunteer services at a shanty town near the Philippine capital of Manila from Oct. 15-19.

In mid-November, Liu said, the TRMPC will send another medical delegation to the war-torn African state of Liberia to offer free medical services for refugees there. "The delegation will stay in Liberia for three month," Liu said, adding that this will be the first time that the organization has offered such a long time of services in a foreign country.
The TRMPC had twice sent two volunteer groups to work in Liberia in the past few years.
In August of this year, Liu said, the group also sent medical professionals to Gambia in West Africa to offer free medical services for its people.
The TRMPC is the only Taiwan non-governmental organization to have been admitted to the U.N.-affiliated Conference of Non-Governmental Organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL LEADERS TRADE COMMENTS ON ISSUE OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and those of two major opposition parties traded public comments Friday and Saturday on the issue of constitutional reform.

Lien Chan, presidential candidate of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), said Friday at an evening party in Chiayi marking the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day that, if elected president next year, he will hold a conference on the development of a national constitution.

Chen Chi-mai, a leader of the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, said Saturday that Lien is inconsistent on the issue of constitutional reform, noting that he first dismissed President Chen Shui-bian's idea to introduce a new constitution as "meaningless" and then said Friday that he would hold a conference on the development of a national constitution.

President Chen first mentioned his idea to campaign for a new constitution on Sept. 28 at a rally marking the 17th anniversary of the founding of the DPP. In his national day address on Friday, Chen also talked about the re-engineering of Taiwan's constitutional system.

He said that the current constitutional framework and the government system it mandates are insufficient to meet Taiwan's practical needs, and that he has an obligation to unite the Taiwan people "in hastening the birth of a new constitution, so as to make Taiwan a normal, full-fledged and great democracy." He also said that "the constitution must be subject to a national referendum for the people of Taiwan to decide."
Chen Chi-mai said that the KMT has repeatedly boycotted the DPP's initiatives for constitutional reform and that Lien is opposed to constitutional reform.
Kuo Su-chun, spokeswoman for the KMT, said that what Lien wants to do is to hold a national conference on the amendment of the constitution when it becomes "impractical."

Kuo said what the KMT wants to do is to make "practical amendments" to the constitution. The general public will be able to see the difference between the ideas of the KMT and those of the DPP, she added.

Meanwhile, Lin Cho-shui, executive director of the Policy Committee of the DPP, said at a press conference Friday that the DPP welcomes the idea of Lien holding a constitutional conference, but added that this is not enough. The DPP hopes that Lien will put forward a detailed proposal for constitutional reform, he said.
Lin said there are similarities between the ideas of the KMT and those of the DPP on constitutional reform.

Chou Hsi-wei, convener of the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, said Friday that Lien's proposal to hold a constitutional conference is feasible. He expressed the hope that both the ruling and opposition parties will make public their detailed plans for constitutional reform for open discussion.
Chou also noted several points of similarity between the ideas of the DPP and those of the pan-blue alliance on constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNING CENTER FOR PINGTUNG BIOTECHNOLOGY PARK TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The planning center for the agricultural biotechnology park in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, will be inaugurated Oct. 12.
The aim of the center will be to develop the park into the most prestigious agricultural high-technology center in Asia.
Lee Chin-lung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), will attend the ceremony.
According to COA officials, local biotechnology companies are expected to begin moving into the park in March next year.

In view of the fact that biotechnology is expected to be the star industry with great potential this century, the government concluded in the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in 2001 that the island should establish an agricultural biotechnology park. The government also listed biotechnology in its six-year national development plan as an industry that the country should launch more efforts into.

The total development cost of the 250-hectare agricultural biotechnology park is estimated at NT$12.85 billion (US$381 million), with eight categories of products to be the main items in the first phase of development, including vegetables, flowers, health foods, biotic fertilizers, and vaccines for animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO LAUNCH MALAWIAN CHILD SPONSORSHIP CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she will launch a campaign for sponsoring Malawian children so that the children of the southeastern African country will get better care.

The vice president made the remarks when she hosted a luncheon in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, in honor of Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his entourage who came to Taiwan for the Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Lu lauded President Muluzi for devoting himself to his country's democracy and progress during his 10 years in office.

She also said that President Muluzi is a long-term close friend of Taiwan, noting that he has instructed the nation's ambassador to the United Nations each year to speak out for the Republic of China's cause when the United Nations holds its annual general assembly.
Such steadfast support for the ROC is touching, the vice president said.
Lu said that some people in Taiwan may complain about the high unemployment rate and the fact they are not earning enough money, but compared with Malawi, "we are very lucky."

She again urged the people to extend Taiwan's love to its diplomatic allies. Following her appeal to sponsor Gambian children earlier this week, she asked for generous donations for Malawian children, saying that the sum of NT$10,000 (US$295.85) will be able to support a child for two years.
She said that she hopes the campaign could start from schools, with groups of two or three students co-sponsoring a Malawian child.

Lu also said that as Taiwan is actively seeking opportunities to join the international community, it is necessary to extend Taiwan's love to Malawi in addition to expressing its appreciation to the country.
After the luncheon, Lu accompanied President Muluzi and his entourage to visit a chicken farm and a vegetable farm in Taoyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD EXPORTERS URGED TO OBTAIN MORE WORLD-LEVEL CERTIFICATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan officials and scholars on Saturday urged exporters of agricultural products to obtain more world-level certifications to boost their sales abroad.

According to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's agricultural exports totalled US$2.51 billion for the first eight months of this year, representing an increase of 4.3 percent over the same period last year, with the main outlets being Japan, Hong Kong and United States.

Chen Chia-ling, a section chief of the Council of Agriculture, said that Taiwan's agricultural exports to Japan for the first eight months rose 13.4 percent over the same period last year due largely to Japan's stricter quality control on products from mainland China, Taiwan's major competitor in the market.

Last year, a large amount of vegetables and livestock products exported to Japan from mainland China were found to contain excessive levels of pesticides and antibiotics, leading the Japanese government to increase the random examination rate on mainland Chinese agricultural products from 5 percent to 20 percent, thus resulting in a heavy decline in mainland Chinese agricultural exports to Japan this year.

Chen noted that although the quality of Taiwan's vegetables and fruits is gradually being recognized in world markets, the island's major outlets have been too concentrated in the United States and Asian countries. He added that there is still much space for Taiwan farmers to develop European and other American markets.

To enlarge their market share, Chen urged domestic farmers to gain more world level certifications, including the HACCP (Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point System), which is being promoted by the World Trade Organization, the European Union and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation.

Liao Yuan-tung, a professor at the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, noted that the HACCP should be adopted as a standard by food entrepreneurs in Taiwan because most products without HACCP certification will not be able to enter American, European countries or Japan in the future.

Chen Chi-tang, a China External Trade Development Council official, said that people all around the world are becoming more and more strict in terms of what they eat and are willing to spend more money on high-quality food. He stressed that the image of "healthy, safe and hygienic" food is an advantage that Taiwan agricultural producers should explore for gaining a greater foothold in international markets.
