DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEWS OF MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES EXPANDED

TEXT.P: Immigration officers began to interview all incoming mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens Saturday with a view to staving off an influx of mainland immigrants through marriages of convenience.

With the number of bogus marriages between Taiwan and mainland Chinese citizens increasing, the Bureau of Immigration under the National Police Administration adopted a personal interview system for incoming mainland spouses from the beginning of last month.

Initially, the bureau only conducted personal interviews on selected mainland Chinese spouses. As of Oct. 8, about 2.5 percent of those interviewed were determined to be in bogus marriages with Taiwan citizens and were either immediately repatriated or ordered to leave the island in 10 days.

On Friday, the bureau largely expanded interviews of incoming mainland Chinese spouses and discovered three of them, including two women and a man, to be in bogus marriages with Taiwan nationals for the purpose of working on the island.

Starting Saturday, the bureau launched an across-the-board interview system at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport -- the main gateway to Taiwan -- in order to prevent entry of mainland citizens through marriages of convenience.
The Aviation Police Bureau (APB) said it has dispatched 30 staff members to assist immigration officers in interviewing all incoming mainland Chinese spouses.
"We believe that stricter entry control will help prevent an influx of mainland immigrants through 'bogus marriages' and thus ward off many social problems," an APB official said.

Meanwhile, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said it will intensify patrols and step up monitoring of mainland fishing boats operating in waters near the center line of the Taiwan Strait to prevent mainland Chinese citizens from illegally entering Taiwan by ship.

CGA officials said the Legislative Yuan's recent passage of a package of amendments to the statute governing cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which allows for confiscation of fishing boats used in transporting illegal mainland immigrants to Taiwan and invalidation of licenses of ships and crew members involved in the criminal operations, will be of great help in discouraging or cracking down on cross-strait human trafficking.

The previous law didn't authorize law enforcement authorities to seize those ships nor allow for revocation of law-breaking crewmen's working licenses. As a result, mainland Chinese human smuggling ring leaders, commonly known as snakeheads, often used Taiwan fishing boats to smuggle mainland people to the island.

According to official tallies, 903 mainland Chinese spouses were interviewed either at CKS International Airport or on the ROC-held frontline island of Kinmen between Sept. 1 and Oct. 8. Thirteen of these, including 11 women and two men, were determined to be in bogus marriages with ROC citizens and were immediately repatriated.

Moreover, 10 other mainland Chinese spouses were determined, following a second round of interviewing after their entry into Taiwan, to be in bogus marriages with ROC citizens. Their entry permits were revoked and ordered to leave the island within 10 days.
In the first nine months of this year, police authorities checked into 1,079 cross-strait marriages and determined that 52 of them were bogus.

Meanwhile, the number of cross-strait intermarriages had reached 190,000 as of Oct. 8. Among these cross-strait couples, 171,582 mainland Chinese spouses had applied to visit Taiwan. Of the applicants, 95,338 have been allowed to come to Taiwan for brief visits; 13,149 have obtained residence permits; and 10,063 have secured ROC citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU HAS MISUNDERSTOOD REVISED CROSS-STRAIT STATUTE: MAC

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy planner said Saturday that the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) has misunderstood the "contents and spirit " of a just revised statute and that it will continue to communicate with the party.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) was responding to bitter attacks by the TSU the previous day after the revision to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area was passed by the Legislative Yuan Thursday.

The TSU claimed that since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in May 2000, it has allowed more than 80,000 mainland Chinese spouses to come to Taiwan, surpassing the figure for the whole preceding decade.

The TSU also said that it is worried that a large influx of mainland Chinese spouses could dilute valuable social resources and even trigger an economic collapse, adding that the government's "wrong policy" will only bring disaster to the nation.
MAC officials said that although cross-strait intermarriages have increased in recent years, only about 11,000 mainland spouses have been given approval to settle in Taiwan.
They said that in the first two years after marriage, mainland Chinese citizens will only be allowed to visit their spouses in Taiwan, and only for a maximum of six months at one time.
The officials said that the visiting mainland Chinese spouses are only short-term migrants and that they have not been entitled to social benefits.
They said that the newly revised statute will follow the principle of making it "easier for mainland people to live in Taiwan, but more difficult for them to obtain citizenship."

They said that following the revision, the related government agencies now have the comprehensive legal basis to control and manage the newly-arrived population and to take their impact on Taiwan society into account.
Consequently, the newly-revised statute will set the quota in view of Taiwan's population growth, the distribution of social resources, social stability and immigration policy, the officials said.

Addressing the TSU's criticism of the government for allowing mainland-based educational institutions to recruit students in Taiwan, MAC officials said that this was a "necessary adjustment in line with the regulations of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , " which they said does not mean "an opening will be imminent."
The officials said that Taiwan and mainland China have yet to conduct bilateral negotiations on the issue under the framework of the WTO.
In addition, the Ministry of Education will have to further assess the impact on Taiwan's education system if mainland educational institutions are allowed to recruit students in Taiwan, they added.

Therefore, they said that the MAC will "not allow mainland educational institutions to do so at this stage, and that there is no possibility of formulation of approval measures in the short term," adding that the TSU has misunderstood the revised regulations and worried too much.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICE WORKERS SINGING THE BLUES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A significant percentage of Taiwan office workers are feeling the blues, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey, conducted by the online human resources company www.9999.com.tw, found that 41.23 percent of respondents said they have been suffering from insomnia, 38.06 percent said that they have been experiencing headaches or sore muscles, while 31.68 percent said that they have contemplated suicide.

Asked about their recent feelings regarding work, 41.14 percent said that they have been feeling short-tempered, while 34.72 percent said they have often felt like taking the day off and not going to work.

Yang Yi-cheng, executive director of the online company, said that due to pressure, clashes in the office have increased, as seen in the fact that 25.91 percent of those surveyed said they have experienced the desire to assault their superiors or co-workers, making them what Yang called a "potent threat in the office."

Faced with mounting pressure, 46.17 percent said they confide in others to relieve their burden, 35.73 percent said they use smoking as an outlet, while 32.28 percent said they ease their pain by shopping. A total of 8.21 percent said they turn to Ecstasy or other drugs for an emotional outlet.

The survey also found that 68.64 percent believe that their superiors often find fault with them or have an unfair management policy, while 76.15 percent also said they think their co-workers are smearing or undercutting them behind their backs.

In terms of occupations, those in the fields of advertising and communications, medical care, and finance have the highest rates of depressed office workers. The lowest rates are seen among civic groups; military personnel, teachers and civil servants; and those in the retail and wholesale sectors.

The main reason stated by those in the advertising and communications sectors for their feelings of depression was the constant deadline pressure, while those in the financial sector pointed to long working hours and a highly competitive environment.
The main sources of bad feelings mentioned by the respondents overall were overwork and job performance worries.

For the survey, 40,000 e-mails were sent out to full-time office workers around the island between Sept. 24 and Oct. 6. A total of 10,576 valid responses were collected in the survey, which is said to have a margin of error of 0.95 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFRICAN HANDICRAFT TRADE FAIR OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An unprecedented African handicraft trade fair opened at the Far Eastern Plaza Shopping Mall in Taipei Saturday with a view to promoting trade and cultural exchanges between the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Africa.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu as well as visiting Gambian President Yahya Jammeh and Malawian President Bakili Muluzi jointly beat drums to mark the opening of the trade fair. Jammeh and Muluzi arrived in Taipei earlier this week to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Chen said he is pleased to see the opening of the special trade show to help boost Taiwan's trade ties with its African allies.
In addition to promoting commercial exchanges, Chen said, the event will also offer local people a rare glimpse into cultures of various ROC allies in Africa.
"I'm hopeful that similar trade fairs can be held in Taiwan frequently in the future to further expand trade, friendship and cultural exchanges with our African allies," Chen said.

Seven of the ROC's diplomatic allies in Africa -- Burkina Faso, Chad, Gambia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal and Swaziland -- are exhibiting eye-catching handicraft items reflecting their own unique cultural traditions in the trade fair. Also for sale at the fair are coffee, black tea and other products from those countries.

The event has been jointly organized by several ROC agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the China External Trade Development Council, as well as the Far Eastern Plaza Shopping Mall and the embassies of the seven African countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD FRONT FORECAST TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN MONDAY

TEXT.P: A cold front is set to arrive in the Taiwan area Monday, bringing rain to the northern, northeastern and eastern parts of the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Saturday.
CWB meteorologists said the weather on Saturday and Sunday will be cloudy and hot in most areas, with a slight chance of showers in the mountainous areas of northeastern, central and southern Taiwan.
Temperatures will range from a low of 24 degrees Celsius to a high of 32 degrees Celsius, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, GAMBIAN PRESIDENTS SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Gambian President Yahya Jammeh signed a joint communique Saturday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting cooperation between the two countries.
The two leaders also expressed their willingness to work hand-in-hand in promoting world peace and prosperity.
In the communique, Jammeh reaffirmed his country's support for the Republic of China's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
For his part, Chen extended his gratitude for Gambia's staunch support for Taiwan's cause and reassured Jammeh of the ROC's commitment to assist in Gambia's economic development.

Before signing the joint communique, Chen and Jammeh held talks on matters of mutual concern. This is Jammeh's fourth visit to Taiwan in his capacity as the Gambian head of state and the first time he has taken part in the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Chen told Jammeh that he was impressed by the dance performances by a Gambian troupe at an ROC National Day rally Friday.
"The dazzling performances not only epitomized Gambia's cultural essence but also brought exotic fanfare to our National Day festivities," he said.
Chen further said he is aware that the Gambian Presidential Office's Web site has been linked up with those of eight other countries around the world, including the ROC's.

"The fact that our Web site comes just behind the White House's indicates the importance Gambia attaches to its ties with Taiwan, " Chen said, adding that he hopes the two countries will strengthen bilateral communications and exchanges through this channel.

As Gambia is focusing efforts on developing its agriculture, Chen said the ROC has prepared high-quality seeds of several tropical fruit and peanut varieties for Jammeh's entourage to take back to the West African state for plantation.
"I earnestly hope that these seeds can grow well in your country to let your people get a taste of the delicious fruits endemic to Taiwan," Chen said.
Jammeh, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday in the company of some senior Gambian officials, wrapped up his four-day visit and left for home Saturday afternoon.

In addition to attending the ROC's National Day celebrations, Jammeh has also visited major Taiwan economic establishments during his stay, including the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s (CPC's) oil refinery in Taoyuan. While there, Jammeh invited CPC Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai to head a delegation to visit his country later this month to explore cooperation possibilities.

PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo said Friday the Philippines could prevent attacks by the Jemaah Islamiyah terror network after an Australian official warned that the country faced the "greatest threat" of an attack in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD FORECASTS ECONOMIC GROWTH OF 3.06 PERCENT FOR 2003

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planning agency issued a report Saturday forecasting that Taiwan's economic growth for this year will reach 3.06 percent.

According to the report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's economic growth for the first half of the year was slow because of the impacts of the U.S.-led war against Iraq in March and the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in Taiwan between March and June.

With the end of the war in Iraq and the containment of SARS, CEPD officials said, Taiwan's economy has visibly turned for the better in the second half of the year, and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has adjusted its economic growth forecast for the second half of the year to 4.32 percent and its growth forecast for 2003 to 3.06 percent.
The DGBAS had originally estimated that Taiwan's economic growth would be 2.89 percent for this year.

The CEPD officials also said that the consumer price index (CPI), which fell by 0.2 percent last year, has continued to drop this year. The CPI for the first nine months of this year was down 0.31 percent over that for the same period last year.
The officials said that they don't think that this indicates that deflation has set in, adding however that they will continue to monitor the situation closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 11, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through Hong Kong merchants.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons, beginning his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain during World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War," and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for literature.
1939: U.S. scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin D. Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration by the government and the Chinese communists announces that an agreement between the two sides has been reached after six weeks of negotiations and that unsolved problems are to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7, carrying U.S. astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle and Walter Cunningham, is launched.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1975: A two-day national conference on "Building a New Asia Through Moral Rearmament" opens in Taipei.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup after Mao's death.
1978: The 1978 World Women's Football Invitational Tournament opens at the Taipei Municipal Stadium with 13 teams from Asia, Australia, Europe, the Americas and the Pacific competing.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhabited islets, located in the East China Sea, is also claimed by Japan and Communist China.
1991: Direct air service between Australia and the Republic of China begins.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique on expanding bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.
1999: Some 7,000 people gather at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei to mourn the death of 2,321 people in the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Chang Yu-hern confirms that Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic have agreed to exchange "temporary aviation rights" with the ROC to facilitate bilateral visits.
2001: Chang Siao-yueh, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs says that the ROC government supports the U.S.-launched war against terrorism and has taken steps to prevent terrorists from laundering money in Taiwan.
2001: The results of the first stage of a nationwide English evaluation examination for people with a junior high school education background are unveiled. The tests are part of a government drive to urge people to improve their English-language ability levels in order to better compete in a rapidly globalizing economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he in this world who is possessed of absolute truth that can order and adjust the great relations of human society, fix the fundamental principles of morality, and understand the laws of creation of the Universe."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST 2007 BASEBALL WORLD CUP

TEXT.P: Taiwan will host the 37th Baseball World Cup to be played in 2007, an official of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association, said Sunday.

Lin Chung-cheng, secretary general of the association, said that the Executive Committee of the International Baseball Federation unanimously approved the application presented by Peng Cheng-hau, president of the association for organizing the tournament at a meeting held in Havana, Cuba.
It will be the second time that Taiwan is to have hosted the Baseball World Cup.
Taiwan hosted the 34th Baseball World Cup in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANGMING MARINE TRANSPORT ORDERS FOUR SHIPS FROM HYUNDAI

TEXT.P: Yangming Marine Transport Corp. has inked an agreement to order four ships from South Korea's Hyundai Heavy Industries Co., Ltd., a spokesman for the Taipei-based shipping company said Sunday.
Witnessed by Yangming General Manager Huang Uan-hsiu, Yangming Vice General Manager Liu Chi-hsiung and his Hyundai counterpart I. Y. Chung clinched the accord on behalf of their respective companies.

Under the terms of the pact, Hyundai will build four 8200 TEUs (twenty-foot-equivalent units) for Yangming, an advanced type of full cargo container ship which is capable of sailing at a high speed of 26 nautical miles per hour. Delivery of the vessels is slated for late 2006 and early 2007.
According to the spokesman, the four ships will be used to ply the routes between Asia and Europe in order to upgrade Yangming's competitiveness and provide better services to its clients.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN HEADS FOR VIETNAM

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong left for Vietnam Sunday to promote foreign understanding of Taiwan as part of the drive to prevent the country from being an outcast on the world stage.

Soong, who has teamed up with leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to form a ticket to compete in the next presidential race slated for March 2004, said the major purpose of his trip to Vietnam is to introduce Taiwan's economic and democratic progress, proof of the country's vigorous existence.

Soong said he will also explain the basic economic and political stance of the two parties to Vietnamese friends from the political and academic sectors as well as Taiwan businessmen operating in that Southeast Asian country.

Commenting on a recent interview printed by a foreign newspaper with President Chen Shui-bian, who accused the Beijing regime of secretly assisting the "pan-blue alliance" formed mainly by the KMT and PFP, Soong said such rhetoric had underestimated the wisdom of the Taiwan people and constituted an insult to the two parties.
Turning to the issue of the administration's plan to hold a referendum, the PFP chairman pointed to the need for a legal basis.
Soong will stay in Vietnam for three or four days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CUTS TIES TO LIBERIA AFTER MONROVIA DROPS RECOGNITION OF TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Sunday that the Republic of China has suspended diplomatic ties and aid to Liberia.

Richard Shih, the ministry's director-general of the Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, made the announcement at a press conference after the information that Liberia had severed ties with Taiwan was confirmed.

Shih said that it was regretful that a provisional government of Liberia, which will be made official in two days, has made the decision, in spite of the fact that the foreign ministry had done all it could to save bilateral ties.

Shih also criticized Beijing for using its influence in the United Nations to pressure Liberia to cut its ties with the ROC by threatening to meddle in the budget for U.N. peacekeeping forces in the war-ravaged western African nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAO ZEDONG SUPPORTED TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: EXAMINATION YUAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Mao Zedong would be turning in his grave if he knew that the leaders in Beijing were doing all they could to block Taiwan independence, according to a book authored by Yao Chia-wen, president of the Examination Yuan.

In the book, "Ten Remarks that Affect Taiwan," Yao quoted Mao as saying in Edgar Snow's 1938 book, "Red Star over China, " that he firmly supported the Korean people's fight for independence from Japan, who ruled the Korean Peninsula at the time, and by the same token, supported the Taiwan people's fight against Japan for a similar cause.

Even Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of the Republic of China, would have welcomed Taiwan's independence, said Yao in his book, citing Tai Chi-tao, one of Sun's confidants and a former president of the Control Yuan, as quoting Sun as saying that Taiwan should have its own government and parliament.
Tai was, therefore, one of the earliest advocates for Taiwan independence, Yao said in his new book.

Yao counts late Minister of Foreign Affairs George Yeh and late Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Shi-kun among the supporters of Taiwan independence, saying that declassified information shows both Yeh and Yang flirted with the idea of Taiwan independence to thwart Beijing's territorial claims on Taiwan in 1971 when the Republic of China's seat at the United Nations was taken over by the People's Republic of China.
Yao's book will hit bookstores after a formal presentation Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOLAR CALLS FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC UNION
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan scholar called for democracies of the Pacific Rim Saturday to form a Democratic Pacific Union to promote the value of democracy, and economic development and cooperation in the region.

Speaking at the annual meeting of the Southwest Conference of Asian Studies of the United States via video conference, Joanne J.L. Chang, research fellow of the Institute of European and American Studies under the Academia Sinica, said that 15 of the 39 nations of the Pacific Rim are not democratic and four of the five remaining communist countries are in Asia.

There is no cooperation framework for Asian nations due to cultural differences and longstanding conflicts, she noted, adding that to actively promote democracy in the region by taking the experiences of democratization of the region's democratic countries as reference and to promote regional economic, cultural and technological cooperation will create a way of sustainable development for the Asia-Pacific region.
Taiwan is a full-fledged democratic nation and has created a "Taiwan miracle" with its "soft power" by promoting human rights, democracy, peace and technology over the past half century.
Taiwan can play an important role in promoting the new oceanic civilization of the Asia-Pacific area, making its "soft power" become a common value of the region, Chang said.
A democratic Pacific assembly was held in Taipei Sept. 19-21 with the participation of some 200 representatives from 24 countries, Chang noted.

The meeting is aimed at establishing a forum for countries of the Pacific Rim, allowing them to discuss jointly their own future development and to form a Democratic Pacific Union as an official organization of the region, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CULTURAL NIGHT HELD AT DANISH PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: A "Taiwan Cultural Night" was held Friday to celebrate the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China at the Danish Parliament, which was attended by more than 50 Danish dignitaries, officials of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission said Sunday.

ROC Representative to Denmark Chang Ping-nan addressed the gathering and thanked the Danish People's Party for helping the Taipei Representative Office in Denmark sponsor the event on the ROC national day to allow the Danish people to gain a better understanding of Taiwan.
Danish People's Party Chairman Pia Kaersgarrd also gave a speech and promised to do his best to help President Chen Shui-bian visit Denmark.

Along with Kaersgarrd during the six-hour activity were 22 Danish People's Party lawmakers and 30 from other political parties, including Danish parliament speaker Christian Mejdahl and second vice speaker Poul Nodgaard, who recently paid a visit to Taiwan. Immigration Minister Bertal Haader was also present.
Many of the attending lawmakers showed much interest in making a fact- finding trip to Taiwan.

Thousands of leaflets were given away to the Danish public at the site with information about Taiwan's tourism, economic and democratic developments as well the island's society and cultural interests. There were also a series of exhibitions featuring Taiwan's traditional arts and folk festivals.
On the same day, nearly a 1.000 ROC nationals living in France poured into the Evergreen Laurel Hotel in Paris to mark the country's 92nd birthday.

ROC Representative to France Chiou Jong-nan thanked everyone for their participation and stressed the government's determination to pursue democracy, freedom and human rights and to achieve a wide range of reforms despite the impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome earlier in the year.
Chiou also awarded honorary certificates to outstanding figures from the local Chinese community for their efforts in the fields of education and international trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SIGNS COMMUNIQUE WITH VISITING MALAWI COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed a communique with visiting Malawi President Bakili Muluzi in Taipei Sunday.

In the communique, both leaders agree that all countries in the world should sort out their internal and international differences through dialogue on the basis of equality and respect for each other's sovereignty and independence.
The two leaders pledged on behalf of their countries to cooperate with each other.
Chen thanked Muluzi and his administration for their firm support for Taiwan's bids to join in the United Nations and World Trade Organization.

Noting that the states in southern Africa are forming a Southern African Development Community, Chen said in the communique that he hopes Muluzi will exercise his personal influence to encourage states is southern Africa to better understand Taiwan.

For his part, Muluzi said he shares Chen's beliefs in democracy, the rule of law and the respect for human rights, adding that his country speaks out for Taiwan in the international community because he believe the voices of Taiwan's 23 million people should not be ignored by the international community.

He reaffirmed his country's support for the Republic of China in its bids to join the United Nations and other international organizations, saying that Taiwan can contribute significantly to world peace, and international prosperity and economy if it is admitted to these organizations.
Both leaders said they have exchanged views on broad issues and vowed to continue their close cooperation to promote peace and prosperity in Asia, Africa and the rests of the world.
The communique said Muluzi invited Chen to visit Malawi at a convenient time and Chen accepted it.
Muluzi, his foreign minister, Lilian Patel, and several Cabinet members arrived in Taiwan on Oct. 9 for a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH WORKERS CLEAN MOSQUITO BREEDING GROUNDS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County officials in charge of public health and environmental protection are taking steps to clean up the breeding grounds of mosquitoes in four villages after a case of dengue fever was reported in a neighboring district in Kaohsiung City.

Hsieh Mei-chun, an official of the Kaohsiung County Public Health Bureau said Sunday that more than 50 workers have begun to clean up mosquito breeding grounds in the villages of Tashe, Jenwu, Chiaotou and Tzeguang. Residents in the area have been asked to clean up their gardens and yards outside their homes to prevent any outbreak of the disease.
A dengue fever epidemic broke out in Kaohsiung County last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO ATTEND ECONOMIC SUMMIT IN SINGAPORE MONDAY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to leave for Singapore Monday morning to give a speech at the 12th East Asia Economic Summit which opened Sunday.

Ma will deliver a five-minute speech at a panel discussion slated for Tuesday morning. In his speech, Ma is expected to stress Taiwan's role in and its contributions to regional economic development in the East Asia area, and highlight Taiwan's potential of becoming a business operations center in East Asia, particularly an operations center for mainland China-based Taiwan business people.

This is the third time that Ma has been invited by authorities of the East Asia Economic Summit to deliver a speech at the regional meeting. Ma, however, failed to attend the first two meetings due to a typhoon and a mayoral election.

The 12th East Asia Economic Summit, sponsored by the World Economic Forum in cooperation with the Singapore Economic Development Board, is Asia's leading gathering of regional business leaders, senior government officials, media representatives and experts on trade and economy.
A total of 800 participants from 32 countries are gathering for discussions and decision-making on the summit's theme "Asia's future: Recapturing dynamism."
Singapore's Prime Minister Goh Chok-Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan-Yew are among international leaders from the region invited to participate in the summit.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: DPM wants PM, SM in his Cabinet.
MR LEE Hsien Loong wants both Mr Lee Kuan Yew and Mr Goh Chok Tong to remain in the Cabinet to advise him, when he takes over as Prime Minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES VIA KINMEN ARE FEASIBLE: CAA

TEXT.P: Operating international charter flight services from Kinmen's Shangyi Airport would not only be pragmatic, but feasible, according to the head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Sunday.

CAA Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said in Kinmen that he supports the proposal made by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng that Kinmen's Shangyi Airport be allowed to operate international charter flight services to increase the service for mainland China-based Taiwanese business people and overseas Chinese who are interested in visiting Kinmen.
The Kinmen Shangyi Airport is currently being expanded and could accept international flights in two years, making it suitable for international charter flight services, Chang said.

Chang said that the primary concern of any international airport is its ability to attract passengers. "Therefore, as long as Shangyi Airport can get enough passengers and international air carriers are willing to operate flights to and from Kinmen, the airport's international charter flight services should be fine," he said.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee said Sunday that Kinmen -- the hometown of hundreds of thousands of overseas Chinese scattered throughout Southeast Asia -- should be allowed to operate international charter flight services beginning with a once-a-week international charter flight connecting Kinmen's Shangyi Airport and Singapore's Changyi International Airport.

The Shangyi-Changyi charter flights would make it easier for Chinese expats to return home to Kinmen, and would make it more convenient for potential investors from Southeast Asia to come to Kinmen, thus rejuvenating Kinmen's tourism sector and boosting its economic development, Lee said.

Lee also asked that entry procedures for overseas Chinese traveling to Kinmen via Xiamen in Fujian province be further simplified to facilitate travel to Kinmen by those people who have already traveled to southern mainland China.

Chang and other CAA officials went to Kinmen Sunday to preside over a shellfish farming event on the Kinmen coast, where clam and oyster farming was destroyed by pollution caused by the dumping of waste soil retrieved from the Shangyi Airport reconstruction work in May this year.

The CAA financed the acquisition of some 1.5 million clam "seed stock." About 200 people, including CAA officials, personnel from the Kinmen County Government, and several Kinmen County councilors walked to the beach to "plant" the baby clams in the hope that the marine ecology in the Kinmen area will be nurtured back to health.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES AWARD FROM TAIWANESE-AMERICAN FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was named to receive an award from the U.S.-based Taiwanese-American Foundation Sunday for her contributions to Taiwan.
In a news conference held in Taipei, the foundation's founder, Kenjohn Wang, lauded Lu for her contributions to Taiwan's democracy, human rights protection, peace and diplomacy.
"Lu has succeeded in bringing Taiwan to the world and bringing the world to Taiwan," Wang said.
The prize has been awarded to seven others before, including Former President Lee Teng-hui and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.
The foundation also announced five winners of other awards. Each of them will get US$20,000 in a ceremony Nov. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY PARK TO BE ESTABLISHED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The first agricultural biotechnology park in Asia will be established in the southern Taiwan city of Pingtung and become operational by the end of next year.

Lee Chin-lung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture of the Executive Yuan, said Sunday at the inauguration of the preparatory office of the park that, occupying an area of 350 hectares, the park will be able to accommodate 120 investors. It is aimed at modernizing and promoting agricultural production. The output from the park is expected to reach NT$20 billion (US$598 million) in 10 years.

Also speaking at the inauguration ceremony, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said the government is planning to establish four other biotechnology parks in four other parts of Taiwan to modernize the production of herbs, orchids, other flowers, and marine products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ASKS ROC OVERSEAS OFFICES TO HELP HOLDERS OF NEW PASSPORT

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals living and traveling abroad who hold the new ROC passport will enjoy better service from Taiwan's representative offices, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said in a written report submitted to the Legislative Yuan Sunday.

Chien said his ministry has required its foreign-based offices to enhance service and assistance to those ROC citizens holding the new ROC passport with the word "Taiwan" on the cover in the face of robust pressure from Beijing, which has demanded that foreign countries deny entry or departure to travelers from Taiwan holding the new passport.
The word "Taiwan" was added to help foreign customs authorities better distinguish ROC passports from those of the People's Republic of China, a move which Chien said was in no way political.

Applications for the new passport increased by 21 percent during the period from its issuance day on Sept. 1 to Sept. 25 over the year-earlier level, an indication that the response to the new passport among the people of Taiwan has been positive, the foreign minister said in the report.
Chien is slated to report and field questions from lawmakers about the issue Monday at the legislative foreign relations and overseas Chinese affairs committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCAF RF-5E RECONNAISSANCE PLANE CRASHES, PILOT RESCUED

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Air Force single-seat RF-5E reconnaissance plane crashed into the sea about 30 nautical miles from Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, at 11: 10 a.m. Sunday, the ROCAF General Headquarters confirmed.

The sole pilot, flight Col. Lee Ching-hsi, who parachuted before the RF-5E Tigergazer nosedived into the sea, was rescued by an ROC Navy frigate around noon. Basically in good condition, Lee is now recuperating at the Hsinchu Air Force Hospital, a source with the ROCAF General Headquarters said.
Initial investigations into the crash point to mechanical failure, said Pan Chih-cheng, a warfare director with the Taoyuan Air Force Command where Lee and his plane are based.
According to Pan, Lee radioed an S-O-S before he ejected.

Further investigations will be needed to determine the exact reasons behind the crash. It was the first crash of any of the seven reconnaissance planes that the ROC Air Force has operated since 1997, Pan said.
The RF-5E is a conversion model of the F-5E that is equipped with reconnaissance equipment, including cutting-edge cameras and an extended nose featuring six apertures.
The squadron of seven RF-5Es, whose members call themselves the Red Fox fleet, was cited as a model squadron by the ROC Armed Forces in 2002.
Flight Col. Lee, 33, graduated from the ROC Air Force Academy in 1995 and has a flight record of 1,290 hours in jet fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE PROSTITUTES IN TAIWAN SOARS

TEXT.P: The number of illegal mainland Chinese prostitutes in Taiwan has soared this year although the overall number of women entering from abroad to engage in the sex trade declined, the National Police Administration (NPA) reported Sunday.

According to NPA tallies, the number of Chinese prostitutes who entered Taiwan via the arrangement of "snakehead" human trafficking rings between January and August this year jumped by 22 percent, or 327 persons, to constitute 40.42 percent of the entire number of the 1,544 women from abroad who were arrested for soliciting in Taiwan in the first eight months of the year.

In the same period of 2002, the number of Chinese prostitutes who entered Taiwan illegally made up only 18.53 percent of all the non-local prostitutes who were arrested by police, NPA officials noted.

A total of 1,544 women from abroad were found by police to have entered Taiwan to engage in prostitution in the first eight months of this year, marking a slight decrease of 59 persons from the 1,603 recorded in the same period of 2002.

Of the total, 58.03 percent or 896 people were Chinese women from the mainland, Hong Kong and Macau who used legal entry papers, while 40.42 percent or 624 people, also Chinese women from the mainland, Hong Kong and Macau areas, were illegal immigrants who had sneaked into Taiwan through illegal channels using bogus entry papers. Twenty-four other women prostitutes were foreign nationals who entered with legal papers, NPA officials said.
By comparison, the number of Chinese prostitutes who entered Taiwan legally in the Jan.-Aug. period, totaling 896, was a sharp decrease of 29.56 percent or 376 persons from the year-earlier levels.

The foreign nationals group, numbering 24, was 10 persons fewer than that recorded in the same period of last year. Of this small group, 11 were Vietnamese, six were Russians, two were Thais, and the remainder being nationals of other countries, according to the NPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATISTICS SHOW AVERAGE AGE OF TAIWAN BRIDES AND BRIDEGROOMS

TEXT.P: A total of 173,343 couples got married in Taiwan last year, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior.
Of the newly married, 82.1 percent of the bridegrooms and 88.6 percent of the brides were married for the first time. The average age of the bridegrooms was 31, and that of the brides was 26.8.
But the average age of the bridegrooms in Hualien County was 36.7 and that of the brides in Taipei City was 30.1. They were the oldest brides and bridegrooms in Taiwan.

DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Local officials back GMA's bid
The country's governors, vice governors, provincial board members, and barangay chairmen have joined the 1,450 municipal mayors belonging to the League of Municipalities of the Philippines (LMP) in expressing their support to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, including her bid for a fresh mandate in the May 2004 elections.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal anti-kidnap czar
President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is taking on yet another hands-on role as a way of addressing the recent spate of kidnappings that has alarmed not only members of the Chinese-Filipino community but also big business.
The Philippine Star: Task force vs terror created
President Arroyo has created a task force to guard vital infrastructure from terrorist attacks, an official Malacanang statement said yesterday. The Task Force for the Security of Critical Infrastructure was formally created on Sept. 24 The Manila Times: ' Al-Ghozi in govt hands'
Military intelligence sources are hinting that al-Ghozi is already in government hands and will be presented to President Arroyo at an appropriate time, presumably on or before US President George W. Bush'svisit on October 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Turkish Daily News: Bush seen disengaging from Mideast peace.
Preoccupied by Iraq and next year's U.S. presidential election, the Bush administration appears to have consigned the Middle East conflict to the diplomatic back-burner, loosening most constraints on Israel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 12, or the 17th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban governdment, deliver a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilataral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: A summit meeting between US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ends in Reykjavik without any agreement on arms control being reached.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: Strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobstrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO ADDRESS INTERNATIONAL CARNAHAN CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech at the 37th International Carnahan Conference on Security and Technology (ICCST) slated to open at the Grand Hotel, Taipei, on Tuesday, officials from National Central University (NCU), co-sponsor of the event, said Monday.
President Chen will address the opening session of the three-day conference on Taiwan's strategic security position and its contribution to Asia-Pacific regional peace, the NCU authorities said.

More than 400 opinion leaders and specialists in security technology from 14 countries, including former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, will participate in the conference, which has "E-security" as the theme of discussions to manifest the significance and urgency of this issue within the "E-society."

A group of ranking Republic of China government officials, including Vice President Annette Lu and National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang, are also expected to take part in the ICCST, one of the most prestigious conferences in the world regarding security issues.

Other internationally-renowned experts who are scheduled to deliver keynote speeches are Dr. Hsinchun Chen, a professor in the field of artificial intelligence at the University of Arizona, who will speak on "Crime and Intelligence Data and Visualization for E-Security: the Coplink Experience."

Dr. Henry Lee, an internationally-acclaimed forensic scientist, will speak on "The Challenge and Changes of New Technology, " while Dr. Jim C.I. Chang, director of the U.S. Army Research Laboratory, will deliver a speech on "Security Technology in the Objective Force."

Opinion leaders and specialists from the United States, the United Kingdom, Spain, Switzerland, France, Germany, Canada, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Australia, the Czech Republic, Egypt and the host ROC will take part in the conference, the sponsor said.
A total of 33 research papers completed by specialists from home and abroad will be displayed at the conference location.

This year's conference is being jointly sponsored by the International Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) , Lexington Section, USA; the IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Society, USA; Taiwan's National Central University; the Chung Shan Institute of Science and Technology; and a number of other organizations from the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR LEAVES FOR SINGAPORE TO ATTEND ECONOMIC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left for Singapore Monday to attend the 12th East Asia Economic Summit which opened in the Southeast Asian city state Sunday.

Ma said prior to his departure that Taiwan must strengthen contacts and exchanges with East Asian countries because regional economic integration is a prevailing world trend and Taiwan cannot afford to be marginalized or isolated from countries in the region.
Ma will deliver a speech at a panel session slated for Tuesday morning. In his address, Ma said, he will tout Taiwan's potential of becoming an Asia-Pacific regional business operation hub.
