DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Visas for NGOs / Blacklist violates treaties.
The National Human Rights Commission yesterday lambasted the government for banning hundreds of foreign activities and NGO members from the Kingdom during the Apec summit, say the ban violates international treaties that Thailand has signed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS CONTRIBUTIONS OF HUMAN RIGHTS PANEL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded the contributions made by a human rights panel set up under the Presidential Office, especially a draft organic law for a national human rights committee and a draft bill for a human rights basic law.

At a dinner he hosted for the members of the panel, Chen extended his congratulations to Vice President Annette Lu, who serves as chairwoman of the panel, on her being named as the 2003 winner of a special contribution award from the Taiwanese-American Foundation.

Before the dinner party, the panel gathered and decided to study the human rights factors in elections, social order and peace, exchanges with mainland China and a plebiscite on Chen's idea for a new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO ENVOY SPEAKS OUT FOR CONTINUATION OF DOHA ROUND
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) announced Monday that the country will continue to back multilateral trade talks initiated in the WTO's Doha Round negotiations.
According to Yen Ching-chang, supporting sound multilateral trade talks under the framework of the WTO is in the country's best trade and economic interests.

Yen made the remarks during a meeting called by WTO General Council Chairman Carlos Perez del Castillo earlier the same day with a dozen WTO-based permanent envoys to discuss feasible measures to reopen the Doha Round following the collapse of talks held in mid-September in Cancun, Mexico. The meeting was held prior to an unofficial envoy-level meeting slated for the next day.

Despite the setback at the Cancun talks, Castillo stressed the goal of accomplishing the Doha Round negotiations by the end of 2004 and he called for member states to do their best to help rekindle the negotiations.

Echoing Castillo's statement, Yen said the failure of the Cancun talks should not be interpreted as a blockage to the Doha Round negotiations and the WTO should not be regarded as an "international court" aimed at resolving trade disputes.
Taiwan firmly supports the reopening of the Doha Round negotiations and the WTO's traditional role in holding trade regulatory talks, he said.

Pointing out that bilateral and multilateral trade agreements will quickly emerge in different regions in the wake of the Cancun talks, the envoy said Taiwan will be soon put in a very difficult position amid such circumstances.

Therefore, he went on, participating in WTO-sponsored multilateral trade talks would create the maximum benefits for Taiwan, while supporting the resumption of the Doha Round talks and backing the WTO's leadership role in international trade mechanisms will also help the country to protect its business interests.

To help toward the goal, Taiwan will be more reserved about the more controversial agricultural issues, while adopting a more positive stance in pushing for a consensus on the so-called Singapore issue -- market opening, regulatory affairs, improvement in transparency in government contracts and simplified procedures for cross-boarder transportation -- he added.
The unofficial envoy-level meeting to be held Tuesday will be the first gathering of member states since the breakup of the Cancun talks.

The Cancun meeting, a follow-up called to discuss a pact reached in the 2001 WTO conference in Doha, Qatar, broke up as a result of sharp differences between the rich and the poor countries over the Singapore issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU PROPOSAL FOR CROSS-STRAIT FISHERY PRODUCT MARKETING APPROVED

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy planner has approved in principle a proposal from the island county of Penghu to transport and market fishery products between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on a trial basis, Penghu fishery officials said Monday.
Penghu has been trying to make a breakthrough in cross-strait fishery and aquacultural transport and marketing, which it believes is crucial to its agricultural and fishery development.

In addition to soliciting Penghu's inclusion as the auxiliary harbor of Kaohsiung harbor, Penghu made an overall review of cross-strait fishery product transport and marketing before it submitted its proposal to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
The MAC gave the nod in principle, but asked the Penghu agriculture and fishery bureau to provide more details of the plan.

Penghu county agriculture and fishery bureau chief Lin Tze-ming said he then convened a meeting with related officials to discuss the views submitted by the MAC, as well as the feasibility and merits and disadvantages of Kaohsiung harbor being upgraded to a free trade port. They also exchanged views on fish aquaculture and fish processing, as well as fish disease and prevention.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT-PROMOTION CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Activities surrounding a four-day international conference organized to lure foreign investment will begin Sunday, according to one of its organizers, the China External Trade Development Council.
The 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference will first hold a briefing by the organizers for domestic and foreign journalists on the purpose of the conference.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun will host a reception for some 1,440 conference participants Sunday evening and give a welcome speech.

An opening ceremony is slated for Monday morning, when President Chen Shui-bian will give an opening speech that will be followed by a forum for chief executive officers of leading multinational and local companies, together with seminars on six different industries.
Foreign Minister Eugene Chien will play host at a lunch party for the participants.
The third day of the conference will feature another forum of CEOs and Vice President Annette Lu will host a lunch party for the participants. Chen will host a dinner party for them that evening.
Various government agencies will display their project plans outside the venue of the conference in an attempt to attract would-be investors.

In order to promote the participants' understanding of the island's investment environment, the organizers have lined up tours of the island's industrial centers on Wednesday, the last day of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FILM WINS PRIZE AT CHICAGO INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A Taiwan film won an award in the international competition category of the 39th Chicago International Film Festival, Government Information Office officials said Monday.
"Goodbye Dragon Inn, " directed by Tsai Ming-liang, won the prize for its "highly distinctive vision," according to the officials.
Iranian director Jafar Panahi's work "Crimson Gold" won the "Golden Hugo" Prize, the highest honor in the annual festival that opened Oct. 2 and will run through Oct. 16.
The winners of various competition categories were awarded at a ceremony held in Chicago Oct. 12, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH CHAIRMAN OF U.S. DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Monday with Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the U.S. Democratic National Committee.

Noting that McAuliffe has served as the national financial chairman for the re-election bids of former U.S. President Bill Clinton and Vice President Al Gore in 1996, Chen lauded him as one of the most powerful men behind the scenes and added that he is interested in finding out more about how McAuliffe earned his reputation as "the greatest fund-raiser in American history."

The president also welcomed proposed trips to Taiwan by Gore and Clinton. Gore is slated to arrive in Taiwan Tuesday to give a speech at an international conference in Taipei, while Clinton will visit the country on an as-yet unspecified day.
As McAuliffe also chairs a committee for the building of a library in Clinton's honor, Chen told McAuliffe that the Taiwan government would like to do something for the library.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD NOT BE MARGINALIZED: TAIPEI MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that Taiwan should not be left out and become marginalized during the economic integration of the countries of East Asia.
Ma, who arrived in Singapore to attend the 12th East Asia Economic Summit, which opened a day earlier, made the remarks shortly after his arrival.

Ma said he attended the meeting mainly to highlight the importance of Taiwan in the economic development of East Asia. He added that the people of Taiwan are very concerned about the regional economic integration and are unwilling to see Taiwan left out and marginalized in the integration process.
"After all, Taiwan has made a substantial contribution to the economic development of East Asia and has its own unique stance, " Ma said.

He explained that as Taipei's mayor, he is nevertheless concerned about issues that involve the nation because as the capital, Taipei's industrial and service sectors will both be affected if Taiwan is marginalized.

Ma is scheduled to deliver a speech on the growth of mainland China and its effects on Asia Tuesday at the summit, and will join in a discussion with experts from Hong Kong, mainland China and Singapore.
Ma had said that he wanted to use the forum to meet more experts from East Asian countries and learn more about their thoughts.

This is the third time that Ma has been invited to address the annual East Asia Economic Summit meeting. He failed to attend the first two meetings due to a typhoon that hit Taiwan and a mayoral election, respectively.

The East Asia Economic Summit, organized by the World Economic Forum in cooperation with the Singapore Economic Development Board, brings together regional business leaders, senior government officials, media representatives and experts on trade and economics to discuss topics related to regional business trends and the investment climate.
A total of 800 participants from 32 countries are attending this year's meeting with "Asia's future: Recapturing dynamism" as its theme.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN ARRIVES IN TAIWAN ON FACT-FINDING VISIT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen arrived in Taipei Monday for a weeklong visit.
This is Shaheen's first visit to Taiwan since assuming the AIT post late last year as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Upon her arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Shaheen said that she was glad to visit Taiwan and had come with "admiration, " hoping to gain a first-hand understanding of the current situation.
Shaheen said she will travel to Hualien to meet with Master Cheng Yen, who heads Taiwan's largest charity organization -- the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.
The AIT chairwoman said that as far as she knows, Cheng Yen is similar to India's Mother Teresa in that both women have contributed a great deal to the world.

Shaheen said that during her stay, she will also call on President Chen Shui-bian and meet with political and business leaders, as well as hold a seminar with students from National Taiwan University, to get a better understanding of the views of the Taiwan people.

Chen Chien-jen, Republic of China epresentative to the United States, said earlier that Shaheen has a keen interest in the Tzu Chi operations as she was involved in Indochinese and Afghan refugee relief work in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Shaheen was Asia regional director for the Tokyo-based Refugee International during that period. Her main missions were raising funds for refugees in the then-Soviet-occupied Afghanistan and for displaced Vietnamese and Cambodian people during border conflicts between their two countries. Her work also included helping improve living conditions in refugee camps in those countries as well as repatriation of refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: More work, fast payment for builders.
The construction industry was thrown two lifelines over the weekend - one offering SIN$600 million (US$342 million) of much-needed work, and the other, some certainty of getting paid for projects done and of being paid faster too. The moves promise to not just help the flailing building sector but, more importantly, to also make it less likely that people will be left in the lurch because their home is delayed as the contractor has collapsed under the weight of his debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES NETHERLANDS WILL ATTACH IMPORTANCE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Monday that the Netherlands will attach importance to its relations with Taiwan and not tilt too much toward mainland China.
The president made the remarks when he met with Henk De Haan, chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the Dutch parliament.

Chen noted that Taiwan's trade exchanges and business cooperation with the Netherlands are very close and added that the country is a very important trading partner for Taiwan, with bilateral trade amounting to US$5.2 billion last year, of which Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$1.5 billion.
He noted that the Netherlands is Taiwan's second-largest trading partner in Europe and that Taiwan is the Netherlands' fifth-largest importer, as well as the second-largest exporter.

Taiwan's investment in the Netherlands amounts to US$250 million, or the nation's second-largest in Europe. In comparison, the Netherlands has invested US$2.34 billion in Taiwan, the largest amount of any European country's investment in Taiwan.

The president said that there is still room for expansion in terms of bilateral business exchanges and trade cooperation, and added that "we hope very much that Dutch officials, especially trade and economic ministers, can visit Taiwan."

Chen noted that the Dutch foreign minister will assume the post of NATO secretary-general and that the Dutch government will also serve as the rotational chairman of the European Union in the second half of next year.
With the growing influence of the Netherlands, the president expressed the hope that the country will seriously consider its policies toward Taiwan and the mainland.
The Netherlands has full diplomatic relations with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PROPOSES MEETING ON DIPLOMATIC STRATEGY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu proposed President Chen Shui-bian Monday call a high-profile meeting to draw up a diplomatic strategy in the face of the relentless diplomatic offensive from Beijing.

Lu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters about the suspension of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Liberia after attending a rehearsal at the Government Information Office of a troupe of children who were about to depart on a tour of the U. S. and Central America to demonstrate traditional children's games.

In view of the fierce competition lying ahead, Lu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs must brace for challenges with new thinking and new drive. "That is the main reason behind my proposal to the president for the meeting, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: I won't allow higher taxes.
Tony blair gives warning to Gordon Brown and the rest of the Cabinet today that he is opposed to higher taxes, insisting that they would damage competitiveness against countries such as China and India.
Financial Times: Baghdad car bombs hit Bush's Iraq hopes.
The White House faced deepenign problems over Iraq yesterday as two powerful car bombs exploded outside a central Baghdad hotel used by coalition officials, killing at least six Iraqis and wounding a further 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE VISIT AIR FORCE ACADEMY

TEXT.P: More than 5,000 overseas Chinese who returned to Taiwan to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, visited the Chinese Air Force Academy in Kaohsiung County's Kangshan township in southern Taiwan Monday.
They were warmly greeted by the academy's faculty members and cadets.
Air Force Deputy Commander-in-Chief Lt. Gen. Feng Shih-kuang said in a welcoming speech that he admires the visitors for their patriotism.

"Over the past decades, whenever our country encounters adversities and challenges, overseas Chinese people have never hesitated to extend a helping hand by either donating funds or offering volunteer services to promote the nation's cause," Feng said.

An exhibition of air force arsenal was held on the academy's campus to offer the visitors a rare glimpse into Taiwan's new generation of warplanes and weaponry systems, including locally built Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters, U.S.-made F-16s, French-made Mirages, anti-submarine helicopters and sophisticated missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL SELF-RESTRAINT ONLY HOPE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TIES: KMT CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mutual self-restraint is the only way to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait until the two sides can find a more effective political and legal framework to address their disputes, a visiting Taiwan opposition leader said in London Sunday.

Addressing the opening session of a Cambridge University-sponsored seminar on regional security, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said that while the United States has played an important role in maintaining peace and stability in East Asia over the past few decades, self-restraint shown by the countries in the region should also be credited for the achievement.

For example, Lien said, the Taiwan Strait has remained largely peaceful over the past several decades because the two sides have exercised self-restraint. Against that backdrop, he went on, mainland China has been able to carry out market reforms and Taiwan has managed to enjoy economic prosperity, to withstand two oil crises and an Asian financial fiasco, and to complete its democratization process.

However, Lien said the self-restraint has gradually weakened since the mainland conducted a series of live-fire military exercises and test-fired missiles into the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to the island's first-ever direct presidential election in 1996.
More worrisome to him, Lien said, is that three adverse tendencies have emerged since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in Taiwan in May 2000.

According to Lien, the three adverse developments are mainland China's intensified military buildup, Taiwan's prolonged economic doldrums and what he said is the DPP administration's failure to adopt a more prudent and moderate approach in dealing with cross-strait affairs.

Lien, who will team up with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid in the 2004 presidential election, said if he wins next year, his administration, while countering Beijing's military threat and political pressure, will avoid provoking the mainland, in order to maintain regional peace and stability.
Lien, a former vice president, arrived in London Saturday for a speaking tour in the company of Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang and several former ROC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC HEAD WANTS TO QUIT FOR HEALTH REASONS

TEXT.P: The head of the state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said Monday that he wants to resign for health reasons and he expressed the hope that there will be no random speculation on his reasons for quitting.
CSBC Chairman Hsu Chiang said that he recently told Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu about his desire to return to his teaching job at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

"For the simple reasons that I have high blood pressure and have accomplished my mission at this stage, " Hsu said, referring to his part in bringing the company's revenue from red into the black, as well as his hand in helping with the company's approaching goal of privatization.
Hsu denied reports that he was bailing out of the company or that there were political considerations behind his decision.
He was responding to reports speculating that as a second-generation mainland Chinese, he is worried about having to take sides in next year's presidential election.

The mass-circulation China Times also claimed that a policy to build submarines for the nation's military -- which has not received clear support from the government -- coupled with an as-yet-realized promise by the Executive Yuan to appropriate NT$2 billion (US$59.3 million) to improve the financial structure of the CSBC have also contributed to discouraging Hsu and making him want to return to teaching.

The reports noted that the CSBC is being privatized and is scheduled to sell its Keelung and Kaohsiung plants, and that MPH, a consortium of arms manufacturers in the United States, is interested in bidding for the Kaohsiung plant and is sending an official to Taiwan this week to discuss the matter with the CSBC.

Hsu said that this May he had been extremely busy and that he was preoccupied with communications with the MPH and other parties interested in investing in the CSBC. Because of time zone differences, he often had to work at night, which caused his blood pressure to shoot up dramatically.

Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, who concurrently serves as the chairman of the nation's top economic agency, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that Hsu had expressed his wish to return to teaching several months ago, but said the Ministry of Economic Affairs which is in charge of administrating all state-owned enterprises, is hoping to "retain him as best we can."

Last year, the CSBC was involved in a fraud scandal that led then-Chairman Yu Chang-nan to step down. Hsu was invited to take over his job and he vowed at the time to get the company out of the red quickly.

Statistics provided by the Commission of National Corporations show that the accumulated losses of the CSBC reached NT$11 billion at one time and the company was on the brink of bankruptcy in 2001. After the implementation of a rejuvenation plan, the CSBC turned the corner last year, recording pre-tax profits of NT$350 million.

Since international shipping is on the rebound, the CSBC has earned profits of nearly NT$300 million in the first eight months of this year, and is forecast to record profits of NT$360 million for the whole year.
Orders for new vessels have reached more than 40, which will keep the company fully booked until 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY WARNS AGAINST HIRING ILLEGAL FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Taipei County Labor Affairs Bureau warned local employers Monday not to hire illegal foreign workers or those on the run, or face fines of at least of NT$150,000 (US$4,477).

The bureau issued the warning in response to the fact that a number of such cases were recently discovered in the county. It stressed that employers must verify the identity of any foreign workers they plan to hire beforehand.
According to the bureau, one of the latest cases concerned an Indonesian worker, who turned herself in to the bureau and accused her boss of holding on to her salary and her passport.

However, the bureau and police discovered that the woman's broker had lied to the authorities that she had absconded from her previous job and he then got her various other jobs working illegally in the cities of Panchiao and Hsintien, as well as in neighboring Taipei City.

According to police, the woman had originally been hired by a local woman surnamed Yu to take care of her elderly and sick father. But Yu's father died before the woman arrived in Taiwan, so Yu told the broker that she could not hire the woman and instructed the broker to make sure the woman was sent back to Indonesia.
However, the broker failed to report the case to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , but said instead that the woman had absconded, which allowed him to assign her illegal jobs.
When the case came to light, the woman was repatriated and banned from entering Taiwan again, while the boss found to have illegally hired her was fined NT$150,000.

The bureau warned local employers verify the identity of potential foreign hires before employing them. When the contract expires, the employer must instruct the broker report the case to the CLA to help the foreign worker legally transfer to a new job or leave Taiwan, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LOSE COMPETITIVE EDGE IF DRAGGING FEET ON REFORM: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday if Taiwan drags its feet on sweeping reforms, it will lose its competitive edge and its sustainable development will also be at stake.
Chen issued the warning at a ceremony marking the inauguration of a preparatory office for a planned independent agency to regulate telecommunications and broadcasting services.
Noting that the time has changed, Chen said, many existing concepts, systems and regulations, including the constitutional framework, have become obsolete.

"We need to make an overall review to determine whether our existing institutions and rules should be updated and how the reforms should be carried out," Chen said, adding that if Taiwan fails to take swift reform steps, it won't be able to maintain its niches in the highly competitive global market.
With fast progress and popularization of digital technology, Chen said, previous concepts and supervisory provisions for communications and broadcasting services can no longer meet the market demand.

"Many advanced countries have thus adjusted their regulatory organizations, policies and operational rules to cope up the prevailing trend of integration of Internet, television and mobile communication services," Chen said.

In line with this trend, he said, the government has decided to to enact a new communications and broadcasting basic law and set up a "National Communications Commission" to administer and supervise all telecommunications and TV broadcasting services.

"The moves are aimed at creating an environment for fair competition among local operators, enhancing their competitiveness in the world market, upgrading the service quality and better protecting consumers' rights," Chen said.

He said the government has already referred to the Legislative Yuan a draft communications and broadcasting services basic bill and a draft National Communications Commission organic bill for approval.

"I earnestly hopes that the opposition-controlled legislature can pass the two bills as early as possible to facilitate a necessary overhaul of our telecommunications and broadcasting services regulatory systems and operational rules," Chen said.

According to his administration's six-year "Challenge 2008" national development plan, Chen said, the government will boost the development of information and communication technologies and expand the number of broadband subscribers to 6 million in six years.

Under the terms of the draft organic bill, the National Communications Commission will integrate several existing government agencies, including the Directorate General of Telecommunications and the Government Information Office's broadcasting and television department.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THREATENS TO SUE PRESIDENT CHEN AFTER HE STEPS DOWN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is consulting with lawyers to sue President Chen Shui-bian after over his claims that Beijing is secretly helping the KMT and People First Party (PFP) in the 2004 presidential election.

Tsai Cheng-yuan, a spokesman for the KMT, said the charge will be brought against Chen after May 20 next year when he fails to win re-election and steps down from the presidency, as the law shelters the president from any legal charges except for treason and sabotage.
Tsai said more than 10 lawyers have agreed to take the case jointly.

The spokesman made the remarks after KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who is on a tour of Europe, challenged the president earlier in the day in London to come up with evidence to substantiate an accusation he made in an interview with the Washington Post.
Chen's office didn't respond to the KMT's threats, but officials and lawmakers of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have come out to defend the president.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said Beijing is not helping the KMT and PFP secretly; rather, it is helping them openly.

Yeh Yi-ching, director for the DPP's Department for Women's Affairs said KMT and PFP supporters solicited votes from the two parties at a dinner party hosted recently by officials of Fujian province for Taiwan businessmen working there.
Another KMT spokesman, Chou Sho-hsun, dismissed the claims as groundless, saying that what certain Taiwan businessmen do has nothing to do with the KMT.

DPP lawmaker Chen Ching-chun, citing what he called much common ground in the views of Beijing and the two opposition parties, ridiculed the KMT and the PFP as "a blind person eating dumplings knows in his mind what it is."

Chen gave the interview in Taipei on Oct. 6. The Washington Post published the full text of the interview Saturday after Chen's office denied part of a story based on the interview published Oct. 7 by the Post.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM LEGISLATION NOT INDISPENSABLE PREREQUISITE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that referendum legislation is not necessarily a prerequisite for holding referendums on major public policy issues.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with five scholars and experts from the United States, Germany, Switzerland and Sweden who are currently in Taipei to attend an international seminar on direct democracy and popular rights to initiative and referendum.

While referendums have been implemented in Western countries for many years as a form of direct democracy and have even become part of their daily lives, Chen said, referendums largely remain taboo in Taiwan.

For example, Chen told his guests that his administration's plan to hold a referendum either before or on the day of the nation's next presidential election -- March 20, 2004 -- on the fate of the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and several other public issues has drawn mixed reactions and even triggered heated debate.
To the best of his understanding, Chen said, not all countries that have allowed their people to exercise their right to a referendum have enacted a law to regulate relevant procedures.

"Many countries have held referendums on the introduction of new constitutions or constitutional amendments, and one thing is clear that not all of them have legislated a referendum law, " Chen explained.
In his view, Chen said, people's right to vote in a referendum should take precedence over referendum legislation by their elected representatives.

Noting that a nation's power comes from its people, Chen said if the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, while insisting on the need of legislating a referendum bill as a prerequisite for holding a referendum, drags its feet on completing such legislation, the people of Taiwan should be allowed to hold a referendum on whether such a bill is needed and what its provisions should be.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS URGE GOVERNMENT TO REVIEW DIPLOMATIC DIRECTION

TEXT.P: Several legislators said Monday that the Republic of China need not feel bad about severing diplomatic ties with Liberia, but they urged the government to review its diplomatic direction.
The legislators made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in the wake of the Republic of China's breaking off of diplomatic relations with the West African state of Liberia.

Former Minister of Foreign Affairs and legislator of the opposition Kuomintang John Chang said that one should not feel sad about breaking with Liberia, but he criticized the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) for blaming everything on mainland China.
Chang said that MOFA's relations with many African countries have often hinged on a single man, and he pointed out that many African national leaders are selfish, thinking only of themselves.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said that although the Republic of China's relations with 26 countries are stable, some relations may change, adding that the opposition party in El Salvador has said that if they are in power, they will sever ties with the ROC.
Chang questioned Chien's words that the ROC's diplomatic relations with the remaining 26 allies are stable, saying that "a lot of them are in danger."

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party also said that if a country only wants things from Taiwan, then such a diplomatic relation is not worthwhile, especially because former Liberian President Charles Taylor is a war criminal and has a bad international image.

"Therefore, Taiwan does not look bad by severing ties with such a country, " she said, adding that the nation should instead make efforts to maintain relations with countries like Senegal, which have better images.

Legislator Parris Chang of the DPP said: "Trading off diplomatic relations with economic assistance is no breakthrough in terms of diplomatic work, " adding that to establish diplomatic relations with countries in Scandinavia and Western Europe will be significant.
Chang reiterated that he had not advocated establishing diplomatic relations just for the sake of adding more "diplomatic allies" since the DPP government came to power in May 2000.

KMT Legislator Sun Kuo-hua suggested the passing of a resolution to condemn mainland China for pressuring Liberia to break its ties with the ROC, using its stance in the United Nations' Security Council.
He also asked MOFA to come up with countermeasures and asked how the ministry is going to settle bad loans with Liberia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC OFFERING 18 MAJOR INVESTMENT PROJECTS FOR FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is offering 18 investment projects for foreign investors to allow foreign capital and technologies access into Taiwan's infrastructure development, a ranking MOTC official said Monday.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chia-chu said the 18 investment projects -- including the development of exclusive areas of the soon-to-be-built high-speed railway, electronic toll booths along freeway systems, and the electrical engineering work in the planned MRT system connecting Taipei City and Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- will allow foreign companies opportunities to cooperate with local businesses in Taiwan.

Chang denied allegations made by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lee Hung-jun that all those 18 investment projects are only "money-making" opportunities for foreign companies, rather than "investment opportunities" which will in turn benefit economic and industrial development in Taiwan in the long run.

The 18 investment projects that the MOTC offered also include the development of an air cargo transportation complex in Taoyuan near the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the building of a freeway system in eastern Taiwan, the development of the Peiyi Freeway connecting Taipei and the eastern county of Ilan, the expansion of Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung international seaports and the building of warehouse districts on those three areas, as well as the development of five new tourist attractions around the island.

The MOTC made the offer in line with a series of investment projects that the Executive Yuan has recently mapped out to be formally announced during an investment promotion conference -- the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference -- slated to take place Oct. 19-22.

The high-profile international symposium -- aimed at prompting a worldwide wave of investment in Taiwan to help improve infrastructure and increase the country's investment incentives -- is being sponsored by the Executive Yuan and organized jointly by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the China External Trade Development Council and the Central News Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST EXPAND TIES WITH EAST ASIAN COUNTRIES: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan must step up contacts and exchanges with East Asian countries to avoid being marginalized or isolated at a time when regional economic integration is a prevailing world trend, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.
Ma made the remarks prior to his departure for Singapore to attend the 12th East Asia Economic Summit which opened in the Southeast Asian city state Sunday.

As ASEAN member economies and major East Asian countries, including Japan and mainland China, have decided to strengthen economic cooperation and remove their trade barriers, Ma said, Taiwan should make every possible effort to beef up ties with all those countries to avoid being marginalized.

Ma is scheduled to deliver a speech at a panel session Tuesday morning. In his address, Ma said, he'll tout Taipei's potential of becoming an Asia-Pacific regional operations hub and recap Taiwan's contributions to regional economic development over the past decades.
Ma said he especially hopes that Taiwan business people operating in mainland China can use Taipei as their operations hub.
This is the third time that Ma has been invited to address the annual East Asia Economic Summit meeting. Ma failed to attend the first two meetings due to a typhoon and a mayoral election.

The East Asia Economic Summit, organized by the World Economic Forum in cooperation with the Singapore Economic Development Board, brings together regional business leaders, senior government officials, media representatives and experts on trade and economy to discuss topics related to regional business trends and investment climate.

A total of 800 participants from 32 countries are attending this year's meeting with "Asia's future: Recapturing dynamism" as its theme. Singapore's Prime Minister Goh Chok-Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan-Yew will deliver keynote speeches at the summit.

TEXT.P: Most members of the Central Election Commission believe that if a national referendum is to be held in tandem with the up-coming presidential election, a legal basis for the referendum would be desirable, chairman of the commission Huang Shih-cheng said Monday at the Legislative Yuan.

Huang made the remarks when asked by legislators about the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's proposal to hold a nationwide referendum together with the presidential election on March 20, 2004. The country does not have a referendum law at the present time.
The commission needs a legal basis to budget for and carry out a referendum, he explained.
When asked whether it is illegal for the commission to hold a referendum without a legal basis, he declined to answer. He only said, "We won't do anything illegally."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 13, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
2001: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan prompts the Central Bank of China (CBC) to add two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish fake bills from real ones.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO REVAMP CONSTITUTION HAS COME: CHEN

TEXT.P: The time has come for the nation to revamp the ROC Constitution to meet the practical needs of Taiwan society and deepen the country's democratization, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

As the president of the Republic of China, Chen said, it is his duty and responsibility to come up with a comprehensive plan on constitutional reform for the people to concertedly review and pave the way for the birth of a new constitution, Chen said during a speech at the National Central Library.

Addressing the opening of the International Conference on Government Reform and the Civil Service System, Chen said that a nationwide referendum will be held later this year or early next year for the people to vote on whether to write and implement a new constitution.

Chen said that the existing ROC Constitution came out of a different political and social era of instability and was designed to unite the 490 million Chinese people of the time. He said it has for long been unsuitable for Taiwan and its people, prompting him to push for a new one to better cope with the present realities.

Over the past few years, he said, the ruling and opposition parties and the general public have repeatedly pointed out that the current constitutional framework and the government system it mandates are insufficient to meet Taiwan's practical needs.

He pointed out that past constitutional amendments were restricted by special circumstances of the time and environment, and were only able to address specific issues through partial adjustments. Not only was it impossible to realize a complete plan for a constitutional government, but even more so, many problems were left unresolved, thus seriously undermining the quality of Taiwan's democracy and the efficiency of the government, he added.

While working on rewriting the constitution, Chen said, matters pertaining to the limits of government power, the roles of the central and local governments, basic human rights and fundamental national policies will all be examined and discussed.
About 250 academics and government officials are taking part in the International Conference on Government Reform and Civil Service System sponsored by the Examination Yuan.

Two dignitaries from abroad have been invited to deliver keynote speeches during the two-day conference. Professor Deborah R. Hensler from Stanford University's law school is scheduled to speak on the subject of "Examination and Selection System of Legal Professionals," while Dr. Udo Bartsch, president of the Federal Academy of Public Administration of Germany's Federal Ministry of the Interior, is slated to speak on the topic of "Senior Civil Servant Training System," according to the sponsor.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS FORESEEN: AIT CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: Direct trade, transport and postal links will be set up in a foreseeable future between Taiwan and mainland China, visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen predicted Tuesday.

Giving a speech on Taiwan's economic future to members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, Shaheen said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will eventually come up with feasible measures to open the links for their mutual benefit, because "money talks."
In addition, the mainland authorities will know the timing for when best to conduct negotiations with Taiwan if President Chen Shui-bian succeeds in his re-election bid next year, Shaheen said.

Describing Taiwan as "the tailor for mainland China's economy, " Shaheen hailed the island's remarkable contributions to the economic development of the mainland and the rest of Asia, and attributed the mainland's expanding economic clout in part to Taiwan's steady investment.

Turning to the issue of Taiwan's efforts to protect U.S. intellectual property rights (IPR) , the AIT chief said she does not expect that Taipei will move toward greater improvements in this regard, as all eyes will be on the approaching presidential election of next March.
Taiwan must display greater commitment to IPR protection and to the implementation of its obligations under the World Trade Organization (WTO), she said.

"In addition to the faithful implementation of its WTO obligations, Taiwan also needs to continue to liberalize trade in goods and services as well as insure the highest level of IPR protection and enforcement, " she noted.
But she stressed that Washington will ask Taipei in strong terms to step up its IPR efforts after the presidential race has ended.

In the face of the mainland's fast economic development, Shaheen said she is optimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects and contended that Taiwan will know very well which path to take in its interaction with the mainland.

Nevertheless, she also warned that Taiwan could encounter harsh economic challenges in the coming 15 or 20 years as the mainland economy increases in stature and weight, should a significant economic recovery be absent in Taiwan.

"The United States stands ready and willing to listen to Taiwan's concerns as it moves along this path and assist where possible, to help revitalize Taiwan's economy and restore Taiwanese self-confidence," she concluded.
The top U.S. liaison official in charge of Taiwan affairs arrived Monday in Taipei for a week-long visit. It is her first visit to Taiwan since she assumed the post late last year.

The businessmen, mainly from the United States and Japan, have confirmed a total of 113 investment projects worth a combined NT$68.21 billion (US$2 billion) and have promised to invest in another 73 projects worth NT$70.16 billion, the officials noted.

The would-be foreign investors are particularly interested in image displaying, optoelectronics, semiconductors, micro-electronics, biotechnology, medical and health services, machinery, telecommunications, financial and insurance services, they added.
The conference, sponsored by the Executive Yuan and jointly organized by the MOEA, the China External Trade Development Council and the Central News Agency, is aimed at soliciting foreign investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS UP TASK FORCE TO PUSH FOR NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) set up a nine-member task force Tuesday to push for a new constitution, and named law professor Lee Hung-hsi as its convener.

In a weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, President Chen Shui-bian, who serves concurrently as DPP chairman, approved the motion to form the task force that will attempt to fulfill his promise to push for a new constitution by 2006.

The group will be composed of scholars and high-ranking government and DPP officials, including Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chiou I-jen, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen.

Lee, a professor at National Taiwan University, said in a recent interview with the Central News Agency that the Constitution, which went into effect in 1947, was not suitable for Taiwan even when it was first set out, while the political changes of the last two decades has made it even more irrelevant.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said that the main job of the task force will be draw up the content of the new constitution, plan out the itinerary of the push for the new constitution, and communicate with the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN ECONOMIST UNVEILS STRATEGY FOR IMPROVING TAIWAN ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, vice president of the Legislative Yuan and a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , unveiled Monday a five-point strategy to improve Taiwan's economy, focusing on lifting Taiwan's role in innovation and as a business operations hub.
Chiang made the comments while giving a speech at a seminar held at Oxford University about Taiwan's economic situation and the new environment in Asia.

To effectively lift Taiwan's economy, Chiang said, it is important that Taiwan finds a niche in the value-added production chain, strengthens its R&D and innovation, builds itself into a global business operations center, steps up labor division in cooperation with mainland China and takes part in regional trade organizations.

Pointing out that the mainland is quickly emerging as an economic power, Chiang said Taiwan has come under mounting pressure to avoid becoming an outcast in Asia at a time when the formation of bilateral and multilateral agreements is set to boom in the region as a result of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's inability to promote investment and trade liberalization.
As the mainland is increasingly becoming a factory for the world, as well as a huge market, Chiang said that these factors will have a great impact on the development of East Asian economies.

Citing statistics compiled by the United Nations, the mainland has continuously been the leading country among the developing nations in terms of attracting foreign investment over the past 10 years. In 2002, as much as US$52.7 billion in foreign capital was channeled into the country, replacing the U.S. as the world's top receiver of foreign capital.

At the same time, Taiwan capital was also entering the mainland at a fast pace, he noted. From 1952 through 2001, mainland-bound investment accounted for 38.82 percent of Taiwan's total foreign-bound capital, he said, adding that the ratio had increased to 66.61 percent by 2002.

According to tallies released by mainland authorities, Taiwan businesses have so far realized a total of 55,691 investment plans on the mainland worth more than US$33.1 billion, he went on. However, it is widely assumed that the actual figure could have exceeded US$50 billion.

Taiwan's mainland-bound investment mainly goes to the electronics and the home appliance sectors, making the mainland a major manufacturing base for the two important domestic industries, the ex-CEPD chief said.
On the other hand, the mainland has also become Taiwan's largest export market, absorbing 25 percent of the island's total outbound shipments.

Since the levels of Taiwan's imports from the mainland are relatively low, the island has been enjoying a comfortable trade surplus with the other side of the Taiwan Strait over the past few decades, Chiang said.

The mainland's rise has pushed Taiwan toward capital- and technology-intensive sectors, he explained, detailing that the percentage of Taiwan's exports of technological products grew from 26.7 percent of its total in the 1990s to the current 46.6 percent.

Attributing Taiwan's economic slowdown in recent years to the global situation and political instability at home, the veteran economist suggested that the government take broad measures in a wide range of fields to pursue progress, including setting up direct cross-strait links, further opening the domestic market to mainland investors and tourists, and joining regional free trade pacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN VISITS DPP HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the U.S. Democratic National Committee visited the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) headquarters Tuesday, where he exchanged views on matters of mutual concern with DPP officials.

Terry McAuliffe was warmly greeted by DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan and Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, director of the International Affairs Department, upon his arriving at the DPP offices.

Those present at the closed-door meeting that followed declined to reveal details of their discussions. Answering questions raised by reporters after the meeting on his views on President Chen Shui-bian's recent proposal to rewrite Taiwan's constitution, McAuliffe said only that it is an internal affair. Chen doubles as the DPP chairman.
McAuliffe, who arrived in Taiwan for a goodwill visit three days ago, also met that day with a group of Taiwan scholars at the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies in Taipei.
During the meeting, McAuliffe told the scholars that his party has long maintained good relations with Taiwan and sees the country as a democratic model for Asian nations.

McAuliffe, who served as the national financial chairman for the re-election bids of former U.S. President Bill Clinton and Vice President Al Gore in 1996, met Chen a day earlier. No details of the meeting were revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN LEGISLATURE APPROVES FTA WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and EH)

TEXT.P: Panamanian government leaders in charge of commercial and agricultural affairs were happy about the approval of the Taiwan-Panamanian free trade agreement Monday by the Panamanian Legislative Assembly.

Speaker Jacobo Salas of the Legislative Assembly said Panamanian farmers, ranchers and animal feed producers will benefit significantly from the agreement. The agreement will also help promote the economic development in the inner parts of the country, he added.

Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome said the agreement can serve as a springboard for traders of the two countries to develop their foreign markets. The agreement will help Taiwan traders sell their products to Latin America through Panama, and help Panamanian exporters send their products to Asia through Taiwan, he explained.

Minister of Agricultural Development Lynette Stanziola said Panamanian farmers will benefit greatly from the agreement. He also expressed his gratitude to Taiwan for sending specialists to help his country promote agricultural development.
The agreement, jointly signed by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his Panamanian counterpart Mireya Moscoso in Taipei Aug. 21, is expected to come into force Jan. 1, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATM THEFT MUST BE STOPPED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun Tuesday instructed Finance Minister Lin Chuan and Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien to resolve the problems of theft via ATM machines.

Bank customers in the southern city of Tainan first reported last week that money had gone missing from their Bank of Taiwan accounts, while customers of other banks made similar reports in later days.

Upon investigation, police have found hidden cameras and IC chips at several ATMs in recent days, which are allegedly used by criminals to scan the ATM card data of the victims, allowing them to duplicate the cards and withdraw money from the victims' accounts.
The number of victims and the total amount of money stolen in this way had yet to be ascertained.

Yu told the authorities to catch the criminals, find effective ways to prevent this type of crime and compensate the victims for their losses as soon as possible. Any negligence on the part of officials that made it possible for the criminals to carry out their operations should also be punished, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT CONCLUDES WHIRLWIND VISIT

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore concluded a one-day whirlwind visit to Taiwan Tuesday after attending an international conference on security and technology.
Gore, who arrived in Taipei a day earlier, was a keynote speaker at Tuesday's 37th International Carnahan Conference on Security and Technology.
Foreign Minister Eugene Chien accompanied Gore to the airport at the end of the visit and talked with him for about one hour. Details of their conversation were not revealed.

At the conference, Gore stressed the importance of making good use of the information already available and of always keeping alert, which he said is even more important than collecting more information.
He noted that it was not until the 911 terrorist attack in 2001 that the whole world began to pay more attention to security.

Gore stressed that some tragedies can be avoided if precautionary measures are adopted, citing the example of the 911 terrorist attacks. Gore noted that two of the men who made the suicide attacks on the United States were already being looked for by both the CIA and the FBI.

He touted the Carnahan Conference on Security and Technology, which brought together more than 400 specialists in security technology from 14 countries, as a very important seminar on security. However, Gore added that what is needed is not more information, but more efficient ways of using information that is already available.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS ISSUE JOINT STATEMENT CONDEMNING BEIJING

TEXT.P: Legislators across the political spectrum issued a joint statement Tuesday condemning mainland China, claiming that it used its key position in the United Nations to pressure Liberia to sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

The legislators said in the statement that they lodged a strong protest and urged the Executive Yuan to unite all its resources to fight against the diplomatic squeezing by the People's Republic of China.

The joint statement was co-signed by caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Kuomintang, the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Alliance of Independent Legislators.

It was confirmed Sunday that Liberia had switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) severed relations with the West African state shortly afterward.
MOFA officials said it is regrettable that Liberia's interim government made the decision to switch diplomatic recognition in spite of all the ROC did to save the bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD TIME A CHARM FOR ROC TORPEDO TEST AS TARGET SUNK

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Navy submarine successfully fired a torpedo at a target ship Tuesday in a drill held off Pingtung, southern Taiwan, the navy reported.

After the decommissioned target destroyer was sunk, ROC Navy Commander-in- chief Miao Yung-ching said the navy's confidence had been restored. He was referring to a similar test firing last month that failed to hit the target ship and the fact that the first try earlier Tuesday was also a failure.
Miao also said he would look into the cause of the two previous failures.

Lin Cheng-yi, head of the ROC Navy Fleet Command as well as the commander of the drill, confirmed that a torpedo fired at 1,571 meters below the sea from a Dutch-built Sea Dragon submarine Tuesday morning failed to hit its target.
The torpedo is designed to lose electrical power 53 minutes after firing and would therefore not pose any threat to fishermen or ships operating nearby, Lin said.
The navy arranged for the Sea Dragon submarine to test fire another torpedo at 2 p.m., but three fishing boats transgressed into the area and the drill was postponed for nearly 30 minutes.

The submarine was able to launch the torpedo at 2:25 p.m. and hit its target -- a decommissioned Yang-class destroyer -- eight minutes after the firing. The destroyer sank and will be used to attract fish as an artificial shelf.
Tuesday morning, the ROC Air Force and Navy conducted two other successful firings.

Three Mirage-2000 fighters took off from the Hsinchu Air Base at 8: 10 a.m. Tuesday and one of the aircraft fired an MICA missile at a propeller-driven target drone designed by the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), making a direct hit. The test was conducted not far from the outlying islands of Penghu.
After the successful downing of the target drone, the marines also test-fired an anti-air shrapnel missile, which successfully hit its target drone, also designed by the CIST.

Last month the ROC Navy test-fired a German-made SUT-type torpedo launched from a locally built Chengkung-class missile frigate during a training exercise in waters off Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, but the torpedo missed its target. It was eventually recovered on Ilan beach. Tuesday's drill was meant partially to overcome the previous month's failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAIN RAMS TOUR BUS; THREE DEAD, 38 INJURED

TEXT.P: A train rammed a tour bus filled with junior high students in Yingko, northern Taiwan Tuesday, killing three and injuring 38.

The level crossing where the mishap occurred, the scene of a similar accident last year, was too narrow for the bus to cross together with a truck that had entered the intersection at the same time during morning rush hour traffic, according to preliminary reports by the Taiwan Railway Administration. The bus driver apparently asked the truck driver to back up out of the level crossing so that the bus could continue, when the train slammed into the bus.
The tour bus was carrying students from Yulin Junior High School in Shulin on a graduation trip.

Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang rushed to the hospital immediately after being notified of the accident. Su urged the central government to designate a budget to improve the design of many level crossings around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS ADVISE CAUTION ON SELECTION OF PRESIDENTIAL RUNNING MATE

TEXT.P: More than a dozen legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) representing various factions offered a joint statement Tuesday with their suggestions on the issue of who President Chen Shui-bian's running mate should be in the presidential election next year.

The president has kept the public in suspense for months about his running mate, saying only that the matter could wait until a party congress in December, although the president seemed to have tipped his hand when he recently appealed for the public to support him and Vice President Annette Lu again in the election. The president's words were interpreted as his wish to maintain the status quo.

The DPP legislators stressed in the statement that the presidential election next year is crucial in terms of "the future of the DPP and Taiwan, " and they expressed the hope that the president, who concurrently serves as the DPP chairman, will "solicit views from all walks of life" and act "cautiously."

They said that they believe that President Chen's vice presidential candidate should meet the following three conditions: to meet the expectations of the general public, to contribute to the popularity of the president, and to coordinate well with the president.

Legislator Lai Chin-lin said that the 2004 presidential election will not only determine whether the DPP will continue to be in power, but will be crucial to whether Taiwan can deepen its democracy, continue its reforms and give a clear direction of the nation's future.
The choice of Lu would be a major factor affecting the result of the election, and the statement co-signed by the DPP factions advised the president to "cautiously consider his decision, " Lai said.

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim said that legislators did not expressly advocate a specific candidate in the statement, but since there is currently a "cacophony" concerning the choice, the legislators felt that it was time to forge a consensus within the party.
Responding to the three conditions, Vice President Lu said that they are "good and correct," and that if the legislators approach her to sign the statement she is "willing to do so."
Meanwhile, several other DPP legislators said Tuesday that the law should be revised to stipulate that either the president or the vice president should be a woman.
Legislator Wei Ming-ku said that this idea is in reaction to the calls by the opposition "pan-blue alliance," - the Kuomintang and People First Party - for more woman members in the cabinet.

Wei said that the concept is to increase the profile of the participation of women in politics, but that this does not mean that the legislators endorse current vice president Lu; other woman candidates could be just as suitable.

Legislator Chen Chi-mai, party whip of the DPP caucus, said that before the party congress in December, which will formally nominate the party's candidates for the president and vice president, the DPP will "fully respect" the legislators' advice and their ideal candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: AL GORE EMPHASIZES IMPORTANCE OF PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore stressed the importance of vigilance and precautionary actions to the enhancement of national security Tuesday at the 37th International Carnahan Conference on Security and Technology in Taipei.

He said making good use of existing information is more important than collecting more information about potential dangers to national security. Many tragedies can be avoided, if precautionary steps are taken as soon as signs of danger are discovered.

For example, he said, the terrorist attacks in New York on Sept. 11, 2001 could have been avoided if precautionary actions were taken soon after law enforcement officers discovered that two Middle Eastern men on the FBI's terrorist list bought tickets in August, 2001 to travel on the same flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY, GERMAN ENTITY INK PACT ON SOLAR ENERGY

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu and the German-based Institute for Elektroniske Systemer's (IES) chief executive officer, Uwe Hartmann, inked a memorandum Tuesday on solar energy exchanges.

Praising Germany's experience with solar energy since the 1970s, Fan said Taiwan can learn a lot from Germany in this field and voiced her hope that legislation of relevant laws could clear the Legislative Yuan as soon as possible.
Fan said the promotion of the use of solar energy and other alternative energy sources will be key to transforming Taiwan into a "green Silicon Valley."
For his part, Hartmann said the IES is very willing to help National Taipei University of Technology set up a program on solar energy.

Hartmann and Wolfgang Rosenthal, president of the Solar Energy School affiliated to the IES, also paid a visit to the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to exchange views with officials in charge on issues related to the government's goal of building Taiwan into a homeland free from nuclear power.

Hartmann and Rosenthal arrived in Taiwan on Oct. 9 for a six-day visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Education to promote Taiwan's understanding of solar energy. They are slated to depart Taiwan late Tuesday.
In addition to government agencies, the two German experts also called at various residential communities in which environmental protection, solar energy and rain-gathering facilities are installed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PROPOSE LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WITHDRAW FROM PARTY ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Tuesday that it will propose a change to the Legislative Yuan's rules to prevent the speaker or vice speaker from concurrently serving in a party post or from engaging in party activities.

Liao Pen-yen, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, said that in previous administrations, this situation often gave rise to misgivings among the other political parties that the speakers were more concerned about their own party's interests when presiding over legislative sessions.
Liao said the TSU has taken its cue from the examples of Japan, South Korea and France in deciding to make the proposal.

TSU Legislator Lo chih-ming said the proposal "has nothing to do" with the Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's impending service as the presidential election campaign manager for Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong, chairman of the People First Party.

Noting that the TSU cannot keep Wang from stumping for others outside the Legislative Yuan, Lo said that the TSU caucus respects Wang and hopes that he will help establish the model of neutrality in matters of the legislature.

Noting that Wang said in a recent speech that as a legislative speaker he has had to harmonize the central committee and legislative caucus of his party as well as the caucuses of the other political parties, and that sometimes "it is difficult to avoid being partial," Lo said Wang "should exercise propriety and be a role model during his term."

TSU Legislator Chen Chien-ming said that the Examination Yuan, Judicial Yuan and Control Yuan all have regulations requiring that their speakers and vice speakers withdraw from political party activities, asking why the Legislative Yuan is an exception.

TSU legislators said privately that Vice Legislative Yuan Speaker P.K. Chiang accompanying KMT Chairman Lien on his current visit to Great Britain goes against established practice under the constitution.
They also said that this has left Legislative Yuan President Wang with more work than he can handle.
Both Wang and Chiang concurrently serve as vice chairmen of the KMT.

The TSU legislators noted that the situation in the legislature could become even more chaotic as the presidential election approaches if the regulations aren't put in place regarding the speaker and vice speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 14, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE MAY LENGTHEN SELETAR AIRPORT RUNWAY FOR AIRASIA FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) said Wednesday that it is prepared to lengthen the runway slightly at Seletar Airport if the Malaysian budget carrier AirAsia chooses to use the airport.
It also confirmed that landing fees for all new airlines would be waived for the first two years to help their businesses take off.

AirAsia's chief executive Tony Fernandes had said earlier that the airline wanted to fly out of Seletar Airport rather than Changi Airport because it would be cheaper and would allow the carrier to cut ticket prices.
The CAAS said that even if AirAsia chooses Seletar, the airline could still use Changi as a stop-gap measure until the runway changes are ready.
Local start-up ValuAir said earlier that it would prefer to fly out of Changi, while Singapore Airlines still has not decided whether to start up a budget airline.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEUTSCHE TELEKOM OFFERS TO SELL ITS STATE IN GLOBE TELECOM

TEXT.P: Singapore Telecommunications (SingTel) has announced that Deutsche Telekom has made a new offer to sell its 24.8 percent stake in Globe Telecom to SingTel and Ayala Corp., the Philippines' second largest telephone firm.
SingTel did not disclose the financial details of the offer but said it and Ayala would evaluate the offer and respond within 45 days.
SingTel owns a 29.1-percent stake in Globe Telecom, while Ayala holds a 32.7-percent stake.
Deutsche Telekom previously offered to sell its stake in Globe Telecom in June.
