DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN VISITS LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen visited Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Wednesday to exchange views with him.

Wang told reporters after the meeting that Shaheen is very interested in the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations. He declined to give more details, but said that Shaheen believes that Wang would be a suitable negotiator for Taiwan in talks with mainland China on the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links.

The referendum and writing of a new constitution for Taiwan was not mentioned in his meeting with the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Shaheen arrived in Taipei Oct. 13 for a weeklong fact-finding visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP TO MAKE TAIWAN GLOBAL LOGISTICS CENTER FOR INFORMATION PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) of the United States announced on Wednesday that it will go forward with a plan to develop Taiwan into a global logistics center for information products.
HP made the announcement at a news conference accompanied by representatives of the major airlines in Taiwan, which will become HP's trading partners in the plan.
Duane Zitzner, HP's vice president and general manager of the company's Personal Information Products Group, flew to Taiwan to preside over the news conference.

Zitzner noted that HP is the largest foreign investor in information products in Taiwan and the first one to react to the policy of the Republic of China government to make Taiwan a global operations hub.
He said that at a time when the high-technology industry has its supply chain professionally distributed, HP should have a more efficient administration of its global resources.

Zitzner added that when many companies shifted their assembly and manufacturing operations to mainland China, HP was confident of Taiwan's capability of being a logistics hub. HP will first help Taiwan become its R&D and supply center, and then develop it into a global logistics hub, Zitzner said.
Under the plan, HP can also efficiently reduce the time and cost for merchandise distribution, thus increasing considerably its competitiveness, Zitzner said.

HP officials said that in the first stage the company will cooperate with Taiwan's major airlines, including China Airlines, EVA Airways, and Far East Air Transport Corp., to transport HP products manufactured in eastern mainland China to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau to export them to the global market, which the officials estimated can reduce the transport time from 12 hours to less than 10 hours.

Meanwhile, ROC Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said that many Taiwanese high-tech companies have shifted approximately 70 percent of their production to the eastern part of mainland China. However, the transport capacity there is insufficient; therefore, using Taiwan's logistics capabilities will be the best way to deliver products to the global market, Lin added.
HP officials stressed that under the plan, Taiwan's electronic industry can more efficiently integrate production both on the island and in mainland China, and have a more flexible market deployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTACHES IMPORTANCE TO INVESTMENT PROMOTION CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed all relevant government agencies Wednesday to do everything in their power to make the upcoming 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference a success.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Yu said that the investment-promotion conference, slated for Oct. 19-22 in Taipei, will be the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan and has attracted attention from the international business sector.
President Chen Shui-bian has high hopes for the conference, Yu noted, adding that its success will be helpful for improving Taiwan's image internationally.

The theme of the conference: "Invest in Taiwan, Access the World, " represents both the government's and the business sector's intention to bring Taiwan's economy to another climax by courting more investments from excellent domestic and foreign enterprises, Yu stressed.

According to organizers of the conference, more than 1,780 businessmen from 30 countries have registered to participate in the four-day event which is sponsored by the Executive Yuan and jointly organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, China External Trade Development Council and the Central News Agency.

Foreign participants of the meeting will receive a top quality treatment beginning from their arrival at the airport where specially assigned receptionists will lead them to clear customs and then special service buses or sedans will take them to hotels in Taipei, the organizers said. The special services will be available from Oct. 17, they added.
The organizers will also set up service desks at hotels where foreign guests will stay during the meeting period, providing them with any assistance they need.

Many renowned multinational enterprises are expected to announce their respective investment projects in Taiwan or to sign cooperation accords with their Taiwan counterparts during the meeting, including Acatel of France, Fujitsu of Japan, and Crane Aerospace of the United States.

Participants have confirmed thus far a total of 113 investment projects worth a combined NT$68.21 billion (US$2 billion) and have promised another 73 projects worth NT$70.16 billion, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, AUSTRALIA SIGN PROTOCOL ON SECURITIES COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) Chairman Ting Ker-hua clinched a protocol agreement Wednesday in Seoul with Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) Chairman David Knott to substantiate two-way cooperation and information exchanges, according to SFC officials.

The accord not only will bolster bilateral cooperation in securities and futures markets, but also is hard evidence that the SFC's long-term efforts in setting market regulations and operational mechanisms have aroused a keen interest from the international securities market, the officials said.

According to the officials, the cooperation protocol was the first of its kind ever signed by the SFC with a foreign counterpart. The SFC had already inked a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to step up two-way interaction with its other 19 counterparts, they noted.

A protocol provides a higher degree of legal status for mutual cooperation and requires concrete measures to boost a wider scope of information exchanges on a larger range of financial derivatives than an MOU, the officials explained.

They further pointed out that the Taiwan-Australia agreement also represents a breakthrough in Taiwan's efforts to move toward its aim of having more throw weight in the global market, which is also in concert with the government's market liberalization policy.

Ting and Knott were in the South Korean capital to take part in the 2003 annual conference of the International Organization of Securities Commissions. The two men used the occasion to ink the pact on the sideline of the Oct. 14-17 meeting.

Republic of China Representative to South Korea Lee Tsai-fan was also present, in addition to a dozen heads of IOSCO's members in the Asia-Pacific region, including Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, New Zealand, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Vietnam, as well as many ranking officials from the World Bank and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PITCHES FOR NEW CONSTITUTION AS CURE TO PROBLEMS PLAGUING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Rewriting the ROC Constitution is the cure for many problems dogging the country, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Speaking to a group of the country's industrial leaders, the president said a new constitution is necessary and should be put to a referendum vote to side-step the red tape surrounding the process of amending the current Constitution.

Chen, who created political ripples on Sept. 28 by calling for the formulation of a new constitution for the country by 2006, disputed critics' claims that he has an axe to grind, saying that he wouldn't benefit from the idea because any new constitution enacted in 2006 would not take force until 2008, when his second term, if he wins re-election in 2004, has run out.

Whether or not the country should stay out of mainland China's fold forever is not the only problem to be solved through a new constitution; many other problems, such as people's basic rights, environmental protection, election of public officials, the structure of the government, and the concerns of industry all need to be addressed in a new constitution, Chen went on.

Citing as an example, Chen said it is unfair that the Executive Yuan has only one deputy premier while every county of the nation has two deputy magistrates according to the existing Constitution. Furthermore, the president said, whether or not the administrative level of Taiwan Province should be abolished should be dealt with in a new constitution.

Repairing the flawed existing Constitution is a difficult political task in view of the troublesome procedures. In order to cut corners to get the new constitution ready by 2006, the president called for a plebiscite on the new constitution rather than having to follow the procedures provided for in the current Constitution.
"Giving the 23 million people a final say in writing the constitution is the materialization of a full democracy, " the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS FLOCK TO TAINAN TO OVERWINTER

TEXT.P: With the weather getting cooler, scores of endangered black-faced spoonbills have begun flocking to the Chiku Wetlands in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan to overwinter, wild bird conservationists said Wednesday.
Among the birds was one wearing a tag that indicated it had been released from temporary captivity in Taiwan last March after receiving treatment for botulism poisoning.

"The bird had a blue-red colored 'T20' ring on it leg. It was one of the 17 black-faced spoonbills that were released into the wild after they recovered from botulism poisoning, " said a member of a local private black-faced spoonbill research association.
Also arriving at the wetlands Wednesday was a bird that carries an "A08" ring, indicating that it was once caught and tagged by Hong Kong wild bird conservationists for research purposes.
"The move is aimed at facilitating research on their migration paths and reproduction habitats," the association member said.

Wild bird conservation groups in North and South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong have been conducting such research. Taiwan alone has tagged 26 black-faced spoonbills, while other countries have placed rings on 33 other birds.

Each year, a large proportion of the world's remaining black-faced spoonbills migrate from the Korean Peninsula and northeastern mainland China to the Chiku wetlands to overwinter. More than 700 arrived last year, during which 71 of the birds died. It was the first time a massive die-off had occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES INNOVATION IN HIGH-TECH SECTOR

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that Taiwan' s economy was gaining strength and encouraged businesses to remold the saying "made in Taiwan" to "invented in Taiwan."

Lu made the remarks while giving a speech at the inauguration of the Taiwan Optical Information Storage Technology Association (TOISTA) , comprised of over 80 information industry-related companies, including leading firms such as CMC Magnetics and RITEK.

Lu said Taiwan will regain its economic footing internationally, citing figures that she said indicate that Taiwan's economic recovery is already underway. Taiwan posted an economic growth rate of 3.6 percent for 2002, ahead of the United States' 2.4 percent, Singapore's 2.2 percent and the world's average of 2 percent.

Taiwan also sits on the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves and enjoys a strong competitiveness in terms of technological development potential, its macro-economy, investment climate and export growth, she added.

The vice president said she had high hopes for the association, encouraging it to pool the wisdom of the government, academic and research sectors to help transform Taiwan into an innovation-oriented country capable of creating its own brands, instead of just being a contractor. She stressed that the logo "made in Taiwan" should be upgraded to "invented in Taiwan."

The output value of Taiwan's optical information storage industry hit NT$210 billion (US$6.17 billion) in 2002, the world's third-highest level, and is expected to top NT$1 trillion in 2008, business sources said.

Huang Teh-ruey, TOISTA president and vice director of the Opto-Electronics & Systems Laboratories under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, said the domestic sector has done much to promote related businesses in recent years, including setting up a Secure Digital Memory (SDM) Club composed of more than 100 companies from related fields such as DVD and SDM.

According to Huang, Taiwan-based companies also have gotten together to form an institutionalized alliance dedicated to helping settle disputes about intellectual property rights with foreign companies and to research and develop programs. Initial results obtained by the alliance has already gained a high degree of international attention, he noted.

RITEK's chief executive officer, Yeh Chue-ching, said Taiwan-made CD-ROMs enjoy the lion's share of 70 percent in the global market, giving Taiwan an advantage in having a say as to setting industry standards and rules for compact discs for the coming generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO LEAD 1-MILLION RALLY NEXT FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will mobilize 1 million people Feb. 28, 2004, to stump for President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid in March, the head of a pro-Lee organization said Wednesday.

Friends of Lee Teng-hui President Huang Kun-fu, presidential adviser and chairman of the World United Formosans for Independence Chairman Huang Chao-tang, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Secretary-General Lin Jih-jia, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan and the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the name of Taiwan Executive Director Wang Hsih-chi called on the former president at the Taiwan Research Institute, where Lee serves as honorary chairman.

During the more-than one-hour meeting, they discussed issues related to drumming up support for Chen's re-election bid and decided that the rally will be held simultaneously in 22 cities and counties around the country, with either Taipei or Kaohsiung serving as the main venue.

The decision to seek a meeting with Lee was made after 25 pro-DPP groups, including Friends of Lee Teng-hui, World United Formosans for Independence, Taiwan Society North, the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan and the Taiwan Association of University Professors met the previous evening to work out the plan to stage the rally, and invited the DPP to join.

The participants said that as Feb. 28 is less than a month before the presidential election set for March 20 and is significant in Taiwan's quest for democracy, the former president decided it would be the most suitable day and that the rally will call for the solidarity of the people, the defense of the "native regime" and support for Chen's re-election bid.

The former president noted that although Hong Kong has only 6 million people, half a million of them took to the streets July 1 to protest against an anti-subversion law. "It certainly will not be a problem to mobilize 1 million people in Taiwan, " the participants quoted Lee as saying.

Lee also said that "if President Chen succeeds in his bid, then the following work, including the introduction of a new constitution and the rectifying the name of the nation will be carried out, " according to the participants.

TSU official Hsiao Kuan-yi said that although the rallies will be staged across the island, they will be connected through teleconferences, and the speeches of Lee and Chen at the major venue will bring the activities to a climax. The final details will be finalized Oct. 31 when the former president meets again with representatives of the pro-DPP groups, they said.

DPP Vice Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan also presented Lee with a matching cap and vest of support for an Oct. 25 rally in Kaohsiung orchestrated by the DPP to drum up support for referendum legislation, but the participants of the meeting quoted Lee as saying that he wants to focus on the Feb. 28 rally and would not attend.
TSU Secretary-General Lin Jih-Jia said that the party will mobilize 50,000 people to participate the referendum rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN SPEAKER TO DELIVER SPEECH AT HOUSTON CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will leave for the United States later this month to attend a world conference of overseas Chinese to be held Oct. 31 in Houston, sources in the legislature said Wednesday.
Wang will leave Taiwan for New York Oct. 25, where he will receive an honorary doctorate in law from St. John's University Oct. 27. It will be Wang's first honorary doctorate.

He will then travel to Houston to attend the overseas Chinese democratic conference sponsored by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, where he will deliver a speech concerning freedom, equality and human rights.
Wang is scheduled to return to Taiwan Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR VOLUNTEER SERVICE, DIPLOMACY BY PEOPLE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he looks forward to seeing more Taiwan people volunteer their services to help boost the nation's development and its diplomatic relations.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with two volunteer groups who will soon leave Taiwan to work abroad helping cement Taiwan's relations with its diplomatic allies or cultivating partnerships with countries that do not have official ties with Taiwan.

One group is composed of 41 young men who have been assigned to work in selected countries as alternative to mandatory military service, and the other group comprises 44 civilian volunteers who will be sent abroad to work for various cooperative projects organized by the Taiwan-financed International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF).

Chen noted that this year marks the third time that the Republic of China has sent conscripts abroad to carry out alternative diplomatic service and the seventh time that the ICDF has sent volunteers abroad to assist in Chinese language teaching, vocational training and medical and technical services.

"Through these projects, we can demonstrate to the world our willingness to volunteer our services in helping boost the well-being of needy countries," Chen said, adding that he admires the dedication of both groups to the nation's diplomatic cause.

He further said he believes that if all local people were willing to contribute some of their leisure time to volunteer services, either at home or abroad, Taiwan would be able to sustain its national development and project a "global volunteer" image in the international community.
In his view, Chen said, volunteer service, international cooperation, sustainable development and diplomacy by the people should not be just political slogans.
"They offer new visions and should be new core values in our pursuit of a new international image for Taiwan," Chen added.
Six of the 44 ICDF-trained volunteers are aged over 50 and this is the first time the ICDF has selected retired professionals to join its overseas volunteer corps.
"Despite their age, the six 'elderly' volunteers have expertise and as much passion to work for our diplomatic cause as other younger members," said an ICDF official.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ASSIST TAITUNG EXPORTS OF CUSTARD APPLES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is to help the southeastern county of Taitung to export one of its most famous products, the custard apple, a legislator said Wednesday.

Legislator Huang Jian-ting of the opposition Kuomintang said that the first batch of custard apples will be exported to Singapore Oct. 20, with further shipments to be exported to Hong Kong and Shanghai next year at the earliest.

Huang noted that custard apples produced by Australia are exported all over the world with great success, even though they are much smaller and dark brown in color. In comparison, Taitung's specialty -- the hybrid "pineapple" custard apple -- is huge, bright green and sweet.
He lamented that poor marketing and the perishable nature of the succulent fruit has prevented growers from exporting for many years, while intensive production of has caused the price to plunge.

Huang noted that custard apples currently only sell for between NT$30 and NT$40 (US$0.88-US$1.18) per kilogram this year, which is a far cry from just two years ago, when the fruit could command prices of NT$200 or NT$300 per kilogram.
To expand the distribution network for the fruit, Huang said, he has solicited help from the COA to overcome the technical problems of refrigeration so as to facilitate exports.

Huang said that following great efforts, he was happy to learn that the COA is willing to help Taitung growers export their fruit, which he said will help solve the overproduction problem and the slumping price.

Huang noted that COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung has been seeking to establish an export network for Taiwan fruit ever since he assumed office. He has several times invited domestic suppliers to meet and discuss the export of various types of fruit, including custard apples, and has also invited foreign importers to come to Taiwan to learn about and observe fruit cultivation here.

Huang noted that Taitung custard apple growers have enjoyed small success with exports, although the volume has been small, with only 2,030 kg exported last year, worth US$4,300, and purely as a result of the efforts of the growers without COA help.

"It is good to know that the government is willing to help promote Taitung's pineapple custard apples, " Huang said, adding that it will not only solve the marketing problem, but will also help increase the earnings of Taitung growers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN E-EXPO KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The four-day e-commerce exhibition "2003 e-ASIA Expo" was inaugurated Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with enterprises from 11 Asia-Pacific countries demonstrating the latest global e-commerce developments.

At the opening ceremony, President Chen Shui-bian said that he could see before him the future of the Asia-Pacific region, as information industry professionals from around the area had gathered to contribute to the development of the Internet.

According to Chen, in the 21st Century, the extent of e-society reflects a country's power. In order to make progress in this regard, the government has been making great efforts in this regard, including the promotion of an e-government, e-commerce and e-society.

These efforts have borne fruit, as many prestigious institutions have given Taiwan high e-rankings, Chen added. Last year, Taiwan was ranked at the top of a global e-government ranking among 198 countries conducted by Brown University of the United States.
In 2003, Taiwan was ranked second in terms of government network readiness in a survey conducted by the Switzerland-based World Economic Forum (WEF).
Noting that Taiwan has the confidence to excel in the future global e-commerce, Chen said that Taiwan's progress can make considerable contributions to global economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET WITH CLINTON: DPP

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton will call on President Chen Shui-bian when he visits Taiwan in mid-November, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Wednesday.

"Clinton will certainly pay a courtesy call on Chen during his upcoming trip to Taiwan, " DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said, adding that the two men are expected to exchange views on Taiwan-U.S. relations, the general international situation and other matters of mutual concern.

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, who concurrently heads the DPP's international affairs department, said Chen will host a dinner in Clinton's honor. Top leaders of major domestic political parties, other prominent politicians and socialites will also be invited to the dinner to greet Clinton, Hsiao said.
She added that although Clinton is no longer a president, he remains an important political figure.
With eight years in the White House, Hsiao said, Clinton is familiar with international politics and the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.
"I think he will have in-depth talks with President Chen on issues of mutual concern to Taiwan and the United States, " Hsiao said.

During his presidential tenure, Hsiao noted, Clinton sent an aircraft carrier battle group to help defend security in the Taiwan Strait in 1996 when Beijing conducted live-fire military exercises and test-fired missiles into Taiwan waters in an attempt to influence the result of the island's first-ever direct presidential election.

Clinton will visit Taiwan at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy. In addition to meeting with Chen, Clinton will deliver a speech during his stay in Taipei.
Taipei will be a stop on Clinton's upcoming Asian tour and his Taipei itinerary has yet to be fleshed out, Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEASURES TO THWART ATM THEFT TO BE AVAILABLE BY MONDAY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun promised the nation Wednesday to ensure swift crisis management over the recent spate of thefts from ATM machines islandwide, saying that measures to crack down on this type of crime are expected to be hammered out by next Monday.

Yu directed the National Police Administration to intensify its crackdown on fraudulent cash withdrawals while cooperating with the Ministry of Finance and other relevant government agencies to jointly work out effective measures to prevent similar crimes from occurring again.

The premier also called for the early passage of several draft bills concerning amendments to the Banking Law and six other financial and monetary statutes that have been submitted to the Legislative Yuan.
He added that the amendments contain articles stipulating stricter punishments for financial criminals, including ATM thieves.

Vice Minister of Finance Chang Hsiu-lian reported Wednesday that as of 7 p.m. the previous evening, 257 accounts at 24 banks, half of them Bank of Taiwan branches, had been found to have fallen victim to ATM thefts, with more than NT$30 million stolen.
As of Wednesday noon, stolen money from 19 accounts, to the tune of NT$2 million, had been refunded by the banks to some of the victims, Chang added.

Bank customers in the southern city of Tainan first reported last week that money had gone missing from their Bank of Taiwan accounts, while customers of other banks made similar reports in later days.

Upon investigation, police have found hidden cameras and IC chips at several ATMs in recent days, which are allegedly used by criminals to scan the ATM card data of the victims, allowing them to duplicate the cards and withdraw money from the victims' accounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were generally lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 29 points to close at 5,950, with 11,557 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 9 points to finish at 5,973, with 21,396 contract transactions, while December futures fell 13 points to finish at 5,980, with 17 contracts traded.
March futures decreased 47 points to finish at 5,966, with 7 contract transactions, while June futures increased 5 points to close at 5,976, with 2 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,979 for October, 5,982 for November, 5,993 for December, 6,013 for March, and 5,971 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
October TE futures moved up 0.35 points to finish at 258.75, with 2,072 contract transactions, while November TE futures gained 0.8 points to finish at 260.8, with 6,094 contracts traded.
December TE futures remained unchanged at 261, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures lost 17 points to finish at 851, with 2,264 contract transactions, while November TF futures fell 10.4 points to close at 853.8, with 5,028 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 16.8 points to finish at 851, with 9 contract transactions, while March TF futures decreased 8.6 points to close at 851, with one contract changing hands.
June TF futures lost 38 points to finish at 853, also with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN EXPRESSES APPROVAL FOR ROC KIWANIS NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday expressed approval for the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International's recent name change from the "Republic of China District of Kiwanis International."

The ROC District of Kiwanis International authorities applied with Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior and the U.S.-based Kiwanis International in early September for the name change to better reflect the reality and cope with international situations.

President Chen met with visiting international executive director of Kiwanis International, Eddie Sigurosson, at the Presidential Office where he offered his appreciation to the organization for its support to the Taiwan-affiliated chapter regarding the name change.
Chen said the name change is of great significance for both the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International as well as all the people of Taiwan in terms of identity.

The president also expressed his admiration for Kiwanis International -- which he described as a thriving organization of service- and community-minded individuals who support children and young adults around the world -- for choosing to hold its annual general meeting in Taiwan in 2001.
On behalf of the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International, Chen made a donation of US$100,000 to Kiwanis International to help out with the organization's humanitarian aid efforts around the world.
According to Chen, the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International has donated more than US$3.5 million to Kiwanis International for humanitarian assistance worldwide.

For his part, Sigurosson said that it was his pleasure to assist Taiwan in hosting the 2001 Kiwanis International general meeting, adding that he admires Taiwan's economic prowess and its people's compassion shown to other peoples around the world.
Sigurosson offered his appreciation for Taiwan's fresh donation, which he said will be used to serve the children of the world.
Kiwanis was founded in Detroit, Michigan, in 1915. The name Kiwanis comes from an old American Indian term meaning "we make ourselves known." The club's motto is "We Build."

Kiwanis is an organization of local clubs of business and professional men and women who are interested in community service. More than 600,000 Kiwanis family members in 89 countries regularly support community projects and are active in public affairs as well as work to promote international understanding and good will. They also provide career guidance to young people and sponsor youth activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 14.04 points to close at 5,924.38.
The bourse opened at 5,967.93 and then fluctuated between 5,978.47 and 5,913.28 during trading.
A total of 4.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.35 billion (US$3.11 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major stocks categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.9 percent, construction stocks at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, textile issues at 1 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 372 to 365, with 152 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR THAILAND FOR APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu left for Thailand Wednesday to take part in a ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum opening the same day in Bangkok.

Lin is expected to meet with his counterparts from the other 20 APEC member states to exchange views on a wide variety of issues, including the development of the knowledge-based economy, anti-terrorism cooperation, healthy and stable financial structures, the development of new micro-enterprises as well as small- and medium-sized enterprises, and commitments to assisting developing countries.
The APEC ministerial meeting is a lead up to the 2003 APEC informal leadership summit scheduled to be held in Bangkok Oct. 20-21.
Lee Yuan-tse, president of Taiwan's top research institution, Academia Sinica, will represent Taiwan at the summit meeting on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

APEC, which began as an informal dialogue group in 1989, is now the world's largest trade cooperation group, with a combined population of over 2.5 billion, about half the world's trade, and a combined gross domestic product (GDP) of US$19 trillion.

Leaders expected to take part in the summit meeting include U.S. President George W. Bush, Russian President Vladimir Putin, mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao and Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.

The 21 APEC members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN, KETAGALAN INSTITUTE HEAD ATTEND MEETING IN PRAGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Liu Ming-teh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two prominent Taiwan politicians -- opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Ketagalan Institute President Chen Shih-meng -- arrived in Prague Tuesday to attend an international seminar.
Lien flew to the Czech Republic capital after concluding a speech tour of London, while Chen, who once served as President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, traveled directly from Taipei to Prague.
The seminar, scheduled to open Wednesday, has been organized by the 2000 Forum which was founded by former Czech President Vaclav Havel three years ago.

This year's meeting will focus discussions on measures to narrow international gaps. Topics to be addressed during the two-day conference will include existing barriers to fair and equal development opportunities in today's world, trade and agriculture, global public assets, foreign debt, and international cooperation.

A number of world-renowned scholars, experts, leaders of non-governmental organizations, and politicians, including former South African President Frederik W. de Klerk and former U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, will attend the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 15, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander in chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and new elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single Republic of China air force Saber jet, piloted by Capt. Sun Szu-wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese Communist MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried in a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y.T. Wong, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the ROC army headquarters and also the ROC navy headquarters.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, an Academia Sinica member, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo would send a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for democracy in South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
2000: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, urges the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
2001: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih arrive in Shanghai to attend a series of ministerial meetings under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for Oct. 15-18.
2001: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, dies in Hawaii at the age of 101.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES ANNOUNCES LONG-RANGE ADDITION TO FLEET

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) on Wednesday announced the newest addition to its fleet -- the ultra long-range Airbus 340-500.
Dubbed the "A345LeaderShip, " the new aircraft will offer the longest non-stop commercial service in the world.

SIA said in a statement that the new plane's maiden flight will be from Singapore to Los Angeles in February 2004. This will complement SIA's existing twice daily services to Los Angeles which currently operate via Taipei and Tokyo.

Then, from August 2004, the Airbus 340-500 will be used on SIA's Singapore-New York City route. The service from New York to Singapore will shorten travel time by two hours, while the Singapore-New York service will cut travel time by six hours. The New York-Singapore flights will take about 18 hours in each direction.

DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Huang Ching-ching & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Yokohama Mayor Horoshi Nakada will arrive in Taiwan Oct. 23 for a four-day visit, a Yokohama City Hall official said Thursday.

The official, who asked not to be identified, said that Nakada will first visit Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, where he will hold talks with Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and tour the Kaohsiung Harbor facilities.
Nakada will proceed to Taipei Oct. 24, where he will meet President Chen Shui-bian and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou before departing Oct. 26.
During his stay, Nakada will also visit marine companies that use Yokohama Harbor, to promote the harbor's business, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHILE HOLD TALKS ON SYSTEMATIC EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Flor Wang and Wu Hui-chun)

TEXT.P: High-ranking trade officials from Taiwan and Chile held bilateral talks Thursday in the hope of building a systematic negotiation channel to forge closer trade and investment relations, according to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming.

Yiin said that Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu, head of the Taiwan delegation to the ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum being held in the Thai capital, talked with officials of the Chilean delegation on the sidelines of the annual conference.

Yiin said Taiwan hopes to establish a regular negotiation mechanism with Chile in order to boost two-way trade and investment exchanges, at a time when member countries of the World Trade Organization are increasingly signing regional free trade agreements among themselves.

Bilateral Taiwan-Chile trade totaled more than US$700 million last year, with Chile enjoying a trade surplus, he noted, adding that Chile would serve as an ideal springboard for Taiwan businesses seeking to tap the South American market. Taiwan and Chile maintain no diplomatic relations.

Chile is slated to sponsor the 2004 APEC annual conference, and has invited Taiwan to take part in the meeting to talk about its experience with small- and medium-sized businesses -- the theme of next year's annual conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND URGED TO IMPLEMENT DOUBLE TAXATION AGREEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Lin Chuan urged the Thai government Thursday to allow a bilateral agreement to avoid double taxation to go into effect as soon as possible.
Lin, who is in Bangkok to attend a ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, made the appeal in a meeting with his Thai counterpart, Chaowisit Suchat.

Lin noted that Taiwan and Thailand signed an agreement to avoid double taxation in 1999, but the agreement has not come into effect due to legal problems in Thailand. Suchat promised to try to resolve these problems.
The related agencies of the two countries also decided to strengthen their cooperation against crime to stem the sale in Thailand of cars stolen and shipped from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN HOMEOPATHIC MEDICINE PRODUCER MAY OPEN R&D CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Dr. Willmar Schwabe Group, the world's largest producer of homeopathic medicine, will make Taiwan its top choice when considering whether to set up a research and development (R&D) center in the Asia-Pacific region, a company official said Thursday.

Klaus-Peter Schwabe, president of the oldest and most venerated homeopathic manufacturer in Germany, said his company will consider opening an R&D regional center in Taiwan because of the country's high-quality professional talent, production facilities and research level of Chinese herbal medicine.
Although mainland China, Singapore and some countries in Southeast Asia are trying very hard to vie for the R&D center, Schwabe promised that the group will "give precedence" to Taiwan.

Schwabe said he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's progress in the biotechnology field and has gained a better understanding of Taiwan's development in this area after paying visits to biotechnological centers and facilities over the past two days on his first visit to Taiwan.

Heinz Stumpf, the group's manager in charge of R&D programs, noted that Taiwan, with assistance from the government sector, has made a great deal of progress in the biotechnology- and pharmaceutical-related areas. It was Stumpf's second visit to Taiwan in four years.

Prior to his departure later the same day, Schwabe also inked cooperation accords on technology transfers with three Taiwan companies, agreeing to authorize them to manufacture certain Schwabe products for sale in Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN CONCERNED ABOUT NEW CONSTITUTION DRIVE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's drive to write a new constitution and mainland China's intensified military buildup are major concerns of the visiting top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Thursday.
Chien made the remarks after hosting a luncheon in honor of American Institute in Taiwan Chairwoman Therese Shaheen, who arrived in Taipei Oct. 13 for a week-long fact-finding trip.
During the lunch meeting, Chien said, Shaheen expressed concern about President Chen Shui-bian's latest proposal to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006.

"I told Shaheen that Chen's call for a new constitution is mainly aimed at facilitating Taiwan's democratic reforms and creating a constitutional framework that fits Taiwan's present reality, " Chien said.

After listening to Chien's briefing, Shaheen was quoted as having said she could understand Taiwan's need. She suggested that the ROC government let its people know more about the new constitution's content and the timetable for its formulation, Chien said.
"Shaheen also told me that the U.S. government hopes to get more information about developments in Taiwan's new constitution drive, " the minister added.

Chien said Shaheen is also concerned about Taiwan's enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) laws. "Shaheen said there is still ample room for Taiwan to improve its IPR law enforcement to better protect U.S. firms' legitimate rights and interests, " Chien said.

According to Chien, cross-Taiwan Strait relations are also high on Shaheen's agenda. "With mainland China continually expanding its military arsenal, Shaheen wants to know our combat preparedness and hopes that we can beef up our military muscle to defend our own security," he added.

Earlier in the day, Shaheen met with Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min, who reportedly expressed Taiwan's hope that the United States can deliver on its promise to sell Taiwan eight conventional submarines.

During their talks, Tang reportedly also urged the United States to allow Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. to participate in the construction of some of the submarines to be sold to Taiwan.
Later that evening, Shaheen paid a courtesy call on Vice President Annette Lu.
Lu gave Shaheen a warm welcome. "I hope you can get first-hand information about Taiwan's latest developments and its progress in various aspects," Lu was quoted as having told her guest.
This is Shaheen's first trip to Taiwan since she assumed the AIT post late last year. In addition to meeting with ROC officials, she will also inspect AIT operations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS NO LONGER PROBLEM; FLU MORE TROUBLESOME: HEALTH OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A health official said Thursday that people should be more alert this winter against flu than a reoccurrence of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) that affected the country earlier this year.

Su Yi-jen, director of the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, made the remarks in a speech on the government's future quarantine strategy against SARS to a group of entrepreneurs with operations in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
The official said that the government is well-prepared against the return of SARS this winter and that it will not pose a major problem.
However, he added, the public should pay more attention to common flu, which has similar early symptoms to SARS.
According to Su, approximately 10 percent to 20 percent of Taiwan people get flu each year, and the medical cost for treatment reaches NT$31.2 billion (US$925.8 million) annually.
Su warned that the elderly people, especially those with diabetes, have a higher risk of getting flu and he suggested that such people get vaccinated against the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SIGN FREE TRADE PACT WITH 2ND ALLY SOON: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with a second diplomatic ally soon, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said in Bangkok Thursday.
Lin arrived in Bangkok a day earlier to attend the annual ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, which will formally open Friday.

"Once Taiwan had signed a free trade pact with Panama, several other ROC diplomatic allies in Latin America began showing keen interest in striking a similar deal with us, " Lin said, adding that Taiwan is negotiating detailed terms with those countries.
If all goes well, Lin said, Taiwan will sign a free trade agreement with one of those countries soon. He did not divulge the name of the country.
In addition to negotiating free trade pacts with its diplomatic allies, Lin said, Taiwan also looks forward to signing similar accords with countries that do not recognize the ROC diplomatically.
On the sidelines of the annual APEC ministerial meeting, Lin said he will hold bilateral talks with his counterparts from at least 10 other APEC member economies.
"I'll take advantage of those occasions to lobby them to sign free trade pacts with Taiwan to boost economic cooperation for mutual benefit," Lin said.

As a matter of fact, Lin went on, various major world trading powers are interested in signing free trade agreements with Taiwan. "But they have shown some reservations because of pressure from mainland China," Lin said, adding that despite Beijing's obstruction, Taiwan will still make every possible effort to sign free trade pacts with its major trading partners, most of which do not recognize Taiwan.
As for Taiwan's designation in free trade pacts to be signed with major trading partners, Lin said the most favored is the nation's official title "Republic of China."

"Taiwan would be the second choice, followed by the designation of 'Taiwan economy,'" Lin said, adding that the last choice would be the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" -- a designation used to describe Taiwan in the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR RELATIVELY STABLE: CBC GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said Thursday that the new Taiwan dollar remains relatively stable, despite rampant speculation that the currency will shortly appreciate noticeably.

Perng made the remarks while fielding questions at a legislative committee from lawmakers who are deeply concerned about the course of the new Taiwan dollar at a time when Asian currencies, including the yen of Japan and the renminbi, are under strong pressure from the United States to appreciate.

Stressing that the domestic currency has remained stable against an appreciating U.S. dollar compared to the yen and the won of South Korea, Perng said its value is decided basically according to the market momentum. "The central bank will interfere only when necessary or because of seasonal reasons," he explained.

The new Taiwan dollar dropped by 1 percent in value, lower than the yen's 1.2 percent and the won's 1.6 percent when it was reported that the third-quarter U.S. economic growth rate had reached 6.5 percent, while the fourth-quarter ratio was estimated at 4 percent.
The currency stood at 33.95 against the greenback Thursday, finishing NT$0.05 higher than Wednesday's level.

Perng said the CBC will ask the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to transfer to Washington the position papers it has prepared about Taiwan's stance, now that Taiwan's trade surplus with the United States has narrowed.

Turning to the question of whether the local currency has been underestimated and whether that could lead to an influx of international "hot money, " the CBC governor pointed out that the central bank will not allow players to speculate on the new Taiwan dollar, even though the domestic foreign exchange market has already become more open and liberal.

Citing CBC statistics, Perng said about US$60 billion in foreign capital was channeled into Taiwan during the first nine months of this year. As a "flat-dish" economy, Taiwan's economy will be easily affected by market dealers in the absence of appropriate management.

Regarding the CBC's attitude toward allowing mainland Chinese capital to enter Taiwan, Perng said the matter must be weighed carefully due to the delicate relations between the two sides. He added that the CBC is cautiously open to setting up a swap mechanism between the new Taiwan dollar and the renminbi and has called meetings with the relevant agencies to study the issue.

A recent revision to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area will allow Taiwan travelers to carry a certain amount of renminbi to and from the mainland, raising concerns as to whether an accountability system should be established between the two currencies.

The Japan Times: China p- uts its first man into space.
China lanunched its first manned space mission Wednesday,becoming the third country in history to send a person into orbit-four decades after the former Soviet Union and the United States." I feel good," China's instant hero radioed back to mission control.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OFFER BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES AT UPCOMING CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government will offer up to NT$400 billion- (US$11.79 billion-) worth of business opportunities to international manufacturers at an upcoming conference to create an "irreplaceable edge" for Taiwan.

The president made the remarks when he addressed a summit forum on the nation's technology industry strategy, which was co-sponsored by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Hewlett Packard (HP).
Vice Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang, HP Executive Vice President of Personal System Group Duane E. Zitzner, and various domestic enterprise executives, took part in the forum.

The president said that the forum was a prelude to the forthcoming 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference that will run Oct. 19-22, and he added that all those who participated in the forum are prime movers who have helped create Taiwan's competitive edge.
"The information industry has become the backbone of Taiwan's economy, and it plays a major role in the global computer industry," the president said.

He also said that the island is committed transforming its industry, eliminating trade obstacles and speeding up its market liberalization to maintain Taiwan's pivotal role in global technology industry operations.
In addition, "the government will also do its best to attract foreign capital to Taiwan," Chen said.

He said the government will offer NT$400 billion-worth of trade opportunities during the Taiwan Business Alliance Conference and that many international manufacturers have committed to investing in Taiwan. Chen added that through the concerted efforts of the government, the private sector and "international friends," they will be able to create Taiwan's "irreplaceable edge" under a division of labor system.

Chen also said that the recent government promotion of measures for faster and more convenient cross-strait air-cargo transportation should reduce the obstacles to Taiwan's information industry going global, maintain the edge of the domestic air cargo industry and help to realize Taiwan's vision of becoming a regional operations hub.

Zitzner said that Taiwan has played a pivotal role in HP's division of labor around the world, that HP continues to look highly on Taiwan's place in the division of labor system in the world, and is willing to provide timely assistance.

Shih said that the government will also offer trade opportunities as part of its six-year national development program to lure foreign capital to Taiwan and encourage the setting up of research and development centers or regional headquarters, so as to move toward building Taiwan into a regional operations hub.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION COULD COME INTO EFFECT 2008: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: Certain procedures would need to be undertaken after a new constitution was enacted in 2006, thus explaining President Chen Shui-bian's statement that the constitution would not come into effect until 2008, Chen's chief of staff said Thursday.

Chiou I-jen, the Secretary-General of the Presidential Office, also reiterated what Chen has said before -- that the formulation of a new constitution would not be the work of only one person or party. It would need the participation of everyone.

The Democratic Progressive Party group formed to hash out details of a new constitution would be aimed not to single-handedly create a constitution, but to raise the public awareness about the necessity for writing a new constitution and set up a time frame for enacting it.
A national constitution-drafting committee will probably be formed in the future to write a draft constitution, and put the result to a referendum.

The current procedure provided in the ROC Constitution for revisions includes a debate by the legislature and the approval by the National Assembly, a time-consuming process that denies the general public any say and thereby should be sidestepped all together, Chiou said.

Although the president hasn't mentioned anything like a constitution-drafting committee thus far, an organization similar to it will be set up to bring together different views of various political parties, Chiou said.

Chiou is elaborating on a call made by Chen on Sept. 28 for a new constitution by 2006 and a follow-up statement on Wednesday that he wouldn't benefit from such a constitution because it would not take effect until 2008 when he would have served out his second term, that is, if he wins a second term in the election next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS U.S. TO FULFILL SUBMARINE SALE PROMISE: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min told the top United States liaison official with Taiwan Thursday that he hoped the U. S. would make good on its promise to sell Taiwan eight diesel-powered submarines and that Taiwan would be able to participate in the building of some of them.
The United States agreed to sell Taiwan the submarines in an April 2001 arms deal, the largest weapons sale to Taiwan from the United States in a decade.
Observers have said that delivering on the promised subs could be difficult if not impossible given that the United States no longer builds diesel submarines.
Tang made the remarks when he visited the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucus in the Legislative Yuan to solicit support for next year's defense budget.

TSU Legislator Ho Min-hao said the party has long advocated that the Ministry of Defense should purchase subs under the understanding that Taiwan should be able to contribute to the construction of the subs.

Ho was referring to the concept of the United states allowing Taiwan's state- owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) to help with the construction of the first of the subs and then turn over the entire project to the CSBC to finish via transfer of technology.

Ho said that Tang agreed with the policy of Taiwan building the subs and said as much to visiting America Institute in Taiwan Chairwoman Therese Shaheen, who arrived in Taiwan Oct. 13 for a weeklong fact-finding trip.
Tang did not comment Shaheen's response but to say that many obstacles must be overcome for Taiwan to participate in the sub building project, according to Ho.

Ho also said that Tang, while explaining the defense budget, said that the defense ministry has listed C4ISR (command, control, communications, computer, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance) systems as its top purchase priority next year, and will include in the 2005 budget funds for the purchase of six Patriot missile batteries to upgrade the combat readiness of the nation.

During the same meeting with the TSU legislators, Tang also addressed concerns over the failure of the ROC Navy's torpedo test firing. One of two torpedoes fired at a stationary, de-commissioned destroyer failed to hit its target Tuesday. Another similar test failed in early September.

Tang stressed that the Navy officials in charge of the exercise are all well trained and that the problem lies with the hardware, the torpedo, and not the men. He pointed out that torpedoes were purchased some 10 or 20 years ago, and that he had instructed his subordinates to review the torpedo inventory and test fire them irregularly.
Tang also instructed that the purchase contracts be reviewed to see if there is a guarantee after sale. If it so, the ministry will seek redress.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TO EXERCISE PRUDENCE IN OPENING DOOR TO MAINLAND UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will exercise prudence in paving the way for mainland Chinese universities to recruit prospective students from Taiwan, a senior official said Thursday.

Minister of Education Huang Jung-tsun made the pledge during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee where opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Jhih-ming questioned the appropriateness of allowing mainland Chinese universities to recruit students from Taiwan.

"Is it justifiable to open the education market to mainland Chinese universities at a time when many of our universities and vocational schools have A hard time recruiting enough students? " Lo asked.

In response, Huang said that although the newly revised statute governing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait allows for mainland universities to recruit students from Taiwan, this new open-door policy cannot be substantiated until several complementary measures are worked out.
The cross-strait statute has been amended in line with the provisions of the World Trade Organization (WTO) which require its members to mutually open their education markets.
Huang said although Taiwan and mainland China are now WTO members, they have yet to forge a bilateral consultative mechanism to address the education market opening issues.
Moreover, Huang said, the cross-strait academic accreditation issue must be resolved before any open-door measures can be adopted.

Anyway, Huang said, the MOE will make extensive consultations with relevant government agencies and domestic private and public universities before drafting detailed enforcement rules for mainland universities to legally recruit students from Taiwan.

As a matter of fact, many Taiwan students have traveled to mainland China to study at prestigious mainland universities or graduate institutes in recent years. But Taiwan has so far not recognized academic degrees granted by those schools.
"While drafting the market opening regulations, the MOE will take into consideration the move's possible grave impact on local universities," Huang assured lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ENTER INTO ERA OF DIGITAL TELEVISION IN 2006: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said on Thursday that the country will enter into the era of digital television in 2006, when the proportion of digital televisions on the island reaches 85 percent.
Yu made the announcement at the opening ceremony of the five-day Taipei International Electronics Show -- TAITRONICS-Finished Products -- at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Yu pointed out that the production volume of Taiwan's electrical and electronics products totaled US$127.1 billion last year, accounting for 50.98 percent of the total industrial production of the island.

With its exports reaching US$65.2 billion in 2002, accounting for 49.9 percent of Taiwan's total exports, the electrical and electronics sector is posed as the industry with the greatest potential in Taiwan, Yu said.

With regard to the main theme of the electronics show -- digital Technology, Yu noted that the government is actively supporting the video industry, including LCD and plasma televisions, to bring Taiwan into an era of digital television (DTV) technology, which will allow broadcasters to offer television with high-quality picture and sound, along with a great variety of other enhancements.
DTV technology can also be used to transmit large amounts of data into homes, which may be accessible by computer or television sets.

Noting that Taiwan's information and electronics sectors are quick to react to changes, the premier still urged domestic electronics entrepreneurs to accelerate the establishment of global logistics systems, in addition to strengthening research and development capabilities to maintain their high competitiveness.

Although the scale of the exhibition is somewhat smaller than that of last year, there are 61 foreign exhibitors, a considerable rise of 65 percent over last year. Mainland Chinese manufacturers also sent their delegations for the first time to participate in the show.

TAIEX Index futures for December gained 85 points to finish at 6,065, with 92 contract transactions, while March futures rose 84 points to finish at 6,050, with 6 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 111.36 points to close at 6,035.74.
The bourse opened at 5,935.15 and then fluctuated between 6,037.53 and 5,928.7 during trading.

A total of 5.85 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$135.84 billion (US$4.01 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 4.99 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$105.35 billion (US$3.11 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.3 percent, textile issues at 2.1 percent, electrical shares at 2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.9 percent, cement shares at 0.5 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EYES MAY 20, 2008 FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he hopes a new constitution can be implemented on May 20, 2008 when a new president will be inaugurated.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of German and U.S. legal experts, including Winfried Hassemer, vice president of Germany's Federal Constitutional Court.

Just like the European Union, which is discussing the formulation of a new constitution to cope with the new situation that will arise following the entry of 10 more states into the union next year, Taiwan also needs a new constitution that fits the island's present realities, Chen said.
Chen told his guests that his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is pushing for the writing of a new constitution for Taiwan.
"According to our preliminary work agenda, we hope that a new constitution can be ready for a nationwide referendum in 2006, " said Chen, who concurrently serves as DPP chairman.
And if all goes well, Chen continued, the new constitution can be put into force May 20, 2008, to coincide with the inauguration of a new president of the nation.

The German and U.S. legal experts, including several specialists in criminal codes and constitutional law, have gathered in Taipei to discuss constitutional reform topics with local grand justices and other law professors.

Chen said the seminar, co-sponsored by the Judicial Yuan, National Chengchi University and Germany's famous Alixander von Humboldt-Stiftung Foundation, is timely and is expected to offer valuable insights for Taiwan's constitutional reform drive.
Ulrich Dreesen, director-general of the German Institute in Taipei, was also present at the meeting.

Meanwhile, Chen said a day earlier that revising the flawed existing constitution is a difficult political task in view of the troublesome procedures. In order to cut corners to get the new constitution ready by 2006, the president called for a plebiscite on the new constitution rather than having to follow the procedures prescribed in the current Constitution.

"Giving the 23 million people a final say in writing the constitution is the materialization of a full democracy, " the president said, adding that enacting a new constitution will help resolve a host of problems dogging the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 16, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti-revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
2001: Taiwan atmospheric scientists successfully obtains vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.
2001: A Taipei delegation leaves for Indonesia to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival in Jakarta.
2001: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. invests US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMBARDIER PLANNING REGIONAL HUB IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Canada-based Bombardier Inc. is planning to base its regional business operations center in Taiwan to better explore the Asia-Pacific market, a company executive said Friday.

Pierre Lortie, president of Bombardier's transportation department, said the company, the contractor of engineering construction for the planned Neihu Line of Taipei's mass rapid transport system, will search for qualified Taiwan businesses to cooperate in the manufacture of some relevant facilities through technology transfer.

According to Lortie, the Neihu Line's engineering construction plan worth NT$18.5 billion (US$548 million) is a "big contract" for the company, which specializes in mass transit system, passenger rail and other vehicles.

Around 80 percent of the line's 202 cars will be assembled in Taiwan, with the remaining to be completed in the United States, he noted, adding that most of the car facilities, including machinery, telecommunications equipment and automated toll collecting systems will be manufactured in Taiwan by a subcontractor.

Lortie said he was very confident of the planned cooperation model, as Taiwan is strong in the computer and electronics industry. If the cooperative venture with Taiwan-based companies goes smoothly, the Taiwan partners will be commissioned by Bombardier to help in exploring overseas markets, he added.
Lortie said the company will start its drive in the Asia-Pacific region with the Neihu Line by providing the most advanced technologies to the local partners.
A seminar sponsored by Bombardier in late September on the Neihu Line cooperative venture attracted 109 Taiwan companies.
