DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES TAIWAN DELEGATION TO APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received the members of the Taiwan delegation to the 2003 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Friday at the Presidential Office, encouraging them to increase Taiwan's visibility through active participation in summit activities.

Chen said that APEC is an important international organization that Taiwan has accessed. All members of the delegation should take the opportunity to participate actively in activities of the meeting slated for Oct. 20-21 in Bangkok.
Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Academia Sinica, who will attend the informal summit on Chen's behalf, will have a series of interactions with leaders of other APEC member nations during the meeting.

Chen said that he believes Taiwan's international visibility and the value of its participation in the meeting will be markedly increased through active participation and introduction of constructive and concrete proposals.
He also wished the delegation much success in fulfilling its missions.
Chen has named Lee, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986, as his personal envoy to the informal APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OFFERS NT$400 BILLION-WORTH OF INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: In order to attract as much foreign investment as possible, the central and local governments will display investment opportunities worth more than NT$400 billion (US$11.81 billion) on the sidelines of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference in Taipei Oct. 19-22.
The conference will feature two forums and twelve workshops designed to help would-be foreign investors understand Taiwan's favorable business environment.
Government leaders including Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and Minister of Finance Lin Chuan have devoted much energy to ensure the success of the conference.

More than 1,800 company executives from 35 countries and Taiwan will take part in the conference, and investors have already promised to funnelled NT$178.38 billion (US$5.25 billion) into 186 projects -- far beyond the expected participation of 600 people and a total investment of NT$100 billion (US$2.95 billion).

Nineteen out of the country's 21 counties will have booths outside the venue of the conference to show investment opportunities in their counties. Private companies will also showcase themselves in the hope of attracting the attention of their foreign counterparts.
As a result, the number of stalls has increased from the initially planned 90 to 183.

In addition to seeking investment from abroad, the conference is aimed at enhancing Taiwan's profile in the global business world by inviting foreign business leaders to Taiwan so that they can understand Taiwan's investment climate, said the organizers of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF OF TAIWAN PEOPLE FAVOR DIRECT ACROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT: POLL

TEXT.P: About half of the people in Taiwan are in favor of opening direct transportation links with mainland China, according to the results of a government survey made public Friday.

The survey, conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , found that 46 percent of Taiwan citizens think that the links would have a positive impact on Taiwan's economic development, while 55 percent and 45 percent contend that Taiwan's national security and job market would be adversely affected, respectively.

At the same time, around 35 percent of the public said Taiwan's pace toward a full opening of direct transportation, trade and postal links is appropriate, while 28 percent said it is too slow and 15 percent said it is too fast.

As to the government's idea of permitting indirect cargo charter flight services between Taiwan and Shanghai, 50 percent said they had no thoughts on the concept, while 54 percent said they support the government's plan.

In contrast to the 40 percent who are opposed to the idea of allowing mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to collect funds through listing shares in the domestic stock market, 37 percent expressed support for the proposal.

Regarding the issue of whether Taiwan should recognize academic diplomas issued by mainland-based colleges and universities, 60 percent of the respondents agree to the plan but with "stricter conditions." Only 6 percent totally rejected the idea.

Around 42 percent of Taiwan citizens said that the eight-year waiting period imposed on mainland spouses to receive Taiwan ID cards is acceptable, ahead of 29 percent who said it is too harsh and 15 percent who said it is too lenient.
Some 45 precent were not satisfied with the government's performance in its dealings with cross-Taiwan Strait issues, according to the survey.

In addition, 34 percent of the people polled supported the proposal of writing a new constitution in 2006, slightly ahead of 32 percent who disagree with the idea. Nevertheless, 57 percent favor maintaining the status-quo across the Taiwan Strait, while 23 percent are pro-Taiwan independence and 7 percent are pro-unification.
The random telephone survey was carried out by the RDEC Oct. 7-8, collecting 1,083 valid questionnaires from Taiwan citizens aged over 20. The poll has a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESENTS VISITING BRITISH PARLIAMENTARIAN WITH MEDAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented a visiting British parliamentarian with a medal Friday at the Presidential Office in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of Taiwan-United Kingdom relations.

Speaking at the ceremony where David Martin Steel, a member of the British House of Lords, was awarded the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon, President Chen thanked Steel for the support and assistance he gave Taiwan during his tenure as president of Liberal International from 1994 to 1996.

President Chen said that the Prize for Freedom that Liberal International awarded him in 2001 represented not only a great personal honor, but also recognition of the 23 million people of Taiwan who accomplished the first peaceful transfer of political power between parties in Chinese history in 2000.
The president was not able to receive the award in person. Republic of China first lady Wu Shu-chen accepted the prize on Chen's behalf at a ceremony Nov. 14, 2001 in Strasbourg, France.

Steel has visited Taiwan four times and has witnessed Taiwan's democratic and economic development, Chen pointed out, adding that the people of Taiwan appreciate the experiences and achievements brought by democratization.
Chen also congratulated Steel for the rapid growth of the Liberal Democratic Party he founded. The party has become the third-largest party in the U.K.

He expressed the hope that relations between Taiwan and the U.K. will further strengthen. The U.K. has become the third-largest trading partner of Taiwan in Europe with two-way trade hitting US$4.26 billion in 2002.
In response, Steel said that he has been impressed on each of his visits by the progress made in Taiwan.
Steel arrived in Taipei Oct. 15 at the head of a five-member parliamentary delegation on a goodwill visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLDERS OF JAPANESE BONDS ASK FOR ASSISTANCE TO RECOVER LOSSES

TEXT.P: Taiwan citizens who purchased Japanese bonds during World War II urged the Republic of China government Friday to help them seek compensation for the now worthless script.

Twelve people appealed to the government during a public hearing sponsored by Legislator Cheng Kuo-chung of the Democratic Progressive Party in the Legislative Yuan to help them contact the Japanese government about the issue.

Tseng Chi-cheng, one of the bond-holders, said that during Japan's colonial occupation of Taiwan from 1895 to 1945, the public was asked to purchase the savings bonds issued by the Japanese finance ministry and Kangyo Bank.
Tseng pointed out that Japan has already settled on compensation with holders of its bonds in other countries, including those in South Korea, but has ignored the pleas of Taiwan citizens.
Another bond-holder, Tseng Yi-yen, said that Japan had encouraged Taiwan people to buy its bonds, but that they are now worthless scraps of paper.

The bond-holders said that the peace agreement between China and Japan after the war ended stipulated that the Republic of China government could negotiate for the settlement of compensation regarding bonds held by Taiwan citizens.
"The compensation must be done through the government, " said a bond-holder.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL MUSEUM OF TAIWANESE LITERATURE INAUGURATED IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The National Museum of Taiwanese Literature (NMTL) was inaugurated Friday in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan -- one of the island's earliest developed areas.

Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, said at the inaugural ceremony that the museum will mark the dawning of an era in which the people of Taiwan "tell their own stories, create their own literary works and develop their own historical perspective."
Tchen, who has actively advocated the establishment of the museum, said the NMTL is expected to become one of the most important institutes for the study of Taiwanese literature.

The new museum is housed in the old Tainan City Government building which was built during Japanese colonial rule and has been designated as a cultural relic. The museum, the Confucius Temple and several other historic buildings in the vicinity will form a special cultural complex, Tchen said.

The new museum boasts a large collection of literary works and documents donated by local authors and artists. Tchen said the museum will focus on collecting books featuring Taiwan's literature, history and development, activities of major literary groups and literary works of local novelists and essayists.
"The collection will cover traditional literary creations dating back to the Ming dynasty and the Japanese colonial era as well as contemporary literary works," Tchen added.
The new museum has organized a series of seminars on topics related to Taiwan's literary development to mark its inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP TO FILE A LIBEL SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) have decided to file a libel suit against President Chen Shui-bian over his allegations that mainland China has secretly helped the opposition in order to defeat his 2004 presidential re-election efforts.
In an interview with the Washington Post earlier this month, Chen said: "They have even given clandestine assistance." But he did not say what kind of help mainland China has allegedly provided.

Leaders of the KMT and PFP caucuses at the Legislative Yuan said Friday at a press conference that the two opposition parties have decided to file the lawsuit against Chen over the remarks and to ask for a nominal one new Taiwan dollar in punitive damages. They have also demanded an open apology.
Chen Chi-mai, a leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said at another press conference that the opposition's threat is "meaningless."
"If they want to sue, let them go ahead. Nobody will dance to their music," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAY FESTIVAL TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI ON NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Lesbians, gays, and their sympathizers will participate in the 2003 Taipei Gay Festival in the afternoon of Nov. 1.

A spokesman for the Gay Hotline said Friday that the participants will march from the 228 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei to a plaza about two miles away in a parade, which is unprecedented in Taiwan. Singing, dancing, and other performances will be given in the plaza to celebrate the so-called "Taipei fun-for-all festival."

The spokesman said the activity is aimed at making gay issues visible. Representatives of gay organizations in the United States and other countries have been invited to take part in the activity, he added..

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY CHIEF PLANS TO SEEK FOREIGN AID TO DEMINE KINMEN

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said Friday he plans to seek foreign financial aid to clear landmines in coastal regions of the Republic of China-held island of Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
Lee said the landmines littering Kinmen's coastal areas not only pose great danger to local residents but have also had an adverse impact on the island's tourism development.
While the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has come up with a three-year plan to demine 12 obsolete minefields, Lee said, the plan is not expected to kick off until 2006.
According to the plan, the MND will budget a total of NT$468 million between 2006 and 2008 to demine the 12 minefields, which cover an area of 317,000 square meters.
"Priority will be given to minefields that could affect tourism and public security," said Lt. Gen. Hu Chieh, deputy commander of the Kinmen Defense Command.
The 12 minefields to be cleared under the three-year plan include Kuang-ao, Tzuti, Chienkungyu, Hsipien, Mashan and Hsishan.
Lee said the presence of minefields has discouraged private corporations from investing in Kinmen and has hindered the island's economic development over the decades.

"The MND's three-year demining plan has come too late," Lee said, adding that given the government's deteriorating financial straits, the military may have difficulty appropriating enough funds to finance the demining project.

With the consent of the Kinmen county council and the support of Kinmen's civilian residents, Lee said he plans to enlist international assistance with a view to ridding the island of dangerous landmines and unexploded ordinance as soon as possible.
"I earnestly hope that foreign human rights groups and activists can offer us financial and technological aid in clearing up landmines in the above-mentioned coastal regions," Lee said.

With relations across the Taiwan Strait gradually stabilizing, the MND has demined 16 minefields on Kinmen since 1998 and is scheduled to launch a new three-year plan from 2006 through 2008 to clear up 12 other minefields.

After listening to Lee's and Hu's briefings on the landmine issues, two Control Yuan members -- Lin Chu-lang and Hsieh Ching-hui -- recognized the MND's demining drive. Nevertheless, they said they agreed with Lee's views that the MND's new three-year demining project should be advanced to help boost Kinmen's tourism and economic development.
The two Control Yuan members arrived in Kinmen Thursday to inspect various development projects on the frontline island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG COUNCIL SPEAKER ELECTED

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Council Deputy Speaker Tsai Sung-hsiung was voted Friday by city councilors to serve as an acting speaker after the speaker was removed from the post for vote-buying in last year's city council election.

The Kaohsiung city council called a meeting to decide whether a new speaker should be elected to fill the vacant post. However, attending city councilors voted unanimously to have Tsai temporarily serve in the post left vacant by Chu An-hsiung, as by-elections might be held soon to replace other councilors who are involved in another vote-buying scandal on the election of council speakership.
Thirty-four councilors out of a total of 44 members, including Chu and Tsai, were indicted in that case.

Chu was kicked off the council after being sentenced Sept. 25 to a 22-month jail term for vote-buying during the council election last December. However, he failed to report to the Kaohsiung District Court Thursday to begin serving his term. The prosecution authorities urged Chu to turn himself in before Oct. 20 or face arrest.
Although Chu's wife Wu Teh-mei gave her assurance in a telephone call to a prosecutor that Chu will report to the court "in a few days," it has been widely speculated that Chu has fled overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR NEWS MEDIA COME TO TAIWAN FOR BUSINESS ALLIANCE CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Thirty-seven journalists from nearly 30 major news media organizations around the world will cover a major business conference that kicks off this Sunday, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Friday.

CETRA officials said that journalists from news media such as the Washington Times, the Chicago Sun-Times from the United States, Le Figaro, Les Echoes and Le Moniteur Du Commerce International from France, Kefler Nachrichten, Seudenetusche Zeitung from Germany, De Telegraaf from the Netherlands, La Republica from Italy and Ma'ariv from Israel have all sent senior correspondents to cover the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance scheduled for Oct. 19-22 at Taipei International Convention Center.

In addition, organizations from the region such as Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun, Sankei Shimbun, Mainichi Shimbun, Jiji Press, the Nihon Kogyo Shimbun and Kyodo News agency, the South Korean Chosunilbo, Hong Kong's South China Morning Post and Singapore's Lian He Zaobao have all sent journalists, the officials said.
Their presence is expected to promote Taiwan's visibility around the world, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market moved up Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November surged 20 points to close at 6,080, with 16,856 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December gained 10 points to finish at 6,075, with 65 contract transactions, while September futures rose 151 points to finish at 6,124, with one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,060 for November, 6,065 for December, 6,053 for March, 6,116 for June and 5,973 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
November TE futures moved up 0.25 points to finish at 264.75 with 5,771 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 264.7, with 14 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures increased 11 points to finish at 884, with 11,018 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 14.4 points to close at 885, with 34 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN OFFICIAL VISITS TAIPEI COUNTY GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The deputy governor of Mongolia's Dungobi Province, S. Torbat, accompanied by J. Narantsatsralt, who is currently a member of Mongolia's national legislature, paid a courtesy call on the Taipei county government Friday.
Torbat met with Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang for talks mainly on the prospects of forging sisterhood ties between Dungobi and Taipei County.
Torbat also invited Su to attend Mongolia's National Day celebration, to be held in the summer of 2004.

The Dungobi deputy governor is in Taipei to attend a one-month workshop on civil servant and public-office manager training. Twenty-five Mongolian officials are attending the workshop sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission. Most of the 25 participants are incumbent deputy governors from Mongolia.

J. Narantsatsralt is a member of the Mongolian national legislature, called the State Great Khural. An old friend of Taiwan, Narantsatsralt has also served as mayor of Ulan Bator, Mongolia's capital, and as prime minister of Mongolia. He signed an agreement with former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian for sisterhood ties between Ulan Bator and Taipei City.
Narantsatsralt has also been instrumental in efforts to strengthen economic, trade, cultural and tourism exchanges between Mongolia and Taiwan.

Meanwhile, a 30-member trade group from Mongolia headed by Sambuu Demderel, chairman of the Mongolian Federation of Commerce and Industry, has arrived in Taipei to take part in the Second Joint Taiwan-Mongolia Economic Conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO HOLD PUBLIC HEARINGS TO REVIEW MINI-THREE LINKS POLICY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that it will hold a series of public hearings to review the "mini-three links" between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu and designated harbors in mainland China's Fujian Province.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong noted that direct trade, postal and transport links between the two outlying islands and the mainland, which were implemented in January 2001, is part of the nation's overall mainland China policy.

The hearings are in line with the recent revised regulations of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which has given a more comprehensive legal basis for the mini-links.

Chen said that the MAC will make an overall review of the links, including shipping links and personnel exchanges and the regulation of imported goods. It will then make necessary adjustments based on the overall consideration of local demand, software and hardware construction, and a balanced consideration of the interests of Taiwan proper in terms of maintaining security and social stability.
He said that the development of Kinmen and Matsu should be linked with that of Taiwan proper as much as possible.

Meanwhile, he went on, the government has yet to allow the mainland real estate sector to advertise in Taiwan and those who violate the regulations will face fines of between NT$100,000 and NT$500,000 (US$2,950-US$14,750).

Chen made the remarks after the mainland-based Shimao Group kicked off a three-day promotion in Taipei for a luxurious housing complex in Shanghai. The group, which aims to sell at around NT$20 million (US$589,970) per unit of the complex, has already placed prominent advertisements in all Taiwan major news media.
Chen stressed that the mainland real estate sector is not allowed to come to Taiwan. The sector is prohibited to publish, air or broadcast ads or conduct promotions in Taiwan.
Chen said that the Ministry of the Interior is in charge of the real estate sector and added that the MAC will immediately notify the ministry so that it can handle the matter.
This is not the first case of mainland real estate operators violating the regulations. Three fines have been issued this year, each of which has amounted to NT$300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200,000 PEOPLE EXPECTED TO TAKE PART IN NEW CONSTITUTION RALLY: DPP

TEXT.P: More than 200,000 people are expected to take part in a rally to be held in Kaohsiung Oct. 25 to push for the birth of a new constitution in Taiwan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

According to Chang, the rally, which he described as a demonstration of Taiwan's progress as well as its democratization, will be a crucial boost to the success of a referendum, in which the Taiwan population will vote to decide whether and how a new constitution should be enacted and promulgated.

Addressing a press conference called by the Referendum Legislation Promotion Alliance (RLPA) to drum up support for the Oct. 25 rally, Chang said holding referendums will no longer be "an impossible dream" for the Taiwan people and that successful holding of referendums will eventually mark a milestone in Taiwan's democratization.

"It is my honor to tell you that about 100,000 people were originally scheduled to take part in the rally, but the number has grown to 150,000 and is expected to reach and even exceed 200,000 by Oct. 25," Chang said.
DPP Legislator Trong Chai, one of the major proponents of referendums in Taiwan, said a torchlight marathon is scheduled to kick off in Kungliao, Taipei County Oct. 19 as a sideline to the rally.

Chai said the marathon will kick off at the site of the partially completed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, where former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung will lead the "north team" of the marathon on a seven-day, 492.3-kilometer run from Taipei County in the north to the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to lead the "south team" of the marathon on a three-day, 157-kilometer run from Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, arriving in Kaohsiung City Oct. 25.
The runners who finish the last sections of the run will join the other rally members in the evening of Oct. 25, when the new constitution rally culminates.

According to Chai, the DPP will mobilize some 100,000 members and supporters to take part in the rally, while the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a DPP ally, will have some 50,000 people show up and the Taiwan Presbyterian Church is expected to have some 20,000 people attending.

Lin Chih-chia, chief secretary of the TSU, which is also co-sponsoring the rally, said promoting the legislation of a referendum law is a task that requires cooperation and concerted efforts from all parties across the political spectrum.

With an Aaron Boone thunderbolt of a home run in the 11th inning Thursday night, the New York Yankees stepped forward and once again crushed their century-old rivals from Boston, 6-5, in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series. DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN ARRIVES IN N.Y. EN ROUTE TO BOSTON

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the major opposition Kuomintang, arrived in New York Thursday evening en route to Boston, where he will attend a meeting at the Fairbank Center in Harvard University.

Lien, who is a candidate for the Presidential election in March, next year, will come back to New York on Oct. 22 to meet with overseas Chinese in China Town to thank them for their enthusiastic support and friendship.
He was greeted at the Kennedy International Airport upon arrival from Europe by many supporters Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices rose slightly on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.97 points to close at 6,042.71.
The bourse opened at 6,063.4 and fluctuated between 6,077.6 and 6,016.1 during the trading session.

A total of 5.69 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.92 billion (US$3.77 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 5.85 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$135.84 billion.
Of the eight major stock categories, only bank and insurance shares gained ground, moving up at 2.0 percent.

Paper shares moved down the most at 3.0 percent, followed by cement and foodstuff stocks, both at 1.5 percent, textile shares at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical issues at 0.4 percent and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 421 to 309, with 163 stocks remaining unchanged.

The Security Council unanimously approved Thursday an American and British resolution authorizing an American-led multinational force in Iraq. The measure also set a Dec. 15 deadline for the Iraqi Governing Council to lay out a timetable for creating a constitution and democratic government.
The Wall Street Journal:The Legacy of Pope John Paul II.
Under Pope John Paul II, the Catholic Church has gained ground in the developing world, but slipped in its traditional Western base. The question of how the church can bridge that growing divide looms large over the world's oldest institution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GAMERS BAG TWO GOLDS AT WORLD CYBER GAMES GRAND FINAL
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Liu Kai-hsun and Huang Cheng-pin added another gold medal for Taiwan, also in the nation-to-nation competition, later in the evening in the "War Craft: Reign or Chaos" PC game competition.
The Wu-Huang team beat formidable rivals from Canada, the United States, France and Spain in nerve-racking competition in the PC game "The Age of Mythology" to take top spot.

According to Wu and Huang, the U.S. team was particularly tough to deal with as they used certain tricks that were in violation of the rules, leading the Chinese Taipei side to voice objections at the referee.
Wu and Huang will each be awarded with a medal and a cash prize of US$7,000.

Meanwhile, Liu and Huang, who will also be awarded a cash prize of US$7,000, said they burst into tears upon winning the gold following five days of bad luck and poor performances that almost prevented them from qualifying for the final round.

Nearly 600 top gamers from 55 countries are taking part in the the WCG -- the world's largest e-sport festival for gamers and digital entertainment culture -- being held at Seoul's Olympic Park Oct. 12-18. In addition to 36 medals, the WCG Committee, which is sponsoring the event, has put up for grabs a total of US$350,000 in cash prizes.

Gamers have been competing for medals in seven official games, including six PC games, namely "Age of Mythology," "Star Craft: Brood War, " "War Craft III, " "FIFA 2003," "Half-Life: Counter Strike" and "Unreal Tournament 2003, " as well as one Xbox game, "The Survival Project."
The top three cash prizes for nation-to-nation competitions are US$7,000, US$5,000 and US$2,000, respectively, while the top three prizes for individual winners are US$20,000, US$10,000 and US$5,000.

Cash prizes for the five-member group competition - which will be held exclusively for the game "Counter Strike, " are the highest, at US$40,000 US$20,000 and US$10,000 for the top three places, according to the sponsor.

Meanwhile, the WCG Committee decided Thursday that the WCG 2004 Grand Final will be held in San Francisco, marking the first time that the ultimate WCG event will take place outside of South Korea -- the birthplace of the WCG.

MALACANANG, its colonial facade having received a good scrubbing and a fresh coat of paint, was looking its royal best Friday as though the leader of the most powerful nation had arrived.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN INTRODUCE RESOLUTION WELCOMING PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: The four co-chairs of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. House of Representatives, have introduced a concurrent resolution welcoming President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming transit stop in New York.

The resolution says: "(Congress) recognizes that the visit of Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian to the United States is a significant step towards broadening and deepening the friendship and cooperation between the United States and Taiwan."
The resolution was jointly initiated by Reps. Robert Wexler (D-Fla.), Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) and Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) Thursday evening.

The Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), a U.S.-based non-profit organization dedicated to promoting Taiwan's cause in the international community, said the introduction of this resolution is "more than just a routine friendly gesture to a visiting president of a fellow democracy."

FAPA President Wu Ming-chi stressed that with the recent attention in the U.S. media surrounding the blunt policy remarks made by President Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui, the FAPA interprets the timing of the introduction of this resolution as an "endorsement of President Chen's policy statements and actions."
Chen is scheduled to arrive in New York on Oct. 31 for a two-day transit stop on his way to Panama for an official visit.
During his stay in New York, Chen will be honored at an annual meeting of the International League for Human Rights (ILHR).

ILHR Chairman Scott Horton will bestow the 2003 Human Rights Award on Chen in recognition of his outstanding contributions to promoting human rights in Taiwan. Previous recipients of the prestigious award include the Dalai Lama and former South African President Nelson Mandela.
Chen is scheduled to deliver a 20-minute speech on human rights issues after receiving the award.

While in New York, Chen will also meet with influential U.S. congressional members, visit "ground zero" of the 911 terrorist attacks in the company of former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, and attend a dinner on the Hudson River to be given by Chinese community leaders in his honor. Chen will leave New York for Panama Nov. 2.
During his visit in Panama, Chen will attend the Central American country's centennial celebrations.
On his way back to Taipei from Panama, Chen will make a transit stop in Alaska at the invitation of Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski, a staunch supporter of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 17, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE COULD TAKE UP TO 3 YEARS TO REBOUND STRONGLY: MAS

TEXT.P: Singapore's economy may need three years before it records a strong recovery, the city-state's Monetary Authority said in its biannual macroeconomic report released Friday.
That's when Singapore's manufacturing sector will likely be done with structural reforms, which will in turn lead to a more broad-based economic pickup, the central bank said.

It said it reckons the recovery this year will be modest and more gradual compared with previous cycles, describing the current turnaround as a typical rebound from a transitory shock, namely the recent SARS outbreak.
For now, the central bank is maintaining its earlier forecast that Singapore's economy will grow by zero to 1 percent this year before registering growth of 3 percent to 5 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHIUNG MAYOR TO ATTEND LI MEETING IN SENEGAL

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will head a delegation to attend an annual Liberal International (LI) conference to be held in the West African state of Senegal next week, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.
The Liberal International is a London-based organization that groups more than 80 liberal democratic parties in 63 countries around the world. The DPP formally joined the alliance last year.
Hsieh, a member of the DPP's decision-making Central Standing Committee, will attend the meeting on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian who doubles as DPP chairman.
Several DPP politicians and Kaohsiung City Government officials, including Legislators Hung Chi-chang and Hsiao Bi-khim, will accompany Hsieh on the trip to Senegal.

Hsieh's mission will leave for Senegal Monday. Hsieh said President Chen was originally scheduled to attend the LI conference. "But he dropped his plan due to his busy schedule," Hsieh said. Chen will leave for an official visit to Panama late this month.
The Liberal International has been very friendly toward Taiwan. It conferred its prestigious Freedom Prize to President Chen in 2001.
Hsieh said he will take advantage of the upcoming LI meeting to forge closer ties with major LI member parties from Europea and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COAST GUARD SEND BACK ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Coast guard and police officers in Kinmen, a frontline island of Taiwan, on Saturday jointly sent back to mainland China 12 illegal immigrants.

It was the first repatriation mission concerning mainland Chinese illegal immigrants made by Kinmen law enforcement agencies following the Legislative Yuan's passage earlier this month of revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area which increased the punishment to mainland Chinese illegal immigrants.

After the legal process was completed and through the coordination of the Red Cross office in Kinmen, the 12 illegal immigrants, most of whom are from Fujian Province, were transported home by vessels sent by their relatives in mainland China.

Meanwhile, the repatriation of three detained mainland fishing boats, which was originally to be conducted Saturday, has been postponed due to mechanical problems with the vessels. The Kinmen coast guard has agreed to wait until the mainland fishermen repair the boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION DRIVE HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH INDEPENDENCE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum said Saturday the island's new constitution drive has nothing to do with its future relations with mainland China.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tse, who will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the Oct. 20-21 APEC summit in Bangkok, made the remarks during a news conference held after his arrival in the Thai capital.

Noting that Taiwan needs political reforms to stay competitive in the world market, Lee said Chen's recent call for writing a new constitution is mainly aimed at crafting a political framework that fits Taiwan's present reality.
Lee stressed that the drive to introduce a new constitution for Taiwan has nothing to do with the issue regarding whether Taiwan should seek de jure independence or unify with mainland China.
Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit and has instead had to name a proxy to attend the meeting on his behalf.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said he hopes to hold talks with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the APEC summit.
Mainland Chinese President Hu will also attend the APEC summit. "I may have the opportunity to talk with Hu. Should that be the case, it will be my first encounter with him," Lee said.
"I feel a little bit curious about Hu, " he said, adding that if he meets with Hu, he will suggest that Hu sit down to talk with President Chen to enhance mutual understanding.
Last year, Lee also represented Chen at the annual APEC leadership meeting held in Mexico. At that time, Lee recalled that he had friendly chats with then-mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Lee said there exists much misunderstanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"I hope both sides can shelve their preconditions or presumptions and sit down to talk first. We should increase contacts and interaction to forge mutual trust. Despite differences between their governments, I believe, all individual people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are kind-hearted and have goodwill toward each other, " Lee added.

Lee said he feels honored to be able to represent President Chen at the APEC summit. He added that he will do his utmost to contribute to Taiwan's cause while attending the APEC activities in Bangkok.
Lee said Taiwan has actively participated in APEC activities since it was admitted to the regional economic cooperation forum in 1991 along with mainland China.
Over the past years, Lee said, Taiwan has contributed much to helping boost Asia-Pacific regional development, stability and prosperity.

Lee said he will take advantage of the summit meeting to exchange views with top leaders of other APEC member economies on various regional and global issues. In addition, Lee said, he will also hold bilateral talks with leaders of some other APEC members on bilateral trade and economic matters and other topics of mutual concern.
Among others, Lee said, he hopes to meet with U.S. President George W. Bush to discuss issues related to the signing of a free trade agreement between the two countries.

He said President Chen has not given him any specific assignments. "Anyway, I'll coordinate with other members of our delegation to fulfill my mission as Chen's special envoy to the meeting," he added.

Many Taiwan businesspeople operating in Thailand and ethnic Chinese community leaders greeted Lee when he arrived at the Dustin Thani Hotel. Eight major international news media organizations, including CNN, Reuters, and Japan's Sankei Shimbun and Asahi Shimbun, have asked to interview Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH COLUMBIAN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIPEI NEXT WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Oct. 17 (CNA) (by Y. K. Lin and EH)

TEXT.P: British Columbian Minister of Competition, Science, and Enterprise Rick Thorpe is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Wednesday to promote trade.

While in Taiwan, Thorpe will promote the Canadian province's forestry, technology, tourism, and education sectors. He will be accompanied by officials from the British Columbian Council of Forest Industries.
Canada exports 50 million Canadian dollar worth of timber to Taiwan each year, and hopes to increase the export by 100 percent in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN WRAPS UP TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen headed back home to the United States Saturday after a six-day fact-finding visit to Taipei.
The top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan said prior to her departure that her Taipei trip was fruitful, but she didn't elaborate on this.

Shaheen arrived in Taipei Oct. 13 to inspect AIT operations and meet with senior Taiwan officials on matters of mutual concern. This was Shaheen's first visit to Taiwan since assuming the AIT chairmanship late last year.
The AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized to handle U.S. relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

During her stay, Shaheen met with President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and other senior officials. She also delivered a speech at a meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and held a colloquium with National Chengchi University students.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCILORS SUGGEST MORE POSITIVE APPROACH BE USED FOR STRAY DOG PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Several Taipei City councilors on Saturday urged the city government to adopt a more positive approach of dealing with the stray dog problem than putting the dogs to sleep.
Councilors Huang Shan-shan, Wang Chi-ping and Wang Hsin-yi made the remarks after visiting Taipei's animal shelter for stray dogs and other animals.
Citing a report by the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health, Huang said that as of September, Taipei City had a total of 240,000 dogs, with around 110,000 having been implanted with chips.

Noting that the maximum number of stray dogs that can be accommodated at the Taipei animal shelter is 380, Huang said that the shelter has a policy of putting stray dogs to sleep 10 days after they are rounded up if nobody comes forward to claim them.
As of September, the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health had put more than 5,000 stray dogs to sleep and had commissioned other organizations to put an additional 3,000 stray dogs to sleep.
The councilors said that Taipei City Government has used a "passive" approach in dealing with stray animals, suggesting that it adopt a positive approach.
They suggested that the city government take the initiative in investigating dog vendors in night markets and flower markets to learn the source of their dogs.

Noting that Taipei City Government has appropriated NT$3,600 (US$106) for the management of each stray dog that enters the animal shelter, the councilors said that if the city government, based on humanitarian concerns for the dogs, gave the money to private shelters in other cities and counties, then the stray dogs could live six months longer.

Taipei City Government officials said that they will study the feasibility of implementing regulations requiring that those selling dogs only be allowed to do so after implementing the animals with chips and completing the proper pet registration procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SAYS POLITICIANS WHO DWELL IN THE PAST UNABLE TO EMBRACE REFORM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that if political figures only think about themselves and dwell in the past, they will be fearful of reform and be unable to move forward on the path of progress with the people.
The president made the remarks when he addressed the opening of new classes at the Ketagalan Academy, a school founded by himself and with the aim of nurturing future leaders of the nation.

His words were interpreted as being an indirect criticism of his rivals in the 2000 presidential election, namely Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) , and James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) . Chen won the last election by garnering 39.3 percent of the total vote, with Soong trailing close behind and Lien a distant third. Lien and Soong are teaming up to challenge Chen in the next presidential election set for March 20, 2004.

"If political figures only think about themselves, then they will only be able to dwell in the past and try to cling to their privileges and position, " the president said, adding that such political figures "are antagonistic toward reform, fearful of democracy, and mistrustful of the people." He said that politicians with this mentality will be unable to move forward with the people and could even plunge the nation into danger.

Faced with the nation's woes accumulated over five decades of authoritarian rule, Chen said, the people have long aspired for reform, which he said could not be accomplished over the course of a single presidential term.

Referring to the 2000 presidential election in which the KMT regime which had ruled the nation for more than 50 years was swept out of power, Chen said "we should not unrealistically think that the problems accumulated over the past five decades can evaporate in one day."
"Nor should we expect that those political figures who are opposed to democracy, reform and progress will suddenly turn around and become the standard bearers of reform."
The president made the comments in highlighting his theme of "reform vs. anti-reform" for his re-election bid in the next presidential election next March.

Chen said that "what we should be going after is enlisting more reform-minded people to join the reform campaign" so that the force of reform will gain broader support and the nation will be able to move forward.

The president also said that the road to reform is long and winding and the resistance of the anti-reformists is "beyond your imagination, " but he added that if one cannot bear the pain of carrying out reform or if one withdraws because of fear of losing power, then all previous efforts and sacrifices will be washed down the drain.

The president noted that many people have asked him why he has spent so much time and money in setting up the Ketagalan Academy instead of using them to develop the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), of which he concurrently serves as chairman, or for his re-election bid.

Chen stressed that he had said at the inauguration of the school in March of this year that it "is not a DPP school and will not serve specific individuals, but instead will be open to all people and serve as a platform for communication and exchanges on democratic ideals."
"The significance of the school is to quicken the pace of Taiwan's democratic reforms," the president said.
He said that as a figure who has dedicated himself to politics, his task is to care about the people, and not about his own interests.

He said that if political figures think only about the people, then they will be able to courageously shoulder the reform responsibilities even if this means having an adverse effect on their own power and position.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY TO SET UP BRANCH IN MALAYSIA IN 2003 AT EARLIEST

TEXT.P: Officials from National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, revealed Saturday that the school will set up a branch in Malaysia in 2004 at the earliest.
The officials made the revelation during a two-day conference of the heads of Southeast Asian universities which kicked off Saturday in Taipei.
It is expected that Cheng Kung University will be Taiwan's first national university to set up a branch in Southeast Asia.

National Cheng Kung University has nurtured many overseas Chinese students from Southeast Asian nations over the years. Every summer, the university president travels to Malaysia to attend the annual meeting of the Cheng Kung University alumni.

Currently, Cheng Kung University offers MBA classes in Vietnam and Malaysia. Taiwan has also promoted a cooperation project with Malaysian junior colleges, allowing their graduates to come to Taiwan universities that have established cooperation relations with them to study in junior and senior classes and obtain bachelors' degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 2,300 PEOPLE TAKE PART IN TERRY FOX RUN IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 2003 Terry Fox Run, a charity activity originated in Canada in 1980, was held Saturday in Kaohsiung to raise money for cancer research.

More than 2,300 people took part in the 5-kilometer run. They started from the Kaohsiung Medical University (KMU) after Ted Lipman, executive director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei; Wang Kuo-chao, president of the KMU, and Lin Yung-chien, deputy mayor of Kaohsiung blasted the starting guns.
Among the runners are officials of the Kaohsiung City Government, including Han Min-jung, director of the Bureau of Public Health, and Cheng Ying-yao, director of the Bureau of Education.

The Terry Fox Run is held in 4,300 cities in 58 countries in memory of a young Canadian athlete named Terry Fox, who had lost his right foot to bone cancer before he tried to run across Canada and asked every Canadian to donate one Canadian dollar for cancer research. He accomplished his goal before he died of cancer in 1981.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO APEC SUMMIT ARRIVES IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum said Saturday he hopes to hold talks with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of the summit.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tse, who will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the Oct. 20-21 APEC summit in Bangkok, made the remarks after his arrival in the Thai capital.
Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit and has instead had to name a proxy to attend the meeting on his behalf.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said he feels honored to be able to represent President Chen at the APEC summit. He added that he will do his utmost to contribute to Taiwan's cause while attending the APEC activities in Bangkok.
Lee said Taiwan has actively participated in APEC activities since it was admitted to the regional economic cooperation forum in 1991 along with mainland China.
Over the past years, Lee said, Taiwan has contributed much to helping boost Asia-Pacific regional development, stability and prosperity.

Lee said he will take advantage of the summit meeting to exchange views with top leaders of other APEC member economies on various regional and global issues. In addition, Lee said, he will also hold bilateral talks with leaders of some other APEC members on bilateral trade and economic matters and other topics of mutual concern.

He said President Chen has not given him any specific assignments. "Anyway, I'll coordinate with other members of our delegation to fulfill my mission as Chen's special envoy to the meeting," he added.
Mainland Chinese President Hu will also attend the APEC summit. "I may have the opportunity to talk with Hu. Should that be the case, it will be my first encounter with him," Lee said.
"I feel a little bit curious about Hu, " he said, adding that he hopes to have bilateral talks with him on the sidelines of the APEC summit.
Last year, Lee also represented Chen at the annual APEC leadership meeting held in Mexico. At that time, Lee recalled that he had friendly chats with then-mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Lee said there exists much misunderstanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"I hope both sides can shelve their preconditions or presumptions and sit down to talk first. We should increase contacts and interaction to forge mutual trust. Despite differences between their governments, I believe, all individual people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are kind-hearted and have goodwill toward each other, " Lee added.

Many Taiwan businesspeople operating in Thailand and ethnic Chinese community leaders greeted Lee when he arrived at Dustin Thani Hotel. Eight major international news media, including Japan's Sankei Shimbun and Asahi Shimbun as well as CNN and Reuters, have asked to interview Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN LEGISLATIVE VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The vice president of El Salvador's National Assembly, Jose Manuel Melgar, is set to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a five-day visit.

Heading a 19-member parliamentarian delegation, Melgar will call on Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the office of Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund, and the Central American Trade Office.

The Salvadoran delegation is also scheduled to visit several economic and cultural establishments in Taiwan, including an agricultural research center in Taoyuan run by the Council of Agriculture, a vocational training center operated by the Taipei City Government, as well as the Taipei World Trade Center and the National Palace Museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 18, or the 23rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty-three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT MATTERS NOT AN ISSUE IN TAIWAN INVESTMENT: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: While cross-Taiwan Strait relations is a factor to be considered in investing in Taiwan, foreign corporations do not need to take sides between Taiwan and mainland China, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang said Sunday.

Shih made the remarks at a news conference in response to foreign journalists' inquiries about the possible impact of cross-strait relations on foreign business people's willingness to invest in Taiwan.

Forty-one foreign journalists from around the world have traveled to Taipei to cover the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference -- the largest investment conference ever held in Taiwan. Many of them were interested in the latest developments in cross-strait relations and their possible impact on Taiwan's investment climate and economic prospects.

During the news conference where Shih briefed foreign correspondents on the theme of the Oct. 19-22 investment event, a correspondent from the French daily Le Figaro asked: "Will Taiwan be a more attractive investment destination if it forges closer ties with mainland China?"

As a matter of fact, Shih replied, Taiwan companies have maintained close interactions with their mainland Chinese counterparts. And for its part, he continued, the ROC government has also drawn up a comprehensive blueprint for forging direct cross-strait transportation links in a step-by-step approach. Shih said he believes a major breakthrough will be achieved after Taiwan's next presidential election on March 20, 2004.
As to how Taiwan can attract foreign investors given mainland China's "one China" principle, Shih said foreign investors tend to set their sights on long-term development prospects or potential.

"Investment involves many factors and is not a simple 'yes or no' choice. While cross-strait relations may be a factor to be considered, it's not necessarily a decisive one. More important, foreign companies do not need to take sides between Taiwan and the mainland," Shih explained.
As Taiwan enjoys a large surplus in its trade with mainland China, foreign journalists were concerned about future cross-strait trade development.

Shih said Taiwan companies have invested a large amount of capital in mainland China. Up to 60 or 70 percent of semiconductors and LCD products exported from mainland China are manufactured by Taiwan-funded plants there. Against this backdrop, he said, cross-strait trade ties will become even closer in the future.

A reporter from the German daily Sueddeutsche Zeitung asked whether Taiwan's intensive investment promotion drive is aimed at avoiding being marginalized in the face of gradual economic integration of Southeast Asian countries and mainland China's "magnet effect" in attracting foreign capital.

In response, Shih said Taiwan intends to court high value-added and high-tech industries. "Our per capita national income is much higher than mainland China's and ASEAN countries'. Our targets are different from theirs," he added.

Some foreign journalists asked about Taiwan's prospects for signing free trade agreements with other countries. Shih said Taiwan has signed a free trade pact with Panama and will endeavor to negotiate similar agreements with major trading partners, including the United States, Singapore, Japan and European countries. "Trade is our lifeline. We'll spare no effort in seeking closer trade ties with other countries."

Asked whether President Chen Shui-bian's recent call for writing a new constitution and the ongoing "Call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement initiated by former President Lee Teng-hui will have an adverse impact on Taiwan's drive to attract foreign investments, Shih said he is not in a position to talk about sensitive political issues. Nevertheless, he said politics should not interfere with economic activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES, NATIONAL SECURITY TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: Taiwan Advocates, a group devoted to research on Taiwan's course, is slated to hold a seminar on the impact of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and national security Nov. 1-2 in Taipei.

Chou Mei-li, chief of the Taiwan Advocates' legal affairs department, said now is the right time to conduct a comprehensive review of the opening policy initiated by the late President Chiang Ching-kuo in 1987, under which retired veterans were allowed to go back to mainland China to visit their family.

Stressing that the policy has had a profound impact on every walk of life in Taiwan over the past 16 years and that the aim of the seminar is to find the means to help with Taiwan's sustainable development, Chou said scores of experts will be invited to discuss issues related to national security and economic exchanges amid the increased contacts between the two sides of the strait.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, who serves as chairman of the Taiwan Advocates, will give a speech at the opening of the seminar and he will also take part in the roundtable forums that will follow.
Gordon G. Chang, author of the book -- The Coming Collapse of China -- will also give a keynote speech in the seminar.
