DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS CONFERENCE BEGINS WITH NUMEROUS CONFIRMED INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: The curtain was raised on the long-planned 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference at the Taipei International Convention Center Sunday evening as part of the government's intensive campaign to attract investment.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said at a news conference held earlier in the day that 15 world-renowned foreign companies have agreed to sign investment contracts during the conference.

Those companies include Japan's Asahi Glass Co., Toppan Printing and NTT DoCoMo as well as Corning and Dupont of the United States, Infineon of Germany and Cerberus Asia Capital Management of Thailand, Shih said.
Moreover, he added, 13 business groups have announced their decision to set up research and development (R&D) facilities in Taiwan.
Shih briefed local and foreign journalists on the main purposes of the Oct. 19-22 Business Alliance Conference -- the largest investment promotion event ever held in Taiwan.
In the evening, Premier Yu Shyi-kun hosted a cocktail reception to welcome the 1,913 prospective investors from Taiwan and abroad on behalf of the ROC government.

Shih said that the theme of the meeting is "Invest in Taiwan, Access the World" with the ultimate aim of helping Taiwan build an internationally competitive investment climate and to spur sustained domestic economic growth.

To ensure the conference is a success, Shih said, government agencies have made strenuous efforts to push for the realization of investment projects. In addition to visiting numerous foreign companies in the past few months to understand their investment plans, Shih said, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has also coordinated with other relevant government agencies to resolve investment obstacles pointed out by foreign business people.
All those efforts have paid off, Shih said, adding that MOEA has so far received 186 promised investment projects, with 113 of them, worth NT$68.22 billion (US$2.02 billion), having been confirmed.

These projects cover a variety of industries, including finance and insurance, video display and optoelectronics, telecommunications, precision machinery, semiconductors, microelectronics, biotechnology and health care, Shih said.
"The four industries with the most foreign investment are video display/optoelectronics, semiconductors/microelectronics, finance/insurance, and telecommunications," he added.

Meanwhile, Shih said, the 73 promised investment projects will be worth NT$70.17 billion, with semiconductors/microelectronics, biotechnology/health care, video display/optoelectronics and telecommunications expected to bring in the largest amount of capital.
Shih said there will also be 290 follow-up investment projects, worth an estimated NT$94.9 billion, to be launched in Taiwan in the future.

With concerted efforts by the central, county and city governments, Shih said, the four-day business alliance conference has already attracted foreign investments well over the original target of NT$100 billion.

Moreover, Shih said, various government agencies have come up with a total of 126 public construction projects to be opened for foreign investments. All these projects will offer more than NT$400 billion worth of business opportunities for prospective foreign investors, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION ARRIVES IN IRAN FOR FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tehran, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 20-member delegation from Taiwan arrived in the Iranian capital of Tehran Sunday to take part in the 48th Asia-Pacific Film Festival from Oct. 20-23.
Led by Central Motion Picture Company General Manager Chiu Shung-ching, the delegation, including director Lin Chen-sheng and actress Yang Kuei-mei, arrived in the city after a 24-hour flight.
Chiu said the delegation was warmly received by the festival organizers. Yang said she hopes to introduce Taiwan's achievements in art and film-making to the rest of the participating countries.

A total of 18 cities -- Taipei, Bangkok, Bombay, Hanoi, Hong Kong, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Kuwait, Manila, Moscow, Seoul, Singapore, Sydney, Tashkent, Tbilisi, Tehran, Tokyo and Wellington -- which are members of a regional film-makers alliance, will jointly participate in the event, which also includes academic seminars and a poster exhibition.

Three Taiwan-made films -- Robinson Crusoe by Lin Chen-sheng, Goodbye Dragon Inn by Tsai Ming-liang, and Somewhere Over the Dreamland by Chang Wen-tang -- will be competing for a series of awards at the festival.
Tokyo will sponsor the 49th Asia-Pacific Film Festival next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTORS FROM 35 COUNTRIES ATTEND TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The 2003 Business Alliance Conference kicked off its four-day meeting Sunday at the Taipei International Convention Center.
There were 1,913 investors registered to participate in the largest business conference in Taiwan, with 689 coming from 35 countries, accounting for 53.06 percent of the total registrants.

There were 689 guests from overseas including those from the seven major industrialized nations -- the United States, Japan, Great Britain, Germany, France, Canada and Italy -- as well as Singapore, New Zealand, Australia, the Netherlands, Israel, Hong Kong and other countries. There were 41 reporters from more than 30 countries in attendance.

Out of the total attendees, 536 foreign businessmen have already invested in Taiwan, and 569 local manufacturers as well as 119 foreign trade officials stationed in Taiwan also registered for the conference. The turnout has far exceeded the original estimate of 600 participants.

The foreign trade officials were interested in the larger-than-expected turnout by foreign investors given the so-call "magnetic effect" of mainland China, which has drawn investment away from many countries in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL IMPASSE LOOMING OVER BUDGET PLAN

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will find it difficult to review the Executive Yuan's budget plan Monday if it refuses to correct legal defects as requested by the legislature, opposition lawmaker Chou Hsih-wei said Sunday.

With help of other parties, lawmakers from Chou's People First Party railroaded a resolution through the legislature last week, demanding that the Executive Yuan take back its budget plan and correct what the legislators described as legal errors by Monday. The demand was refused by Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who insisted that there is nothing inappropriate in the budget.

Chou said the legislature will not be able to remit the budget plan to committees for review on Monday as the Executive Yuan has refused to comply with the Legislative Yuan resolution, a problem for which the Executive Yuan is to blame.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APEC ENVOY TO PASS MESSAGE TO U.S. PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Lee Yuan-tseh, Taiwan's envoy to the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's leader's summit, said Sunday that he hopes to tell U.S. President George Bush that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will honor his promise not to seek independence.

In interviews with the international media, the Nobel laureate and president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica said that if he gets the opportunity to meet Bush on the sidelines of the APEC meet, he will tell the U.S. leader that Chen is not a troublemaker and will refrain from flirting with the idea of seeking permanent separation from mainland China as he promised in his 2000 inaugural speech.

Lee was quoted by Lee Cher-jean, a spokeswoman for the Taipei APEC delegation, as saying in the interview that Lee will also explain to Bush that Chen's calls for a plebiscite and a new constitution are efforts to give the public a say in the country's policy-making and to adapt existing political systems to the reality of the present situation and as such, do not constitute a breach of his inaugural promises.

Lee said he also wants to meet with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao to discuss developing democracy and the economy, although he admitted that the chances of Hu agreeing to such a meeting are slim.
"Only talks without preconditions can sort out misunderstandings and improve bilateral ties," Lee said.
Beijing missed a good chance to reach out to the Taiwan people earlier this year when Taiwan fell into the grip of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks, Lee went on.
Instead of helping Taiwan to fight SARS, Beijing complicated the country's efforts by thwarting its bid to join the World Health Organization, said Lee.
Lee's interview is expected to be broadcast by the BBC on Monday or Tuesday and will be replayed several times, according to Lee Cher-jean.
Lee was appointed by Chen as Taipei's envoy to the APEC summit, which is off-limits to Taiwan's leaders because of pressure from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE PACT WITH PANAMA CONCLUDED ACCORDING TO CONSTITUTION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed a free trade agreement (FTA) with Panama in August in accordance with all legal procedures, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Sunday.

Shen Pei-huang, director of the Treaty and Legal Affairs Department under the MOFA, said his ministry briefed various political factions at the legislature in February and March and submitted a report to the Foreign Affairs Committee and the Economic Affairs Committee at the Legislative Yuan in May.

The official said all treaty-conclusion procedures provided for in the Constitution were followed before Chen inked the pact with his Panama counterpart Mireya Elisa Moscoso in August. The legislature was not overlooked at all, he added.

He made the remarks in response to criticism from opposition lawmaker Hsu Yuan-kuo of the People First Party, who claimed that the president broke constitutional procedure by inking the pact first before asking the legislature for ratification.

DPP whip at the legislature Chen Chih-mai echoed Shen's view, noting that the Constitution empowers the president to conclude agreements with other countries while giving the legislature the power to review any treaty with other countries. However, the Constitution does not specify which step goes before the other.

The MOFA and the Economics Ministry informed the economic affairs and foreign affairs committees of the legislature in February and May, respectively, about the pact and no party raised any objection at the time, Chen said.

The FTA with Panama, inked in Taipei Aug. 21, is the first of its kind for the country and is touted as a diplomatic feat of the government, which hopes it will pave the way for similar pacts with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVNET ELECTRONICS MARKETING ANNOUNCES SETTING UP OF TAIWAN HUB

TEXT.P: U.S.-based Avnet Electronics Marketing, one of the world's largest technology, marketing, distribution and services company, announced Sunday that it will set up a new service center in Taiwan to meet fast-growing demand in Asia.

Avnet Electronics Marketing President Andy Bryant said the company made the decision because it had reached its benchmark goal of US$1 billion in sales last year, representing an annual growth rate of 40 percent.

Avnet is determined to provide the best technology and service to its clients in Asia and the rest of the world by making increased investment in personnel and facilities to satisfy Asia's strong demand. This includes recruiting 70 frontline workers last year to join the current line-ups in Taiwan and mainland China, Bryant said, noting the opening of the Taiwan service center will bring to 20 the number of its offices in the Greater China area.

Raymond Tsang, head of Avnet Electronics Marketing Asia, said the current Taiwan team has made an outstanding contribution to the company's success in the region and added that the mother company will continue to invest in Taiwan in the face of the booming developments in the Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland markets.

Avnet has already opened a logistics hub in Taiwan, one in Hong Kong and three on the mainland, Tsang noted, adding that the five logistics centers have markedly shortened the traffic time of products and provide a sound warehousing environment in Asia.

The five Asian logistics centers, linked with others in the rest of the world, offer Avnet clients, including those in Taiwan, a quick and high-quality service in logistics flow and a warehousing network, Tsang said.

Avnet, based in Phoenix, Arizona, is a leading B2B supplier of interconnections, electro-mechanical and electric components and material logistic services. Leading world-class companies, such as IBM, Motorola, Intel, Microsoft and HP are among its clientele. Business revenue of its 2003 fiscal year (as of June 30) hit US$9.05 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY TO ENTERTAIN FOREIGN SPOUSES WITH CARNIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, central Taiwan, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A carnival is scheduled to be held in Touliu Oct. 26 to honor foreign spouses in Yunlin County, which is home to the largest number of "foreign brides" among all the cities and counties of Taiwan.

The carnival will feature a comic drama of a kaleidoscope of life in Taiwan involving assorted cultures and peoples, singing, dancing, folk arts and other performances, culminating with a street carnival featuring a procession of women attired in traditional costumes and wedding gowns from different countries.
According to the Yunlin Family Education Center, which is sponsoring the event, Yunlin County is now home to 9,199 foreign wives.

Some of them -- most of whom are from Southeast Asia -- have encountered problems adapting to daily lives in Taiwan because of differences in language, national customs and personal habits. The foreign nationals find it particularly difficult in areas such as children's education and getting along with their Taiwan husbands and in-laws, according to the sponsor.

DOC.HEADLINE: 41 FOREIGN JOURNALISTS IN TAIPEI TO COVER BUSINESS ALLIANCE CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Forty-one foreign journalists from around the world have traveled to Taipei to cover Taiwan's largest-ever investment conference scheduled to open at the Taipei International Convention Center Monday.

At the joint invitation of the Government Information Office and the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) , major news organizations from the United States, Germany, France, Israel, Hong Kong, Japan and Singapore have sent senior correspondents to cover the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

On the eve of the investment-promotion conference, Central News Agency (CNA) Chairman Su Tzen-ping and CETRA secretary-general Chao Yung-chuan briefed the visiting foreign journalists on press services available during the conference.

Su told the foreign journalists that the conference press center set up by CNA under the commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs will issue press releases for the conference and will serve as a link between organizations and journalists.
"We will try to keep in close contact with all of you over the next few days," Su said.

As Taiwan's national news agency, Su went on, CNA, is charged with a mission and responsibility different from those of other media, which is to inform the world about events in Taiwan as quickly as possible.
"In order to make Taiwan's role in the global village stronger, CNA will do its best to serve all of you during the conference, " he added.

Located on the first floor of the venue of the conference, Su said, the press center has editors who will edit and issue news stories in Chinese, English, Spanish, French and Japanese during the conference to serve the media of different countries.
During the conference, Su said, the center will issue English press releases five times a day, Chinese press releases eight times a day, and Spanish, Japanese and French press releases twice a day.
CNA President Hu Yuan-hui, and CNA Vice Presidents Lee Wan-lai and Liu Chih-tsun also attended the press briefing.

After the briefing, Su and CETRA Secretary-General Chao gave foreign journalists a tour of the conference press center and introduced to them various advanced news facilities, including a digitalized editing system.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: Bush voews Mindanao support.
United States President George W. Bush yesterday reiterated his country's commitment of support to the Philippine development efforts in Mindanao, its education program, and a fiveyear military modernization assistance as he urged Congress to "invest" more in guaranteeing victory against terror.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Bush hails RP as top ally of US.
US PRESIDENT George W. Bush Saturday poured on the charm and rhapsodized on the country he called the United States' "oldest ally in Asia" and "one of America's most valued friends in the world."
The Philippine Star: Bush: We stand together.
Calling Philippine-US military alliance a "rock of stability in the Pacific, " US President George W. Bush lauded yesterday both nations'security cooperation and committed support against terrorism in the country and the rest of Southeast Asia.
The Manila Times: Bush acclaims RP democracy.
US President George W. Bush on Saturday commended the Philippines for its role in the Asian democratic movement and the worldwide war against terrorism, and declared that the United States cherishes Philippine friendship and that it will keep this strong for years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MINISTER HAILS TAIWAN FOR HOLDING MEETINGS ON SMES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Economic ministers attending the annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in the Thai capital issued a joint statement Saturday hailing Taiwan's successful organization of incubator forums and meetings to promote small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

The economic ministers of the 21-member APEC trade grouping praised Taiwan's holding of two incubator forums in July and August and an SME seminar in August at the end of a two-day ministerial-level meeting. They said Taiwan's organization of the meetings has benefited the region's SMEs a great deal and has helped give a boost to the sector's development in the Asia-Pacific region.

The ministers have the plan to work out in 2004 action guidelines to promote SMEs and micro-businesses, including establishing a small business databank and a network for trade promotion and market exploration strategy.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRIES TO START TALKS WITH U.S. ON FREE TRADE PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will try to explore the possibility of concluding a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United State when the two countries talk about a trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA) , Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said here Sunday.

Lin, who is attending a ministerial conference of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, told CNA that Washington has agreed to resume the TIFA talks with Taiwan next year and that Taipei intends to include FTA discussions.

Taipei and Washington started a series of working group-level talks in October 2002 with a view of starting the TIFA negotiations in Washington in November that year. But the formal talks never materialized because of Washington's complaint that Taiwan did not fully honor promises, which it made when it entered the World Trade Organization in 2002, concerning protection of intellectual property rights, opening markets to foreign rice and foreign telecommunication companies.

Taiwan has experienced difficulties in its attempts to forge free trade pacts with countries that do not recognize it, as these countries are vulnerable to diplomatic pressure from mainland China, the minister said.
This situation, however, could change if the United States, which also does not maintain official ties with Taiwan, takes the lead in entering into such a pact with Taiwan, Lin went on.
Lin said his ministry is pleased to learn that Washington has given a green light to TIFA talks and is trying to convince Washington to conduct FTA talks at the same time.
Besides the United States, Lin said Taiwan is trying to push for similar pacts with Japan, New Zealand and Singapore, Lin added.

In a bilateral talks on the fringes of the Bangkok conference, Lin said that Japanese Economic, Trade and Industry Minister Shoichi Nakagawa agreed to start the process by having private scholars study the feasibility of such a pact first, with an outcome hopefully by the end of this year.
Taiwan is hoping to set up a joint panel with Singapore to study the possibility of a FTA and is also approaching New Zealand about the issue, said Lin.
Wrapping up the APEC ministerial conference in Bangkok, Lin was slated to fly back to Taipei later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORTS FREE AND FAIR ELECTIONS IN TAIWAN: STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States supports free and fair elections in Taiwan, but does not favor one candidate or one party over another, a State Department spokesman said Saturday.

In March 2004, Taiwan will hold its third direct democratically contested presidential election, which will be another milestone in Taiwan's remarkable democratic development, said Adam Ereli, deputy spokesman for the State Department.
"We look forward to working with whomever the people of Taiwan elect as their next president and vice president, " Ereli said in a statement.

"The traditional bonds of friendship between the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan remain as strong and vibrant as ever," the statement said, adding that "Taiwan and its leaders can count on the United States to pursue a steady and constructive policy toward East Asia and the Taiwan Strait area."

"We will continue to adhere to our one-China policy. We will insist on a peaceful resolution of differences between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China. We support constructive dialogue between the two sides as the best means to bring about, on a mutually acceptable basis, a lasting peace in this important region," said the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE ROCKS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale occurred at 5:20 a.m. Sunday in Hualien in eastern Taiwan.
The Central Weather Bureau said the epicenter was located about 7.7 kilometers southeast of Hualien at a depth of 50 kilometers under the sea level.
The earthquake had an intensity of 2.0 at Nanao in Ilan County and Hsilin in Hualien County.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO ESTABLISH DR. SUN YAT-SEN MEMORIAL LIBRARY

TEXT.P: The major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) plans to establish a library in its headquarters in downtown Taipei in memory of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of the Republic of China.

A KMT official said Sunday that Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Library will be open to the general public. It will have an exhibition hall, a conference room, reading rooms, and many kinds of books and other publications published on the Chinese mainland and Taiwan in the late 19th century and the early 20th century.
He said construction of the library will begin next year. The blueprint for the library will be announced on Dr. Sun's birthday on Nov. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Economic reform passes test in Berlin. Lower house votes for Schroder's plan to revamp welfare.
The lower house of the German Parliament on Friday passed a major part of the economic reform package that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder had said was essential to reduce unemployment and prod this country out of its prolonged economic stagnation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 19, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DEDICATED TO UPGRADING GLOBAL COMPETITIVENESS: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Monday that the government is dedicated to upgrading Taiwan's global competitiveness.
Lin made the remarks during his address at the opening ceremony of the
2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, which is being attended by more than 1,900 potential investors from around the world.

The vice premier said that "Putting investment first, the economy first, and Taiwan first has always been the Republic of China's core economic development policy." Under this policy, he said that the government has made major breakthroughs in improving the business environment of Taiwan and upgrading its national competitiveness.

Lin noted that the government has continued to appraise industrial land acquisition and investment incentives, convenience and efficiency in applying for licenses, liberalization of the stock and financial markets, and the environment.
"The success of efforts in these areas has been acknowledged around the world, " Lin said, citing
Dell, Intel, IBM, HP, Sony and other major multinational companies that have established R&D centers in Taiwan.

Lin stressed that the aim of the largest international investors conference ever held in Taiwan is "to help the multilateral enterprises understand the advantages of the island's investment environment better." With this knowledge, companies can "plan their global development strategies using the Republic of China as their logistics center for the development of Asia-Pacific markets."

Lin noted that the conference encompasses an comprehensive series of activities, mainly summit forums, industry workshops, booths displaying business opportunities, and visits to relevant business locations in Taiwan.

Lin stressed that two of the summit forums will feature leaders from top global multinational companies who will share their experiences on globalization and localization to stimulate new thinking for the government and corporations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS URGED TO KEEP PHOTOS OF ACCOUNT HOLDERS

TEXT.P: Banks should establish a photo filing system by the end of this year so that they can keep photos of new account holders in their files, an official of the Executive Yuan said Monday.
Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said that Premier Yu Shyi-kun issued the instructions at a special Cabinet-level meeting on enhancing domestic security and public order.

Yu also instructed related government agencies to set up a special task force to crack down on financial crimes, to hold talks with mainland China on establishing liaison channels for jointly combating crime, to accelerate the issuance of financial IC cards, to enhance the scrutiny of applications for new bank accounts and to take other preventive measures, according to Liu.
For her part, Vice Minister of Finance Chang Shiu-lien said that banks should establish a monitoring center by the end of June 2005 to supervise their own ATM machines 24 hours a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PRESIDENT TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush will make an official visit to Singapore Oct. 21-22 at the invitation of Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong.
This will be Bush's first official visit to Singapore, according to the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

He will be accompanied by U.S. first lady Laura Bush and key U.S. officials, including National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice, Chief of Staff Andrew Card Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly and National Security Council Senior Director for Asian Affairs James Moriarty.
Bush will call on Singapore President S.R. Nathan and will meet with Goh and other Cabinet ministers. Goh will host a dinner in honor of Bush and his entourage Oct. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNNEL-BORING WORK ON BEIYI FREEWAY COMPLETED

TEXT.P: Tunnel-boring work on the Beiyi Freeway was completed Monday, representing a big step forward in the construction of the freeway that will link Taipei City and the northeastern county of Ilan.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the completion of the boring work, President Chen Shui-bian claimed that it shows his administration's efficiency in carrying out public projects, as well as Taiwan's dynamism and international competitiveness.
Chen was accompanied by Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san to witness the fall of the last piece of rock in the tunnel prior to the ceremony.

Officials of the Taiwan Area National Expressway Engineering Bureau said that the completion of the boring shows that all the difficulties that could be encountered in developing the tunnel have been overcome.
The tunneling of the main section of the Shueishan Tunnel will be finished by next September, smoothing the way for the completion of the whole project by the end of 2005, they added.

The 12.9-km Shueishan Tunnel, also known as the "tunnel beneath troubled waters" because of the engineering difficulties encountered during its construction, is the centerpiece of the 31-km Beiyi Freeway project.
Construction on the project has long been delayed because of the geological formation of Shueishan (Snow Mountain), through which the tunnel will pass.
More than a decade has passed since construction began in 1991. Boring work has often been halted due to the frequent upwelling of water at the construction site, as well as mud slides.
When the freeway is completed, the drive from Taipei to Ilan will take only 40 minutes, compared to the two hours required at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF TECHNOLOGY SERVICE SECTOR EXPECTED TO GROW

TEXT.P: The production value of the technical and engineering service sector is expected to grow by between one to two fold in the next five years, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

Chen Chao-yih, director-general of the IDB, made the remarks when he presided over a technical and engineering service seminar as part of the 12 industry seminars of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

Chen noted that the ratio of the service sector to the gross domestic product (GDP) hovered between 40 and 50 percent in the 1950s, and the ratio has risen steadily since. In 1977, with the conventional industries moving overseas and the government's opening of indirect investment in mainland China, the ratio of the service sector in the GDP rose rapidly, with the number shooting up to 67.3 percent, almost on par with industrialized nations, last year.

The ratio of the technology service sector accounted for between two to three percent, and the production value of the technical and engineering service sector is expected to grow by between one and two fold in five years.

Liao Jen-hsiang, president of HP Taiwan, said on the same occasion that looking over the past three decades, Taiwan produced mainly umbrellas and shoes in the first decade, then moved to PC production in the second 10 years, and with the deregulation in the third decade, the telecommunications, banking and financial service sectors rose rapidly.

With the transformation of Taiwan in recent years, Liao said that HP has increased its purchases in Taiwan to reach US$14.5 billion last year, or more than its sales in Taiwan, and that HP never dreamed of such success when it first invested in Taiwan 30 years ago. He said that HP has 140,000 staff worldwide, with Taiwan accounting for 10 percent.

One of the participants, Taigi Watanabe, president of Ever Power Co., said that it is not easy to build a power plant, and that it has chosen Taiwan for investment because of political stability, good infrastructure and the high education and banking system. The company has obtained syndicated loans from more than 20 banks.

Another participant, Chen Hsin-pu, president of Brambles Group Cleanaway Taiwan, addressed environmental protection services, saying that when the Environmental Protection Administration was established in Taiwan more than 10 years ago, much information was lacking, but that the transparency of the present government is quite high, which he said would reduce business risks for manufactures.

Chen said that the regulations of Taiwan are more comprehensive than in other developing countries, but expressed the hope that Taiwan could pass a bill on the use of renewable energy, which he said will attract more foreign investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN ATHLETE BREAKS WEIGHT LIFTING RECORD OF ASIAN GAMES

TEXT.P: A new record was set Monday at the 2003 National Taiwan Athletic Meet when Lee Feng-ying made her best-ever performance to seize the weight lifting championship, breaking three previous bests registered at the Asian Games.

Lee, a female weight lifter in the 58-kg category, set a new record with a total lift of 226 kg -- 127.5 kg in the clean and jerk and 98.5 kg in the snatch -- all of which exceeded the best levels ever posted in previous Asian Games.
Lee's records are also the first-ever posted during this year's national meet that exceed Asian Games records. The National Taiwan Athletic Meet is held every two years.

The best Asian Games record of 125 kg in the women's clean and jerk in the 58-kg category was posted in Busan, South Korea, while the previous Asian Games records of 98 kg in the snatch and 220 kg in total lift were set in Bangkok. Both record breakers are from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC LANDS MAJOR DEAL WITH BOEING

TEXT.P: Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) said Monday it has landed a deal to provide main landing gear doors for next-generation Boeing 737 airplanes.
The state-owned AIDC made the announcement at a panel session of the ongoing 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.
An AIDC spokesman said the first delivery of the landing gear doors is scheduled for February 2004, with subsequent deliveries continuing into 2014.

Wade Cornelius, vice president of Global Strategies of Boeing Commercial Airplanes, said at the session that Boeing has been pleased with its business ties with AIDC -- Taiwan's only aircraft manufacturer.
"Their adherence to schedules and market-based pricing are what we value throughout our supply base as we continue to increase efficiency and become more competitive," Cornelius said.
Since 1996, AIDC has been a supplier-partner of Boeing, having participated with the aerospace giant on the development and building of B717-200 empennages.

"AIDC is proud to be a supplier for the most popular commercial airplane in the world, " said AIDC Vice President James Mao. "Participation in the Boeing 737 program is an indication of AIDC's greater role in the aviation industry and Boeing's commitment to our partnership."

DOC.HEADLINE: FSA TO SET UP REGIONAL HEADQUARTERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou welcomed the Fabless Semiconductor Association (FSA) to set up its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Taipei during a meeting with the association's executive director Monday.
Ma told Jodi Shelton that Taipei hopes to have members of the FSA set up in Taipei and said he would ask the Taipei City Government to provide further assistance to the association.

Ma also seized the opportunity to introduce the Neihu Science Industrial Park and Nankang Software Industrial Park. Shelton said she was happy to learn that the Taipei City Government will meet the demands of manufacturers by expanding parking lots and opening more bus lanes to the two parks in suburban Taipei.

Shelton said that she was receptive to Taipei's plan to build a network city, as well as developing itself into an international convention center. The FSA is also considering sponsoring a business exhibition in Taipei next year.

Shelton earlier lauded the strengths of Taiwan in its semiconductor industry at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, which formally began Oct. 20. She also said that this was the reason why the FSA wants to set up its regional headquarters on the island.

The FSA was founded in 1984 with more than 400 semiconductor enterprises to promote a balance between foundry supply and demand. Because the growth of the semiconductor industry in Asia and the Pacific region is rising, it has decided to set up regional headquarters in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Terrorism and North Korea discussed before APEC meet.
U.S. President George W. Bush met with world leaders and discussed terrorism and the North Korean crisis Sunday ahead of a summit of 21 Pacific-Rim nations to be held under heavy guard in the Thai capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT FOREIGN COMPANIES SIGN COOPERATIVE PACTS WITH LOCAL FIRMS

TEXT.P: The ongoing 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference has recorded initial success, with eight foreign business groups signing cooperative contracts with local companies or government units Monday.

The eight cooperative agreements cover a wide range of industries, including railed cars, military helicopters, avionics, semiconductor equipment, heavy-duty vehicles and wireless communications technology.

"All these cooperative projects will effectively help upgrade Taiwan's overall industrial competitiveness, " said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang, who witnessed the signing of the eight agreements at a joint ceremony at the business alliance conference.
The eight cooperative pacts are as follows:

-- A memorandum of understanding on cooperation between TUV Rheinland Taiwan Ltd. and the Center for Aerospace and SystemTechnology under the government-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) under which the two units will cooperate in testing railed car parts and components;

-- A technology transfer contract between Genstar Technologies Co. (Gentec) of the United States and the ITRI's Mechanical Industry Research Institute under which Gentec and ITRI will cooperate in developing new semiconductor-related products;

-- A cooperative pact between Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. and state-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) under which Bell will create an upgrade, remodeling and maintenance center for its AH-1W and UH-1W helicopters in cooperation with AIDC;

-- A letter of intent signed between Crane Aerospace and the Ministry of Economic Affairs under which the U.S.-based firm is committed to setting up an Asian operations headquarters and a research facility in Taiwan;

-- A cooperative accord between Japanese-funded Fujitsu Taiwan Ltd. and three Taiwan firms -- Wistron, Giga-Bytes Technology and Askey Computer -- under which they will jointly develop digitalized supply and inventory control systems;

-- A cooperative accord between Hong Kong-based Forefront International Holdings Ltd. and Taiwan's Forefront Automobile Industry under which they will cooperate in setting up a heavy-duty vehicle assembly plant in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER CANCELS U.S. TRIP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng canceled Monday a trip to the United States planned for the coming weekend, citing a tight schedule at the legislature as the reason for the cancellation.

Wang, who was originally slated to depart for the United States Oct. 25 to give a speech at an overseas Chinese democratic conference sponsored by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Houston, had to cancel the trip because of various important legislative matters such as a dispute over the government's budget plan for fiscal 2004.
Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen will make the trip and address the conference in Wang's stead.
The legislative speaker has also had to put off a plan to receive an honorary doctorate in law Oct. 27 from St. John's University.

Opposition lawmakers, mainly from the People First Party, have demanded that the Executive Yuan withdraw its government spending budget and correct what they call "legal errors, " but Premier Yu Shyi-kun has rejected the request, claiming that there is nothing in the plan that needs changing.
The government's budget plan was slated to be submitted Monday for review by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD TALK WITH MUTUAL TRUST: APEC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Wu Hyi-chun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders summit being held in Bangkok, proposed Monday that Taiwan and mainland China should enter discussions.
According to Lee Cher-jean, spokeswoman for the Taiwan delegation to the summit, Lee made the proposal during an interview with the Nation -- Thailand's largest media group.
Lee said that Taiwan and the mainland should first forge mutual trust so that leaders of both sides can then start talks on a wide range of topics, including the contentious "one China" issue.
Lee was quoted as stressing that the Beijing regime would not need to worry about any declaration of Taiwan independence if the communists would build a free and democratic system in mainland China.

A country's leader has the responsibility to lead his nation and its neighbors toward cooperation and harmonious co-existence, which is a key element to the development of the world's civilization, the Academia Sinica chief said, adding that Chen would make a greater contribution if he were able to participate in the APEC summit in person.

Commenting on Taiwan-Thailand relations, Lee praised the well-established friendly ties between the two countries and revealed that Taiwan has initiated a plan to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with Thailand to further cement bilateral trade and commercial ties.

Taiwan, as Thailand's third-largest foreign investor, hopes to further enhance and strengthen its substantial relationship with the Southeast Asian country, he noted, adding that he strongly believes bilateral ties will continue with positive developments.
Lee also held talks earlier the same day with Papua New Guinea Prime Minister Michael Somare to exchange views and discuss issues of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCATEL SIGNS MOU WITH TAIWAN RESEARCH INSTITUTE

TEXT.P: Alcatel Taiwan Ltd. signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on setting up a research and development center in Taiwan with the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).
C. L. Chang, vice president of Alcatel Taiwan Ltd., and Pual
Lin Bao-Shuh, director of ITRI's Computer and Communication Research Lab, signed the MOU at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference which formally opened Oct. 20.

Alcatel will soon celebrate 30 years in the Taiwan market. The group has set up several businesses including TAISEL, Taiwan International Standard Electronics Ltd, Radio Frequency Systems and Genesys. Among them, TAISEL, Taiwan International Standard Electronics Ltd. is a joint venture between Alcatel and Chunghwa Telecom, with Alcatel holding 60 percent of the shares and Chunghwa Telecom holding the remaining 40 percent.

Alcatel officials said that the group has entered the areas of 2G/2.5G/3G, which have grown mostly in the wireless sectors, and that they are hoping the expertise of the group and its successful global experience will transfer to Taiwan to speed up the dawning of Taiwan's 3G generation.

The ITRI's Computer and Communication Lab, working in tune with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) project to attract foreign investment and foreign companies to Taiwan to set up R&D centers, has taken the initiative to provide assistance, discuss technical cooperation and establish avenues of communication with the government.
The ITRI earlier facilitated the Ministry of Economic Affairs' subsidization of Intel in it's entry to Taiwan to establish an R&D center.

DOC.HEADLINE: APB ISSUED FOR FUGITIVE FORMER KAOHSIUNG COUNCIL SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court issued an all-points bulletin (APB) Monday for former Kaohsiung Council Speaker Chu An-hsing, who failed to report to the court by 3 p.m. that day to begin serving a jail term for vote-buying in a city council election late last year.

Chief Prosecutor Chou Chang-chin said the court immediately issued the APB in compliance with the legal process to seek the arrest of Chu, who was removed from the speaker post after being sentenced Sept. 25 to a 22-month jail term.

The National Police Administration (NPA) and the Coast Guard Administration will cooperate in the mission to bring Chu to justice, Chou said, adding that a task force formed by agents from the police, prosecution and coast guard authorities will be also set up to hunt for him.

Should Chu have fled to mainland China or elsewhere, the police authorities will ask Interpol to arrest him through the channels of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and its Beijing counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Chu was supposed to begin to serve his jail term Oct. 17, but he failed to report at the Kaohsiung District Court. His lawyer submitted later the same day an appeal asking for a three-month postponement on the grounds of Chu's so-called "health condition."
The prosecution authorities immediately urged Chu to turn himself in before Oct. 20 or face arrest.
It is widely speculated that Chu has sneaked out of Taiwan by a fishing boat to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Set to Cede Part of Control Over Aid to Iraq
Under pressure from potential donors, the Bush administration will allow a new agency to determine how to spend billions of dollars in reconstruction assistance for Iraq, administration and international aid officials say.
The new agency, to be independent of the American occupation, will be run by the World Bank and the United Nations. They are to announce the change at a donor conference in Madrid later this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS RIGHT STUFF FOR SUCCESSFUL INVESTMENTS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Successful investments hinge on location and the productivity of the work force, and Taiwan has these elements in abundance, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said Monday at a summit forum of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

Taiwan's geographic location makes it a convenient jumping-off point to other places in the region, and the island boasts a very productive work force. This combination makes Taiwan one of the best destinations for investment in the world, the minister said.
He said more than 11 multinational companies have set up research and development centers in Taiwan while 60 local companies have established similar centers in Taiwan as of September this year.
He predicted that three of Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers would make it to the world's top-10 by 2006.

James Worth Bagley, president of Lam Research Corporation, said his company attaches great importance to Taiwan and put US$13 million into Taiwan when it set up its R&D center in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in 1996.

To brace for fierce market competition, Bagley said his company is spreading its offices around the world to serve customers in different locations while concentrating its resources in a few places to conduct research and development. R&D costs account for 25 percent of the company's revenues, he added.

Y. T. Du, chairman of Citigroup Global Markets Taiwan Ltd., said that the opening of Taiwan's banking market has intensified competition in the banking industry and forced local banks to improve their financial health and diversify their financial products.
As a result, Du said bank customers in Taiwan can now enjoy services via their computers anywhere in the world.

Other prominent participants of the summit included Richard Hill, president of Novellus Systems, Inc., Theodore M. H. Huang, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, Hajime Sasaki, chairman of NEC Corp., and Roger Seager, vice president of GE Aircraft Engines.
They exchanged views on current global economic developments and outlooks, and how to plumb investment opportunities in Taiwan while projecting a global presence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXECUTIVES ADVOCATE DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: A foreign business executive participating in the ongoing 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference said Monday he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can establish direct transportation links as soon as possible.

Speaking at the conference's first summit forum, Lam Research Corp. President James Worth Bagley said his company has set up a regional operations headquarters in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park to explore the promising mainland market.

"Without direct cross-strait transportation links, our staff members have to detour to a third place while traveling to major mainland Chinese cities such as Shanghai and Fuzhou, " Bagley said, adding that the detour is inconvenient and time consuming.

Bagley said business people usually do not like to touch on sensitive political issues. "But we hope direct cross-strait shipping and air services can open as early as possible to facilitate our business operations," he added.
Foreign and local business executives present at the meeting all applauded Bagley's call.

In reply, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, who presided over the summit forum, said the ROC government has completed a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of opening cross-strait transportation links.
"We'll make every possible effort to push for an early opening of direct cross-strait transportation links, but we need mainland China's cooperation in realizing this goal," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROMOTES INVESTMENT PROJECTS AT BUSINESS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou went to the Taipei International Convention Center Monday to promote investment projects in his city.
Mayor Ma stopped in at the Taipei city exhibition booths, which were just two of the many on the sidelines of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference that formally began Oct. 20.

Ma said that the Taipei booths were offering 10 investment projects worth a total of NT$60 billion (US$1.76 billion) . He said that although the monetary value of the investments was not great, many investors had shown interest in them.
He cited the example of a cable car project in Peitou, suburban Taipei, being offered using the build-operate-transfer (BOT) format, adding that 28 keen manufacturers have asked for more information.

In addition, he also spoke of the development project of a three-star business in the Hsinyi district, where Taipei International Convention Center is located, that will provide confortable accommodations as well as a good location for doing business.

Ma said that Taipei City is developing a biotechnology sector and is engaging in the research and development for the information industry. This dovetails with the government's "two-trillion, twin stars" project, which refers to the production value target of NT$1 trillion (US$29.41 billion) for the semiconductor and color imaging sectors respectively, while the twin star industries are digital content and biotechnology.

Ma also said that many manufacturers are now based in the Neihu Science Industrial Park and he expects more to come in the future after they learn of the positive overall investment environment in Taipei.

President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo arrived here yesterday to attend the 11th Economic Leaders' Meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) hosted by the government of Thailand today and tomorrow.

A Day after George W. Bush's eight-hour state visit, Malacanang officials fell all over themselves to say the US president had all but endorsed President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's candidacy.

President Arroyo arrived here yesterday to join 20 other heads of state attending the 11th Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leaders'summit that starts today.

Malacanang has decided to keep Winston Garcia as head of the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) despite complaints that he mismanaged the pension fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN FIRMS SEE TAIWAN AS SPRINGBOARD TO GREATER CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Senior foreign corporate executives participating in the ongoing 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference said Monday they will use Taiwan as a springboard to tap into the promising greater Chinese market.

Speaking at the conference's first summit forum, many senior foreign business executives, including James Worth Bagley, president of Lam Research Corp., and Roger N. Seager, vice president of GE Aircraft Engines said they attach great importance to the greater Chinese market that covers mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau and intend to use Taiwan as a stepping stone to this booming market.
The forum was presided over by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu.

During the meeting, Theodore M. H. Huang, president of Chinese National Industries and Commerce, said many U.S. and Japanese companies have invested in mainland China and that some of them have invited their Taiwan counterparts to cooperate in launching new ventures there.
Huang said he is interested in seeing what Taiwan's and mainland China's roles will be in foreign business groups' future investment plans.

In response, Bagley said Lam, one of the world's leading wafer manufacturing firms, set up a branch in Taiwan in 1993. In 1996, it opened a subsidiary in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and later set up a research and development (R&D) facility in the park worth US$13 million.

Bagley said Lam's Taiwan subsidiary has since flourished, with its annual business turnover expected to reach US$140 million this year. He said Lam has set up production lines in mainland China in recent years, with Taiwan as its regional operations hub.
Of Lam's 1,900 employees around the world, Bagley said, 190 of them are working in the greater Chinese market.
Noting that Taiwan has talented and diligent manpower resources, Bagley said Lam has been using Taiwan's abundant talent pool in expanding its mainland operations.

Novellus Systems Inc. CEO Richard S. Hill said he shares similar views with Bagely, saying that Taiwan has abundant brainpower in developing information-technology industries and other high-tech items.

Speaking on the same occasion, Seager said GE has consistently attached great importance to the greater Chinese market in its global business development drive. In terms of production, he said, Taiwan and mainland China can complement each other. He also said that GE will use Taiwan as a springboard in expanding its mainland market share.

NEC Corp. Chairman Hajime Sasaki said his company will use mainland China as its future production base because the mainland has cheap labor. He said Taiwan should focus on developing knowledge-based industries in its next stage of development.

A total of US$580 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.920 and was traded between NT$33.870 and NT$33.925.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH COMPANY WINS TENDER TO SUPPLY E&M FACILITIES FOR TAIPEI MRT

TEXT.P: The Aston Martin Corp. of France and a Taiwan company won a tender Monday to supply electrical and mechanical facilities for the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system at NT$14.99 billion (about US$440 million).
The tender was jointly offered by Aston Martin and Ctci Corp. of Taiwan.
The facilities will be used in new MRT lines going through several districts in suburban Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS TAIWAN AN IDEAL PLACE FOR INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is a perfect place to invest in, given its key geographic position in Asia and the Pacific, its advanced infrastructure, and its highly skilled work force, Foreign Minister Eugene Chien said Monday.

Speaking at a luncheon for participants of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, the minister boasted of the country's economic resilience, saying that the world economy was adversely affected by the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States and the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome earlier this year in Asia.

Through it all, however, Taiwan's economy has remained stable, he said. Economic growth for the third and fourth quarters of 2003 is set to reach 3.96 percent and 4. 67 percent respectively, said the minister, noting that the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development even listed Taiwan as a "first-grade, newly industrialized economy."

Not content with that, Chien said, the country is creating new opportunities by introducing the "Challenge 2008 -- National Development Plan" with a budget of US$75 billion, in the hope of creating more opportunities for business and trade.
The minister said he hopes the conference will help the participants learn more about Taiwan's advances in hi-tech industries and Taiwan's investment competitiveness.
The three-day conference opened in Taipei Oct. 19 to woo foreign investments and has brought together more than 1,900 business leaders from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, MATSU INVESTMENT ON CHINESE MAINLAND EXCEEDS NT$1.5 B.: MAC

TEXT.P: Residents of the frontline islands of Matsu and Kinmen have been active investors in mainland China, with their total investment there reaching between NT$1.5 billion-NT$4 billion (US$44.25 million-US$118 million), Taiwan's top mainland China policy planner said Monday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Kinmen and Matsu residents have been investing lavishly in mainland China, particularly in buying homes and real estate.
The investment has basically been "one-way, " with very little money from the mainland being invested in the two offshore islands, Tsai said.
Tsai made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan Home and Nation Committee meeting.

During the meeting, Legislator Hsieh Ming-yuan from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party asked Tsai about why Kinmen and Matsu have continued to lose their glamour and attraction while business there has kept declining since the government initiated the "mini three links" two years ago to help boost bilateral exchanges between the two outlying islands and mainland China's Fujian Province.
The "mini three links, " which came into effect in January 2001, refers to direct trade, postal and shipping links between Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian Province's port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou.
Tsai responded by saying the MAC is in charge of formulating Taiwan's policies toward mainland China but is not responsible for economic development in Kinmen and Matsu.

She attributed the decline being witnessed in Kinmen and Matsu mainly to the scaling back of the number of ROC military personnel stationed there and to the "one-way" flow of capital from the two offshore islands to the mainland.

She also noted that the "mini three links" program was just a measure to assist certain areas and that the question of whether to open the "direct three links" -- namely direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan proper and mainland China -- needs to be studied further.

In related news, it has been learned that several legislators from different political parties will lead a demonstration rally in Taipei Oct. 24 to push the government to allow Kinmen and Matsu immigrants in Taiwan to travel to the mainland via the "mini three links" channel to help facilitate travel during Chinese New Year and other major national holidays.
Currently, only residents in Kinmen and Matsu are allowed to travel to and from Fujian Province via the "mini three links" channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were generally higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 8 points to close at 6,072, with 23,744 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December gained 25 points to finish at 6,100, with 69 contract transactions, while March futures rose 36 points to finish at 6,109, with 2 contracts traded.
June futures lost 27 points to finish at 6,109, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for September futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,080 for November, 6,075 for December, 6,073 for March, and 6,136 for June, and 6,120 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
November TE futures moved up 0.5 points to finish at 265.25, with 4,718 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 265.3, with 20 contracts traded.
September TE futures rose 3.65 points to finish at 268.8, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures increased 16 points to finish at 900, with 11,220 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 14.8 points to close at 899.8, with 53 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
