DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.18 points to close at 6,077.89.
The bourse opened at 6,041.53 and then fluctuated between 6,085.62 and 6,026.39 during trading.

A total of 5.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$111.93 billion (US$3.32 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 5.69 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$127.92 billion (US$3.77 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares moving down 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 4.3 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.9 percent, textile issues at 1.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, and electrical shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 430 to 325, with 138 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 35.18 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving up 35.18 points to close at 6,077.89.
Market turnover amounted to NT$111.93 billion (US$3.32 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY PROPOSES STRICTER PENALTIES TO DEAL WITH ATM THEFT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has hammered out stricter measures to help deal with the problem of thefts from ATM machines and other financial crimes, the head of the MOF Bureau of Monetary Affairs said Monday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Committee of Financial Affairs, Tseng Kuo-lieh, director-general of the Bureau of Monetary Affairs, said the MOF has proposed much more severe penalty terms in a draft amendment to the existing Banking Law in an effort to ensure swift crisis management over the recent spate of thefts from ATM machines islandwide as well as other related crimes.
The more severe punishments that have been drafted are designed not only to help crack down on ATM thefts but also to held restore financial order and rebuild the Taiwan public's trust, Tseng said.

The stricter punishments which were hammered out after Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed the MOF on Oct. 15 to come up with more effective measures to deal with the problem of fraudulent cash withdrawals and related crimes in light of the spate of thefts from ATM machines islandwide earlier in October.

These stricter penalty terms will be added to a draft bill concerning the amendments to the Banking Law and six other financial and monetary statutes that have been submitted to the Legislative Yuan. Premier Yu on Oct. 15 also called for the early passage of the draft bill.

According to Vice Minister of Finance Chang Hsiu-lian, 257 account holders at 24 banks, half of them being Bank of Taiwan branches, have been the victim of ATM thefts to the tune of a total of more than NT$30 million.

Upon investigation, police have found hidden cameras and IC chips at several ATMs which have apparently been used by criminals to scan the data of ATM card holders, allowing them to duplicate the cards and withdraw money from the card holders' accounts.

Meanwhile, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said Monday that harsher law enforcement measures against counterfeit credit card rings have evidently borne fruit in recent months as the total value of purchases made using counterfeit or stolen credit cards has declined compared to previous years.

Quoting tallies from the United Credit Card Service Center, Chen said the total value of purchases made using counterfeit or stolen credit cards was between NT$150 million and NT$17 million for the first half of this year, compared with the record high of NT$3.2 billion for the whole of 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN ARRIVES IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (by J. Kuo and EH)

TEXT.P: Chairman Lien Chan of the major opposition Kuomintang arrived here Sunday afternoon from Boston by train for a four-day visit.
While in Washington, Lien will participate in activities sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute and other organizations.
Lien, who is a candidate for the 2004 Presidential Election in Taiwan, will also meet with overseas Chinese leaders from the greater Washington area.
He was greeted at the Union railway station in Washington by Taiwan officials and many enthusiastic supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO WELCOME INVESTMENT FROM AROUND THE WORLD

TEXT.P: "Taiwan is ready, the world is welcome to invest in us, " President Chen Shui-bian said at the opening of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference in Taipei on Monday.

Speaking to more than 1,900 global business leaders, Chen said Taiwan's economy has already made the transition from an agricultural country to a logistics hub for the information industry. Glancing through the history of Taiwan's economic development, Chen said that in the 16th century, the Spaniards, the Dutch and others coming from Europe began to use Taiwan as a maritime center for ship docking, transactions, and transshipments.

At that time, thanks to its superior geographic location, Taiwan was already performing the role of an East Asian transshipment center. Today, the island of Taiwan, thanks to the hard work and unrelenting efforts of its people, has accumulated abundant foreign reserves and high-quality R&D capabilities, as well as ample high-tech manufacturing capabilities, he said..

"It is for these reasons that Taiwan, amid fierce international competition, has already established the prerequisites for outperforming its competitors and has won the recognition and affirmation of international public opinion," the president said.
He cited reports by several influential international economic research institutes to showcase Taiwan's investment environment and competitiveness.

Firstly, he said that the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD) in its World Competitiveness Yearbook 2003, ranked Taiwan sixth among economies larger than 20 million people.

The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) in Great Britain has upgraded its evaluation of Taiwan's business environment for the next five years from "good" to "very good." In the EIU's latest business environment ranking, Taiwan ranked 18th worldwide and third in Asia, he said.

In the investment climate rating by Swiss-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) , Taiwan tied for fourth place with Japan. At the same time BERI forecasts that Taiwan will overtake Japan in 2008.
Taiwan showed an even more outstanding performance in a global e-government ranking by Brown University of the United States, taking the top spot for the second year in a row, the president said.
"All this only shows that the government's efforts in recent years to improve the investment climate have begun to pay off, " Chen said.

The president also said that to bring a global wave of corporate investments to Taiwan, the government adopted the "Taiwan First Investment Incentive Program" in November of last year, which calls for using preferential land rent schemes for industrial districts and state land to lower land use costs.

Moreover, the government has been working actively to attract international capital and to encourage multinational corporations to establish R&D centers and operations headquarters in Taiwan by providing investment tax credits and payroll and rent subsidies for foreign-owned R&D centers, and incentives such as exemption from the for-profit enterprise income tax for multinationals.

He said that in July this year, the government scrapped the US$3 billion ceiling on investments in the local stock market by qualified foreign institutional investors (QFII) and also opened participation in the domestic Securities Borrowing and Lending Market. Subsequently, the Legislative Yuan passed a number of important financial bills to help with the liberalization of the local financial and monetary markets.
"All of these measures will contribute to the liberalization of Taiwan's investment climate, while perfecting the basic infrastructure to make our financial system more robust, " the president said.
With regard to Taiwan's relations with mainland China, Chen said he has been sincere calling for an improvement in cross-strait ties.

Saying that he proposed in August a three-stage plan for direct transportation links, Chen said that after next year's presidential election, negotiations on direct links should be launched smoothly, based on a process of equality, mutual respect and cooperation, and that before the end of next year, measures leading to the establishment of direct links should be progressively realized and negotiations on direct cross-strait links completed.

Furthermore, Chen said that in early September the government officially announced the "facilitation of air cargo, " which would allow Taiwan's carriers to fly to Shanghai with " scheduled charter flights" using current routes that stop over in Hong Kong or Macao. The concept is currently still waiting for a positive response from mainland China.

As to his call for an unprecedented national referendum next year, Chen said it is a measure aimed to cement the country's democracy rather than provoking the long-standing dispute of whether the country should seek permanent separation from mainland China, and will not contradict the promise he made in his 2000 inaugural speech of not seeking independence.

"Peace across the Taiwan Strait depends on the wisdom and efforts of people on both sides of it, " he said, adding that worldwide investors should have confidence in Taiwan, its democracy, and in its determination to push through with reforms.

He cautioned investors around the world that mainland China, instead of being the world's last word in investment, is a place with a government-controlled economy ruled by the whims of its leader, and, therefore, replete with unforeseen risks.

Saying that both the Taiwan government and its people have long been well-prepared to welcome companies from around the globe to operate in Taiwan, the president called on the international business community to seize the chance to invest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN CONFERENCE ATTENDEES IMPRESSED BY ATTENTIVE SERVICES

TEXT.P: Many foreign participants at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference said they were impressed by attentive reception services offered by organizers.

More than 1,900 corporate executives from major countries around the world have traveled to Taipei over the weekend to attend the Oct. 19-22 business alliance conference -- the largest investment promotion event ever held in Taiwan.

The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) , which organized the event, has posted staff members at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to offer immediate reception and transportation services for arriving foreign participants.

With CETRA staffers' devoted services, all arriving conference-goers can get on a bus to hotels or the conference venue in five minutes after their arrival at the airport. Many foreign business people said they were surprised by the VIP-grade services.

The conference is being held at the Taipei International Convention Center. The Ministry of Economic Affairs has received more than NT$138 billion confirmed or promised investment projects. Central, city and county governments have come up with NT$400 billion worth of various public construction projects for prospective foreign investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 20, or the 25th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONTROL YUAN PRESIDENT VISITS DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 20 (CNA) (by L. Huang and EH)

TEXT.P: Fredrick Chien, president of Control Yuan of the Republic of China, arrived in Santo Domingo Monday for a week-long official visit to the Dominican Republic at the invitation of President Hipolito Mejia.
Chien is scheduled to visit President Mejia and convey President Chen Shui-bian's greetings to him on Tuesday.
While in Santo Domingo, Chien will also meet with high-ranking Dominican officials and deliver a speech on the Republic of China's state control system.
He will also inspect the operations of Republic of China Embassy and meet with overseas Chinese leaders in Santo Domingo.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: In Shift, Bush Open to Pledge for N. Korea.
President Bush holds to no-treaty stance but says he'd sign a promise to not attack if the North Korea took steps to end its nuclear arms effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO ENHANCE TECHNOLOGICAL EXCHANGES WITH JAPAN: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Republic of China envoy to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum leaders' summit met Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi Tuesday and told him that Taiwan hopes to enhance technological exchanges with Japan.

Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Taipei-based Academia Sinica, said in a press conference held after the close of the summit that the brief talks between him and Koizumi were centered on future technological exchanges between the two countries.
Lee said that he highly praised Japan for the progress it has made in technological development and expressed the hope that the two countries can increase exchanges in the field.
During the two-day summit, Lee said, he had talks with leaders of all APEC member nations and that economic and technological cooperation was mentioned in almost all of the meetings.
With the progress it has made in the development of its hi-tech industry, Lee said that Taiwan is willing to share its experiences with other countries and to help less-developed nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SAO TOME TIES SUBSTANTIVE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that two-way ties between Taiwan and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe have become increasingly substantive, now that regular exchanges are being held between the two countries.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with a parliamentarian delegation from the West African diplomatic ally, led by speaker Dionisio Tome Dias.

According to Chen, a delegation led by Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Chang Jing-sen has made an inspection trip to Sao Tome and has already begun drawing up concrete plans to help Sao Tome better develop its economy.
He added that a Taiwan medical group has also been set up to help fight malaria and has already made some initial improvements to the lives of the people there.
The president also thanked Dias for the warm reception accorded to him by the Sao Tome government and people during a visit he made to that country last year.
For his part, Dias praised Taiwan's natural landscape and the diligence of its people. As two friendly partners, Taiwan and Sao Tome have much in common, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY, BEIJING LEADER EXCHANGE VIEWS ON CROSS-STRAIT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Wu Hui-chun & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China envoy to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders' summit and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao exchanged views in a brief meeting Tuesday on cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Taipei-based Academia Sinica, said in a press conference held after the close of the summit that he first conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's regards to Hu and suggested that Taiwan and mainland China should enter discussions.
In response, Hu said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can talk about anything under the principle of "one China, " according to Lee.
Lee then told Hu that Chen has said that "a future China" can also be discussed in the cross-strait talks.
Furthermore, Lee said, he told Hu that both sides of the strait "have responsibility for mankind." He was responding to Hu's remarks that China has responsibility for the people of the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DEDICATED TO ATTRACTING INVESTORS: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economics Shih Yen-shiang said Tuesday that business alliances should proceed continuously through long-term planning and that the government will continued to work hard in its efforts to attract more investors.

Speaking at a news conference after witnessing an agreements-signing ceremony on the final day of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, Shih noted that the government has spent nearly one year planning the event and has achieved its goal of making potential investors and participating firms at home and abroad satisfied.
Six more foreign companies entered into seven cooperation agreements with local companies Tuesday following the eight pacts signed yesterday.
Shih stressed that any investment pact is the result of much work and that the government still needs to continue its efforts to attract more investors.

According to statistics given by Shih, up to Oct. 20, Taiwan had attracted 113 cases of foreign investments worth NT$68.2 billion this year. Among them, 73 will surely be carried out at the later half of next year. In addition, a total of 290 cases worth NT$95 billion are outstanding.

To encourage foreign investors to set up research and development centers, Shih cited the experience of Sony of Japan, and Dell, HP and IBM of the United States as examples of companies that have set up centers in Taiwan and are satisfied with the results.

"They have set good examples for other international enterprises to follow, " Shih said, adding that in the future, the government should offer better opportunities, including funds and sites, to help investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS EDGE TO DEVELOP ITSELF INTO R&D BIOMEDICAL HUB IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Executives from the biomedical field said Monday that Taiwan possesses several advantages that will give it the edge in developing itself into an Asian biomedical R&D hub.

The executives, including Hardy W. Chan, executive vice president and chief scientific officer of ScinoPharm Taiwan; Daniel Lee, President and CEO of Apex Medical Corp.; Thomas Shen, president and CEO of Apex Biotechnology Corp.; and Wang Chang-yi, president and CEO of United Biomedical Inc. made the remarks when he attended a seminar on Biomedical and Health Care as part of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

They concurred that government incentives, low production costs, research and development capacity, protection of intellectual property rights (IPRs) , the common language used in Taiwan and mainland China, and its geographic location have all given Taiwan the edge to become a biomedical R&D center in Asia, as well as to become a springboard to the mainland Chinese market.
Chan said that since ScinoPharm opened its plant in Taiwan six years ago, it has seen the government offer various incentives on R&D and investment projects.

Chan also spoke highly of Taiwan people's diligence and R&D capacity. Compared with the United States and European countries, Taiwan has lower production costs, high-quality pharmaceutical production capacity, he said, adding that he was confident of the prospects for ScinoPharm in Taiwan.

Chan stressed that major manufacturers have established footholds in Asia one by one because the human resources there and production costs are comparatively cheaper. Comparatively, Taiwan has highly trained people. This coupled with its advantages in language and geography, can make it the operations center for foreign businessmen wanting to set a foothold in Asia.
He also reminded other manufacturers, that no matter how high the production efficiency in mainland China may be, its protection of intelectual property is insufficient.
He suggested those keen on investing in the mainland focus their production in mainland China while putting their R&D departments in Taiwan.

Daniel Lee said that health care is growing rapidly in Asian markets, adding that from the experience of Taiwan industry cooperating with other major manufacturers in the past, Taiwan industry already has the capacity to supply stable quality products and possess the capacity of operations management.

This will make Taiwan a suitable location for manufacturers to set up their operations center in Taiwan in their quest to break into the mainland market, Lee said, adding that the potential of household health care in Taiwan is quite great.
Shen said that the Taiwan government has attached great importance to the biomedical industry, and has offered many incentives, including subsides and cash awards, for its development.

Wang noted that Long Island-based United Biomedical Inc. set up its R&D center in Taiwan to develop foot-and-mouth disease vaccines and other products, saying that it decided to set up the center mainly because Taiwan promoted high technology, and that Taiwan also excels in the telecommunications and electronics industries.
Wang also said that mainland China has not attached importance to intellectual property rights and that this is the reason why United Biomedical did not want to put its R&D center in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ERICSSON, BROADCOM TO ESTABLISH RESEARCH CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Telecommunications giant Ericsson announced here Tuesday that it will set up a research and development center in Taiwan.
Ragnar Back, executive vice president of Ericsson and head of the Asia Pacific region, announced the decision at a press conference at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

Back said the innovation center will be directly under the company's Sweden Headquarters and will be counted as one of the company's four regional centers in Asia. It will focus on the development of telecommunications technology for third generation (3G) mobile phones and is expected to create NT$10 billion (US$2.94 billion) in sales.

At the same news conference, U.S.-based developer of broadband communications chip, Broadcom, announced its decision to set up a research and development center in Taiwan, the first for the company in Aisa.

The center, Network SoC, will introduce into Taiwan Broadcom's core technology in broadband communications chips as well as its technicians to produce broadband telecommunications products according to international standards. It is expected to create US$500 million in sales.
The two centers brought the number of multinational company that have R&D centers in Taiwan to 13, according to local economics officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REAFFIRMS VOW TO TURN TAIWAN INTO REGIONAL BUSINESS HUB

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his administration's determination Tuesday to develop Taiwan into a regional R&D center and business operations hub for major corporations from around the world.

Chen made the statement in a speech delivered at a dinner party hosted by the Executive Yuan in recognition of the more than 2, 000 corporate executives and prospective investors who participated in the Oct. 19-22 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

In the face of fierce international competition, Chen said Taiwan will use its robust capital market, high-quality manpower, innovative technology, strategic geographic location and administrative efficiency to turn Taiwan into an R&D and testing center in Asia and a regional sourcing and operations hub.

Before the curtain was raised on the largest investment promotion conference ever held in Taiwan, Chen said the confirmed and promised amount of new investments in Taiwan had already reached NT$138 billion, far exceeding the original target of NT$100 billion.
During the past two days, Chen said, 28 additional investment contracts have either been signed or confirmed, including contracts
between Taiwan's state-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) and America's Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. and Boeing Co.

Under those contracts, AIDC will collaborate with Bell in offering services in maintenance, remodeling and upgrading of military helicopters as well as in becoming a supplier of landing gear doors for Boeing's next-generation 737 airplanes. "These two contracts mark significant steps in the development of our aerospace industry," Chen said.

In addition, Chen said, one of the world's leading printing industry companies from Quebec, Canada will cooperate with local companies in building an Asia-Pacific media transmission and logistics center in Taoyuan County's Chungli industrial park in northern Taiwan.

The investment projects confirmed or signed during the business alliance conference cover a wide range of industries, including optoelectronics, aerospace, telecommunications, semiconductors, energy resources development, biotechnology, banking and insurance, and warehousing and distribution, Chen said.
"These projects fully indicate the diversity and vibrancy of our economic structure and showcase the achievements of Taiwan's industrial transformation and upgrading in recent years, " Chen said.

The conference also helped convince 15 world-class multinational groups, including Hewlett-Packard, Sony, Dell, IBM, Microsoft and Ericsson, to set up R&D and technical centers in Taiwan, Chen said, adding that their intentions affirm Taiwan's efforts to encourage innovation and research.
More important, Chen said, their actions signify their support and recognition of Taiwan's liberal, democratic and open society and lifestyle.

Chen said his administration will accelerate further reforms and market deregulation in response to the demand of foreign investors. "We'll speed up globalization under the principle of 'Invest in Taiwan, Access the World' to accelerate economic recovery and sustain growth," he added.
The business alliance conference has opened up the door for investment in Taiwan and has helped introduce Taiwan's political, economic and industrial achievements to the world.

For years, President Chen said the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei, the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) and the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (JCCI) in Taipei have contributed much to promoting bilateral trade and economic relations.

"They have not only offered valuable counseling to our administrative agencies but have also actively introduced our investment climate and opportunities to their business people, " Chen said, adding that the three organizations have become Taiwan's best partners in its pursuit of economic prosperity.
To express Taiwan's gratitude for their contributions, Chen presented the Appreciation Award for Investment to the three trade associations at the dinner party.
AmCham President Gus Soresen, ECCT Chairman Dirk Sanger and JCCI Chairman Toshimasa Furukawa received the awards on behalf of their organizations.

Chen said Taiwan has developed close production and distribution networks with nearly all world-renowned companies. In appreciation of their contributions to Taiwan's industrial development, Chen presented the "Best IPO Awards" to the top 10 foreign companies in terms of their accumulated procurement of Taiwan's information technology (IT) products over the past six years.
Foreign IT companies are expected to purchase US$48 billion worth of IT products from Taiwan this year, Chen said, adding that the top 10 firms will account for 80 percent of the amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REITERATES U.S. SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: United States President George W. Bush reiterated Tuesday U.S. support for Taiwan, according to the Republic of China envoy to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders' summit.

Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the Taipei-based Academia Sinica, said at a press conference held after the closure of the summit that during a brief meeting, he thanked Bush for the support the U.S. has extended to the people of Taiwan over the years, to which Bush replied: "We will stay."
Lee said that he also conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's regards to Bush.
Lee noted that he also spoke with Bush about cross-Taiwan Strait issues at last year's APEC summit in Mexico and that Bush was "relatively more at ease" on the cross-strait issues afterward.

Rebutting reports that Bush told Lee at that time of his opposition to Chen's "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" statement, Lee said that they did not even mention the issue in their conversation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AGREES TO HOST 2006 ASIA-PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Shiraz, Iran, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei has in principle agreed to sponsor the 51st Asia-Pacific Film Festival in 2006, a member of the Taiwan delegation attending the annual festival said here Tuesday.

Chiu Shun-ching, Central Motion Picture Company general manager and head of the Taiwan delegation, has initially agreed to the proposal adopted unanimously during a board meeting of representatives from other cities that are all members of the Federation of Motion Picture Producers in Asia-Pacific, Hung Su-tang, secretary - general of the federation's Republic of China branch, told CNA.

A total of 34 movies produced by 11 countries, including three from Taiwan -- Robinson Crusoe by Lin Chen-sheng, Goodbye Dragon Inn by Tsai Ming-liang and Somewhere Over The Dreamland by Chang Wen-tang -- are vying for a series of awards in this year's competition -- the 48th of its kind.
The 49th and 50th festivals are slated to be held in Fukuoka, Japan in 2004 and Malaysia in 2005, respectively.

According to Hung, another proposal raised by the Australian delegation suggesting that the festival should invite cities outside the region to take part also won enthusiastic approval from other members.

It was also decided at the meeting that a mainland Chinese city should be allowed to participate in the festival, he said, noting that a country or area can be represented by only a city in compliance with the federation's rules.

The federation was set up in 1954 in Tokyo, with the ROC one of its founding members. It now comprises 18 city members -- Taipei, Bangkok, Mumbai, Hanoi, Hong Kong, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Kuwait, Manila, Moscow, Seoul, Singapore, Sydney, Tashkent, Tbilisi, Tehran, Tokyo and Wellington.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: APEC wants trade talks to get going.
Leaders seek resumption of global talks and agree that the compromise drawn up at Cancun should be the starting point. Talks by Asia-Pacific leaders got off to a fruitful start yesterday with agreement to back a resumption of global trade talks that were stalled in Mexico last month - support that will be crucial as the 21 economies represented here account for almost half the world's trade.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore aims to attract one million foreign patients by 2012.
Singapore wants to attract one million foreign patients by 2012 and see them spend about S$3 billion (US$1,75 billion) a year which will give the local economy a healthy boost.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES TO SEEK TO FTAS WITH OTHER COUNTRIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: In addition to participating in multilateral trade organizations, Taiwan is seeking to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Tuesday.

Although faced with stiff opposition by Beijing, the officials said, they are confident in achieving their goal because countries that sign an FTA with Taiwan will find the arrangement to be mutually beneficial.
For instance, they claimed, member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) have recently suffered economic recessions due to competition from mainland China.

The government has been making efforts to seek the signing of FTAs with other countries since the beginning of 2002, when Taiwan was admitted to the World Trade Organization, the officials noted, adding that the efforts produced fruit this August when Taiwan signed its first FTA with Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Israelis Hit Gaza With 5 Assaults; 11 Dead, 90 Hurt.
Israeli warplanes and helicopter gunships struck Gaza five times Monday, killing at least 11 people and wounding more than 90, Palestinian hospital authorities said, as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon affirmed Israel's threat to remove Yasir Arafat.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Tory leader 'ticked off' over use of official car.
Iain Duncan Smith faced fresh embarassment over his state-funded political perks last night when it emerged he had been spoken to about the alleged misuse of the chauffeur-driven car given to him as Leader of the Opposition.
Financial Times: Carlton row could 'undermine' deal.
Independent directors at Carlton, the ITV broadcaster, warned yesterday that shareholder pressure to oust Michael Green as chairman could undermine its 4.5bn deal with Granada.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NEW JOBS ON RISE: EVTA

TEXT.P: The number of jobs being offered by Taiwan companies is growing in the domestic market, Employment & Vocational Training Administration (EVTA) Director General Kuo Fong-yu said Tuesday.

Thanks to an economic pick up in Taiwan's opto-electronic, semiconductor and telecommunications industries as a result of a global economic upturn, domestic traditional, financial, service and construction businesses also have bottomed out of the recession, helping create more jobs, said Kuo.

Citing information provided by a Web site run by the EVTA, Kuo said the number of job opportunities released by domestic businesses during the June-September period rose by between 8 percent and 10 percent per month, while about 20 percent of job seekers were able to find jobs through the Web site.

At the same time, the number of job seekers fell from 48,725 to 45,048 during the same three-month period, he noted, attributing the drop to the effect of an employment-boosting package launched by the Executive Yuan.

According to Kuo, the Web site, which began operations six months ago to serve as a direct channel between the government and job seekers and headhunting businesses, is aimed at assisting mainly the small and service-oriented businesses as well as underprivileged groups and job seekers with only senior high school degrees.
Kuo claimed that as many as 90 percent of the Web site's visitors are satisfied with its services, while 80 percent said they feel the site is safe in terms of protecting personal privacy.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the EVTA Web site show that about 62.6 percent of the enterprises listed on the site have most demand for middle- and high-level management personnel, skilled technicians and sales personnel aged between 30 and 49.

Only 0.57 percent of the companies do not mind recruiting young people with no previous experience, while only 3.24 percent are willing to hire workers aged between 25 and 29 who previous employers have criticized as changing jobs too frequently.

In an effort to reduce the high joblessness rate among local young people, the EVTA, in cooperation with the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the National Youth Commission, has begun encouraging businesses, using government subsidies as bait, to hire unemployed young job seekers on a short-term basis to help them gain some experience and get full-time work.
According to the EVTA, job seekers are most interested in administrative work, although sales offers the largest number of jobs.

According to the EVTA survey, most Taiwan companies have no preference for men over women, which EVTA claimed is evident in that the number of jobs offered for men are only 5 percent higher than those offered for women.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTENTIAL INVESTORS TO TOUR TAINAN SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: After attending the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference in Taipei, a number of participants and potential investors from foreign countries, including Holland, will visit the Tainan Science-based Park on Wednesday.

A spokesman for the park said that a Dutch trade and biotechnological delegation will arrive at the park on Wednesday morning and attend a seminar to exchange views on science and technology in southern Taiwan.

The spokesman pointed out that in the development of biotechnology, the Netherlands has made outstanding achievements in the fields of agriculture, chemicals, foodstuffs, medicines, health care and environmental protection. He added that because of its superior biotechnological industrial services and suppliers network, many famous global biotechnological companies have chosen Holland as their springboard for entering the European biotechnological industry.

After attending panel discussions on agriculture, foodstuffs and the environment at the Tainan Science-based Park, the Dutch group will tour the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center and other relevant sites.

Biotechnology is one of the six industries being promoted at the Tainan Science-based Park. A planned 24-unit, world-class standard facility, which began construction in mid-April this year, is scheduled to be completed in May next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN MORE COOPERATION PACTS CONCLUDED AT INVESTMENT CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Six more foreign companies entered into seven cooperation agreements with local companies in a high- profile ceremony in Taipei Tuesday.
The event was timed to coincide with the final day of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, with Vice Minister of Economics Shih Yen-shiang participating.

At the ceremony, Japanese company ACCESS signed a memorandum of cooperation with the Institute for Information Industry, agreeing to transfer technology on mobile phone services to Taiwan phone operators. The pact will make Taiwan the base for research and development activities for ACCESS.
South Korea's largest online game maker, NC Soft, signed a joint venture in Taiwan with Gamania to cooperate in the online game business.

Italian company Morini Franco Motori and Taiwan Golden Bee inked a pact to set up a joint venture to produce motorcycle engines. The technology transfer will upgrade the research, development and production of domestic motorcycle-makers. Analysts expect that products worth NT$10 billion will be produced in the next decade.
The Itochu Group from Japan contracted with Taiwan's Emtac Technology to jointly promote the sales of Emtac's products overseas, including its GPS antennas.

Presently, Itochu has already brokered purchase deals for foreign buyers of Emtac's products worth NT$150 million (US$4.41 million). Itochu has also promised to assist Emtac in importing and developing key parts and is prepared to invest in Emtac in the future.
U.S.-based PharmaEssentia teamed up with Taiwan's Genovate
Biotechnology to develop, design, manufacture and sell drugs
designed to fight cancer, high blood pressure and asthma.

PharmaEssentia also concluded an agreement with a local company, Synmosa Biopharma, to grant each other preferential status in mutual cooperation efforts. The two companies agreed to jointly develop products that use mainly raw materials produced by PharmaEssentia and which comply with U.S. market standards. The two companies will separately sell those products in the Asian and U.S. markets.

American company Ryss Laboratory's Taiwan subsidiary and Taiwan's Pharmaceutical Industry Technology and Development Center, which is devoted to the research and development of pharmaceuticals and other life sciences products, concluded an agreement to exchange technology and combine their strengths for the research and manufacturing of new drugs to upgrade domestic pharmaceutical manufacturing standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOT GUIDES TV TRAVELLER SEEKING TAIWAN SPLENDOR AS HER LOCAL HOST

TEXT.P: The presenter of the Pilot Guides TV show is looking for a Taiwanese man to work as her partner in a TV series introducing Taiwan's tourism attractions.

The Knowledge Channel, producer of the new Taiwan series, will interview Taiwan applicants, who must speak English and Mandarin fluently, and will select one candidate to work with Megan McCormick in her travels around Taiwan. The show's itinerary will include scenic Green Island and the Longshan Temple, one of the oldest and most-visited temples in Taiwan.

McCormick, in her first trip to Taiwan, will start her backpacking travel in Taiwan from Taipei City, touring the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the Longshan Temple and one of the city's bustling night markets, followed by ventures to the breathtaking Taroko Gorge and finally Green Island, where she will snorkel and join a game contest among aboriginal hunters.

Knowledge Channel officials said all "young and hot" men who are interested in being a co-host with McCormick can send their resumes and photos to Pilot Guides TV at the Web site: tw_fanclub@discovery.com. for consideration.

McCormick was born in Florida and earned a BA in philosophy and politics. Before becoming a Pilot Guides TV traveller, she taught English in Japan and with the money she made there, travelled to a great number of countries throughout Southeast Asia.

As one of the hosts of the Pilot Guides TV, which take viewers to some of the wildest, weirdest and most dazzling sights and scenes on earth, McCormick has toured New England, Egypt, Java, Sumantra, the West Indies, Micronesia, Scotland, Queensland, Portugal, Greece, Beijing and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TOUTS BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: "Some may consider the Taiwan Strait a spot with tension and hostility. But in our eyes, this is an area full of business opportunities, " said ROC Vice President Annette Lu Tuesday at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.
"Our message is clear: We want peace, not war, " Lu said in a speech delivered at a luncheon hosted by the Ministry of Finance for hundreds of conference attendees from around the world.

Noting that the people of Taiwan have lived under the constant and immense threats and bullying from mainland China over the past years, Lu said the fundamental difference between the two sides actually lies in the different views regarding human rights, individual freedoms and political systems.
"It is the 'basic values' that make the two societies different," Lu stressed.
In her view, Lu said, the ultimate goal of peace is unattainable "unless you can reach both democracy and prosperity."
Fortunately, she said, Taiwan has been able to achieve all three goals of democracy, peace and prosperity.

Lu also explained her "soft power" governing concepts, saying that human rights, democracy, peace, love and technology are the five key elements in ruling a country. They are also intangible common assets of mankind.
In the 21st century, Lu said, military muscle and capital cannot determine a country's supremacy; instead, this depends on a nation's contribution to promoting the five key elements.
Lu said Taiwan is willing to bring its experiences into play for the benefit of all mankind.

"As a result, I'm now preparing to organize the Democratic Pacific Union, a non-governmental organization committed to enhancing greater cooperation among democracies in the Pacific in the areas of governance, human security, economic prosperity and ocean development," Lu said.

Over the past decades, Lu said Taiwan has created many miracles. Economic prosperity is not Taiwan's only achievement, Lu said, adding that Taiwan has made equally admirable progress in political democratization.

"Taiwan's economic performance and efficiency has been highly valued by major international economic organizations, " Lu said, citing as an example the 2003 Global Competitiveness Report, released by the World Economic Forum, that rates Taiwan's growth competitiveness as the third best in the world.
Touching on Taiwan's national development plan, Lu said Taiwan will focus its industrial development strategies on technological R&D as well as innovation.

"On the one hand, we'll strengthen the base of those industries that have already achieved a leading position, especially semiconductors and LCD monitors, to enable them to make it among the top three of the world and exert a strong global influence," Lu said.

On the other hand, she continued, Taiwan wants to use its technological innovation and good living environment as capital to integrate the innovative resources of the Asia-Pacific region with the rest of the world and seize the opportunity of globally emerging new star industries in the digital and biotechnological fields.
Lu further said Taiwan is now implementing a number of financial reforms.

"Strengthening corporate governance and transparency are just a few of our reform efforts. In addition, we are continuously eliminating previous restrictions in order to roll out more new financial products," Lu said.

She added that the Oct. 19-22 business alliance conference is the largest-ever investment promotion event held in Taiwan and is part of the government's efforts to attract investments to upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness in the era of globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Bush wins battle to focus APEC meet on terrorism.
U.S. President George W. Bush forced the war on terrorism to the heart of a Pacific Rim summit Monday despite the resentment of some Asian nations that want the talks to stick to freeing trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CONFERENCE ATTRACTS LARGER-THAN-EXPECTED FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference in Taipei has attracted investments of more than NT$130 billion (US$3.82 billion) so far, far exceeding expectations, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Tuesday after the final day of the conference.

The vice premier, reporting at the Legislative Yuan, said that preparations for the conference were begun last November, and that he was happy to say that from January to the present, foreign investment in Taiwan has reached NT$68.2 billion. Add to this promised investments of NT$70.2 billion and the figure swells to NT$138.4 billion, far more than the original estimate of NT$100 billion. Lin, who concurrently serves as the chairman of the Council For Economic Planning and Development, also said that the government is now aiming to secure additional investments of more than NT$90 billion, adding that the result will definitely be better than expected.

Legislator Kao Meng-ting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was positive about the performance of the government in soliciting foreign investment, although he also pointed out that the government seems only to be targeting the electronics industry.

Lin responded by saying that although the business conference targeted specific industries and manufacturers, it encompassed 12 industries and that there are also a great number of build-operate-transfer (BOT) projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST STEP UP FINANCIAL REFORMS TO STAY COMPETITIVE: GMAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan must step up financial reforms to stay competitive, GMAC Commercial Holding Chairman Scot B. Barker said in Taipei Tuesday.

Speaking at the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference's second summit forum, Barker said most Asian countries want to attract foreign investors; however, only with a transparent financial and economic system can this be achieved. He said that Taiwan must accelerate financial reforms given that many of its manufacturing companies have relocated to mainland China and Southeast Asian countries.

In his view, Barker said, financial reforms, improving operating efficiencies and manpower cultivation are priority tasks Taiwan must accomplish to sustain its economic growth and maintain its niches in the world market.

As an important step, Barker said, Taiwan must cut the number of players in each sub-sector. For example, Taiwan now has more than 50 banks. The number is too large. Taiwan's government should adopt measures to facilitate mergers and differentiation between healthy and troubled banks.
Barker also called for raising standards for underwriting and risk management for local banks and internationalizing management of local banks.
Moreover, Barker said, Taiwan should improve the efficiency of the financial services sector and ensure that funds go to businesses based on merit.
Equally important is to reduce local banks' non-performing loan (NPL) ratios, Barker said, adding that Taiwan can learn from other countries' experience in addressing NPL issues.

Barker said Taiwan's recent passage of an asset securitization law has paved the way for NPLs to become a new industry that could create an annual trading volume of US$1.2 billion for Taiwan. It would also allow financial institutions to realize exits on selected portfolios.

Meanwhile, Barker said Taiwan should speed up formation of an RTC fund to allow government injection of capital into troubled banks and facilitate resolution of the NPL issue. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO OFFICIAL PRAISES TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A senior World Trade Organization (WTO) official has praised highly the performance of Taiwan and mainland China in the WTO, saying that the two sides played "important and statesmanlike" roles in the recently concluded WTO Ministerial Conference in Cancun, Mexico.
Since both sides of the Taiwan Strait entered the organization last year, their interaction has been a focus of all member countries and WTO Secretariat officials.

In the first ever public speech on Taiwan and mainalnd China's memberships by a WTO official, Keith Rockwell, director of information and media relations of the WTO, emphasized the positive effect of the two sides' memberships.

"Both new members have been active in the work of the WTO, " said Rockwell in his speech, titled "China and Chinese Taipei: the Challenge that Confronts them and all Members of the WTO, " delivered earlier this week at a symposium organized by the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. He added that both have made important contributions to the Doha Development Agenda negotiations.

Although admitting that there has been a degree of controversy linked to the two since they joined the WTO and that they have engaged in an ongoing dispute over "nomenclature," Rockwell indicated that they have entered the WTO in "remarkably smooth fashion" and have taken a pragmatic approach to membership by "keeping unnecessary political questions out of the way."

He also noted that there has been some criticism that mainland China has not moved quickly enough in opening its markets to agriculture imports, and foreign insurance, banking and distribution companies.

Despite these existing issues, Rockwell seemed very upbeat about Taiwan and mainland China's introductions into the WTO, noting that it is the consensus view that membership for these trading powers has been a "extremely positive" development, both for mainland China and Taiwan and for those doing business with them.

The Japan Times: former smokers denied in health compensation claim.
A group of sick amd dying former smokers seeking compensation from Japan Tobacco Inc. and the government had their case thrown out of the Tokyo district Count on Thursday bacause the judge ruled they had taken up smoking of their own free will.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ADMINISTRATOR CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun announced the promotion of Vice Environmental Protection Administrator Chang Juu-en Wednesday to the head of the Cabinet-level agency.
Yu praised Chang for his excellent performance and professionalism demonstrated in his career as a public functionary.

Yu said that he believed Chang will make an ideal chief of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) after an assessment for more than two weeks since he served as acting EPA chief after former EPA administrator Hau Lung-bin resigned Oct. 6.
Hau tendered his resignation because he didn't see eye to eye with the premier on referendum issues.
Hau said the premier rejected his suggestion to exclude environmental related issues which had already passed environmental impact assessments from issues which could be put to a referendum.

Chang said at a news conference held after his appointment that he will continue to carry out "good policies" set by his predecessor because he believes that the policies on environmental protection should be consistent.

Chang said that he has no prejudgment on a referendum of the fate of the country's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant that is currently under construction and whether or not to reopen environmental assessments for the plant as well as for opening the service ramp at Pinglin on the Beiyi Expressway that links Taipei City and the northeastern county of Ilan. The expressway under construction is expected to be completed by 2005.
He suggested that the government should fix first the range of sectors or areas that would be affected by subjects to be put on a referendum prior to holding one.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, S. KOREAN LEADERS EXPECTED TO ENDORSE START OF FTA TALKS

TEXT.P: South Korean President Roh Moo-Hyun on Wednesday kicks off a visit to Singapore, during which the leaders of the two states are expected to endorse the start of talks on a South Korea-Singapore free trade agreement (FTA).
President Roh Moo-Hyun is scheduled to call on President S.R. Nathan and also meet with Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

An FTA with Singapore, which would be South Korea's first with a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , is expected to benefit local businesses with close to $99 million a year in tariff savings.

A joint study group looking at the feasibility of a South Korea-Singapore FTA recommended recently that the two sides go ahead with negotiations as the signing of such an agreement would be mutually beneficial.
Trade between Singapore and South Korea stands at close to US$7.7 billion per year, and Singapore is South Korea's tenth largest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TO APEC SUMMIT RETURNS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh returned to Taipei Wednesday night after attending the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation leader's summit in Bangkok as the country's envoy.
Lee told journalists at the airport that he had done justice to his mission and will give a full report to the general public at a news conference Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARY WANG RE-ELECTED AS CHAIRMAN OF ROC CHAMBER OF COMMERCE

TEXT.P: Gary Wang, founder of Taiwan-based Eastern Multimedia Group, was re-elected chairman of the Republic of China Chamber of Commerce Wednesday.

President Chen Shui-bian congratulated Wang's recent election as a member of the international board of directors by the U.S. Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, and hailed his successful introduction of Eastern Multimedia Group to the U.S. market.

Wang noted that the economic development on Taiwan has been particularly difficult in the past few years due to the global economic recession, the 911 terrorist attacks in the United States, and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island.
Fortunately, Wang added, thanks to the efforts made by the Chen administration in stimulating confidence in Taiwan's investment environment, the island's economy is recovering.

The media tycoon said that Taiwan, which boasts one of the best workforces in the world and has an excellent geographic location, has been ranked by Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) as the fourth most attractive place for investment in its report conducted earlier this year.

In addition, the world's largest chipmaker Intel and Phoenix Technologies, the largest supplier of basic input and output systems (BIOS) in the world, have established their research and development centers in Taiwan, reflecting the great potential for Taiwan's development, Wang added.

He said he believes that the ongoing six-year National Development Plan "Challenge 2008" initiated by the Cabinet, which includes the promotion of digital content, adult learning and a program aimed at doubling the number tourist arrivals, will usher Taiwan's economy into a new era.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES PLEDGES LOYALTY TO NEW, LEGALLY ENACTED CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The ROC armed forces will support whatever constitution may be legally enacted and will not favor any political party in the upcoming presidential election, Vice Minister of National Defence Lin Chong-pin told the legislature Wednesday.

Lin, who led a group of top brass to report to the Legislative Yuan on how the armed forces will remain politically neutral in the upcoming presidential election, assured lawmakers that the armed forces will not show a preference for any political party.

He cautiously steered clear of the controversy over President Chen Shui-bian's call for a new constitution, saying that the armed forces pledges its loyalty to the Republic of China and will follow whatever constitution is enacted through a proper legal process.

In order to ensure that the armed forces are not involved in politics, Lin said the Ministry of National Defense issued a decree in 2002 forbidding active military personnel, including military academy cadets, from participating in activities of any political party or faction.

The Armed Forces Reserve Command, which used to recall reservists in the run-up to elections and use them to canvass votes for the ruling party when the country was ruled by the Kuomintang, will stop all recalls from Oct. 1 to election day on March 20 to avoid the military event being used for political purposes, Lin said.

The defense ministry cannot prevent President Chen Shui-bian, who is the supreme commander of the country's armed forces, from speaking to soldiers during the run-up to the election, although Chen is seeking re-election, according to General. Chen Pang-chih, director for the Political Warfare Bureau under the defense ministry.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang from the opposition People First Party urged the country's politicians to spare military personnel the ordeal of being forced to take sides during campaigning, saying that the country has been plagued by the problem of politicians trying to use the military for their own purposes rather than the other way around.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES VISITING NEW ZEALAND PARLIAMENTARIAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received visiting New Zealand parliamentarian Peter Dunne and other members of a delegation from the South Pacific country Wednesday at the Presidential Office, giving them a warm welcome.

Chen thanked Dunne and his other guests for their long-lasting support for Taiwan, particularly, Dunne, who introduced a resolution at the parliament in his capacity as chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations, Defense and Trade to congratulate him for assuming to the 10th term of the Republic of China president on May 20, 2000.

Chen said that he was quite impressed and appreciated the resolution which he said represented Dunne's staunch support for Taiwan as well as his courage in holding up the value of democracy as New Zealand does not have official ties with Taiwan.

Chen also thanked Mark Blumsky, another member of the delegation and a former mayor of Wellington, for the hospitality Blumsky extended to him when he visited the New Zealand capital city in his capacity as Taipei mayor.
Dunne arrived in Taiwan last weekend at the head of the New Zealand delegation to the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference held in Taipei Oct. 19-22.
They will also attend the 16th joint conference of the ROC-New Zealand and New Zealand-Taiwan Business Councils to be held Oct. 23 in Taichung, central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRWOMAN MEETS WITH KMT CHAIRMAN IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen called on visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Tuesday for wide-ranging talks.
The top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties told a group of Taiwan reporters that her 40-minute talk with Lien proceeded in an amicable atmosphere.

During the meeting, Shaheen said, she assured Lien that the U.S. government will maintain neutrality toward Taiwan's internal affairs, including the island's next presidential election on March 20, 2004.

Lien, a former ROC vice president, ended up a distant third in the hotly contested 2000 presidential election. He will team up with People First Party Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year.
Lien had visited London and Prague before coming to the United States as part of his presidential campaign activities.

Shaheen made her first visit to Taiwan as the AIT chairman last week. She returned to Washington, D.C. Sunday. During her stay in Taipei, Shaheen met with President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and other senior officials.
She also delivered a speech at a meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and held a colloquium with National Chengchi University students.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SALUTES GLOBAL CHINESE ARTS, CULTURE LEGACY AWARD WINNERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday received global Chinese art and culture legacy award winners, praising them as the glory of Chinese culture.

There are 12 legacy winners in different areas of arts and culture, and two masters who won lifetime contribution awards this year because of their devotion to works and innovations in the areas of culture, arts, dance and handcrafts.

The president spoke highly of the Republic of China Senior Jaycees Club, the sponsor of the award, saying that it has long been dedicated to servicing society, promoting traditional culture and arts, and has spent a lot of time and money sponsoring the legacy awards and selecting 142 winners over the past decade.
"Their efforts have given a needed boost to the dynamism of the local culture of Taiwan," the president said.

The president also commended the exhibition by the Republic of China Senior Jaycees Club showcasing results of the competition over the last 10 years and the publication of a who's who of past legacy winners.
He expressed the hope that through the concerted efforts of the government, private and business sectors, Taiwan can better promote and preserve the arts and culture.

The winners of the 10th global Chinese culture and arts legacy awards were Chuang Po-lin, Chien Ming-chiang, Lien Sheng-yen, Yeh Wei-han, Cheng Shih-fa, Pang Yueh-hsiung, Chen Chia-teh, Kao Chi-ming, Liu Huei-feng, Ho Kuo-chao, Huang Cheng-tiao, and Chu Hung-ping. The two lifetime contribution award winners were Chen Chi-lu and Wu Mei-lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE TO HELP IN SOONG EMBEZZLEMENT CASE: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is more than willing to help investigators look into charges of alleged embezzlement of party funds by current opposition vice presidential candidate James Soong between 1989 and 1993, one of Lee's political follower said Wednesday.

Chen Cheng-lung, caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) at the Legislative Yuan, quoted Lee as saying that the leadership of a head of state depends much on integrity, and as the leader of the country and chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) between 1988 and 2000, Lee would do his best to defend his honor and is happy to answer investigators' questions to help them find the truth.
The TSU is a political party made up of Lee's political followers.

Chen made the remarks hours after Lee was summoned as a witness to the office of prosecutors at the Taipei District Court to answer questions about the alleged embezzlement of KMT funds by former party secretary-general James Soong.
Lee did not reveal the nature of his testimony, citing a law which forbids the disclosure of anything related to a case being investigated by prosecutors.
The former president, however, has in the past denied that he had any knowledge about a secret slush fund set up by the KMT that was at the disposal of its secretary-general.
Soong is accused of siphoning off NT$360 million (US$10.58 million) from party coffers during his term as KMT secretary-general between 1989 and 1993.

The KMT filed a complaint with prosecutors on Feb. 16, 2000 during the run-up to the 2000 presidential election where Soong ran as an independent against KMT candidate Lien Chan in a three-way race with Chen Shui-bian.
Soong claimed Lee authorized him to use the funds for political purposes and offered to return what was left of the money to the party.

About one year later, after Lien and Soong had lost to President Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , prosecutors decided on Jan. 20, 2001 not to file an indictment against Soong, and the KMT, led by Lien Chan at that time, decided not to appeal the decision.
However, a lawyer for the KMT appealed the prosecutors' ruling on his own, arguing that new evidence against Soong had come to light which legally compelled prosecutors to reopen the investigation.

Lee, who fell out with Soong in 1998 and broke ranks with the KMT in late 2000 over political differences, has publicly disputed Soong's explanation of the fund and has offered to give testimony to prosecutors.
The KMT later reconciled with Soong and decided to cooperate with his People First Party (PFP) to field a joint ticket for the 2004 presidential election.
Lee's appearance at the prosecutors' office Wednesday has drawn partisan reactions from various political parties.
Soong's PFP discredited the prosecutors' move to summon Lee as politically motivated and said that the entire affairs is only being done to try to sully Soong's candidacy for vice president.
PFP lawmaker Chou Shih-wei said the ruling DPP is expected to play up the case as the presidential election in March, 2004 draws near.
KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan Lee Chia-chin said all the evidence offered by Lee in his testimony had already been reviewed by prosecutors before they decided to throw out the complaint in 2001.
The ruling DPP is interesting in the case only because it can be used as political ammunition against Soong in the presidential race, Lee Chia-chin said.
The ruling party, however, praised the actions of the former president for his courage in coming forward and answering prosecutors' questions.
DPP lawmaker Kao Chih-peng said Soong should subject himself to judicial investigation and not try to turn a simple judicial case into a political issue.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The day peace slipped away, again.
An orchestrated operation involving the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland and the leaders of the main political parties fell apart because of a lack of detail over the biggest ever IRA act of disarmament.
