General Dynamics, US defence grouup, has walked away from a transatlantic merger with BAE Systems after explatory discussions with its British rival, people close to the talk said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., SINGAPORE TO START TALKS ON NEW SECURITY AND DEFENSE FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Singapore and the United States have agreed to begin negotiations on a framework agreement for the promotion of a strategic cooperation partnership in defense and security.

The two sides have also agreed to set up a Regional Emerging Diseases Intervention (REDI) Centre to be based in Singapore's newly opened Biopolis, located close to the National University of Singapore.
These were some of the substantive issues discussed in a meeting between Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and U.S. President George W. Bush who is on a visit to Singapore.
In their discussions, the two leaders reaffirmed the need for a strong U.S. security presence in Asia, which continues to be vital for the peace and stability of the region.
Both leaders expressed the desire to see the framework agreement implemented as soon as possible.

President Bush recognized the important role played by Singapore as a major security cooperation partner and expressed appreciation for Singapore's support for the United States as reflected in the 1990 memorandum of understanding between the two sides.

A joint statement Tuesday by the two sides said the strategic framework agreement will expand the scope of current bilateral cooperation in areas of defense and security such as counter-terrorism, counter-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, joint military exercises and training, policy dialogues, and defense technology.

The negotiations are expected to start in January of next year and to be led by the Singaporean Defence Ministry. The talks will cover several areas, including joint military exercises and training, and will allow for new areas of cooperation.
The two leaders also emphasized the value of collaborative efforts in responding to new health threats including emerging diseases and the use of biological agents by terrorists.
The REDI Centre will facilitate the exchange of information and expertise on surveillance, bioterrorism concerns, and communicable and non-communicable diseases prevention, control and research.
The center will also make its research, training, and surveillance facilities available to other economies in the Asia-Pacific region.
To be launched in January of next year, the center's priority will be to work on SARS-specific vaccines and to monitor potential flu outbreaks in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: R&D FUND TO ACCOUNT FOR 3% OF GDP: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday the government will raise the ratio of research and development (R&D) funds to the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) from the current 2.16 percent to 3 percent in two years.
Speaking at a meeting of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce, Chen said that during the era of knowledge-based economies, innovation is pivotal to sustain a country's competitiveness.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, his administration will continue R&D investment to boost the development of high-tech and high value-added industries.
In two years, he said, annual R&D funds will account for 3 percent of Taiwan's GDP, compared to 2.16 percent at present.

Chen further said he is fully aware that local business groups are concerned about the developments in cross-Taiwan Strait relations. He said his administration will continue promoting constructive cross-strait interactions in a gradual and pragmatic manner.

The government will push for the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links with great patience and with the best possible preparations, he said. If he is re-elected next year, Chen said, he will make every possible effort to start negotiations and consultations under the principles of "parity, respect and cooperation."
Chen also cited reports by various world-renowned market research organizations to show that the Taiwan economy has regained momentum and has one of the world's best investment climates.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS CONFERENCE PARTICIPANTS SET OFF FOR ON-SITE TOURS

TEXT.P: Some of the participants of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference set off Wednesday for destinations in Taiwan for tours of a variety of sites of particular interest to businessmen and investors.

The tours were designed to give the participants a deeper understanding of Taiwan's investment environment after the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, which attracted more than 1,900 prospective investors from 35 countries.

Two groups departed for Hsinchu in northern Taiwan and Tainan in southern Taiwan, respectively. While another group toured Taipei to visit the National Palace Museum, Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and Lung Shan Temple and the fourth group toured the scenic Hualien in eastern Taiwan.

The northern group first visited the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu, where officials told the visitors that the institute has been a bridge of cooperation between the industrial and academic sectors over the years and that it has contributed a great deal to Taiwan's industry.

They also expressed the hope that the visit will give the participants a better understanding of Taiwan's industries and the various cooperation projects with foreign businessmen, adding that the ITRI has opened up its laboratories and that three or four foreign businesses have already set up shops there to pursue technology cooperation.

The officials said that the scale of the Taiwan market might be small, but its edge in talent, management and infrastructure cannot be overlooked, while the ITRI offers a world-class research and development environment.
If the ITRI can attract more foreign investors, they went on, it is expected to upgrade industrial standards through technology cooperation.
The group later toured the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Taiwan's technology industry showcase.
Meanwhile, the southern group went to the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, as well as Kaohsiung Harbor and the Kaohsiung Economic Processing Zone, all in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Senate Approves Bill to Prohibit Type of Abortion.
The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure, ending eight years of divisive debate and clearing the way for President Bush to sign the measure into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE EXPECTED TO BE UNDER 5 PERCENT THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate might drop to under 5 percent this year due to stable economic recovery, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.

Chen Chin-cheng, a DGBAS section chief, forecast that the jobless rate in the third quarter of this year will be 4.7 percent, and the average unemployment rate for the year might drop to under 5 percent.
Due to the gradual economic recovery and a government program aimed at boosting employment, Chen noted, first-time job-seekers might have more chances to find work.
DGBAS officials also forecast that the unemployment rate in December will average 4.6 percent as the number of temporary jobs will increase in the run-up to the lunar new year.
Taiwan's average unemployment rate in the first nine months of this year stood at 5.08 percent, according to DGBAS statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 527 ACTIVE SERVICEMEN HAVE CLOSE RELATIVES FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A total of 527 Republic of China military officers in active service have next of kin from mainland China living with them, a senior Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Wednesday.
Chen Pang-chih, director of the MND's political warfare department, made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

At the meeting, Legislator Ho Min-hao of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union said he wanted to know how many mainland relatives of local military officers have come to live in Taiwan and how many of those people have since joined the ROC military or been admitted to military academies.

Ho further said he is worried about the possible adverse impact on Taiwan's national security in view of the fact that some senior military officers have next of kin from the mainland living with them.

In response, Chen said that while 527 military officers have mainland relatives living with them, none of their mainland next of kin have joined the military and nor have any of them been admitted to local military schools.
Under current regulations, mainland Chinese people cannot join volunteer military services until they have been naturalized ROC citizens for at least 20 years.

Chen further said that all military servicemen are prohibited from using military telephone lines to get in touch with any individual persons or units on the mainland. Moreover, the MND has strict security regulations and any military personnel involved in disclosing military secrets will be subject to harsh penalties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NEW ZEALAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE TO KICK OFF IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The 16th joint conference of the Republic of China-New Zealand and New Zealand-Taiwan Business Councils will begin Thursday in central Taiwan's Taichung City.
The meeting is the most important channel for cooperation and dialogue among private enterprises in the two countries.

The delegation of around 20 people from New Zealand will include George Wood, mayor of North Shore City, which has sisterhood ties with Taichung City; Peter Dunne, a member of the New Zealand Parliament; and William Birch, a former New Zealand finance minister.
The annual joint conference takes place alternately in Taiwan and New Zealand. Last year, it was held in North Shore City.
This will be the first time the conference has been held in Taichung City.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who sees the meeting as a good chance to promote trade, has invited some 80 trade representatives and scholars from central Taiwan to participate in the event.

In addition to the conference, there will be panel discussions on the information and telecommunication industry, biotechnology, health food, education and tourism, which are the major areas being promoted by the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI HOSPITAL TEAM TO PROVIDE FREE MEDICAL SERVICES IN THAILAND

TEXT.P: A team from the Chiayi Christian Hospital made up of doctors, nurses, chemists and laboratory technicians is scheduled to leave for Thailand Thursday to provide free medical services to residents in rural areas of eastern Thailand.
The eight-member team will travel to the Buri Ram region, a backwater to the northeast of Bangkok, to provide charity treatment to the residents there.

The Chiayi Christian Hospital, established by American missionary-doctor Marcy Ditmanson in 1962, has in recent years expanded its services to Thai workers in Taiwan. Its Siam Garden Thai Service Center has been in operation for six years, serving thousands of Thai people currently working and living in southern Taiwan.
Wu Su-chu, director of the Chiayi City Health Department, presented a ceremonial banner to the team during a ceremony held at the hospital Wednesday in honor of the team members.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU DIRECTS ALL-OUT EFFORTS TO TRACK DOWN FUGITIVE EX-SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed law enforcement authorities Wednesday to spare no efforts in trying to track down former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung and bring him to justice.
The Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office issued an all-points bulletin for Chu Monday after he failed to turn himself in that day in accordance with an arrest warrant issued for him last Friday.

Chu, who is facing a 22-month jail term for vote-buying in the election for the speakership late last year, failed to report to court to begin serving his term, prompting the Kaohsiung prosecutors to issue the APB.
Chu's whereabouts remained unknown as of noon Wednesday.

Yu said that Chu's sentence is a decision made by the law enforcement authorities in accordance with the law and that Chu's flight tarnishes the image of the government and is a slap in the face to the credit of the authorities.
However, Chu's family accused the government in a press conference Tuesday of imposing "green terror" on Chu, claiming that it dealt with Chu "selectively" for political purposes.
Chu's wife, Wu Teh-mei, told the press that she has not been in contact with Chu and claimed that she did not know his whereabouts. "If he is abroad, he will seek political asylum," she said.

Dismissing the family's claims, Yu said that Chu was dealt with squarely and in accordance with the law in order to fulfill the public's expectations. "The law enforcement authorities' stance on Chu will not swerve or be daunted," the premier said.
Hsieh Yin-tang, director-general of the National Police Administration, said the warrant for Chu's arrest will be posted at airports, harbors and bus stations, as well as on street posts.
However, rumors have been circulating that Chu has been seen recently in a hotel in Zhaihai City, in the southern mainland Chinese province of Guangdong.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT ATTENDS HEARING AS WITNESS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui attended a hearing at the Taipei Prosecutor's Office Wednesday as a witness in the investigations into the Chunghsing Bill Finance Co. scandal.
It marked the first time in Taiwan's history that a former head of state has been questioned by law enforcement officers.
Lee was in good spirits when he left the prosecutor's office after two and a half hours of talks with two prosecutors.

Lee refrained from answering press inquiries about the contents of his talks with the prosecutors, saying he must abide by the law which prohibits any disclosure of any details of a case that is being probed.

The Chunghsing Bill Finance Co. scandal involves People First Party Chairman James Soong, who has been accused of having embezzled Kuomintang (KMT) funds during his tenure as the party's secretary-general in the early 1990s.

The KMT ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000. While Soong served as the KMT's chief manager of day-to-day affairs, Lee was KMT chairman. Prosecution authorities said they believe that Lee might be able to provide them with some information that may help in the investigation.

Soong used to be Lee's protege, but their relationship soured after the central government decided to marginalize the Taiwan Provincial Government during Soong's tenure as the island's first-ever popularly elected governor. The provincial government was marginalized in 1998 when Soong's governorship ended. Soong later defied KMT policy to run in the 2000 presidential election as an independent. He narrowly lost the election and then shortly afterwards founded the PFP.
Soong will serve as incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan's running mate in the 2004 presidential election.

Meanwhile, the Taipei District Court has also issued a subpoena to former President Lee requiring that he appear in court Nov. 12 as a witness in the trial of a former KMT official who has been charged with involvement in a snowballing land development scandal. This will also mark a first in Taiwan history -- namely a former president attending a court hearing as a witness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 23 points to close at 6,051, with 23,581 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December fell 20 points to finish at 6,050, with 51 contract transactions, while March futures lost 28 points to close at 6,075, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,074 for November, 6,070 for December, 6,103 for March, and 6,071 for June, and 6,169 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
November TE futures moved down 0.85 points to finish at 261.8, with 5,205 contract transactions, while December TE futures fell 0.65 points to finish at 262.3, with 20 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures decreased 9 points to finish at 894, with 7,811 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 6 points to close at 896, with 32 contracts traded.
March TF futures moved up 6.2 points to finish at 898, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 19.6 points to close at 6,041.86.
The bourse opened at 6,046.04 and then fluctuated between 6,075.75 and 6,013.08 during trading.

A total of 5.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.83 billion (US$3.17 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 5.63 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$129.27 billion (US$3.8 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent. Electrical stocks remained unchanged.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues and textile issues, both at 0.3 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 380 to 362, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR LEAVES FOR U.S. TO ATTEND MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor Lin Kuang-hua left for the United States Wednesday to attend an annual meeting of the U.S. National Governors Association (NGA) to be held in Pittsburgh, Pa. later this week.
Lin said prior to his departure that Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who concurrently serves as NGA president, has invited him to attend the annual conference.

Lin will deliver a speech at the NGA conference on Taiwan's latest political, economic and social developments. Lin said he will take advantage of the occasion to introduce to the international community Taiwan's cause as well as its achievements in containing the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak that gripped the island between March and June of this year.
The marginalized Taiwan Provincial Government presently maintains sisterhood ties with 42 U.S. states. The NGA has traditionally invited the Taiwan governor to attend its annual conference.
Lin will also meet with Taiwanese community leaders during his stay in the United States. He is scheduled to return Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 22, or the 27th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN TO VISIT NEW YORK TO EXPOUND CROSS-STRAIT POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong is scheduled to arrive in New York City later this week to deliver a speech on Taiwan's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen is one of the few experts in the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration who are versed in mainland China's grass-roots politics and major political factions. He was a chief writer of President Chen Shui-bian's white paper on cross-strait policy during the 2000 presidential campaign.
Chen's speech on Taiwan's cross-strait policy will be delivered at a dinner party at the Taiwan Hall Sunday.

During his stay, Chen will also attend a seminar on the current state of cross-strait relations as well as Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on certain policy issues before or on the day of its next presidential election in March 2004.

The seminar will be sponsored by the Chinese Constitutional Reform Association, founded by Wang Dan, an exiled pro-democracy mainland Chinese student leader who is now working on a doctoral degree at Harvard University.

Wang said cross-strait relations are a critical factor in mainland China's future political development and constitutional reform. In his view, he said, Washington-Beijing relations are crucial to mainland China's modernization and political development. "And a major barrier to U.S.-mainland China relations is the possible outbreak of cross-strait conflicts," he added.

At the upcoming seminar, Chen is expected to expound on the background and reasoning of DPP administration's decision to hold a referendum. Several mainland Chinese scholars will present their views on the DPP's referendum plan.

Andrew Nathan, chairman of Columbia University's political science department, will also attend the seminar to offer his own views and the U.S. academic community's opinions about Taiwan's referendum proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA LISTS NAMES TO BE USED FOR INTERNATIONAL BIDS IN ORDER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has listed a number names in order of preference to be used for Taiwan's bids to join international organizations, Vice Foreign Minister Kau Ying-mao said Thursday.
Kau said that the Republic of China is the first choice of the MOFA in participating in official international organizations because it is the official designation of the country.
However, he noted, Taiwan is frequently forced to change its name in international organizations due to obstruction and pressure from Beijing, which is constantly trying to marginalize Taiwan.

Taking into consideration the need to adopt a flexible diplomatic strategy while defending the national dignity, Kau said that the MOFA has drawn up a priority list of names the country can use for designation in international bodies in the following order: ROC, Taiwan; Taiwan, ROC; ROC (Taiwan); and a variety of other options.
Taiwan is used as the official name in three of the 18 international governmental organizations of which the country is a member, Kau went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOKOHAMA MAYOR VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada paid a visit Thursday to the Kaohsiung city government with the aim of boosting the relationship between the people of the two cities and the ties between Japan and Taiwan.

Noting that he is the first mayor from Yokohama to visit the southern Taiwan port city, Nakada said he is deeply impressed by the city's vigor and progress and added that the Taiwan's largest port possesses advantages that Yokohama can learn about. He voiced the hope that the two port cities can transform themselves into world-class seaports through increased two-way exchanges.

Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lin Yung-chien gave high praise for Yokohama's development of its port and the conservation of the city's cultural heritage. He said many public affairs being promoted by Yokohama's municipal authorities are worth learning by Kaohsiung.

Lin told Nakada that the central government plans to build Kaohsiung into a free trade port zone and welcomes Japanese investment. The two men also agreed in principle to the idea of forging twin-city ties.
Lin received Nakada and a delegation of Yokohama city councilors on behalf of Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is currently visiting Senegal.

The Yokohama mayor and councilmen also paid a visit to the Kaohsiung city council later that same day and the two sides held a seminar to bolster closer and more frequent exchanges. Kaohsiung city councilmen lauded Yokohama's cultural, trade and commerce developments, while Nakada thanked his hosts for their warm reception.
The two city councils set up sisterhood ties three years ago, laying a solid foundation for sound inter-city exchanges and mutual cooperation.
Nakada will also travel to Taipei, where he will visit President Chen Shui-bian and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou before departing Taiwan Oct. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES DHL WORLDWIDE EXPRESS CEO

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu received the head of DHL Worldwide Express Thursday at the Presidential Office and thanked him for the long-lasting support the multinational delivery service firm has extended to Taiwan.

During the meeting, Lu welcomed Uwe Doerken and expressed her appreciation for the support and donations from DHL for the organizers of the first Democratic Pacific Assembly held in Taipei Sept. 19-21.
She also extended views with him on DHL's operations and globalization.
In response, Doerken thanked the government for the support and assistance it has extended to foreign investors in Taiwan.

DHL is to establish a large-scale service center in Dayuan, near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, and is willing to help Taiwan cultivate more talented individuals as a means of rewarding society, Doerken told his host.
Doerken was accompanied at the meeting by a group of DHL regional executives, including John Mullen, chief operations officer of DHL Asia-Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX FOR SEPTEMBER UP MODERATELY: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 135.21 for September, down by 0.22 percent from August but up by 7.49 percent over the year-earlier level, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Thursday.
The manufacturing sector posted an annual growth rate of 6.48 percent, the third consecutive month of growth in a row, according to the official at the MOEA's Statistics Department.

He noted that the information industry registered the largest rise of 11.45 percent, and attributed the growth mainly to a rebound in global demand for consumer electronics, computers and telecommunication equipment.

The chemical and metal machinery industries also expanded by 7.25 percent and 3.24 percent year-on-year, respectively, thanks to the many orders placed with Taiwan companies as a result of an appreciating euro, according to the official.

The official predicted that a moderate growth rate will also be registered in the fourth quarter, basing his optimism on the premise that an expanding world economy will fuel exports from East Asian countries, including Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, MATSU PEOPLE TO REPLACE RALLY WITH PUBLIC HEARING

TEXT.P: A protest rally by people from Kinmen and Matsu who reside in Taipei was called off at the last minute Thursday after the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that it is preparing to address their grievances.

Aides of Legislator Wu Cheng-tian, who was to have sponsored the rally, said that as the MAC has said it is preparing to address the grievances "with goodwill, " they decided to suspend the rally and replace it with a public hearing in the legislature on grievances over the "mini-three links."
The aides said that legislators, government officials, scholars and experts will be invited to take part in the public hearing.

Both Wu, who comes from Kinmen and Legislator Tsao Yuan-chang from Matsu, noted that the mini-links -- direct trade, postal and transportation links between Kinmen and Matsu and designated ports in mainland China -- were put into practice in January 2000.

But they said that Kinmen and Matsu people who live in Taiwan proper do not enjoy the same right as those who register in the two outlying islands for more than six months and can move freely to and from the mainland under the mini-links.

The aides said that they had originally planned to hold the rally Friday in front of the Legislative Yuan to let Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen know that they had "had enough" of the MAC.
Meanwhile, MAC officials pointed out that exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since the inauguration of the mini-links have been "seriously imbalanced."
They noted that as of August this year, Taiwan people had made more than 78,000 visits to the mainland, while mainland people had made less than 4,000 visits to Kinmen and Matsu.
The officials said that if the mini-links are to benefit Kinmen and Matsu economically, it will require matching efforts from the mainland authorities.

They added that Kinmen and Matsu people should not just demand that the government open the doors wider but should also express strongly to the mainland authorities their desire for matching measures from the other side of the strait.

MAC officials recently said that according to media reports and the council's own investigation, Kinmen and Matsu residents have purchased between 1,000 and 2,000 houses in Fujian Province just across the Taiwan Strait, paying an estimated combined total of between NT$1.5 billion and NT$4 billion (US$44.11 million-US$117.64 million).

They also said the MAC had originally hoped that Taiwan cigarettes could be shipped to the mainland via Kinmen and Matsu, but this has not materialized because the mainland has refused to adopt matching measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADS MAINLAND CHINA IN SEMICONDUCTORS: INDUSTRY LEADER

TEXT.P: Taiwan remains well ahead of mainland China in the development of the semiconductor industry amid burgeoning competition between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a prominent industry leader said Thursday.

United Microelectronics Corp. Chairman Robert Tsao made the comment while answering questions from the press following a news conference in which the Fabless Semiconductor Association (FSA) announced its decision to set up an Asia-Pacific operations hub in Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan leads mainland China in the semiconductor industry despite the fact that some mainland-based IC design companies are emerging, Tsao said that Taiwan is still the backbone in development, on the grounds that Taiwan still attracts major investment plans from around the world.

Although many people believe that the mainland is quickly catching up with Taiwan, Tsao said that "Taiwan is still running ahead of the mainland" because "the mainland market is still small and possesses no special advantages for foreign investors."

However, the industry leader also pointed out that it is totally wrong and goes completely against world trends for a country to stay in reclusion. A country must not set limits on itself in the pursuit of globalization, he added.

Echoing Tsao's view, FSA Chief Executive Officer Jodi Shelton agreed that Taiwan remains much more competitive than the mainland because of its efforts in research and development, as well as its drive in innovation and design.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DEMOCRACY ACTIVIST ALLOWED TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong democracy activist who was allowed to visit his critically ill mother in Guangdong Province, returned to the former British colony Thursday.

Pro-democracy activist Leung Kwok-hung traveled to his home town of Nanhai last week after obtaining a mainland Chinese travel document with the help of local officials, including Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG NOT AT HIGHEST LEVEL OF RISK FOR SARS RESURGENCE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Hong Kong is not at the highest level of risk for a resurgence of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus, a Department of Health official said Thursday.

Hong Kong is fully prepared for SARS and has adopted the highest level of vigilance possible for the detection of the virus, the official said, adding that his office has implemented a heightened surveillance system for SARS and has developed comprehensive contingency measures.

"Hong Kong has an advanced laboratory capacity to test for SARS. The Public Health Laboratory Center provides a free laboratory service and public health consultation service to the medical sector," he said.
While Hong Kong had local transmissions of SARS during the outbreak earlier this year, the former British territory was not identified as a source of SARS in November 2002, he added.
Earlier, there were reports saying that the World Health Organization was considering placing Hong Kong on the list of areas at the highest level of risk for a resurgence of SARS.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL RESUME TALKS WITH TAIWAN AFTER MARCH ELECTION: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The nation's top planner of mainland China policy predicted Thursday that Beijing will deal with Taiwan more pragmatically after next year's presidential election and that the long-stalled cross-strait talks will also be resumed.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the predictions in a speech delivered at the 16th joint conference of the Republic of China-New Zealand and New Zealand-Taiwan Business Councils, which took place in Taichung, central Taiwan.

According to Tsai, Taiwan's economic situation will become clearer after the March 20, 2004 presidential election and the Beijing authorities are "bound" to take a more pragmatic stance on relations with Taiwan. This, she claimed will make possible a re-opening of cross-strait dialogue, which she said will allow cross-strait direct shipping links and the adjustment of related trade policies move forward smoothly.

Addressing concern over the direction of Taiwan's long-term economic development, she said that the government is dealing with the issue of direct cross-strait shipping links. In the transitional period before dialogue resumes, the government will promote preparations and assessments for direct links, as well as faster and more convenient cargo transportation measures, so as to create more favorable conditions for direct links.

Tsai said that through an objective assessment, "we have realized that bringing the greatest benefit to Taiwan's economy and cutting the negative impact of direct cross-strait links to the minimum will hinge on several factors."

These factors, she went on, include "whether Taiwan can upgrade its globalization, whether it can improve its overall investment environment and living quality to attract more foreign investment, whether it can maintain the competitiveness of its core industries and whether it can promote a balanced flow of resources between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

Asked about mainland China's development of close economic partner arrangements with Hong Kong and Macao, Tsai said that Beijing is not interested in resuming normal talks with Taiwan and that any arrangements similar to the Hong Kong or Macau models would only be "empty talk" by Beijing.
She claimed that Taiwan should not be rushed in the negotiations over direct cross-strait shipping links, or it will risk losing its bargaining chips.

According to Tsai, cross-strait relations are a major part of international relations that have deep and far-reaching influence on the Asia-Pacific regional and world development. Cross-strait trade development will have to be reviewed under the framework of Asia-Pacific development and the world economy, she added.
In dealing with cross-strait issues, she went on, the paramount consideration will be how to deal with the challenge of globalization and the development of regional economic integration.

She noted that the government is now establishing its "roots in Taiwan, access the world" policy and said Taiwan has to strengthen the foundation of its economy for global competitiveness and turn cross-strait trade into an impetus that will stimulate, not hinder, Taiwan's economic development.

More than 150 participants took part in the conference, including New Zealand-Taiwan Business Council President Bertha Wright, Peter Dunne, chairman of the Foreign Affairs, Defense and Trade Committee of New Zealand's Parliament, and the host, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS BIOTECHNOLOGY SEMINAR HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on biotechnology in the Netherlands was held Thursday in Taipei with the participation of government officials, experts, academics and representatives of the business sector from Holland and Taiwan.

The seminar, which was jointly sponsored by the Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Industries Program Office (BPIPO) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office in Taipei, was aimed at promoting bilateral cooperation in the development of biotechnology.

Speaking at the seminar's opening ceremony, BPIPO Director Chen Chei-hsiang said that Taiwan and the Netherlands have similar experience in biotechnology development, particularly as regards developments in the agricultural sector.
Both Taiwan and the Netherlands consider one another as springboards for tapping the European and Asian markets, respectively, Chen claimed.

Topics of the one-day meeting included Taiwan's biotechnology sector, the latest developments in the life sciences sector in the Netherlands, drugs of the future, biotechnology and genomics research in the Netherlands, the biotechnology sector and opportunities in western Holland and an introduction to biotechnology research institutions and companies in the sector.
The seminar organizers also arranged individual meetings between participants, allowing them to explore cooperation opportunities.
The Dutch delegation to the meeting was headed by Dirk J. Bruinsma, director-general of foreign economic relations in the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Bruinsma and his delegation have been in Taiwan since last weekend to attend the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference held in Taipei Oct. 19-22.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORDERS FOR TAIWAN PRODUCTS INCREASE SHARPLY

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan products ordered in September by foreign buyers totaled US$15.4 billion, an increase of 20.41 percent over the same month last year, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
An official of the ministry said that the value of electronics and communications products ordered during the month increased US$720 million and US$710 million, respectively.
The respective value of precision instruments and machinery ordered in September was US$440 million and US$200 million more than a year earlier, he added.
He said the value of products ordered in October is expected to increase more than 10 percent over a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAUTIOUS ABOUT ONGOING ECONOMIC RECOVERY: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan must be prudent and cautious despite an economic recovery that is taking shape in the face of various uncertain factors, such as a reappearance of severe acute respiratory syndrome, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Thursday.
Lin made the remarks while giving a keynote speech at a three-day Taiwan-United States seminar on technological exchanges, which opened the same day.

Although a set of prime economic indicators shows that the domestic economy is moderately regaining momentum, Lin said Taiwan must remain alert for the negative impact of a possible reemergence of the potentially deadly disease this winter.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has set Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2003 at 3.06 percent, which he said is lower than the forecast by many other research institutions.

Compared to mainland China, Taiwan remains very competitive in various critical fields, the vice premier claimed. He said Taiwan is stronger in research and development (R&D) , international cooperation, overseas investment and location.

As of Oct. 21, world-class multinationals, including IBM, Intel, Sony, HP and Software, had set up 15 R&D centers in Taiwan, and eight top foreign companies had opened distribution centers, he noted, adding that leading local enterprises, including Hon Hai Precision, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., Compal, ACM and Delta Electronics also had opened 61 R&D hubs at home.

Stressing that wages are not the decisive element for a country to gain a foothold in the international market amid fierce global competition, he said Taiwan industries must build its own advantages to remain competitive.

At a time when many countries have left Taiwan behind in terms of production costs, he urged local businesses to dedicate their energy to technology- and capital-intensive industries and spare no effort to promote their brand names and engage in distribution.

In a bid to call for greater efforts from the private sector on creation and innovation, he said the government will increase its spending in R&D to account for 3 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) by 2007.

According to the vice premier, Taiwan spends about US$11 billion per year in R&D, accounting for some 2.16 percent of its GDP, lower than Japan's 2.98 percent, the U.S.' 2.7 percent and South Korea's 2.68 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIGHTS REFERENDUM TORCH AT SOUTHERN TIP OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu lighted a "referendum torch" at the southern tip of Taiwan Thursday to drum up support for a large rally scheduled for Saturday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Lu ignited the torch in front of the Oluanpi Lighthouse in Pingtung County, and later ran with 16 legislators for a kilometer before passing it to a torch relay team to continue the journey to Kaohsiung.
Delivering a speech before the run, the vice president said, "Although Taiwan has been moving toward democracy for quite some time, it has yet to promote a referendum."

She said that neighboring countries such as Japan, the Philippines, and South Korea have all conducted referendums, and holding a referendum is fairly common in the United States, adding that the Republic of China Constitution has endowed its people with the rights of election, recall, initiative and referendum and that when the people are not satisfied with the government's policy or the legislation passed by the Legislative Yuan, they can exercise their rights.

She expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will pass referendum legislation this session, adding that it is the obligation of legislators to pass the referendum legislation and that all voters should ask the legislators to do their duty.

The torch-lighting ceremony was presided over by Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who serves as the convener of an alliance to push for referendum legislation with 16 other legislators, including Lo Chih-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, Cheng Chao-ming, Chiu Chui-tseng and others from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party also attending.
The Oct. 25 rally is expected to mobilize more than 200,000 people to take to the streets, officials of an alliance to push for a referendum said.

The officials said that Kaohsiung is the birthplace of Taiwan's democracy movement and the referendum rally aims to awaken the consciousness of Taiwan people to display their support for "Taiwanization, democracy and progress."

The vice president headed the "southern leg" of the three-day, 157km run from Oluanpi, while the "northern leg, " which was led by former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung at the site of the partially completed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, will meet up on Saturday evening with President Chen Shui-bian shooting a "referendum arrow" toward the metaphorical target of "a referendum for a new constitution" to bring the event to a climax.

The "northern leg" running team began its 492.3km run Sunday from Taipei County to the southern port city of Kaohsiung, crossing through Keelung City, Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County in the north, down to Taichung County, Taichung City and Nantou, Changhua and Yunlin counties in central Taiwan, and Chiayi County, Chiayi City, Tainan County and Kaohsiung County in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION MAY VISIT MACAU NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries is considering sending a trade mission to Macau next month to study the Closer Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) between mainland China and Macau, an official of the federation said Wednesday.

Speaking at an economic and trade conference of overseas Chinese merchants in Macau, the official said Taiwan is interested in the preferential treatment mainland China has offered under the agreement. Mainland China signed CEPAs with Hong Kong and Macau earlier this year.

The federation official was interested in learning if Macau can offer similar or better treatment to Taiwan investors. If the answer is affirmative, Taiwan investment in Macau should increase significantly, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC MULLING NEW DESIGNATIONS FOR OVERSEAS SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) is mulling new designations for its overseas service organizations to distinguish them from those set up by mainland China, a senior official said Thursday.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, OCAC Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei said that the OCAC currently has 17 educational and cultural service centers abroad.
"As their current designations carry the words 'Chinese,' they have often been mistaken as mainland China's service centers for overseas Chinese people," Chang said.
In the face of the campaign to "rectify the name of Taiwan," Chang said, the OCAC is considering changing their designations to avoid unnecessary confusions and misunderstandings.

Chang said the OCAC's service center in Toronto has been re-designated as the Culture Center of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Toronto. "Other overseas OCAC offices may follow this model," she added.

Moreover, Chang told lawmakers that the OCAC may be re-designated as Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission. "This title will avoid confusions with mainland China's organizations and its acronym will be same as the original one," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO ADDRESS DESIGNATION ISSUE TO MAINTAIN NATIONAL DIGNITY: KAU

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will propose suitable designations for the Republic of China to facilitate its presence in the international arena and satisfy local people's expectations, a senior official said Thursday.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying Mao Kau made the remarks while delivering a report on the issues of the nation's designation and foreign affairs to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.

In the face of the campaign to "rectify the name of Taiwan" and the nation's increasingly difficult diplomatic situation, Kau said MOFA will address the designation issue by "complying with existing statutes and epitomizing Taiwan's sovereign status."

Kau said the drive to "rectify the name of Taiwan," also known as the "Call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement, arises from three major background factors -- mainland China's intensified suppression and all-out diplomatic embargo against the ROC; the necessity to upgrade Taiwan's global presence amid the prevailing globalization wave; and the keen desire of local people to enhance Taiwan's international profile.

Against this backdrop, Kau said the MOFA must work out suitable options for the nation's designation to distinguish the ROC from the People's Republic of China (PRC) -- mainland China's official title -- while keeping the nation's dignity.

"We must resolve the designation issue under the present constitutional framework and the principles of democracy and rule of law so that domestic political parties and non-governmental organizations (NGO) can attend major international activities.

Kau said the MOFA has different options for the nation's designation in engagements with the ROC's diplomatic allies and with countries that do not recognize the ROC diplomatically, for membership in international organizations and for applying for a seat in the United Nations.

"While engaging our 26 diplomatic allies, we use our official title of the Republic of China. In some cases, we would advise our allies to call us the 'R.O.C.' or 'Taiwan' to distinguish us from from the PRC, which is commonly known as 'China' in the international community," Kau said.

As the ROC's designation in international governmental organizations (IGOs) or NGOs has often been affected by mainland China's political interference, Kau said MOFA has worked out a priority list for use in membership applications -- the ROC, Taiwan, Taiwan, R.O.C., and R.O.C. (Taiwan), in that order.

Besides, he said, the ROC's designation in the World Trade Organization (WTO) -- the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu -- may also be used under certain special circumstances.

While engaging with countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC, Kau said Taiwan cannot unilaterally change the designation of its representative offices in those countries. "We must be pragmatic and consult with the countries of residence."

As to Taiwan's U.N. bid, Kau said, it's a highly sensitive political issue. "Changing our national title alone cannot ensure our entry to that world body. We must take international political reality into account," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LET CHINESE STUDENTS TAKE COURSES IN TAIWAN: MAC ADVISERS

TEXT.P: Several advisers to the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan said Thursday that Taiwan should promote cultural and educational exchanges with mainland China in a gradual and orderly manner.

According to Chang Shu-ti, director of the MAC's Department of Cultural and Educational Affairs, the advisers said in an MAC meeting that the first step is to let mainland Chinese students, or employees of Taiwan investors in mainland China, take courses in Taiwan schools.

Chang said the MAC will study the feasibility of the suggestion. Taiwan has started to promote cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland, he said, adding that 123 mainland Chinese graduate students have come to Taiwan for short-term studies since 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTABLE WATER ON OUTLYING ISLAND TO IMPROVE WITH NEW PIPELINE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday the development of small islands off Taiwan proper is important to his administration and that is why a second undersea fresh water pipeline will be constructed to better supply Liuchiu township.

The outlying islet called Hsiaoliuchiu (Little Liuchiu) , off southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, is currently supplied with only one water pipeline from Taiwan proper. The new pipeline could begin construction as early as next year, the president said.

President Chen noted that the first undersea water pipeline between Pingtung County and Liuchiu township is 30-year-old, and whenever it requires annual repair and maintenance the residents suffer much inconvenience.

The president made the remarks while presiding over the inaugural journey of the second government-run ferry at Tafu fishing port in Liuchiu township. The president, accompanied by Pingtung Magistrate Su Chia-chuan, earlier took the ferry at Tungkang Pier, Pingtung County, to Liuchiu township.

The president said that when he visited Liuchiu township three years ago, he learned that people there needed another government-run ferry to ply the township and Pingtung County. He said that after the persistent efforts of the central and local governments, the appropriation of more than NT$80 million (US$2.35 million) and over seven months of construction, he was happy to be able to have delivered on his promise to the local people.

"The government attaches great importance to the transportation infrastructure of Taiwan's outlying islands, " the president said, adding that he has instructed the Executive Yuan to plan construction projects for outlying islands between 2003 and 2006, and that the improvement of the supply of potable water in Liuchiu township and the development of local tourism are part of that project.

He also said that a project to develop a sea park at Hsiaoliuchiu is proceeding smoothly, and that he hopes that local fishermen can upgrade the value of fishery products with the guidance and assistance of the government to better fishermen's lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NEW ZEALAND ECONOMIC PROMOTERS MEET IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Trade promoters of The ROC-New Zealand Economic Council and their New Zealand counterparts met in the central Taiwan city of Taichung Thursday for the promotion of trade and economic relations between the two countries.

Peter Dunne, chairman of the Foreign Affair, Defence and Trade Committee of the New Zealand Parliament, said at the meeting that there is room for economic cooperation between the two countries. He expressed the hope that the two countries will negotiate a free trade agreement and increase their cultural and economic exchanges.

Huang Chih-peng, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said the two countries will benefit from the free trade agreement. He said the agreement will help New Zealand develop the market in mainland China and Southeast Asia.

TAIEX Index futures for December fell 89 points to finish at 5,961 with 234 contract transactions, while March futures lost 100 points to close at 5,950 with 14 contracts traded.

The bourse opened at 5,971.42 and then fluctuated between 5,997.82 and 5,938.67 during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB VERIFYING REPORTS ABOUT WANTED FORMER SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration is contacting mainland China to verify reports that the wanted former speaker of Kaohsiung City Council is currently in the southern mainland Chinese province of Guangdong.
CIB Commissioner Hou You-yi made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan where he was responding to questions about reports that Chu An-hsiung was seen in Zhuhai, Guangdong, last week.
The mass-circulation daily China Times reported that Chu took a fishing boat to sneak into Guangdong and that he is now under the care of his friends in Zhuhai.
"If there is substantial evidence to show that Chu is indeed on the mainland, the CIB will ask for assistance to obtain his return as soon as possible," Ho said.
Ho stressed that the cross-strait mechanism for jointly cracking down on crime is working well and that Beijing has always responded to the CIB's requests.
"So long as it does not obstruct mainland China's judicial system, " Ho said, he is sure the mainland "will be willing to help in such a high-profile case."

After Chu's disappearance, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation contacted its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, and provided it with Chu's photo, finger prints and other related material and information.

Kaohsiung District Prosecutors' Office issued an arrest warrant for Chu after he failed to show up last week to serve his 22-month jail term for voting buying in the election for speakership late last year. Chu has also been charged with involvement in several other criminal cases.
Chu's wife Wu Teh-mei, a former legislator, said Thursday that she was "put at ease" after receiving a "reliable" call the previous night informing her that her husband was now in mainland China.
Wu held a press conference Tuesday, accusing the government of imposing "green terror" on Chu, claiming that the government "selectively" dealt with Chu for political purposes.
Wu also said at the press conference that she has not been in touch with her husband and does not know his whereabouts.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VISITS OVERSEAS CHINESE LEADERS IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 22 (CNA) (by E. Tseng and EH)

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the major opposition Kuomintang, on Wednesday told overseas Chinese leaders in New York the basic principles his administration will follow if he is elected president of the Republic of China next year.
Speaking to some 800 overseas Chinese leaders at a dinner party, Lien said one of the principles is "to be loyal to the Republic of China and respect the ROC Constitution."

The second principle, Lien said, is for his administration to do its best to revitalize the economy, improve Taiwan's investment climate, and sharpen the island's competitive edge in the world market.
He said the third principle is to promote social justice and equality.

On relations between Taiwan and mainland China, Lien said both sides should not lose sight of the more distant future. They should instead set aside their dispute over sovereignty for the time being, and improve their relations on the basis of equality, mutual assistance and mutual benefits.

Lien, who is a candidate for the 2004 presidential election in Taiwan, was enthusiastically greeted by many overseas Chinese when he visited the Overseas Chinese Benevolent Association in New York before the dinner party.
He will leave for Los Angeles on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 23, or the 28th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE HEALTH MINISTRY PLANS TO SAVE US$12 MILLION PER YEAR

TEXT.P: Singapore's Health Ministry is working to trim some fat by allowing its two healthcare clusters, SingHealth and the National Healthcare Group (NHG), to cut their running costs.
They expect to save S$22 million (about US$12 million) per year. For patients, this could mean lower bills.
The NHG has a project to cut down hospital stays by its patients. Wherever possible, medical tests are done without the need to stay overnight.
Another project is buying drugs in bulk, and the NHG is doing this with SingHealth. They saved S$13 million last year.
SingHealth expects to save another S$9 million on non-drug costs like stints, implants and housekeeping services.
The two healthcare clusters will share tips on cutting costs and improving work procedures twice a year.
This move is part of the overall effort by the Health Ministry to keep hospital costs low by doing more with less, increasing productivity and sharing ideas on how to go about it.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH SECTOR KEEN ON NATIONAL DEFENSE BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: The private high-tech sector is keen on gaining business opportunities from national defense industries, as a total of 122 companies are taking part in the 2003 National Defense Research Show at the Taipei World Trade Center, a spokesman for the Taipei Computer Association said Friday.

Tu Chuan-chang, secretary-general of the association in charge of organizing the event for the Ministry of National Defense, said many top domestic hi-tech groups, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., the Acer Group, Via Technologies and Asustek Computer, are vying for a slice of the big pie, particularly in the field of C4ISR capabilities -- combat telecommunications, computer, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance.

As many Taiwan-based companies are able to supply key parts and components and software of the ministry's planned procurement of C4ISR systems and early monitoring systems, the ministry is willing to purchase from qualified domestic companies to help beef up Taiwan's national defense industry and also to reduce costs, Tu said.

In a bid to seize business opportunities from the military, companies are displaying their products and facilities made with biotechnology and nanotechnology at the show, he noted, adding that the ministry has long been hoping to incorporate the most advanced technology from the private sector to help it strengthen information-related combat capabilities for the armed forces.

Minister without Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen and Vice Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min visited the show, which opened earlier in the day and will run through next Monday. Innovation, research and development, as well as science and technology and defense are the leading themes of the show.
According to Chen, the show is a concrete result of the coordination of hi-tech reservists recruited by the ministry in concert with private companies.

Since the inception of the reservist system in 1980, the ministry has trained more than 10,000 individuals in hi-tech for the private sector by allowing conscripts to do four-year military services at contracted private companies, Chen noted, adding that such a cooperation platform has largely helped upgrade Taiwan's national defense industry and also sharpened the private sector's competitiveness.
Taipei Computer Association Chairman Hung Chung-jen said many hi-tech company executives have told him that the ministry's reservist system has become the cradle of high-quality manpower for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON POSTPONES HIS VISIT TO TAIWAN UNTIL NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: Former United States President Bill Clinton has decided to postpone his scheduled visit to Taiwan in mid-November to next spring, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

Victor Chin, director-general of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said that Clinton decided to postpone his visit to Taiwan due to the tight schedule of his upcoming tour of Asia, which will also take him to Japan and South Korea.

Clinton was scheduled to visit Taiwan Nov. 15 for a stay of less than 24 hours, according to an itinerary coordinated between Clinton's office and his office commissioned by the Democracy Foundation of Taiwan, which is to sponsor the former U.S. president's speech and visit to the island, Chin said.

Clinton originally planned to visit Taiwan in early November and decided to set a later date for the visit due to President Chen Shui-bian's planned visit to Panama around the same time, Chin explained.
Clinton hopes to stay in Taiwan longer to meet his "old friends" and to take a more extensive look at the island during his upcoming visit, he said.
Clinton visited Taiwan four times during his tenure as governor of Arkansas before being elected the U.S. president in November, 1991 for his first four-year term that started in 1992.
He was also scheduled to visit Taiwan on Sept. 12, 2001 and failed to make it due to the 911 terrorist attacks on the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN GIVES TAPED SPEECH AT LIBERAL INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian delivered a taped speech at the annual meeting of the Liberal International at Dakar, the capital of Senegal, Friday, according to a news release issued by Chen's office.
The news release said Chen gave the speech in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which joined the Liberal International last year.
A DPP delegation led by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh brought Chen's recorded speech to the conference and played it Friday.
In his speech, Chen invited member parties of the Liberal International to take part in an Asian conference of the organization in Taipei in March, next year.
The president touted his party's contribution to Taiwan's democracy, calling the DPP a trailblazer in terms of Taiwan's development of democracy.

He also promised to support Liberal International's human rights program with donations from Taiwan's newly established Taiwan Democracy Foundation as well as sponsor seminars in Asia and Central America in cooperation with other international organizations.
Chen also thanked the host country of Senegal, which is one of 26 states that recognize the ROC diplomatically.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES VISITING YOKOHAMA MAYOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian welcomed visiting Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada and members of his city council delegation Friday at the Presidential Office.
Chen said he appreciated Nakada's visit to Taiwan as it represents his support for and goodwill toward Taiwan.

The president told his guest that he visited Yokohama several years ago when he served as Taipei mayor. However, he went on, the then-Yokohama mayor dared only to meet him behind closed doors at a reception hall located on the coastal area of the port city for fear of irritating Beijing because Yokohama has sister-city ties with Shanghai.

Therefore, Chen noted that his meeting with Nakada at the Presidential Office and the latter's visit to Taiwan hold special significance. The president said that he hopes to visit Yokohama again in the future. Chen served as Taipei mayor from 1994 to 1998.
Chen also thanked Nakada for supporting former President Lee Teng-hui's request to travel to Japan for medical treatment two years ago when he served as a Japanese Diet member.
In response, Nakada praised Chen for his contribution to Taiwan's democratization and said that he believed the democracy in Taiwan will be further consolidated under his leadership.

Nakada arrived in Taiwan Thursday at the head of a delegation of Yokohama City councilors for a four-day visit. They toured Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan on the first day of their stay in Taiwan and are scheduled to depart the island Oct. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO CONTINUE EFFORTS TO LURE FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Friday the government's relentless efforts to modernize Taiwan and court foreign investment.

Chen made the remarks while giving a speech at a ceremony welcoming companies moving into the second compound of the Nankang Software Industrial Park in Taipei. Vice President Annette Lu and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou were also present.

Stressing that Taiwan must promote knowledge-based and clean industries, Chen noted that the park, set up to house mainly IC design, digital content and biotechnology businesses, is the brainchild of such a mindset.

As long as the government offers a sound investment climate and modern infrastructure, both foreign and domestic enterprises will be willing to invest in Taiwan, he said, pointing to the recent completion of various major investment projects, such as a key tunnel of the Beiyi Expressway connecting Taipei and Ilan, and the success of the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.

In the face of the huge challenges ahead, including the emergence of mainland China's economy as a global force, Chen said Taiwan must upgrade its industries and improve infrastructure to maintain its competitive edge.

For the time being, 94 foreign and domestic companies have applied to open shop in the second compound of the Nankang software park, including world-class groups such as IBM, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Infineon, Sony and NEC, occupying more than 90 percent of the space for rent.
Initial production value of the park has been estimated at NT$108.3 billion (US$3.19 billion).

In addition, the Industrial Technology Research Institute, Academia Sinica, a semiconductor research institute, a digital content institution and various incubator centers will also move into the park.

The 4.2-hectare compound, a partial realization of the government's flagship "two trillion, two star" program designed to advocate Taiwan's most promising hi-tech industries, is a joint venture between the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the private sector.
The "two trillion" industries refer to the semiconductor industry and the display industry, which are predicted to register each an annual production output of more than NT$1 trillion by 2006.
The "two-star" industries are the digital content and the biotechnology industries, which have been seen as Taiwan's most potential star industries.

Production value forecast for the digital industry (including software, computer games, electronic media, publishing, music, animation, Internet services, etc.) is set at NT$370 billion in 2006, while business volume of the biotechnology industry will hit NT$250 billion for the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO CHECK 50 TONS OF FISHERY PRODUCTS CLOSELY

TEXT.P: The departments of health and agriculture said Friday that they want to check more closely 50 tons of fishery products that are ready to be shipped to the European Union.

The 50 tons of fishery products, including processed eels, catfish and tilapia belong to five fishery product processing companies and originated from aquaculture farms in Tainan and Pingtung in southern Taiwan, the officials said.
Officials are now traveling to southern Taiwan to examine the fishery products that are being stored in freezers at the farms. The results of the testing will be released in two or three days.

They said that if the aquaculture farm operators are found to have been using banned chemicals, they will be fined between NT$6,000 and NT$30,000 (US$176 and US$880) and if they have added banned substances to fish feed, they will be fined between NT$3,000 and NT$10,000.
Hu Shin-hwa, director of the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Administration, and Department of Health (DOH) officials made the remarks during a news conference.

The latest incident came after the EU's recent rejection of 30 tons of Taiwan fishery products exported between August and October, for allegedly containing carcinogens such as chloramphenicol and chemical residue such as furajolidone.
The 30 tons of fishes and shrimps were exported from processing companies in Kaohsiung and had originally come from the counties of Kaohsiung, Chiayi, Pingtung and Tainan.
The reports have sparked an almost islandwide check of seafood for contamination.
Government officials said that they might consider buying more sophisticated equipment to test for chemicals more accurately.
Meanwhile, Kaohsiung fishery product processors appealed for the government Friday to vigorously monitor the feed used by aquaculture farms.

Kaohsiung is the stronghold of Taiwan fishery products, with more than 100 large operators. As the competition is steep, many processors are worried that news report about Taiwan's exported fishes containing banned chemicals might have an adverse impact on the exports of Taiwan fishery products in general.
