DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION NOT CONSTRUED AS PROMOTING INDEPENDENCE: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of the respondents to a recent poll, the results of which were released Friday, said they do not think that the push for a new constitution is aimed at promoting Taiwan independence.

The poll, conducted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , came after controversy over President Chen Shui-bian's promotion of referendum legislation for next year, as well as the introduction of a new constitution by 2006.
The poll, which was conducted Oct. 19-20 by telephone, obtained 1,071 effective samples with a margin of error of 3 percent.

The results show that 66.1 percent favor the idea that any change of Taiwan's status quo must be decided by referendum, while 64.2 percent said that only major policies should have to be decided by referendum.
DPP officials defined major policies as the fate of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, parliamentary reforms and membership of the World Health Organization.

The survey also found that 67.2 percent of those polled do not agree that promotion of referendum is aimed at promoting Taiwan independence, compared with 22.3 percent who said the referendum has Taiwan independence in mind. Meanwhile, 57.2 percent the respondents said that the introduction of a new constitution is for the purpose of promoting Taiwan independence, against 26.3 percent who disagreed.
The results also show that to save on costs, 55.5 percent of those polled favor the sponsoring of a referendum to coincide with the presidential election of March 2004.

As for which political parties have worked hardest to promote referendum, 34.1 percent named the DPP, followed by its ally, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union at 26.8 percent, the Kuomintang at 15.2 percent and the People First Party at 10.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH OF MADAME CHIANG CLOSES PAGE ON AN ERA: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu offered her condolences Friday on the death of Soong Mei-ling, widow of the late Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, saying her death represents the end of an era.

Speaking during a visit to several private companies in Kaohsiung County, Lu told journalists that she felt saddened by the death of Chiang, whose life was entwined closely with the history of the Republic of China.
However, Lu went on, her death marks the end of a bygone era and the people of Taiwan should look forward to the new age.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, S. KOREA TO BEGIN TALKS ON FTA EARLY NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Singapore and South Korea have agreed to begin talks on a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) early next year with the aim of inking a deal within 12 months.

In a joint statement following a summit meeting held Thursday, Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and visiting South Korean President Roh Moo-Hyun expressed the hope that the FTA talks will open up new opportunities for businesses from both states. Total trade between the two sides amounted to US$7.7 billion last year.
The leaders also pledged to work together closely to promote both states as regional hubs.
Singapore also expressed its support for Roh's policy for peace and prosperity, including making the Korean Peninsula free from nuclear weapons.
Roh arrived in Singapore for a three-day visit on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS LIEN-SOONG SUPPORTERS DECLARE SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By E. Tseng and EH)

TEXT.P: The overseas supporters of presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong issued a joint statement Thursday to show their support for Lien's election campaign.

The statement, issued when leaders of the Overseas Association of Lien-Soong Supporters visited Lien in New York, said that they support his position on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, as indicated in his speech delivered earlier this week in Washington.

Lien said in the speech that both Taiwan and mainland China should not lose sight of the more distant future but should instead set aside their dispute over sovereignty and improve their relations on the basis of equality, mutual assistance and mutual benefit.

The statement also said that they support Lien's policy of "giving first priority to the interests of Taiwan, maintaining the status quo in cross-strait relations, revitalizing the economy and promoting trade."

The statement said that the Republic of China is a sovereign country and not part of the People's Republic of China. It is therefore not necessary for the country to proclaim independence or to hold a national referendum on its identity. In addition, the statement said that the ROC has a legitimate right to join in world organizations and that the mainland should not threaten Taiwan with military force.
Lien left New York later that day for Los Angeles on the last leg of a trip that has taken him to several cities in Europe and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIVER TRANSPLANT OPERATION ON FILIPINO BABY SUCCESSFUL: HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: A 14-month baby boy from the Philippines has received a piece of his mother's liver in a successful operation performed by surgeons of Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, hospital authorities said Friday.

The little boy, named Nicolai, and his mother, were described as "doing fine" after the operation, Chang Gung doctors said. Both Nicolai and his mother had been taken off artificial respirators as their conditions have been excellent since the 12-hour operation conducted a day earlier.
The doctors said the mother is expected to be allowed to leave the hospital in one week, while her child is expected to be discharged in a month.

The boy, who had suffered from biliary atresia since birth, has undergone several operations in the Philippines since he was four months old. Failure following failure, the Filipino doctors suggested that the boy receive a live-donor transplant, with the surgery to be performed in Taiwan, which is advanced in terms of hepatology.

Donor and recipient arrived in Kaohsiung Oct. 19 and after the Chang Gung surgical team determined that the mother was capable of donating part of her liver, the live-donor transplant operations went ahead Thursday.

The Kaohsiung Chang Gung Liver Transplant Team has so far performed 152 successful live-donor liver transplants, with the youngest recipient only eight months old. Among the recipients, six are foreign nationals, of whom Nicolai is the youngest.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGE OF OFFICES NOT PART OF MINI-LINKS: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A proposal that Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands exchange offices with mainland China to bolster two-way ties is not an issue related to the so-called mini-three links, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said Friday.

Liu made the remarks in response to a request by residents of the two islands that the MAC, Taiwan's top mainland policy-planning agency, further open the mini-links -- direct trade and transport and postal services that have been in place between Kinmen and Matsu and the Fujian Province ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou on the mainland since Jan. 1, 2001.
According to Liu, the links issue forms a segment of the government's overall policy toward the mainland and also has an impact on the whole country.

Residents of Kinmen and Matsu demanded a day earlier that the central government further enhance the links to help with the economic development of the islands in the face of an extreme imbalance in exchanges between the two sides.

According to MAC statistics, mainland-bound Taiwan travelers had made a total of more than 78,000 trips as of the end of August via the links, while Taiwan-bound mainland people only made a little more than 3,000 trips.

An MAC official blamed the mainland authorities for the situation, on the grounds that full cooperation from the mainland is indispensable if the links are to proceed smoothly and progressively so as to benefit both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF PROBING ARREST OF TAIWAN FALUN GONG MEMBER IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday that they had heard not a word from the mainland Chinese authorities about the alleged arrest of Taiwan citizen Lin Hsiao-kai, who has been missing since Oct. 7 when he was last heard from in Shanghai.
Officials from Shanghai's Taiwan Affairs Office confirmed Friday that Lin has been detained and that he is under interrogation for taking part in Falun Gong activities in mainland China.

SEF officials told the CNA that they wrote to the SEF's mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), several days ago to inquire about Lin's whereabouts, but had yet to receive any response.
The officials said they will continue to contact ARATS for further information about Lin.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taiwan and the mainland, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of formal ties between the two sides.

Lin, 29, formerly an assistant researcher with the Coastal Hydraulics Research Center of National Cheng Kung University, went to Shanghai to visit friends on a tourist visa in September. He sent a message to his wife in Taiwan Oct. 7 via cell phone saying that he would be home that night. However, he did not return and has not been heard of since.
Lin's wife, Chen Shu-ya, called a press conference in Taipei Oct. 21 to make known her husband's plight and to call for help in finding him.
Chen said she believes Lin was arrested because his notebook computer contained information on Falun Gong, which has been branded a dangerous cult by the mainland regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: MADAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK PASSES AWAY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, considered by many to be one of the most outstanding Chinese women of the 20th century, passed away at 11:17 p.m. Thursday at her New York home at the age of 106.
Andrew Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, cited Chiang's friends and relatives as saying that the former first lady passed away peacefully in her sleep.
Chiang's niece, Kung Lin-yi and her husband were at her bedside when she died, according to friends.

President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu expressed their condolences and Chen instructed Hsia and Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen to extend his condolences to the Chiang family on behalf of himself and the government.
President Chen instructed Presidential Secretary-General Chiou I-jen to coordinate the relevant agencies to provide assistance pertaining to the funeral and other arrangements.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien also expressed his condolences and praised Chiang for her stature in the diplomatic arena, as well as her contributions to the ROC.
Chiang, the widow of the late Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, had spent most of the 28 years since her husband's death in 1975 in seclusion in New York.

Chiang, whose maiden name was Soong Mayling, was born in March 1897 in Shanghai. She went to the United States in 1908 and entered Wellesley College in 1913, where she majored in English literature and minored in philosophy.
After her graduation from Wellesley in 1917, she returned to China, where she honed her fluency in spoken Chinese and studied the classics and literature of China. There she met her husband in 1920.

Chiang's life was inextricably linked to the history of modern China and Taiwan. With her western-education and impeccable English, she became the best spokeswoman for the Chinese cause against the invading Japanese Imperial Army in the 1930s.

She and her husband together faced the military crackdown on the warlords of northern China, the crusade against communist rebellion, the eight-year war against Japanese aggression and the struggle against the Chinese communists, with the ultimate goal of reclaiming mainland China.

After the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949, the ROC first couple retreated to Taiwan and became Asia's foremost symbol of anti-communism. Generalissimo Chiang served as ROC president and KMT chairman until his death in Taipei in 1975.

The former first lady made a rare public appearance in mid-1995 when she attended a reception at Capitol Hill in her honor in connection with celebrations to mark the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN LOS ANGLES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 23 (CNA) (by L. Chu and EH)

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the major opposition Kuomintang arrived in Los Angeles from New York Thursday to visit overseas Chinese leaders in southern California.
He is scheduled to visit the Overseas Chinese Benevolent Association and other organizations of overseas Chinese in Los Angeles on Friday and deliver a speech at a dinner party in Pasadena, Calif.
He was greeted at the airport by Taiwan officials and many supporters upon arrival at the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL ALLIANCE FOR DEMOCRACY, PEACE TO MEET IN HOUSTON
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Texas, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Chen Ying-ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The second world conference of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace (GADP) is slated to be held in Houston, Texas Oct. 30-Nov. 1, with the participation of nearly 500 representatives of 58 GADP chapters from around the world.
High-ranking Republic of China officials and a number of prominent lawmakers and scholars from the United States are expected to attend the three-day conference.
The topics for discussion at the conference will focus on democracy and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

U.S. dignitaries expected to attend the conference as special guests will include Congressman David Wu (D-OR) , chairman of the Congressional Asian Pacific Americans Caucus; Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-TX), chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus; and Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee (D-TX).
Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech Oct. 31 titled Democratic Taiwan and Cross-Strait Peace.

Other Taiwan officials scheduled to take part in the conference as special guests will include Chen Tsung-wen, vice minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, and Lee Chen-hsiung, a deputy representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Dr. Hans Stockton, an assistant professor at the Center for International Studies of the University of St. Thomas, is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech on Taiwan's future, while Dr. Uk Heo, a professor in Asian international relations with the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, will speak on Taiwan's position in the changing security environment of East Asia.
The conference is also scheduled Oct. 30 to elect a new GADP chairman to oversee the alliance's operations for the coming year.
The GADP was set up by the ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in November 2002 to rally overseas Chinese to promote the values of democracy and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 34.09 points to close at 5,918.14.
The bourse opened at 5,972.65 and then fluctuated between 5,990.72 and 5,918.14 during trading.

A total of 3.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.92 billion (US$2.32 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.32 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$94.24 billion (US$2.78 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical stocks moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, constructions stocks at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and electrical shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 403 to 303, with 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. RESTATES INSISTENCE ON PEACEFUL RESOLUTION OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament on Thursday reiterated the European Union's "insistence" that the cross-Taiwan Strait problems be solved in a peaceful manner.

The European Parliament passed a general annual report on the common diplomacy and security policies of all E.U. member countries, reiterating that the European Union "insists" with "strong interest" that both sides of the Taiwan Strait seek to solve the Taiwan issue through dialogue.
The report also called for mainland China to remove all the missiles it has deployed in its coastal provinces opposite Taiwan so as to help maintain peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

The annual diplomacy and security report, submitted jointly by the Parliament's committees of diplomatic affairs, human rights, common security and defense policy, explicitly echoed a European Commission statement issued Sept. 10 calling for the European Union to build closer ties with Taiwan under multilateral frameworks and to support Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations.

During Thursday's passionate discussions, members of the European Parliament committees also unanimously passed a resolution for the inclusion of the emergency resolution that it passed May 15 calling for support for Taiwan's admission into the World Health Assembly (WHA) into the 2003 European Parliament general annual report on the common diplomacy and security policies of all E.U. member countries.

The annual report stressed the crucial importance of developing economic relations and improving the political atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait. It also insisted that the European Union should, through bilateral or multilateral frameworks, seek to engage in closer ties with Taiwan, a move which it said is in line with the European Union's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 24, or the 29th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: MADAME CHIANG CLOSE FRIEND OF U.S.: BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush issued a statement Friday on the death of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, praising the former ROC first lady as a "close friend of the United States throughout her life."
Bush said in the White House statement that generations of Americans will always remember and respect her intelligence and strength of character.
The statement reads:

"Laura and I were saddened to learn of the death of Madame Chiang Kai-shek. Madame Chiang was a close friend of the United States throughout her life, and especially during the defining struggles of the last century. Generations of Americans will always remember and respect her intelligence and strength of character. On behalf of the American people, I extend condolences to Madame Chiang's family members and many admirers around the world."
Madame Chiang died in New York Thursday at the age of 106.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEQUIVOCAL POSITION STATEMENT HELPFUL FOR CROSS-STRAIT TIES: CHIOU

TEXT.P: Clear and unequivocal position statement is helpful to maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff said Saturday.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks in a speech delivered at a meeting of the Taiwan chapter of the Rotary International. The meeting was held as part of the group's support of President Chen's re-election bid.
Chiou said there are two dimensions in cross-strait relations, namely basic stances and actual policies.
As far as the basic stances are concerned, Chiou said, both sides of the Taiwan Strait are firm on their positions.
"Chen's administration has stick to its 'one state on each side' of the Taiwan Strait stance, while Beijing's cardinal position is its cherished 'one China' principle," Chiou explained.
While neither side has shown signs of compromise or retreat from their stances over the past three-plus years, Chiou said, cross-strait have actually made progress.
In his view, Chiou said, Beijing leaders are far more pragmatic and smarter than local opposition politicians have thought.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration was inaugurated in May 2000, he said, the two sides have completed Hong Kong and Macau aviation rights negotiations. Moreover, Chiou said, Taiwan now can repatriate about 2,000 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants annually. "All these issue couldn't have been resolved if the two sides had not have contacts," he added.

Over the past three-plus years, Chiou continued, the DPP administration has adopted a total of 18 measures to facilitate cross-strait exchanges in various fields, or one measure for every two to three months.
"The figures indicate that we have moved toward normalization of cross-strait ties in a gradual and prudent manner," Chiou explained.

With Beijing-Washington and Beijing-Tokyo relations improving, Chiou said, Taiwan faces even greater diplomatic challenges. Worse still, he said, mainland China has continued stepping up military buildup.
"In the face of all these new developments, we must redouble efforts to beef up our national strength and survive in the highly competitive international market," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 200,000 PEOPLE TAKE PART IN DEMONSTRATION IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Some 200,000 people took part in a demonstration in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung Saturday to highlight their call for nation-wide referendums and a new constitution.
Vice President Annette Lu said at the beginning of the demonstration that Taiwan is not part of the People's Republic of China. "Taiwan belongs to Taiwan people."

She said it is necessary for Taiwan to hold national referendums and to craft a new constitution. Taiwan and China should improve their relations on the basis of equality, peace, and mutual assistance, she added.
The demonstration is sponsored by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan (PCT), and 21 other organizations.

Led by leaders of the DPP, TSU, PCT, and some other organizations, the demonstrators marched 2.5 miles through six streets in Kaohsiung, chanting such slogans as "All citizens can take part in referendums," "Let the number of legislators be reduced by half," and "Referendum is a basic human right."
The demonstrators, who came from various parts of Taiwan, also attended an evening party after the march.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABOUT 9% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE SINGING THE BLUES: DOH SURVEY

TEXT.P: About 9 percent of Taiwan people aged over 15 are feeling the blues, according to the results of a survey released by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) Saturday.

The DOH conducted the survey last year. It interviewed 32,660 randomly chosen residents aged 15 or over and collected 26,755 valid replies. Senior high school graduates, married people and those aged between 45 and 64 formed the bulk of the respondents.

The survey found that 8.9 percent of the respondents felt the blues during the month before the interview. The percentage was far higher than the world average of 3 percent estimated by the World Health Organization.

The figure also indicated that about one million local people showed symptoms of depression. Worse still, 5.2 percent of them were patients of serious depression and the number of women in this group was 1.8 times that of men. The DOH estimated that only 2.3 percent of those patients have received professional medical treatment.
While 8.4 percent of elderly people (aged 65 or over) interviewed said they felt the blues, 6.8 percent of those aged between 15 and 17 also said they suffered from depression.
Health was the elderly people's main cause of depression while uncertainty about the future was the largest source of the blues among young people.

With the jobless rate rising, career prospects have become the biggest source of depression for those aged between 25 and 44. Most male patients attributed their blues mainly to unemployment or economic factor while many female respondents cited parents-children relations as the main cause of the blues.

The DOH survey also found many male depression patients were aged between 25 and 44, divorced, lived in metorpolitan areas, grew up in familes with parents from mainland China, had low income and suffered from chronic diseases.

Meanwhile, women who said they often felt the blues concentrated in two age groups of 15-24 and 25-44. Many of these women had only received elementary or high school education, were divorced or widowed, and suffered from chronic diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PRAISES TAIPEI COUNTY GOVERNMENT FOR BEING ECO-FRIENDLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday praised the Taipei County Government for using environmentally friendly techniques to clean up several rivers.

At the Taiwan Ecotechnology Exhibition held in the MRT station in Tamsui, northern Taiwan, Chen, along with Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang, several high-ranking government officials, and representatives of domestic environmental protection groups, read a declaration as a promise to work for the continued preservation of Taiwan's beautiful mountains and rivers.

Su noted that the former government and even the people have not paid much attention to the importance of environment conservation, which has thus resulted in great damage to Taiwan's natural environment.
Under the instruction of the Chen administration, Su said that clean-up operations along several rivers in his county have used ecotechnology to preserve the beauty and pristine nature of the land.
After visiting the ecotechnology exhibition, Chen also inspected the clean-up work of Tatun Creek, Sanchih, northern Taiwan.

Chen said he has designated Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, the most prestigious academic institute in Taiwan, as the convener of a consulting commission for the preservation and development of the land of the country, focusing on ecotechnology.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 200,000 PEOPLE TAKE PART IN DEMONSTRATION IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Some 200,000 people took part in a demonstration in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung Saturday to highlight their call for nation-wide referendums and a new constitution.
The demonstration is sponsored by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan (PCT), and 21 other organizations.

Led by leaders of the DPP, TSU, PCT, and some other organizations, the demonstrators marched several miles through six streets in Kaohsiung, chanting such slogans as "All citizens take part in referendums," "Let the number of legislators be reduced by half," and "Referendum is a basic human right."
The demonstrators, who came from various parts of Taiwan, also attended an evening party after the march.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FOLLOW E.U. STANDARDS IN FISHERY PRODUCTS INSPECTIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will adhere to European Union (E.U.) standards in inspecting for chemical residues in aquaculture products, a senior official said Saturday.

Hu Shin-hwa, director of the Council of Agriculture's (COA's) Fisheries Administration, made the remarks while briefing local aquaculture farm operators on the country's new fishery products inspection rules.

Hu traveled to National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan to give the briefing after the E.U.'s recent rejection of 30 tons of Taiwan fishery products exported between August and October for allegedly containing possible carcinogens such as chloramphenicol and furazolidone, which are used in the treatment of infections caused by bacteria.

Hu told aquaculture farm operators and seafood processors that the European Union has raised chemical residue standards. "This is a general world trend. We must follow this trend to maintain our market niche and business reputation," he added.

In the past, the maximum chloramphenicol and furazolidone residue was set at 0.3 parts per billion. "In the future, we'll comply with the E.U. standard of no more than 0.1 parts per billion," Hu said.
Moreover, he said, the number of cases to be subject to spot checks as well as the frequency of inspection wills all be substantially raised.

The stricter residue standard will increase the cost to NT$5,000 per inspection from the current NT$2,000, Hu said, adding that the COA will also invest an additional NT$50 million in acquiring new inspection equipment.
According to Hu, inspectors from fishery and health departments are visiting major aquaculture farms around the island to check whether banned chemicals are being used.
"Operators who are found to have been using banned chemicals will be fined between NT$6,000 and NT$30,000 (US$176 and US$880) , " Hu said.
Taiwan produces some 350,000 tons of aquaculture products a year, worth an estimated NT$30 billion. Annual aquaculture exports account for about one-third of total production.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CAMP RALLIES AGAINST CREATION OF A NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: More than 500 supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" rallied Saturday on the front line island of Kinmen to express their opposition to the writing of a new constitution and Taiwan independence.

Yok Mu-ming, chairman of the opposition New Party, said his party held the rally in Kinmen because it has always been a fortress of defense for the Republic of China, and on Oct. 25, which has the symbolic meaning of victory.
On 0ct. 25, 1945, Taiwan was formally returned to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation, while on Oct. 25, 1949, ROC government troops withstood sustained bombing from Communist China.

The "pan-blue alliance" supporters called for a victory by the joint presidential and vice presidential candidates of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and "Long live the Republic of China."
In a joint statement issued Friday, KMT and PFP representatives said they will amend the Constitution rather than forge a new one as has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
Participants at the rally also included many political heavyweights of the three political parties including former Premier Hau Pei-tsun.

Lien, who is a candidate for the 2004 presidential election in Taiwan, was busy visiting overseas Chinese leaders and other supporters during the day.
He visited the Overseas Chinese Benevolent Association in Los Angeles and then met with leaders of 26 other overseas Chinese organizations in southern California at a tea party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO XINHUA NEWS AGENCY REPORTERS COVER REFERENDUM RALLY

TEXT.P: Two reporters from mainland China's official Xinhua News Agency have traveled to the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung to cover a large-scale rally to promote referendum legislation and formulation of a new constitution for Taiwan.

Zhang Yung, a reporter from Xinhua's Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau affairs department, and Wu Zengxiang, a photo-journalist from Xinhua's Shandong bureau, arrived in Kaohsiung Wednesday to cover the referendum rally which started at 2 p.m. Saturday and will last through 10 p.m.

Zhang said he has covered major Taiwan news events in the past few years and is pleased to cover the referendum rally, the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan. More than 200,000 are expected to take part.

Both Zhang and Wu said they believe that the referendum rally is just a campaign strategy adopted by the pro-independence "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union in the run-up to Taiwan's 2004 presidential election.

They said mainland Chinese authorities have kept a low profile toward the DPP administration's plan to hold a referendum on certain public issues either before or on the election day of the island's next presidential election even though the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has yet to pass a referendum bill. "Beijing will respect the choice of the people of Taiwan," Zhang said.
Zhang further said he himself is more concerned about Taiwan people's views on the establishment of direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY GUARDS GETTING TOO FRIENDLY WITH MAIDS A PROBLEM IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: A new code of ethics is being drawn up for security guards across Singapore. Among the no-no's -- security guards at condominiums will be discouraged from getting "friendly" with maids.
The move is a joint effort by the Association of Certified Security Agencies and the Security Association of Singapore.
A code of ethics is expected to be drawn up and implemented next month.
Many residents are worried that small talk between maids and security guards may lead to big problems.

Ratan Singh, who heads the Industry Capability Upgrading Programme to raise standards in the local security industry, says some security agencies have received complaints from condo residents about this ongoing issue.

"There have been complaints from tenants about maids talking to guards while washing cars in the morning so we are trying to get them to refrain from doing all this. It projects a bad image, " he said. "They could check on certain things and make themselves more productive rather than chit-chat and laugh away the time.

"There was one situation in one of the condos some time ago when one of the maids was very friendly with all the security personnel there and then she invited her boyfriend to come because her employer was away for one month, " said S.T. Moorthy of King's Security and Safety Management.
"Just to oblige her, they let him in. And he has been sleeping there all the while and later it was reported to police that many items were missing from the house.

"Security guards are not supposed to fraternize with any female or male because once you fraternize, you cannot check them. That is a security risk. So, if anybody gets involved with a maid, we transfer the guy out," said Moorthy.
But residents have mixed views, especially since the problem, they say, only involves a few bad apples.
"Being friendly is no problem but the most important thing is the security guard has to draw the line," one person said.

"It does affect their work. Management changed some of the security that had this hanky-panky going around. But sometimes you cannot stop them; they are very friendly. You know they have to patrol around," another said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 25, or the first day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five-yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.

Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NAVY TEAM ARRIVES TO REPORT SUBMARINE PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: A U.S. Navy group arrived in Taipei Sunday on a mission of giving a report to Taiwan officials on the progress of a submarine procurement project.

The 10-member U.S. team, headed by Gibson Leboeuf, deputy chief of the U.S. Navy International Program Department, will be meeting with officials from the ROC Navy General Headquarters to brief them on the progress of the plan on Taiwan's procurement of eight diesel submarines from the United States.
The U.S. government announced in 2001 a robust package of arms it had agreed to sell to Taiwan, including the eight diesel-powered submarines.

Taiwan formally filed a request in 1995 for procurement of the submarines from the United States in an effort to beef up its deterrence capabilities against possible attempts by mainland China to blockade Taiwan.
Since the United States stopped producing diesel submarines long ago, its contractors will have to cooperate with their European counterparts to build the subs for Taiwan.

However, most of the countries that are capable of producing subs have been reserved about supplying Taiwan with subs for fear of negatively affecting their relationship with Beijing. The U.S. Navy has thus been endeavoring to talk those sub makers into cooperating with the United States on the issue, according to a source from the Legislative Yuan.
The Executive Yuan has agreed in principle to allocate a "special budget" of about NT$300 billion-NT$400 billion (US$8.84 billion - US$11.8 billion) to support the sub procurement project.
Leboeuf and his group is expected to stay in Taiwan until Oct. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PAYS HOMAGE TO LATE MADAME CHIANG

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu visited the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Sunday to pay homage to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek, who passed away at the age of 106 in New York Thursday.
Lu payed homage to Madame Chiang by bowing to a picture of the late Republic of China first lady that was set up at a temporary memorial service site at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
Lu shook hands with Chiang-Fang Chih-yi, the granddaughter-in-law of Madame Chiang, and offered her condolences to the Chiang family for the passage of the "eternal first lady."
The vice president praised Madame Chiang as "a neo-woman in an old era" who witnessed Chinese, Taiwan and world history unfold during a life that stretched across three different centuries.

With the passing of the respected Madame Chiang, a new era has arrived, Lu said, adding that it is time now for all the people of the country to "adopt a brand new perspective on matters dealing with internal, diplomatic, as well as cross-strait relations.

Lu said that while commemorating Madame Chiang, the Taiwan public should also emulate the spiritual model that Madame Chiang had laid -- a model telling that women should bear the same level of responsibility as their male counterparts to their nation.
Madame Chiang died Thursday morning in her Manhattan home where she had spent much of her later life after her husband's death in 1975.
In Taiwan and the United States, many political leaders have expressed their condolences to Madame Chiang's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY WELCOMES TAIWANESE INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 26 (CNA) (by E. Lim and EH)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese investors are urged to invest in the Philippine electronics industry, especially in the manufacture of leadframes, substrates, molding compound, liquid crystal display, and semiconductor wafers, the Philippine Department of Trade and Industry said in a recent news release.

In the news release, Secretary of Trade and Industry Manuel Roxas was quoted as saying that Taiwanese companies are encouraged to follow the example of Ulead, a software company in Taiwan, to set up facilities in the Philippines "to provide real-time support."

He said that, last year, electronics accounted for 87 percent of the country's US$2.5 billion exports to Taiwan and 67 percent of its US$1.9 billion import from Taiwan. "This trade has contributed to the Philippine's robust semiconductor manufacturing services industry."
Roxas said there are also good opportunities for Taiwanese companies to invest in the agriculture, fishery, and aquatic resources of the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OPENS HAKKA CULTURAL FESTIVAL IN MEILUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who can claim credit for helping raise the status of Taiwan's minorities, notably the Hakka people, on Sunday opened the Hakka Cultural Festival in Meilung, Kaohsiung County.

Although the Hakka people are the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan, they were largely ignored by past governments. Chen's administration established the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs and then set up the All-Hakka TV Channel in July this year.
In order to revive the Hakka dialect and Hakka culture, Chen said, his administration is compiling a textbook on the Hakka dialect and is training Hakka dialect teachers.

The Hakka Cultural Festival, which will run through Nov. 16, is another example of the emphasis his administration attaches to the Hakka people, Chen said, pledging to create a diversified society where the various ethnic groups are on an equal footing and receive their due respect.
"I am a Hakka person too and need your support, " Chen said in not so fluent Hakka, to the great applause of his audience.
The festival is featuring Hakka opera and Hakka music performances which will be staged every weekend for the duration of the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY SEES CROSS-STRAIT LINKS NEGATIVELY FOR TAIWAN SECURITY

TEXT.P: MAJORITY CONCERNED ABOUT IMPACT OF LINKS WITH M'LAND ON SECURITY: POLL

Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) Although many people consider that direct shipping links with mainland China would be a plus for Taiwan's economic development, more people worry about the impacts of such links on Taiwan's security, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.

The survey, commissioned by the Taiwan Advocates, a group made up of political followers of former President Lee Teng-hui, found that 57.5 percent of those surveyed said that direct transportation links with mainland would be a threat to Taiwan's security, while 49.6 percent said they would help Taiwan's economic development.

Meanwhile, 52.2 percent of those polled said mainland Chinese residing in Taiwan have impaired their chances of landing jobs, 65.8 percent said these mainlanders' political rights in Taiwan should be seriously restricted, 73.6 percent said these mainlanders should not be allowed to work as government employees, and 46.9 percent said that the number of 3,600 mainland spouses per year being allowed to enter the island is too high.

A total of 52.8 percent of the respondents said direct transportation links with mainland would accelerate Taiwan's brain drain and capital flight, while 54.2 percent said the economic and trade exchanges with mainland China are one of the leading reasons behind Taiwan's surging unemployment rates.

Furthermore, 57.5 percent said they believe direct transportations links with mainland would inevitably harm Taiwan's security, and 50.2 percent said economic development should be subordinate to security when the two are in conflict.

The survey showed that 65.3 percent of the respondents believe mainland China is hostile toward Taiwan in general, while 49 percent said they are concerned about the political loyalty of local politicians who visit the mainland frequently.
Local businesspeople's calls fro closer economic ties with mainland China were played down by 74.6 percent of those polled, who dismissed their opinions as serving their own interests.

The survey, conducted by the Focus Survey Research Corporation in Taichung City, was carried out Oct. 21-22 on 1,062 adults in Taiwan. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.01 percentage points, according to its author.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 20% OF 4TH GRADERS HAVE HAD SUICIDAL THOUGHTS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 20 percent of fourth graders, or 10-year-olds, in Taipei City and Hsinchu County have had suicidal thoughts at one time or another, according to a research paper released Sunday.

Chiang Yi-chen, a doctoral student at National Taiwan University's Institute of Public Health and Welfare, interviewed a total of 2,075 fourth graders from Taipei City and Hsinchu County, as well as 1,841 mothers and 1,652 fathers of these pupils, as part of her research into the factors behind suicidal tendencies among elementary school students.
According to her survey, 26 percent of the Taipei fourth graders interviewed said they have thought about committing suicide, while 13 percent of the Hsinchu students said that they have.
This indicates that children in urban areas are more likely to succumb to the stress in their daily lives resulting from school or family relations or other personal reasons, Chiang said.
Chiang also found from the survey results that girls are more likely to have suicidal thoughts.

She further concluded that children who live in big cities and often feel lonely or depressed, or who are not on good terms with their family members, or have violent tendencies are more likely to think about committing suicide.
Chiang said she found that most of the 10-year-olds that she interviewed are genuinely aware of the meaning of death and what suicide is.
Family-related factors, including violence or low income, are major factors prompting the fourth graders to think about killing themselves, according to Chiang's report.

The one child that Chiang found to be the saddest among those she interviewed was a boy who lives in Taipei City who said he has attempted suicide three times over the past 17 months, including jumping from a building, slashing his wrist, and trying to hang himself.

The boy, who suffers from tongue problems due to a genetic defect, said he often feels depressed and bullied, particularly when he is with his peers at school. Influenced by his family's religious beliefs, the boy said that he believes in reincarnation and that he is not at all afraid of dying, according to Chiang.

Chiang's research is part of a five-year project authorized by the National Health Research Institute to probe into abnormal behavior in children and teenagers in Taiwan. The project is being conducted by several universities in Taiwan, but mainly by National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATION PRAISES PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has contributed greatly to Taiwan's democratization and has therefore won the Human Rights Award from the International League for Human Rights (ILHR) , the league's chairman Scott Horton said Sunday.
The ILHR will present Chen with the Human Rights Award on Oct. 31 when Chen makes a stopover in New York City on his way to Panama for an official visit.
He noted that Chen defended human rights while he served as a lawyer and that as president, he has made an important contribution to Taiwan's democratization.
Horton said that after discussing it at length, the ILHR decided to give Chen the award to honor his achievements.

Former South African President Nelson Mandela, former South Korean President Kim Dae Jung, the late human rights activist Andre Sakharov from the former Soviet Union, and Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama are some of the prominent previous winners of the award, according to Horton.

The league also presents a Defending Defenders award to those who have improved the human rights situation in a given place around the world. U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan attended the organization's award presentation ceremony last year, Horton said.
Founded in 1941, the New York-based International League for Human Rights monitors the human rights situation around the world and publishes a report on human rights every year.

The award-presenting ceremony will be jointly presided over by former U.S. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, who is chairman of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, and Wu Li-pei, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.

The workshop was jointly sponsored by the Taipei-based Republic of China Foundation for International Cooperation and Development and the Agriculture Department of Grenada, the official said.
The participants studied the methods to produce dried fruits and many kinds of fruit juice and fruit jam from the produce of their own country, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAT OPENS TWO NEW ROUTES

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT) on Sunday launched two maiden flights, one to Da Nang in central Vietnam and the other to Shanghai via Cheju in South Korea.

The trip from Taipei to Da Nang takes two hours and 50 minutes, about four hours shorter in travel time than transferring from Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh City, an FAT official said, noting that the two weekly flights will provide a much quicker service for Taiwan tourists and businesspeople heading to the central part of Vietnam.
Da Nang, with a population of 800,000, is the largest deep-sea port and business center in central Vietnam.
FAT and the mainland-based China Eastern Air Ltd. also reached agreement recently to jointly conduct flights on the Taipei-Cheju-Shanghai route.

FAT will operate seven flights to Cheju on a weekly basis, from where China Eastern Air planes will transport passengers to Shanghai following a stopover of 80 minutes. Travel time on the Taipei-Cheju-Shanghai route is about four hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC CAPABLE OF BUILDING SUBS: GERMAN CONSULTANTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) is capable of building submarines, given the strength of the CSBC and the ROC Navy, as well as the capabilities of the private industrial sector, a consultant group from Germany said Sunday.

The idea of the CSBC building submarines for Taiwan is by no means a fantasy, said members of the German consultant group, who have recently completed a one-week assessment tour of Taiwan, mainly to CSBC's plants.

By combining the capabilities and resources of the ROC Navy and Taiwan's private industrial sector, the CSBC could produce submarines after upgrading some of its facilities, the German consultants said in a just-released assessment report.

The Executive Yuan established a cross-division ad hoc committee, headed by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, in January this year to facilitate plans calling for part of the eight diesel-powered submarines that the United States has promised to sell to Taiwan to be built in Taiwan by the CSBC.
The U.S. government announced in 2001 a robust package of arms it had agreed to sell to Taiwan, including the eight diesel-powered submarines.

Taiwan formally filed a request in 1995 for procurement of the subs from the United States in an effort to beef up its deterrence capabilities against possible attempts by mainland China to blockade Taiwan.
Encouraged by the assessment results, the CSBC has become more confident about its potential to partake in the submarine building project.

According to CSBC officials, it is hoped that a "2-2-2-2" plan will be followed in the building of the eight diesel-powered subs, where the first two subs are built totally in the United States or elsewhere abroad, one-third of the third and fourth subs are built in Taiwan, two-thirds of the fifth and sixth subs are manufactured in Taiwan, and the last two subs are built completely in Taiwan.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said he believes that the Legislative Yuan will support the CSBC attempts to co-build the eight subs so long as the overall manufacturing quality is acceptable, the prices are not abnormally high and the building period not too long.
Co-building the subs with the involvement of domestic companies will help upgrade Taiwan's shipbuilding capabilities and increase job opportunities for Taiwan citizens, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP ALLIANCE TO ANNOUNCE ELECTION PLATFORM IN STAGES

TEXT.P: The "pan-blue alliance" of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) is planning to announce its platform in installments over the next two months, a press official of the alliance said Sunday.

Pang Chien-kuo said that the platform will be divided into 14 parts, with each part dealing with a single issue of concern to the voters. The first part, which focuses on women's welfare, has already been released.
The second part, which will probably be announced in early November, centers on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he said.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan will run as the "pan-blue alliance" candidate in the presidential election set for Mar. 20, 2004, while PFP Chairman James Soong will be his running mate.
Peng said the alliance will hold a series of large-scale campaign activities in various parts of Taiwan in the run-up to the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT JOB MARKET

TEXT.P: With the steady economic recovery and greater demand from the private sector, the government is optimistic there will be an improvement in Taiwan's employment market.

According to the newest forecast by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), Taiwan's jobless rate is expected to fall below 5 percent in October and to 4.6 percent in December. The DGBAS also predicted that the average unemployment rate for the fourth quarter will be around 4.7 percent and that the average for the whole year will be lower than 5 percent.

The latest statistics compiled by the DGBAS show that Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 5.05 percent in September, down by 0.16 percentage points from the August level, or the largest August-to-September decline since September 1998. The September figure also represented a drop of 0.27 percentage points from the level posted in the same month of last year.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun reported recently at the Legislative Yuan that unemployment, particularly among the middle-aged and older workers, will pose a serious threat to social and economic stability, noting that specially designed measures are required to solve the problem of joblessness among elderly workers.
"The whole of society will have to pay a greater cost if unemployment is not properly resolved in a timely fashion, " he stressed.

Pointing to South Korea as example, Yu said the South Korean government succeeded in reducing the country's unemployment rate from 4.8 percent in 1998 to 3 percent in Nov. 2002 by spending an equivalent of NT$170.7 billion (about US$5.02 billion) on public service projects.

A similar employment-boosting program in Taiwan worth NT$20 billion implemented by the Executive Yuan on June 18 has also started paying off, with more than 70,000 jobs having been created so far, Yu pointed out.
The Executive Yuan forecast that with the special budget of NT$20 billion, about 75,000 jobs can be created a year and the jobless rate reduced to less than 4.5 percent.

In addition, the government took complementary measures to curb the so-called structural joblessness by lowering the number of foreign laborers allowed to be introduced into the Taiwan job market. The government also introduced a job insurance law this January, allowing unemployed workers to receive government subsidies to help them deal with their short-term financial straits.

Job opportunities in the private sector will also gradually increase for Taiwan's 9 million workers thanks to an improved economy at home, including temporary jobs with the approach of the Chinese New Year, according to the DGBAS forecast,

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 26, or the second day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU PAYS RESPECTS TO LATE MADAME CHIANG

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun paid his respects to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek Monday at a temporary memorial housed in the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.
Yu bowed three times to a picture of Madame Chiang who died in New York last Thursday at the age of 106.
Yu said he was paying homage to the late Republic of China first lady on behalf of the Executive Yuan. Yu also extended his condolences to Madame Chiang's family.
Commenting on local people's mixed views on Madame Chiang's role in modern Chinese history, Yu said historians will give her a fair judgment.
Madame Chiang had led a peaceful, reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband -- the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek -- died in 1975.
Born Soong Mayling, Madame Chiang became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist Japanese forces, which began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the ROC government, under Chiang's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his U.S.-educated wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN RELEASED AFTER FAMILY PAYS RANSOM

TEXT.P: A mainland China-based Taiwan businessman who was kidnapped in Dongguan, Guangdong, last week was reportedly released Sunday after his family paid a ransom of US$1.68 million.
The Taiwan businessman, whose name was withheld, was reportedly abducted at midnight last Wednesday when he was driving home with a friend after a KTV party in Dongguan.

Two days later, the Dongguan-based kidnappers called the businessman's wife in Taichung, Taiwan, telling her to pay the ransom -- one of the highest in recent years related to cross-strait kidnappings -- at a central Taiwan roadside point along the Sun Yat-sen Freeway at midnight of the same day.

The ransom was paid in accordance with the kidnappers' instructions, but because the wife of the businessman did not hear from him after paying the ransom, she made an emergency call to a Taichung City councilman for help at around noon Saturday.
The businessman's wife finally received a call from her husband Sunday morning telling her that he had been released by his kidnappers.

As of Sunday, four of the businessman's alleged abductors had been arrested by Dongguan public security authorities, according to Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials, who have been in contact with their Dongguan counterparts for information on the case.
Mainland police are currently working to find out the identity of the four abductors, their motives and whether the kidnapping ring's mastermind is in Taiwan, the CIB said.

According to the CIB officials, the businessman's wife tried to haggle the ransom down to about US$1 million, telling the kidnappers that the amount of U.S. dollars in cash that they were asking for was difficult to obtain in a single day. However, the kidnappers firmly insisted on the original ransom amount.
CIB police said they believe that the kidnapping ring's mastermind, who they claim is well aware of the financial status of the businessman's family, is currently in Taiwan.
The businessman is reportedly returning to Taiwan Monday, according to CIB authorities and Taichung City police, who are continuing their investigations into the case.
