TEXT.P: National Police Administration (NPA) head Chang Szu-liang urged mainland China Monday to join hands with Taiwan in cracking down on criminals who take advantage of the absence of an institutionalized channel of contact between Taipei and Beijing.
Only close cooperation between law enforcement agencies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can close this loophole, Chang said.
He made the appeal after four people who allegedly kidnapped a Taiwan businessman in Dongguan, Guangdong Province last Wednesday were arrested by public security officers there Sunday.
The kidnapped businessman was released in Dongguan after his family in Taichung, central Taiwan, paid a ransom of US$1.68 million on Friday.
His family raised the sum demanded by the kidnappers in a telephone ransom demand and threw the money over a freeway overpass as instructed by the kidnappers' Taiwan contact.

The contact, who is believed to have fled to the mainland, was still at large, although US$1.5 million of the ransom money, which the contact had hidden in an abandoned factory in Changhua, central Taiwan, was discovered by a person unrelated to the case, who alerted the police Monday.
The names of both the victim and the kidnappers' suspected accomplice were withheld.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH JAPANESE DELEGATION TO ENGINEERING SEMINAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Monday with a group of Japanese engineers who came to Taiwan to attend a engineering seminar and urged them to do their part to improve bilateral ties while joining hands with their local counterparts to raise the level of both countries' engineering technology.

If the size of the Japanese delegation to the Sino-Japanese Modern Engineering and Technology Seminar is anything to go by, the significance of the seminar is increasing year by year as more and more of the top engineers from both countries are attending, the president said.
The seminar, the 23rd of its kind, opened Sunday in Taipei and will last until Friday. It is organized by the Taipei-based Chinese Institute of Engineers.

Japan has sent a 30-member delegation, the biggest ever, to exchange views with local engineers on issues in the fields of applied science, steel and iron, mechanical engineering, nuclear energy, the environment and various other relevant topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Series of Blasts Across Baghdad Kill at Least 15.
A series of blasts shook Baghdad early Monday, including a suicide attack on the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COLLEGE OF NURSING SIGNS MOU WITH QUEENSLAND NURSING SCHOOL

TEXT.P: The National Taipei College of Nursing (NTCU) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Monday with the School of Nursing of Australia's Queensland University of Technology.

Under the terms of the MOU, those who enroll in the two-year NTCU program and complete 18 months of the course, and those who enroll in the four-year program and complete the first three-and-a-half years of the course can apply to go to Queensland University of Technology to study at the nursing school there.

If the NTCU students successfully complete one year at the Queensland school, they will receive bachelors' degrees in Taiwan and Australia simultaneously, as well as a licence to nurse in Australia which will enable them to work in Australia legally.

NTCU officials said that they are happy with the signing of the MOU and said it will enhance the international competitiveness and edge of the students, expand their horizons and increase their employment opportunities, as well as help ease the oversupply of nurses in Taiwan.
The School of Nursing of Queensland University of Technology was established in 1978 and is the oldest and largest center for tertiary nursing education in Queensland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOOSTS TIES WITH 15 STATES ON FRINGES OF APEC MEET: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan held bilateral talks with 10 states and has improved bilateral ties with at least 15 states on the fringes of a ministerial conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Bangkok, an economics official who returned after the conference said Monday.

In a briefing to the legislature, Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Foreign Trade Bureau, said that the Republic of China (ROC) delegation to the 15th APEC Ministerial Meeting, which took place Oct. 17-18, made good use of its presence at the international gathering by associating with as many delegations from other member states as possible.
Huang said the ROC delegation had bilateral talks with delegations from Chile, Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, Vietnam, Thailand, Canada, Indonesia, Japan and Russia.

Singapore, Australia, New Zealand and Japan expressed interest in concluding free trade agreements with Taiwan, but preferred the issue to be dealt with by private organizations as a pure economic one rather than having it handled by the government as a political issue, Huang said.
Meanwhile Chile, Indonesia and Russia expressed interest in beefing up cooperation with Taiwan's small- and medium-sized business, Huang went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HOPES TO GIVE MADAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK GRAND BURIAL

TEXT.P: The government will assist the family of Madame Chiang Kai-shek to bury her in the most grand manner if her family agrees to let the government handle the funeral and other related arrangements, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Monday.

Lin Chia-lung said that Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, has been instructed by President Chen Shui-bian to coordinate the matter, paying attention to the legal and protocol aspects.

Lin said that if the Chiang family agrees to let the government handle the funeral, the national funeral law will be invoked to provide the most grand funeral for Chiang, who died in New York Thursday at the age of 106.

Lin noted, however, that since the revised national funeral law was passed in 1948, no national leaders, including Chiang's late husband Chiang Kai-shek, former president Yen Chia-kan, and former vice president Shieh Tung-min, have ever been buried under the framework of the law, so there is therefore no precedent to follow.
The Presidential Office will discuss the matter with the Chiang family and the Executive Yuan will work according to instructions from the Presidential Office, Lin added.

The national funeral law stipulates that Republic of China nationals who have done distinguished work or who have made great contributions to the nation that have enhanced the national glory or human welfare can be honored with a national funeral. In such cases, the president would send officials to pay their respects to the deceased at the funeral, while flags would be flown at half-mast on that day.

Reports have said that Chiang left no will or burial instructions and her family is divided over her final resting place. Some wish her body to be returned to Taiwan, while others want her to be buried in New York at a cemetery in which several of her family members, including her sister and brother, are interred.

Madame Chiang's life was inextricably linked with the history of modern China and Taiwan and she is credited with using her Western-educated background to lobby for China during its fight against the Japanese in the 1940s, as well as her devotion to women's rights and charity work.
She spent most of her time in seclusion in New York after her husband's death in 1975.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SETS TARGET OF 4.7 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan has set Taiwan's economic growth rate target for 2004 at 4.7 percent, according to a national development program approved Monday by the government's top economic planning agency.

CEPD Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh said that the "challenging target" can be achieved if a NT$500 billion (US$14.8 billion) program for expanding public construction in five years can be carried out smoothly and the existing program for increasing job opportunities can continue.

Taiwan's economic growth was registered at 1.73 percent in the first half of this year due to the impact of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Ho noted, adding that the growth rate is expected to reach 4.32 percent in the second half of the year.

According to the latest report on Taiwan's economic situation published by the CEPD, the country's economy enjoyed steady growth in September and is expected to continue to grow, she went on, predicting that the annual growth rate will reach 3.06 percent as estimated by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

Looking forward to the prospects for the next year, Ho predicted that private investment will increase by 7.11 percent, while the unemployment rate will fall to 4.5 percent and the consumer price index will move up 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Civil service tries short-term hiring.
Singapore's biggest employer, the civil service, is hiving off some jobs into contract hires, with several ministries employing officers on short-term contracts for permanent posts.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Wolfowitz's Baghdad hotel targeted in rocket attack
In a dawn strike from near point-blank range yesterday In Baghdad, anti-American forces unleashed a shower of rockets on a hotel where the visiting United States Deputy Defence Secretary was staying.

DOC.HEADLINE: 63 TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN, DEPENDENTS KILLED IN MAINLAND CHINA SINCE 1991

TEXT.P: Sixty-three Taiwan businessmen and members of their families have been killed in mainland China since 1991, according to statistics released Monday by the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
In addition, SEF officials said, 115 other people from Taiwan have gone missing on the mainland during the same period.
Meanwhile, the officials went on, 50 Taiwan citizens have either been kidnapped or illegally detained there, while 78 others have been robbed, injured or blackmailed.
In the first nine months of this year alone, six Taiwan people were killed on the mainland, according to the SEF tallies.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO FORGE CLOSER COOPERATIVE TIES WITH ASIAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the Republic of China hopes to forge closer cooperative relations with all Asian countries for the mutual benefit of all.

Addressing the opening of the seventh annual meeting of the Asian Science Parks Association (ASPA) at the government-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , Chen said regional economic integration has become a prevailing world trend.
In the face of this wave of integration, Chen said, the ROC will make every possible effort to develop constructive interaction with all Asian countries.

Noting that Taiwan sits on a strategic location between Northeast and Southeast Asia and ranks among the world's top four exporters of high-tech products, Chen said his administration will do its utmost to forge closer ties with its Asian neighbors based on the existing frameworks.

As research and innovation hold the key to high-tech industrial development, Chen went on, Taiwan has set up many research laboratories to encourage the development of innovative technologies and help aspiring businessmen to launch high-tech ventures.

These innovative centers, plus the island's three core science-based industrial parks in Hsinchu, Taichung and Tainan, have formed a "technology corridor" in western Taiwan that will play the role of locomotive to turn Taiwan into a "green silicon island," home to environmentally friendly high-tech industries, Chen said.
He lauded the ITRI for its contributions that have helped nurture many new high-tech companies on the island over the past seven years.

"Since the ITRI set up an open laboratory seven years ago, it has successfully helped create 110 high-tech firms, with an accumulated paid-in capital of NT$41 billion, " Chen noted, adding that the ITRI is the most suitable organization to represent Taiwan in organizing the 2003 ASPA annual conference.
About 200 representatives from science-based industrial parks in 11 Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea and mainland China, are attending the ASPA annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: U.S. surprised in Iraq by insurgents'fight.
Secretary of State Colin Powell conceded Sunday that the Bush administration had not expected armed resistance in Iraq to continue as long as it has at so high a level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO PAY RESPECTS TO LATE MADAME CHIANG DURING STOP IN N.Y.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will pay his respects to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek when he makes a transit stop in New York at the end of this month on his way to Panama for an official visit, a Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.

Joseph Wu, deputy secretary-general to the president, said Chen is adjusting his itinerary in New York in order to pay his respects to the memory of Chiang, who died at her Manhattan home last Thursday at the age of 106.
Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei Oct. 31 and Wu said the president plans to pay his respects to the late Republic of China first lady immediately after his arrival in New York.
"The Presidential Office is still consulting with the ROC representative office in the United States and Madame Chiang's family on technical details," Wu said.
According to Wu, Chen attaches great importance to Chiang's funeral.

"Chen has said that Madame Chiang's funeral is not a personal affair, but rather a national affair. He has directed his chief of staff, Chiou I-jen, to consult with the Chiang family and to assist in the funeral arrangements, " Wu said, adding that Chen wants all relevant government agencies to assist in making the best possible funeral arrangements.
According to Wu, Chen has instructed that all national flags will fly at half-mast on the day of Chiang's funeral.
Moreover, Wu went on, Chen will issue a posthumous commendation in honor of Chiang for her contribution to the ROC, particularly in the diplomatic field.

Commenting on local press reports that Chiang's niece Kung Ling-yi has expressed the hope that Chen will personally drape an ROC national flag upon Chiang's coffin at the funeral, an unidentified Presidential Office official claimed that there is no precedent in world history for such a thing.
He added, however, that when Chen pays his respects, he will present a large ROC national flag to the Chiang family that can be draped upon the coffin at the funeral.
Due to his busy schedule, the official added, Chen might not be able to attend the memorial service.
Chen will leave New York for Panama Nov. 2 to attend the Central American country's Nov. 3 centennial celebrations.
Chiang led a reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband -- the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek -- died in 1975.
Born Soong Mayling, Chiang became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist the Japanese forces that began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the ROC government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his U.S.-educated wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST STRENGTHEN REGIONAL RESOURCES: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said Monday that to prepare for mainland Chinese capital coming into Taiwan, the island should strengthen its position as an integrator of regional resources.

Lin made the comments in a report delivered at the Legislative Yuan in the wake of the legislature's clearing earlier this month of a revised law governing exchanges between the people of Taiwan and mainland China.

The revised Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland made major revisions to such major topics as cross-strait direct transportation, mainland Chinese capital entering Taiwan and the circulation of mainland China's currency, the renminbi, in Taiwan.

Lin said that in line with the revision of the statute, Taiwan should strengthen its position as an integrator of regional resources and encourage foreign companies to set up operational headquarters, research and development facilities and logistics centers in Taiwan to facilitate their inroads into the mainland.
In the meantime, Taiwan should accelerate its industrial upgrading and build a comprehensive infrastructure to induce foreign companies to make investment in Taiwan one of their priorities.

On the entry of mainland Chinese capital to Taiwan, Lin said the government will regularly review the items opened to mainland China and open others in stages. If mainland investment becomes overheated or "abnormal, " then the ministry will adopt appropriate measures to cut the economic risk.

The government will also review goods imported from the mainland and will step up its defense mechanism against mainland products under the framework of the World Trade Organization so as to use the trend of the division of labor on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to invigorate Taiwan's economy.

Statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that trade with the mainland amounted to US$24.56 billion in the first seven months of this year, accounting for 22.2 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade. Of this figure, exports to the mainland totaled US$18.83 billion, up 18.7 percent from the same period of last year.

In comparison, Taiwan imported US$5.73 billion-worth of goods in the first seven months, up 35.3 percent, accounting for 8.3 percent of Taiwan's total imports and giving the country a trade surplus of US$13.1 billion.
Mainland China is the largest export destination of Taiwan and the third-largest source of imports, as well as the largest trade surplus source.
Taiwan has invested an aggregated US$32.97 billion on the mainland since 1981 when it first started keeping records, accounting for 49.1 percent of Taiwan's outbound investment.
The mainland has become the largest destination for Taiwan investment, which is mainly focused on the traditional manufacturing industry in provinces such as Jiangxu, Guangdong and Fujian.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGES WITH MAINLAND SHOULD BE BASED ON THREE CRITERIA

TEXT.P: Cultural exchanges with mainland China should adhere to three criteria, namely dignity, reciprocity and safety, Huang Chieh-cheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in Keelung, northern Taiwan, Monday.

Speaking at a workshop on academic exchanges with mainland China, Huang said cultural exchanges with the mainland are the least controversial and stabler form of exchanges. The only principle regarding them is that they should not compromise the dignity and safety of the country,
He cautioned the participants at the workshop to be on their guard against Beijing's attempts to politically deny Taiwan statehood in its dealings.

Huang urged local colleges and universities, which often have faculty exchanges with their mainland counterparts, to ensure that their guests from the mainland are not trying to sneak into the island to sightsee or work.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON COMPETITION POLICY AND LAW TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A two-day symposium on competition policy and law will open in Taipei Tuesday with 200 scholars and experts from Taiwan, Japan, Russia, France, the United States and nine other countries participating.

Dr. Frederic Jenny, chairman of the Competition Committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , will deliver a speech at the meeting. Taiwan became an observer of the OECD's Competition Committee on Jan. 1, 2002.

Discussions at the meeting will center on the future development of competition framework, especially in the fields of globalization, technological innovation and financial reform, an official of the Fair Trade Commission of the Executive Yuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO SET UP INSURANCE FRAUD PREVENTION CENTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will set up an insurance crime prevention center to cope with ever-growing fraudulent insurance claims, a senior official said Monday.
Political Vice Minister of Finance Susan Chang made the remarks at ameeting of the Legislative Yuan's Budget and Final Accounts Committee.

During the meeting, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lo Ming-tsai said that amid the current economic doldrums, there have been a number of reports of fraudulent insurance claims. "How can the MOF help insurers handle those cases?" he asked.
In reply, Chang said the MOF has decided to earmark money from the ministry's NT$3.5 billion Insurance Industry Development Fund to form an insurance crime prevention center.
The new center will collaborate with insurers and law enforcement authorities to intercept fraudulent insurance claims, Chang said.

In another news development, Administrative Vice Finance Minister Yang Tzu-chiang confirmed at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee that from Jan. 1, 2004 all people who intend to open accounts at local banks must have their photos taken by banks with digital cameras.
"The new measure is part of the government's efforts to stop the increasing prevalence of 'figurehead' bank accounts, which are often used for criminal purposes," Yang said.
He said although taking fingerprints is the most effective way to prevent the opening of 'figurehead' bank account, the nation has yet to reach a consensus on such a measure.

"As a substitute measure, would-be bank account applicants will be asked to have their photos taken from the beginning of next year," Yang said, adding those photos are expected to offer clues for law enforcement officers in probing financial crimes in the future.

The Conservative party was on the brink of a leadership battle on Sunday night as momentum towards a no-confidence vote against Iain Duncan Smith gathered pace.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAR-DISABLED IRAQI BOY TO RECEIVE MEDICAL TREATMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 12-year-old Iraqi boy who was maimed during the U. S. bombing of Iraq arrived in Taipei Monday to receive medical treatment that may include fitting prostheses.

Khaldon-Kh-Thiab, who lost his right hand and left foot as a result of U.S. bombing, is scheduled to stay in Taiwan two months to receive check-ups and treatment mainly at the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, according to a spokesman for the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which sponsored the Iraqi boy's Taiwan trip.
Doctors at the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital are expected to treat the boy's injuries before deciding on the nature of the prostheses, the Eden spokesman said.
According to the Eden foundation, Khaldon-Kh-Thiab was playing with two of his younger brothers in the courtyard of their house when U.S. bombers swept across the skies of Fallujah near Baghdad.

The boys fled the courtyard and went inside their house where they waited. After about one hour, when the bombing had stopped, they ventured outside. The boys began investigating what turned out to be unexploded ordinance. The subsequent detonation killed the two younger boys instantly and maimed Khaldon-Kh-Thiab.
Khaldon-Kh-Thiab's family has 28 children. Three have been killed in the war. Only eight of them have been able to attend school with their father's subsistence wage of US$5 a month.
Before the war, Khaldon-Kh-Thiab was a happy boy who liked to play football and shoot the breeze. His greatest dream was to become a driver.

The Eden Social Welfare Foundation, one of the major charitable organizations in Taiwan, which has continued to help the poor and needy at home and abroad, decided to sponsor Khaldon-Kh-Thiab's Taiwan trip after receiving a report from the United Nations Children's Fund in July.

According to the UNCF report, at the height of the U.S.-led war against Iraq early this year, one of the major hospitals in Baghdad reported the admission of 100 injured people every hour. During the first month of the war, the hospital was forced to amputate the limbs of more than 100 children who had been injured by bombings or shootings.

The Hashemite Charitable Society for Soldiers with Special Needs in Jordan and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' liaison office in Jordan have been largely instrumental in arranging Khaldon-Kh-Thiab's trip to Taiwan, according to the Eden spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPOSIT INSURERS URGED TO HAVE GOOD RISK MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: Deposit insurance companies should be savvy in risk management to reduce costs and avoid problems, an expert on deposit insurance said Monday.

Jean Pierre Sabourin, chairman of the International Association of Deposit Insurers (IADI) , made the remarks in a symposium on finance risk management and crisis resolution sponsored by Taiwan's Central Deposit Insurance Corp. (CDIC) in Taipei which was also attended by local financial operators and scholars.
Sabourin said that with the changing financial environment, the role and the responsibility of deposit insurers have also changed dramatically.

He said that the deposit insurer should not only passively play the conventional role to compensate, but should actively try to reduce the risk to the minimum to reduce the costs in dealing with ensuing problems and avoid the development of a crisis.
Sabourin initiated the IADI in 2002 and there are currently 49 participants, including the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U. S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.028 to close at NT$33.992.
A total of US$273 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.021 and slid to a low of NT$33.980.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON ENGINEERING TECHNOLOGY OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: More than 60 Japanese and 1,500 Taiwanese engineers are participating in a four-day symposium in Taipei to exchange experience and knowledge in 15 categories of engineering technology, including micro-electronics, nanotechnology and telecommunications.
In a speech delivered at the opening ceremony, Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed the hope that the symposium will help promote technological exchanges between the two countries.
More than 800 Japanese engineers in total have participated in the symposium, which has been held 22 times.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODUCTS EXHIBITED IN ISTANBUL
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Oct. 27 (CNA) (by C. H. Kuo and EH)

TEXT.P: Some 20 Taiwan manufacturers displayed their products Monday in an exhibition in Istanbul, Turkey.

An official of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council said the Taiwan trade promoters exhibited their products in Kazakhstan before coming to Istanbul. They will leave for Moscow and St. Petersburg later this week for trade promotion.
On display were computers and peripherals, medical equipment, auto parts, sports goods, and catalogues of products from more than 600 other Taiwan companies.

He said trade between Taiwan and Turkey increased significantly in recent years. Taiwan exports to Turkey amounted to US$302 million in the first seven months of this year, an increase of 38 percent over the same period of 2002. Taiwan exports to Turkey jumped 83.4 percent last year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST DECREASE RELIANCE ON MAINLAND ECONOMY: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker urged the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Monday to rein in Taiwan's increasing dependence on mainland China for its export growth.

Legislator Christina Y. Liu of the People First Party said Taiwan's exports to the United States, Japan and Europe have continued declining in recent years while its exports to mainland China have risen consistently at a rapid rate.
Quoting MOEA tallies, Liu said Taiwan's exports to the United States, Japan and Europe dropped 3.5 percent, 6.8 percent and 6.9 percent, respectively, in 2002 on a year-on-year basis.
In the first eight months of this year, exports to the United States fell 5 percent from the same period last year, while sales to Japan also declined 3.8 percent.
In contrast, Liu said, Taiwan's exports to mainland China, including sales to Hong Kong, registered a whopping 96 percent growth in 2002 as compared with the year-earlier level.
Thanks to the huge gain in exports to mainland China, Liu said Taiwan managed to register positive growth in its overall exports last year.

"This phenomenon is worrisome because the mainland Chinese economy faces a host of problems and risks, including the exchange rate of the mainland currency, the huge non-performing loans by mainland banks and the uncertainty regarding whether the mainland economy can withstand the opening of its financial market in 2006 as it promised in its World Trade Organization entry protocol, " Liu explained.

Noting that exports have been a key factor to Taiwan's economic growth, Liu said the island's ever-growing reliance on the mainland market will make the Taiwan economy vulnerable to adverse changes in the mainland's economic development.
Liu said the MOEA should work out effective measures to diversify Taiwan's export market and reduce its reliance on the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 42 points to close at 6,000 with 16,969 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December rose 42 points to finish at 5,995, with 64 contract transactions, while March futures gained 29 points to close at 5,983 with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,958 for November, 5,953 for December, 5,954 for March, 5,935 for June, and 5,950 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
November TE futures moved up 2.2 points to close at 259.7, with 3,010 contract transactions, while December TE futures rose 2.3 points to finish at 259.9, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures increased 6.2 points to finish at 882, with 4,337 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 7 points to close at 882, with 9 contracts traded.
March TF futures gained 1.2 points to finish at 881, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE TO DROP BELOW 4% BY 2008: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he is confident that Taiwan's unemployment rate will fall below 4 percent by 2008.
Chen made the remarks during a grass-roots community reach-out tour of Hsinchu County's Hsinfeng township in northern Taiwan.
Surrounded by a large crowd of townsfolk in front of a Taoist temple, Chen said the domestic economy has bottomed out of a recession.
Quoting official tallies, Chen said Taiwan has registered economic growth of 3.59 percent for the past three months as compared with the same period of last year.

"Moreover, the work force at Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- the heartland of Taiwan's high-tech industries -- has rebounded to more than 100,000 from about 80,000 in 2000, and export orders received by local manufacturers amounted to US$15.4 billion in September, while the jobless rate dropped to 5.25 percent for the month," Chen said.

All these figures indicate that the local economy is back on a steady upward streak, Chen said, adding that he is convinced that the nation's unemployment rate will continue falling to below 4 percent by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.41 points to close at 5,958.55.
The bourse opened at 5,946.02 and then fluctuated between 5,976.38 and 5,941.09 during trading.

A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.54 billion (US$1.75 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.36 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$78.92 billion (US$2.32 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.9 percent, followed by construction stocks at 2.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 1 percent, textile issues and electrical shares, both at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.5 percent. percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 451 to 301, with 151 stocks remaining unchanged.

The Washington Post: Wildfires' Toll Spreads in California At Least 13 Dead; Tens of Thousands Forced to Evacuate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 40.41 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving up 40.41 points to close at 5,958.55.
Market turnover amounted to NT$59.54 billion (US$1.75 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CALIFORNIAN MISSION TO VISIT TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (by J. Liu and EH)

TEXT.P: A 20-member mission from the U. S. state of California is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit.
Members of the mission will include law makers, local government officials, and business leaders. They will be led by Jim Brulte, minority leader of the Californian Senate.

They will meet with government and business leaders in Taipei, and also visit the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the National Palace Museum before leaving for Macao and Hong Kong on Nov. 6, according to a news release from the U. S. Commerce Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUMS ARE BASIC RIGHT OF THE PEOPLE: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Referendums are a basic right of the people of the Republic of China in accordance with the nation's Constitution, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Monday.

The KMT has never said that referendums are not workable in Taiwan or that they should not be held in Taiwan, Lien claimed at a press conference held at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his return from an overseas trip.
Lien's trip, which took him to London, Prague and the east and west coasts of the United States, is widely considered as being part of his presidential campaign activities.

Lien, a former ROC vice president, ended a distant third in the hotly-contested 2000 presidential election. He will team up with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year.
Referendums, designed to allow the people to vote on issues of public interest, should be organized by the people, rather than the government, Lien said.
He ridiculed the Democratic Progressive Pary-ruled government's linking of referendums with the 2004 presidential election, asking whether the government's only job is to promote referendums.

Meanwhile, Lien said the "one China" policy that he has been advocating refers to the Republic of China on Taiwan. The "one Republic of China" policy is the fundamental strategic weapon in efforts at seeking peace across the Taiwan Strait and is a policy that is acceptable to all the people in Taiwn, he added.
PFP Chairman James Soong and scores of legislators from the KMT and the PFP, commonly known as the "pan-blue alliance, " joined Lien at the press conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL URGES COST-FACTORS BE INCLUDED IN RESEARCH INTO NEW DRUGS

TEXT.P: A Singapore health economist said over the weekend that local researchers should work out how cost-effective a new drug is in addition to studying its curative powers when they conduct clinical trials.
Phua Kai Hong, an associate professor at National University of Singapore (NUS) , said that if this is not done, Singapore's bid to become a regional medical center may be thwarted.

Phua was speaking to about 220 doctors and pharmacists, including some from Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan, at a symposium on health economics. The two-day symposium was organized by NUS, Tan Tock Seng Hospital and Pfizer Singapore.
"Drug companies are coming to Singapore now because we have a reputation for producing quality drugs that are safe and effective, " Phua said.
"We need to add cost-effectiveness to that list to make us more competitive," he pointed out.
This would entail researchers collecting extra data on such things as the length of a patient's stay in hospital and the loss of productivity from a drugs side effects, he said.

The pharmaceutical industry has in the last few years tried to respond to the demand for this sort of additional information on new drugs, said Dr. Sandeep Duttagupta, director of Pfizer Pharmaceuticals Group's outcomes research unit in New York.

He cited the example of the clinical trials for a new antibiotic in which the expected length of hospital stay for patients using the drug was included in the findings. The new drug was found to reduce hospital stays by three to seven days, meaning reduced costs to both patient and hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 27, or the third day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
2001: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opens at a Auckland, New Zealand hotel with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AND BAHRAIN TO NEGOTIATE FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Bahrain and Singapore have agreed to negotiate a free trade agreement, following a meeting Monday between the leaders of the two states.
Bahrain's Shaikh Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa, who is in Singapore for a three-day official visit, called on President S.R. Nathan at the Istana. He also met with Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong.
Bahrain and Singapore also agreed to re-activate an economic pact signed in 1979.
The services and financial sectors of both states are expected to get a boost, as the two sides will share expertise and experience in these areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO SEND 192 SOLDIERS TO IRAQ

TEXT.P: Singapore will send 192 men and women to Iraq to provide logistics support in rebuilding the country, marking the first time the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) sends troops to Iraq.
Although they will not be involved in combat roles, the soldiers' logistic support missions mean that they will be in the theater of operations in Iraq.
An air force C-130 Hercules transport plane will carry out airlift, transportation and supply missions.

Joining the support team at sea will be a landing ship tank, the "RSS Endurance." The vessel will provide a platform for helicopter, maritime boarding and patrolling missions. Manning the ship will be a crew of 161 sailors, including 15 volunteers and eight women.

"As the situation in Iraq is still in transition and not yet stabilized, there will be some risks to our personnel as they carry out their operational missions, " said Read Adm. Teo Chee Hean, the minister of defense.
Singapore earlier sent a police contingent to help train Iraqi police officers.

DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian greet the people of Panama in a videotape released here Tuesday by the ROC Embassy.
In the tape, Chen thanks Panama for its firm support for his country and pledges to do his best to cement bilateral ties.

Chen, who is scheduled to visit Panama Nov. 2-4 to celebrate the country's centennial, said he is greatly flattered by the invitation to the celebration and vowed to step up Taiwan's cooperation with Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL MIGHT LIFT FREEZE ON NEW INDONESIAN LABORERS

TEXT.P: A freeze on admissions for new Indonesian laborers might be lifted by the end of November if a three-month period of assessment proves that fewer Indonesian workers already in the country have absconded from their jobs, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the introduction of Vietnamese laborers might be halted if their absconding rate has not dropped in the same three-month period, Chen said.
According to statistics compiled by the National Police Administration, a total of 890 foreign workers ran away from their jobs in September, 430 of whom are Vietnamese.
At present, nearly 11,200 foreign laborers remain unaccounted for in Taiwan, including 1,953 Filipinos, 4,000 Indonesians, 1,480 Thais and 3,533 Vietnamese.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES SOLOMON ISLANDS FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received visiting Solomon Islands Minister of Foreign Affairs Laurie Chan Tuesday at the Presidential Office and extended him a warm welcome.

During the meeting, Chen expressed his appreciation for Chan's speech delivered at the United Nations General Assembly earlier this year in which he voiced the desire of the 23 million people of Taiwan to join the world organization.

Chen also thanked the Solomon Islands for the assistance and support it has extended to Taiwan in the international arena. With its assistance, he noted, Taiwan became one of the partners of the South Pacific Forum in 1992 and a member of the Convention on the Conservation and Management of Highly Migratory Fish Stocks in the Western and Central Pacific in 2000.
Chen told his guest that Taiwan and the Solomon Islands have maintained diplomatic relations for 20 years and that he believes bilateral ties will be further strengthened.

In response, Chan conveyed a two-point message from Solomon Islands Prime Minister Allan Kemakesa, affirming that his country will further promote its relations with Taiwan and thanking Taiwan for its assistance.
Chan also revealed that his country and Tuvalu have jointly initiated a proposal to establish an international organization on South Pacific tourism and he invited Taiwan to join the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO WORK ON ANTI-TERRORISM DRAFT BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will discuss an anti-terrorism draft bill Wednesday under which convicted terrorists could face capital punishment.

The draft bill, aimed to underscore the country's determination to wipe out terrorism and to bring itself into line with other civilized nations in terms of cracking down on terrorism, will empower the Executive Yuan to set up an anti-terrorism panel, while the National Security Bureau should coordinate the efforts of different government agencies in collecting information on terrorist organizations and their activities.
Any person convicted of committing a terrorist act will face punishment from ten years imprisonment to death.
After it is drafted by the Executive Yuan, the bill will still have to be approved by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI-BUILT HOUSING TO BE INAUGURATED IN EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: A housing compound built by the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation for earthquake refugees in El Salvador is slated to be inaugurated Oct. 31, a spokesman for the charity group based in eastern Hualien County said Tuesday.
Salvadoran President Francisco Flores and his wife will personally take part in the ceremony and give a speech on the occasion, according to the spokesman.

The Daai (Great Love) Second Village in Chanmico comprises 835 houses capable of accommodating some 4,000 people, the spokesman said, adding that Tzu Chi will also sponsor a charitable medical checkup on the same day to help the refugees.
The building of the Daai First Village in Sacacoyo, in which 340 houses are located, has also been completed recently.

The two residential compounds include schools, clinics, activity centers, children's playgrounds and football pitches, the spokesman said, adding that Tzu Chi will cooperate with local private organizations to help train the residents and find them jobs. As many as 80 percent of the Sacacoyo and Chanmico residents are unemployed.

Two tremors measuring 7.6 and 6.6, respectively, on the Richter scale rocked El Salvador in early 2001, wreaking havoc across the Central American country. More than 1,200 people were killed and 7,000 injured by the two quakes, while 220,000 houses were left in ruins and 1.2 million people were made homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAUSE OF TRANS ASIA CARGO CARRIER CRASH REMAINS UNKNOWN

TEXT.P: Bad weather has not been ruled out as the cause of the crash late last year of a cargo carrier belonging to Trans Asia Airways off the island county of Penghu, a spokesman for the Flight Safety Council under the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

An initial investigation conducted by the council showed no evidence of serious icing or turbulence during the flight of the ATR72 cargo plane from Taipei to Macau in the small hours of Dec. 21 last year, chief investigator Chou Kuang-tsang reported, adding that the probe will now focus on pilot error, weather equipment failure and aircraft maintenance to find out the cause of the accident.

Chou pointed out, however, that a possible fault that could have arisen from air traffic control, flight facilities and telecommunications systems has been temporarily excluded from the list of factors that could have led to the crash.
He forecast that the entire investigation will be complete by the end of 2004.

Although information contained in the plane's cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder indicates that the plane was subjected to serious icing during the flight, Chou noted that none of the weather authorities in Taiwan, Hong Kong or Naha in Okinawa issued warnings of icing over the Taiwan and Penghu area.

According to the rules established by The International Civil Aviation Organization, weather authorities are obliged to issue such a warning to the whole world only when the icing problem is serious. Meteorologists in the Hong Kong and Naha flight information areas found only medium icing on the day in question.

Noting that the council has yet to continue seeking the cause of the accident, Chou reported that ATR42/72 planes registered eight accidents related to icing during the 1994-2002 period. He added that the council has urged aviation companies to emphasize the icing problem to pilots through proper training.
The bodies of the plane's pilot and co-pilot have not been recovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL MEMBERS TO GREET PRESIDENT AT KENNEDY AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: At least two U.S. congressional members will greet President Chen Shui-bian at the John F. Kennedy Airport when he arrives in New York Oct. 31 for a two-day transit stop on his way to Panama for an official visit.
Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative to the United States, said Monday that many U.S. Congress members have welcomed Chen's arrival for a two-day transit stop.
When the president made a transit stop in New York last year, 22 U.S. senators and House members traveled to New York to meet him.
According to his itinerary, he will meet with the New York mayor, the New York City Council speaker and New York State lawmakers after his arrival on Oct. 31.

That evening, Chen will be honored at an annual meeting of the International League for Human Rights (ILHR) in which ILHR Chairman Scott Horton will bestow the 2003 Human Rights Award on Chen in recognition of his outstanding contributions to promoting human rights in Taiwan. Previous recipients of the prestigious award include the Dalai Lama and former South African President Nelson Mandela.
Chen will deliver a 20-minute speech on human rights issues after receiving the award and will host a lunch party Nov. 1 for U.S. Congressmen.
He will leave for Panama Nov. 2 to attend the Central American country's Nov. 3 centennial celebrations.
On his way back to Taipei from Panama, Chen will make a transit stop in Alaska at the invitation of Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski, a staunch supporter of Taiwan.

Chen will exchange views with Murkowski on feasible measures to further boost cooperation between Taiwan and Alaska. He will also take a train ride to view Alaska's magnificent scenery. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Nov. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR MADAME CHIANG TO BE HELD NOV. 5
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A memorial service for the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek, Taiwan's most famous first lady, will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan Nov. 5, her family said Monday.
Taiwan's representative office in New York -- the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office -- is expected to issue a press release on details regarding the memorial service Tuesday.

Chiang's body is being kept at the Franklin E. Campell funeral house and her family is considering choosing a day during this week to open her coffin for public viewing. Meanwhile, her family plans to invite 1,000 people to attend the funeral.

Chiang, the glamorous, U.S.-educated Republic of China first lady who helped her husband -- the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tension, died at her New York home Oct. 24 at the age of 106.

Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun arrived in New York over the weekend to pay his respects to Chiang's memory and described her as one of the most outstanding women of the 20th century. "Her contributions to the ROC can hardly be epitomized by a grand funeral," Hau added.
Many of Chiang's relatives, friends and former aides and proteges have flown to New York to pay their respects and assist in funeral arrangements.
Meanwhile, President Chen Shui-bian will pay his respects to the late ROC first lady when he makes a transit stop in New York at the end of this month on his way to Panama for an official visit.

Chen has instructed that all national flags will be flown at half-mast on the day of Chiang's funeral. Moreover, Chen will issue a posthumous commendation in honor of Chiang for her contributions to the ROC, particularly in the diplomatic field.
When Chen pays his respects, he will present a large ROC national flag to the Chiang family that can be draped upon the coffin at her funeral.
As Chen will leave New York for Panama Nov. 2 to attend the Central American country's Nov. 3 centennial celebrations, he will not attend the memorial service.

The Chiangs were once one of the most famous couples in the world -- a dashing general married to a beautiful, urbane woman. Time magazine publisher Henry Luce named them "Man and Woman of the Year" in 1938.

Madame Chiang led a reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband died in 1975. Born Soong Mei-ling, Chiang became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist the Japanese forces that began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the Republic of China government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING RELEASES TAIWANESE FALUN GONG FOLLOWER

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese Falun Gong follower who was detained by mainland Chinese authorities during a recent visit to Shanghai had been released and has returned home, the Taiwan Falun Dafa Association (TFDA) said Tuesday.
"Lin Hsiao-kai returned to his home in the central county of Changhua Monday evening, " TFDA President Chang Ching-hsi told local reporters.
Chang said Lin was haggard due to grueling questioning by mainland law enforcement officers during his detention in Shanghai.
"Lin will brief the press on his ordeal after he has recovered from his nightmare," Chang said.

Lin left for Shanghai Sept. 30 to do some sightseeing and visit friends. His family in Taiwan lost contact with him Oct. 7 and his wife called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan Oct. 21, pleading for help in rescuing her husband and urging the mainland authorities to release Lin immediately. Her appeal drew concern from lawmakers and local human rights activists.
According to Chang, Lin was not tortured but was subjected to long hours of repeated questioning in an incident that Chang said epitomizes mainland China's attitude toward human rights.

Falun Gong is outlawed by the mainland authorities, who consider it to be a dangerous cult, but it is a legal social or quasi-religious organization in Taiwan, where its adherents number more than 300,000.
Chang said the mainland's inhumane treatment of Lin and many other Falun Gong followers only serves to further alienate the people of Taiwan.
Noting that freedoms of assembly and association are basic human rights, Chang said the mainland's brutal suppression of Falun Gong followers has tarnished its international image.

Meanwhile, Chang and 19 other TFDA members launched an islandwide bicycle journey Tuesday to enlist public support for a campaign to push the mainland authorities to release some 20 mainland-born TFDA members who have been detained during visits to their mainland hometowns.
"It seems to me that the mainland authorities especially like to arrest female mainland-born Falun Gong followers who have married Taiwan men," Chang said.
At least one of them has obtained Taiwan citizenship, but she is still in jail on the mainland because she is a Falun Gong member, Chang said.

In another case, a mainland wife of a Taiwanese Falun Gong follower was arrested in September 1998 when she returned to her parents' home in Jinlin in northeastern China. After serving a two-year prison term, she was released on parole, but the mainland authorities still will not allow her to be reunited with her husband in Taiwan.
The 20 TFDA members will cycle around the island to seek the signatures of local people in support of their campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO STUDY TAKING IN INJURED IRAQI CHILDREN FOR TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that Taiwan will study whether to bring in additional Iraqi children who were injured in the United States-led attacks for advanced medical treatment.

Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung of the opposition Kuomintang proposed in a general interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan that the government let Iraqi children come to Taiwan for medical treatment under the brokerage of international organizations.

Hsu, who himself is disabled, said that in the opening days of the U.S.-led attacks, he suggested that 50 Iraqi children wounded in the bombing come to 10 medical centers in Taiwan, or each medical center accommodating five children.
Hsu said that the Department of Health agreed then, but the Ministry of Foreign Affairs interceded, and the plan was aborted.

The legislator's remarks came at a time when a 12-year-old Iraqi boy who lost his right hand and left foot during the war arrived the previous night under the sponsorship of a private charitable organization dedicated to the care of the handicapped.
Hsu pointed out that Taiwan gave NT$150 million (US$4.41 million) toward war effort, but he wondered what effect the money had had in terms of diplomacy.

Responding to his questions, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said that after the beginning of the Iraq War, the ministry, heeded the advice of legislators and contacted relevant agencies to express the intention of bringing in Iraqi children to Taiwan.

But as Taiwan was fighting its own battle against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) at the time, and a great number of medical institutions had their hands full, the program to help the Iraqi children was put on hold, Chien said.

He said that the NT$150 million (US$4.41 million) aid was not much compared with other countries and that the money was largely spent on food aid, which he said should have been noticed in the international community.
The premier said that he would undertake to study the proposal by Legislator Hsu that Taiwan uses its "imagination and creativity" to try to break through its diplomatic difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION A MATTER OF KEEPING RESPONSIBILITY FOR REFORMS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that winning the presidential election next year is important for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) so that it can continue shouldering the responsibility of implementing reforms, not simply to remain the ruling party of the nation.
President Chen, who concurrently serves as DPP chairman, made the remarks at a regular meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee.

The president pointed to the rally in the southern city of Kaohsiung last Saturday which attracted more than 200,000 people in support of referendum legislation and the formulation of a new constitution as proof of a milestone in Taiwan's democratic movement.
"It is heartwarming and stimulating to see the people come forward to support democratic reforms with actions, " the president said.

For this reason, the president said he wanted to express his gratitude the efforts of the party and the support of the people and vowed to continue to work hard with "humility, solidarity, responsibility and confidence."

He said that the large turnout was an indication that the DPP's "promotion of referendum legislation and the formulation of a new constitution" have won the support and identification of the majority of Taiwan people, a situation that he said will not make the party complacent, but will make it act "with humility. "

"The people of Taiwan have given the DPP a key to democratic reforms, " the president said. "After the door to democracy opened with the transfer of power in 2000, the road ahead was still rough and bumpy, " he said, "but the party has continued to work hard against adversity to reap the fruits of democracy."

He stressed that the grand task of democratic reforms will not be accomplished by one individual or one party alone, but must rely on national solidarity. Chen said he hoped that all 23 million people on the island will support democratic reforms.
He also said that since the inception of his party 17 years ago, the DPP has taken to heart the people's aspirations for democracy and their expectations of reforms.

After the DPP took the helm of the nation in 2000, public expectation was even higher, and the party's responsibility was greater, he said. Whether it is to "fight for the economy" or complete a "major reform" advocated by the DPP, the goal is to fulfill the expectations of the people and make Taiwan and its people better off.

The president stressed that the significance of the presidential election next year will not be to maintain power, but to continue having the responsibility of the nation within its mandate because democracy in Taiwan has to be deepened, and the DPP also has to stay the course with its reforms.
He said that the party has encountered numerous difficulties since becoming the ruling party more than three years ago, but that it has never lost confidence.

The president said the DPP believes in "democracy, in reforms, and in Taiwan," adding that after sweat and tears, the people are now gradually seeing the results of steady progress, whether it be dynamism in the private sector, the government's willingness to carry out reforms or the upgrading of competitiveness of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO SPONSOR SEMINAR ON NATIONAL SECURITY, DEFENSE STRATEGY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will sponsor an international seminar Thursday to discuss the general international situation after the U.S.-led war in Iraq as well as the possible impact of North Korea's nuclear arms development plan.

Maj. Gen. Wang Yang-cheng, director of the Institute of Strategic Studies at National Defense University, said Tuesday that five military strategy scholars and experts from the United States, Japan and Australia have been invited to attend the seminar to offer suggestions on maintaining regional security and stability.

In addition to reviewing the post-Iraqi war world situation and the North Korean issue, Wang said, the seminar will also evaluate the Taiwan Strait situation before and after Taiwan's 2004 presidential election.
Wang said local scholars and National Defense University professors will present academic papers on the three main topics for discussion at the seminar.

The five foreign military strategists will give analytical comments on the papers read at the symposium, Wang said, adding that the conclusions will be used as reference in formulating the nation's defense and military buildup policies.
Wang said the MND has cooperated with National Chenchi University in organizing the seminar with an aim to helping map out strategies to maintain regional stability and peace.

Among the foreign participants are Steve Benson, a research fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies -- a noted U.S. think tank; John Caldwell, a research fellow at the U.S. Marine's research institute -- Center for Emerging Threats and Opportunities; Robert Ayson, an Australian military strategist; and Tomohide Murai, a professor at Japan's Defense University.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS WARN OF SOCIAL FRICTION ARISING FROM MAINLAND WORKERS

TEXT.P: The government must pay greater heed to social friction which might arise from an increasing number of mainland Chinese workers in Taiwan due to worsening unemployment resulting from a structural joblessness in the domestic market, according to some scholars.

Lin Hsiang-kai, a professor of economics at National Taiwan University (NTU), made the call over the weekend at a news conference after Taiwan Advocates, a group dedicated to Taiwan independence, made public the results of a survey which showed that Taiwan people would be concerned about national security if the government allows the opening of direct transportation links with mainland China.

Lin claimed that the government must pay full attention to the costs that the entire society might have to pay should a larger number of mainland Chinese people be allowed to work in Taiwan, because Taiwan is troubled by structural joblessness at present.

According to Lin, only public servants, police and military officers, ranking white-collar executives, hi-tech professionals and students are less affected by the increasing number of mainland Chinese workers in Taiwan.

Lin Wan-i, an NTU professor of social services, said elderly unskilled workers with low educational backgrounds, are the most threatened group in the face of the continued entry of workers from mainland China.

There are estimated to be more than 50,000 mainland Chinese workers in Taiwan currently, including fishermen working aboard Taiwan fishing boats, spouses and relatives of Taiwan residents and illegal stowaways, he added, noting that a vast majority of them are employed in high-risk and labor-intensive sectors.

He called on the government to weigh the issue rationally and thoroughly on the grounds that an influx of mainland Chinese workers into the domestic job market has fueled public resentment against the mainland.
The telephone survey carried out by the Focus Survey Research Corporation from Oct. 21-22 polled 1,062 Taiwan residents aged over 20.

Just over 57 percent of the respondents said that opening direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait will undermine Taiwan's national security, ahead of 49.6 percent who believe it will be helpful to Taiwan's economic development. About 65 percent thought that the mainland is hostile toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMPLOYEES OF TAICHUNG BUS CO. TO PROTEST IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Union members of the Taichung Bus Co. will stage a demonstration Wednesday in Taipei over a salary dispute.

Huang Ho-chung, a leader of the union, said the demonstrators will go to Taipei by bus in the early morning. While in Taipei, they will stage a protest at the headquarters of the major opposition Kuomintang first, and then go to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) of the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to petition.
At night, they will camp in the plaza in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei together with employees of the Taoyuan Bus Co., he added.
Officials of the CLA are trying to defuse the labor dispute, informed sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS ROLL SUSHI TO BOOST RICE CONSUMPTION AND HELP FARMERS

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) took part in a sushi making and eating contest in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to encourage rice consumption and help local farmers make a living.

KMT Legislator Cho Po-yuan invited chefs from a local Japanese-style food store chain to offer tips on preparing sushi with locally grown fine-quality rice. Many KMT and PFP lawmakers then began competing making and eating sushi.

Cho said although Taiwan is currently in its second rice harvest of the year, most local farmer are heartbroken to see that the price of rice has dropped to a 20-year low of NT$10 per kilogram, far lower than the minimum price of NT$15.22 eligible to receive government emergency relief subsidies.
"With the price of rice at such a low level, local farmers are having a hard time making a living. They lose at least NT$2,000 for planting one-tenth of a hectare of rice," Cho noted.

He said locally grown "koshi hikari" rice -- a rice strain originating from Japan, which is usually used for sushi production -- can match its Japanese counterpart in terms of quality, while its price is far cheaper.

Rice paddies in Ilan County's Wuchieh township, Changhua County and Taitung County all produce fine-quality "koshi hikari" rice. "Top-grade locally grown 'koshi hikari' rice is sold for only NT$40 per kilogram, far lower than that for imported Japanese rice, " Cho said.
He urged local people to eat an additional half bowl of rice per meal to help local farmers tide over their difficulties resulting from increasing foreign competition and overproduction.
Cho said the government should also raise financial subsidies for farmers who have been forced to leave their rice paddies fallow to avoid overproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON SARS OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international symposium on influenza and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) opened Tuesday night and will include three days of seminars starting Wednesday.

The symposium is being sponsored by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), which will also conduct drills on transporting SARS patients from the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu to Taiwan proper for treatment.
Su Yi-jen, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said that participants in the symposium will discuss possible transmission channels from animals to human beings.

This will be the second time that the DOH has sponsored an international SARS symposium since April 20. Epidemiologists and virus experts from the United States, Canada, Germany, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and Vietnam are taking part in the symposium and more than 100 papers will be read.
The DOH had originally wanted to invite Zhong Nanshan, who is known to be the father of SARS research in mainland China, to visit Taiwan, but he was unable to come due to other engagements.

Researchers say they suspect about 10 percent of the workers in meat markets in the southeastern province of Guangdong had come into contact with the virus that causes SARS but were not infected, leading researchers to speculate that there was some sort of immunity in those individuals
Researchers are keen to understand why these people did not develop full-blown symptoms of SARS.
Taiwan scientists are also interested in the nature of the SARS virus that is found in such animals as civets, fowl and snakes, and whether it has made the jump to humans.

Taiwan was hard hit by the pneumonia-like disease between March and June this year. Official statistics in Taiwan included 84 as dying from SARS, but the World Health Organization's revised total for the island is 37. The losses in the tourism and aviation sectors are hard to estimate.
Taiwan hopes to be well prepared for any resurgence of the atypical pneumonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES ENTER INTO AGREEMENT WITH UNC

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Normal University, National Physical Education University, and seven other universities and colleges in Taiwan separately signed an agreement with the University of Northern Colorado (UNC) on Monday to enhance their cooperation and academic exchanges.

The other seven universities and colleges that signed the agreement Monday are National Changhua Normal University, Taichung Teachers College, Taipei Teachers College, Hualien Teachers College, Taipei Physical Education College, Hsinchu Teachers College, and Taipei Municipal College of Physical Education.
Under the five-year agreement, the Taiwan universities and colleges will also exchange students with UNC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST SERVICE SECTOR MEMBERS FLUNK IN TELEPHONE SERVICE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: About nine-tenths of the members of Taiwan's five major service sectors receive failing grades for their telephone information services, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

Only about one-tenth of the operators of tourist hotels, department stores, discount supermarket chain-stores, convenience stores or franchise restaurants were found to have provided useful and satisfactory front-line telephone information service, according to the survey conducted by Global Views Monthly.

The Global View Monthly pollsters made 1,216 phone calls under the guise of ordinary customers to 58 tourist hotels, department stores, discount chain-stores, convenience stores and franchise restaurants between Oct. 3-10, finding that only one-tenth of the telephone information service personnel rated a 60 or above on a scale of 100 in telephone courtesy, professional knowledge and empathy.
The survey found that about 70 percent of the telephone service personnel phoned could not provide a clear introduction or explanation regarding their establishment's products or services.
A high of 80 percent of the operators displayed poor performance in the category of empathy -- or the ability to effectively handle questions raised by critical or rude callers, the survey found.
The Shin-Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store topped all operators in the five major service sectors with the best telephone information services.

By sector, Wellcome topped all supermarket chain-stores in regard to telephone information service, the Landis Taipei Hotel (previously the Ritz Taipei) ranked No. 1 among all tourist hotels in Taiwan, TGI Fridays led all franchise restaurants and 7-Eleven topped all convenience stores, the survey found.
The pollsters obtained 608 valid responses out of the 1,216 calls made. The poll is said to have a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ COMPANIES HOPE TO HIRE MORE FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: A number of companies in Taiwan's export processing zones (EPZs) have voiced their desire to hire more foreign workers to work at their manufacturing plants, a source from the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) Kaohsiung Office said Tuesday.

The executives of these EPZ companies said hiring foreign workers will not have an adverse impact on job opportunities for Taiwan's domestic workers as the foreign workforce is generally "complementary" to its Taiwan counterpart, as opposed to being an "alternative" aimed only at replacing local workers.

Among the industries in the EPZ, the plastics, garment and apparel manufacturing, and footwear manufacturing industries are more traditional sectors that require a greater number of manual laborers, including those from overseas, an EPZA official said.

The number of workers in Taiwan's EPZs, including the Kaohsiung EPZ, the Nantz EPZ and the Taichung EPZ, is currently between 60,000 and 70,000. Foreign nationals make up only about 10 percent of this workforce, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAILWAY UNION TO DECIDE ON LUNAR NEW YEAR STRIKE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Workers' Union is expected to make a final decision Wednesday whether to strike during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holidays.
A spokesman for the union said Tuesday that the union preliminarily decided on Sept. 11 to strike during the lunar new year.

He said the strike is the workers' last resort to make their opposition to the privatization of the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) known to the government. "We are not militant, but we are not afraid of fighting," the spokesman said.
TRA Administrator Huang Der-chih said Tuesday that the government understands the position of TRA employees.
He said he believes that the TRA will not be privatized, but it has to be market-oriented. The interests of the employees will be well taken care of, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 116.9 points to close at 6,075.45.
The bourse opened at 5,997.3 and then fluctuated between 6,087.32 and 5,994.87 during trading.

A total of 5.18 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.42 billion (US$3.37 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.84 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$59.54 billion (US$1.75 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 3.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2 percent, electrical stocks at 1.7 percent, textile issues at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues and cement stocks, both at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 521 to 246, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.
