DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO SPONSOR INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR IN MEMORY OF MADAME CHIANG

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday that it plans to hold an international seminar in late March or early April next year to commemorate the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek.

Madame Chiang, the glamorous, U.S.-educated Republic of China first lady who helped her husband -- the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tension, died in her New York home Oct. 24 at the age of 106.
According to the KMT's plan, the seminar will be held after the next presidential election scheduled for March 20, 2004.

The theme of the seminar will focus on the Chiangs' roles in China's modernization, a KMT spokesman said. Chinese affairs experts and scholars from home and abroad will be invited to present academic papers for discussion at the planned symposium.

The Chiangs were once one of the most famous couples in the world -- a dashing general married to a beautiful, urbane woman. Time magazine publisher Henry Luce named them the "Man and Woman of the Year" in 1938.
"The seminar will review the couple's different roles in China's modernization," the KMT spokesman said.

Chiang headed the KMT for decades until he died on April 5, 1975. The spokesman said the period between late March and early April is suitable for the holding of the planned seminar as Madame Chiang's birth anniversary and the late president's death anniversary fall in this period.
The spokesman said the KMT's party history and cultural affairs departments will flesh out details regarding the planned seminar, including the meeting agenda and the list of scholars to be invited.

Madame Chiang led a reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband's death. Born Soong Mei-ling, Chiang became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist the Japanese forces that began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the Republic of China government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.
The KMT's women's affairs department will organize a memorial service Friday in remembrance of Madame Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIMED IRAQI BOY IN TAIWAN TO RECEIVE MEDICAL TREATMENT

TEXT.P: A 12-year-old Iraqi boy who was maimed during the U.S. bombing of Iraq arrived in Taipei late Monday to receive medical treatment that may include being fitted with a prosthetic foot and hand.

Khaldon kh-Thiab, better known in his local community as Aldon, lost his right hand and left foot as a result of a cluster bomb explosion in the front courtyard of his family's home in April this year, according to a spokesman for the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which has sponsored the Iraqi boy's trip to Taiwan.
Aldon was accompanied by his father to Taiwan. The youngster was by no means camera shy when he was met by well-wishers and flashing cameras upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
The boy, who has moved around with the aid of a crutch over the past six months, smiled from ear to ear when he was offered a wheelchair donated by a private enterprise in Taiwan.
Aldon's father expressed appreciation for the warmth of the Taiwan people shown toward him and his son, saying "thank you" in mandarin Chinese.
Aldon is scheduled to stay in Taiwan for two months to undergo examinations and treatment, mainly at the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, the Eden spokesman said.
Doctors at the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital are expected to treat the boy's injuries before deciding on what kind of prosthesis to provide for the boy.

According to the Eden foundation, Khaldon kh-Thiab was playing with two of his younger brothers in the courtyard of their house when U.S. bombers swept across the skies of Fallujah, which is located about 50 kilometers from Baghdad, one day in April.

The boys fled into their house when the bombing started. They waited inside for about one hour until the bombing stopped and then ventured outside again. The boys began investigating an object that looked like a cluster of balls that had landed in the courtyard. It turned out to be unexploded ordnance. The subsequent detonation killed the two younger boys instantly and maimed Aldon.

Khaldon kh-Thiab's family has 28 children from three mothers. Three of the children have been killed in the war, and only eight of them have been able to attend school on their father's subsistence wage equivalent to US$5 a month.
Before the war, Aldon was a happy boy who liked to play football and shoot the breeze. His greatest dream was to become a driver.

The Eden Social Welfare Foundation, one of the major charitable organizations in Taiwan, which has continued to help the poor and needy at home and abroad, decided to sponsor Khaldon-Kh-Thiab's Taiwan trip after receiving a report from the U.N. Children's Fund in July.

According to the UNICEF report, at the height of the U.S.-led war against Iraq early this year, one of the major hospitals in Baghdad reported admitting an average of about 100 injured people every hour. During the first month of the war, the hospital was forced to amputate the limbs of more than 100 children who had been injured by bombings or shootings.

The Hashemite Charitable Society for Soldiers with Special Needs in Jordan and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' liaison office in Jordan have been largely instrumental in arranging Khaldon kh-Thiab's trip to Taiwan, according to the Eden spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 28, or the fourth day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, RUSSIA CONCLUDE THIRD WTO BILATERAL CONSULTATION MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 28(CNA) (By Neil Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Russia on Tuesday concluded their third bilateral consultation meeting related to Russia's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), with Taiwan gaining many concessions from the former communist country.

It has been learned that the bilateral consultations between the two countries are close to the final stage and that Moscow has already accepted most of Taiwan's requests on issues regarding tariff cuts and service market access for most sectors, including the computer service, publishing and printing service, audio-visual, and air cargo service sectors.
Although the two countries have not reached a final agreement, much progress was made during the third meeting, sources close to the bilateral consultations said.

In the meeting, the Russian side also committed to opening up its service market in the areas of telecommunications, financial items, tourism, law services, education, taxation administration and construction.

However, Taiwan expressed concerns about Russia's agricultural products market access regime, particularly the "tariff quota" regime that regulates meat imports. The island also expressed the hope that Moscow could further open its market for certain Taiwan steel products.

In response, Russia promised that it will only apply the "tariff quota" regime for agricultural products for a period of six years and that it will review the regime after five years, adding that its agricultural market will definitely be opened further.
Meanwhile, Taiwan requested that Russia join the "Information Technology Agreement" and also join the "Government Procurement Agreement" as an observer.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Russia for 2002 amounted to US$1.18 billion, with Taiwan experiencing a bilateral trade deficit of US$670 million.
The island's major export items to Russia are computers, electronic products, machinery, textiles, plastic products and automobile parts.

Taiwan attaches great importance to its bilateral negotiations with Russia and hopes to obtain better access to the Russian market for its products and services, including information, telecommunications and financial services.

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu encouraged small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) Wednesday to focus on innovation.
Addressing the 2003 National Business Start-Up Award ceremony, Lu said that Taiwan's SMEs have made great contributions to the national development.
Along with increasing globalization and the development of the knowledge-base economy, she noted, SMEs should attach more importance to the acquisition of technology as well as to innovation.

Lu said that she hoped that Taiwan enterprises will make use of the advantages they have in the knowledge-based economy, such as their creativity and technological ability, to cope with the impact brought by globalization.

The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Cojuangco solons challenge SC order to keep status quo.
The impeachment issue worsened into what lawmakers termed a constitutional crisis Tuesday, after the Supreme Court (SC) "called" on Congress to "maintain the status quo"--that is, to refrain from transmitting the articles of impeachment against Chief Justice Hilario Davide Jr. to the Senate for trial.
The Philippine Star: SC stops impeachment.
The Supreme Court issued yesterday a status quo order that effectively stopped Congress from continuing with the impeachment proceedings against Chief Justice Hilario Davide Jr. until petitions assailing its constitutionality are resolved.
The Manila Times: SC blocks impeach trial.
The Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered the House of Representatives and the Senate to maintain a status quo on the second impeachment complaint filed against Chief Justice Hilario Davide Jr. until the Court resolves all the six pending petitions seeking to declare the complaint unconstitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREED TAIWANESE FALUN GONG PRACTITIONER RECOUNTS ORDEAL IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioner who had been detained in Shanghai for 20 days before being allowed to return home a day earlier said Wednesday that mainland China's "white terror" threatens the security of innocent Taiwan people.

Lin Hsiao-kai, a member of the Taiwan Falun Dafa Association (TFDA), said at a news conference that he left for Shanghai Sept. 30 to do some sightseeing and visit friends. But he was arrested by mainland Chinese security authorities Oct. 7 for unknown reasons and was not released until Oct. 27.

On the first day of the detention, Lin recalled that he was subjected to round-the-clock interrogations. "In the following days, mainland security officers continued to interrogate me for seven to eight hours a day."
Lin said they wanted information about Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioners and the TFDA's activities.

"Mainland Chinese investigators warned me that they would hunt me down in Taiwan if I revealed what was discussed during the interrogations," Lin claimed, adding that his interrogators told him that they would definitely be able to find him.

Lin said he was shocked to find that his mainland interrogators knew almost everything about his life and work in Taiwan. They had information about his wife, friends and even had an e-mail address he had canceled, he added.

Falun Gong has been outlawed by mainland authorities, who consider it to be a dangerous cult, but it is a legal social or quasi-religious organization in Taiwan, where its followers number more than 300,000.

Lin's wife called a news conference last week to call for help to push mainland authorities to release her husband as soon as possible. Her appeal drew concern from lawmakers and human rights activists.

Lin said he was lucky to be able to return home safely. Nevertheless, Lin said he had been traumatized by the 20-day detention in Shanghai. "It was a nightmare and has left me with mental scars," he added.

According to Lin, some 20 mainland China-born TFDA members have been arrested by mainland authorities during visits to their mainland hometowns. Most of them are wives of Taiwan citizens, Lin said, adding that the ROC government should take active steps to urge mainland China to stop persecute them.

Meanwhile, 20 TFDA members began an islandwide bicycle journey Wednesday to enhance public awareness of mainland China's suppression of Falun Gong practitioners and to enlist public support for a campaign to push Beijing authorities to release all detained TFDA members.
TFDA President Chang Ching-hsi said it seems to him that the mainland authorities especially like to arrest female mainland-born Falun Gong followers who have married Taiwan men.
At least one of them has obtained Taiwan citizenship, but she is still in jail on the mainland because she is a Falun Gong member, Chang said.

In another case, a mainland wife of a Taiwanese Falun Gong follower was arrested in September 1998 when she returned to her parents' home in Jinlin in northeastern China. After serving a two-year prison term, she was released on parole, but the mainland authorities still will not allow her to be reunited with her husband in Taiwan.
The 20 TFDA members will cycle around the island to seek the signatures of local people in support of their campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE EPZS DRAW BILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN INVESTMENTS IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Fueled by a steady economic upturn, six investment applications worth NT$1.568 billion (US$46.12 million) have been approved for nationwide economic processing zones (EPZs), a government official said Wednesday.

According to an official at the Economic Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the administration held a meeting earlier the same day in which the six investment projects raised in October by private businesses at islandwide EPZs were given the green light.

The investment projects will be launched in principle at EPZs in the counties of Taichung and Kaohsiung, he noted, adding that corporate investors are mainly from the domestic hi-tech sectors, such as optical and automation, stainless steel, biotechnology and LCD display modules industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUGUST BUSINESS TURNOVER GROWS FOR THIRD STRAIGHT MONTH: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's business turnover in August totaled NT$758.5 billion (US$22.3 billion), the third month of growth in a row, a spokesman for the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

The official attributed the expansion to rebounding private-sector consumption and forecast that the trend will steadily continue into the fourth quarter. He pointed out, however, that a more noticeable increase will emerge only when unemployment has been properly addressed.
The August figure represents a 5.85 percent rise over the year-earlier level, according to the official.

The retail sector contributed NT$228.5 billion in business volume in August, up by 5.28 percentage points year-on-year. The growth was mainly a result of the good sales of home appliances, jewelry, cosmetics and cleaning products.
The wholesale sector generated NT$505.1 billion in August business turnover, a 5.85 percent rise from a year ago, thanks to machinery equipment, automobile and accessories sales.
The food and beverage businesses chalked up a business volume worth NT$25 billion, up by 11.34 percentage points from the previous-year level, according to the official.

The International Heralb Tribune: Bush is steadfast on his Iraq policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO PAY RESPECTS TO MADAME CHIANG IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will pay his respects to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek after his arrival in New York Oct. 31 for a two-day transit stop on his way to Panama for an official visit, the Presidential Office announced Wednesday.
Chen, heading a 100-member entourage, will leave Taipei Friday via a chartered China Airline plane. This will be Chen's fourth overseas tour since assuming office in May 2000.

A Presidential Office spokesman said Chen will go to the Franklin E. Campell funeral house to pay homage to Madame Chiang, the Republic of China's most famous first lady, immediately after his arrival in New York.

Madame Chiang, who had helped her husband -- the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tensions, died at her Manhattan home Oct. 24 at the age of 106.
In the evening of that day, Chen will be honored with the International League for Human Rights' (ILHR's) 2003 Human Rights Award on Oct. 31, 2003, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City.
The event, to be hosted by the non-profit organization, will be chaired by William S. Cohen, chairman of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, and Thomas Rabaut, president and CEO of United Defense.

The ILHR Human Rights Award is being presented to President Chen in recognition of his life-long dedication to the international human rights movement. Moreover, Chen has been chosen for the honor due to the key role he has played in Taiwan's democratization. Chen will deliver a 20-minute speech on human rights issues after accepting the award.
During his stay in New York, Chen will meet with U.S. politicians, including congressional members, the New York City mayor, the New York City Council speaker and New York State lawmakers.
On Nov. 1, Chen will visit 911 Ground Zero and attend a dinner aboard a yacht on the Hudson River to be given in his honor by major Taiwanese associations in the greater New York area.

Chen will leave for Panama Nov. 2 to attend the Central American country's Nov. 3 centennial celebrations. While there, Chen will also exchange notes with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso on a free trade agreement signed by the two leaders in Taipei Aug. 21. He will also hold talks with Moscoso on ways to further boost bilateral ties.
On his way back to Taipei from Panama, Chen will make a transit stop in Alaska at the invitation of Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski, a staunch supporter of Taiwan.

Chen will exchange views with Murkowski on feasible measures to promote cooperation between Taiwan and Alaska. He will also take a train ride to view Alaska's magnificent scenery. He is scheduled to return to Taipei Nov. 6.

Members of Chen's entourage will include National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, leaders of the nation's five largest commerce and industry associations, lawmakers of various political parties and many other senior officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ANNOUNCES TIMETABLE FOR NOMINATING PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Wednesday its timetable for nominating the party's candidate for the presidential election set for March 20 next year.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said that the registration for the party primaries will take place Nov. 3-7, with the drawing of numbers for candidates slated for Nov. 15 and the primary polling day slated for Nov. 29.
The DPP Central Executive Committee will hold a meeting Dec. 10 in Taipei in which the party's presidential candidate will be formally nominated, Lee went on.
The DPP national congress will ratify the nominations of the presidential candidate and his running mate in a meeting slated for Dec. 13, Lee continued.
The DPP presidential candidate's campaign offices around the nation, including the campaign headquarters, are expected to be established by the end of this year, he predicted.
The candidate registration fee is NT$7 million (US$206,500) , including NT$1 million for conducting public opinion polls, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, SOUTH KOREAN PROVINCE SIGN TOURISM EXCHANGE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: As part of its efforts to promote Taipei tourism and share tourism resources with foreign cities, Taipei City signed a tourism exchange agreement Wednesday with the South Korean province of Chung Cheong Bukdo.
Jason Tse-ying Lin, commissioner of the city's Bureau of Transportation, signed the agreement with Kwak Yeon-Chang, chief of the Cultural and Tourism Bureau of Chung Cheong Bukdo.
Lin noted that Taipei is promoting tourism and can learn from Chung Cheong Bukdo, which has displayed its numerous advantages through tourism.
Kwak for his part said that Taipei, as the capital of Taiwan, enjoys its status as a metropolis, while its efforts to promote tourism are also recognized internationally.
Under the terms of Wednesday's agreement, both sides will send tourism groups for mutual exchange visits, help each other promote tourism and investment, and share experience in promoting tourism.

Chung Cheong Bukdo, located in central Korea, is one of the nine provinces of South Korea. Covering 7,432 square kilometers, it boasts both coastal and mountain areas. It is famous for its tourist attractions and rich culture.
At present, there are chartered flights to Chung Cheong Budko from both Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED CONSCRIPTION, VOLUNTEER MILITARY SYSTEM TO BE ADOPTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan will adopt a combined conscription and volunteer military service system at some point in the future.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with 105 "model" retired military servicemen. The outstanding veterans will be honored Friday in connection with the celebration of Veterans Day, which falls on Oct. 31.
Chen said his administration plans to upgrade the current Veterans Affairs Commission to the level of a ministry, allowing it to offer better services and welfare benefits for retired servicemen.

Moreover, he went on, the conscription-only military service system for enlisted men will be transformed into a combined conscription and volunteer service system that will better meet the changing combat demands.
"With the advances in defense technology and weaponry systems, we need more well-trained career soldiers who are willing to serve for longer than the period of time served by conscripts," Chen said.

Taiwan began to accept volunteer enlistees this year on an experimental basis. Chen said the ratio of volunteers will be raised in accordance with the government's financial status and progress in the military's restructuring plan.
Under the existing regulations, Chen said, local male citizens can be drafted for mandatory military service when they turn 18 years old, even though they don't get voting rights until they are 20.

"These provisions are unreasonable, " Chen said. "With the prevalence of compulsory education and the upgrading of the knowledge level of local citizens, the age of suffrage should be lowered to 18. This is a general world trend. Nearly all advanced democratic countries, including Britain, Germany, France, Switzerland, Holland and the United States have lowered their age of suffrage to 18," Chen noted.

He added that this is partly the reason behind his administration's decision to push for the formulation of a new constitution that better fits Taiwan's present reality and facilitate its political, social and economic reforms to upgrade overall national competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN COMPLETES ANTI-TERRORISM DRAFT LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday an anti-terrorism draft bill, paving the way for the formation of a Cabinet-level panel in charge of the fight against terrorism and giving clear legal guidelines for punishments for those convicted of terrorist acts.

Under the terms of the draft bill, anyone convicted of engaging in terrorist activities could face the death sentence, life imprisonment or a jail term of at least 10 years. Those who are convicted of having taken part in terrorist organizations could be sentenced to a minimum five-year jail term or punished with a fine of up to NT$100 million (about US$2.95 million).

The purpose of the draft bill is to set up a government agency especially designed to handle such issues and to coordinate cooperation and information exchanges among the relevant authorities, both at home and abroad.

Once the ad hoc group under the Executive Yuan has been set up, the National Security Bureau will be required to report to it as and when necessary about any individual or organization suspected of involvement in terrorist acts.

The draft bill also demands that operators of telecommunications systems be equipped with recording facilities that can allow them to track information and crack down on cross-boarder crimes on the Internet.

Police authorities will be given the power to take suspects into custody without charge for no more than 24 hours, while the Coast Guard Administration, the Investigation Bureau and the National Police Administration will be authorized to freeze or sequester property and real-estate holdings allegedly used by suspects in terrorist activities.
The bill will have to be approved by the Legislative Yuan before it can be promulgated.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT SHOULD PURSUE PARALLEL DEVELOPMENT: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday that his party believes the most important thing at present is for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to pursue parallel development.

Lien made the remarks when he received a delegation from the European Parliament -- the legislative branch of the European Union -- led by Gerard Collins, vice chairman of the Taiwan Friendship Group in the European Parliament, which arrived in Taipei Monday on a goodwill visit.

Lien said that he believes national leaders have to "deal with urgent matters with urgency" and added that for the KMT, the most compelling task at present is to improve the welfare of the people, which he claimed is different to the ideas of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Lien said that he made clear during his recent visit to London, Prague and the United States his personal belief that the KMT and Taiwan people have little interest in the issue of Taiwan independence or unification with mainland China.
The KMT believes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should promote parallel development and that there is no need to worry about unification or independence issues, he added.

Lien also said that he will lead a KMT delegation to New York to attend the funeral of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, the former Republic of China first lady who passed away last Thursday in her New York apartment at the age of 106.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN PASSES DRAFT REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed a draft referendum law Wednesday despite opposition from Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who speculated that it might undermine the checks-and-balances mechanism between the executive and legislative branches.

The Executive Yuan passed the draft law in a floor meeting in the wake of criticism by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) that the issue of referendum was promoted to the public extremely heavily before the Executive Yuan even had a draft law to present to the Legislative Yuan, a contradiction to normal practice in which the draft law is presented before promotion to the public takes place.
The draft referendum law will immediately send to the Legislative Yuan for review.

According to Premier Yu Shyi-kun, the version truly upholds the democratic values of referendum, which he said aims to protect the basic human right of citizens to take part in politics, so that the people can be the true masters of the nation.

The draft referendum law "sets no restrictions on the issues to be put to referendum, provides multilateral channels to initiate referendum, sets a reasonably appropriate threshold for the number of signatures collected and sets no unnecessary restrictions on the timing of referendum, " the premier said, adding that it will "uphold the democratic values" of referendum and conform with the spirit of the Constitution.
The premier expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will start rational debate and consultation so as to complete the legislation in the shortest possible time.
Ma, a member of the KMT, spoke twice to raise questions about the draft law.
He noted that the Executive Yuan sent a draft initiative and referendum law to the Legislative Yuan in April 2002, but withdrew it in October the same year.
Ma said that he had three questions concerning what he claimed was the hastily worked out draft referendum law.

He said the first article of the draft law does not list the legal basis of the law according to the Constitution. In addition, the Constitution stipulates that the initiative and referendum rights should be stipulated by law. The draft law also has to be defined by law, but it does not include such wording, he said.
Ma said that the draft law allows the people to collect signatures to initiate a referendum, while the government can also conduct referendums on policy issues, which he said could create problems.

He said that if a bill sent by the Executive Yuan fails to clear the Legislative Yuan, the Executive Yuan can resort the issue to a referendum, which will affect the checks-and-balances mechanism between the legislative and executive branches.

The mayor noted that Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien said in the floor meeting that governments in Europe can initiate referendums, but he noted that their rights are stipulated in their constitutions.
Ma said that if the government has the right to initiate a referendum, then it must be stipulated in the Constitution and not just in the form of a law.

Ma also said that Minister Without Portfolio Chen Chi-nan said in the floor meeting that various villages and townships islandwide are already conducting "referendums, " but the Cabinet's version of the draft referendum law contains no related regulations and addresses only regulations governing referendums in municipalities, counties and cities.

This means that administrative units below the district level in Taipei cannot initiate referendums, while the smaller villages and townships can, Ma pointed out, adding that this is a question to which the Ministry of the Interior has failed to respond.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP unveiled its version of a draft referendum law last week that rules out the possibility of the government initiating referendums and excludes issues concerning the national flag, the nation's name and national territory from being put to a referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE RESTART ALL-OUT SEARCH FOR FUGITIVE FORMER SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The law enforcement authorities restarted an all-out search Wednesday in an attempt to track down the fugitive former speaker of the Kaohsiung city council, who has been missing since fleeing in mid-October to avoid serving a jail term.
The renewed search was called for following a Beijing official's claim earlier the same day that Chu An-hsiung is not hiding in mainland China.
Zhang Mingqing, a spokesman for Beijing's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, rebutted rumors at a regular press conference that Chu is in hiding on the mainland.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration has been in contact with the mainland authorities to verify reports that Chu is in Zhuhai City, in the southern mainland province of Guangdong.
The Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office issued an all-points bulletin for Chu Oct. 20 after he failed to turn himself in that day in accordance with an arrest warrant issued Oct. 17.

Chu, who should by now have started serving a 22-month jail term for vote-buying in the election for city councilman in Kaohsiung late last year, failed to report to court to begin serving his term, prompting the Kaohsiung prosecutors to issue the APB. Chu has also been charged with involvement in vote-buying for election for city council speakership.
His wife, former legislator Wu Teh-mei, said Oct. 23 that she was "put at ease" after receiving a "reliable" call the previous night informing her that her husband was on the mainland.

Wu held a press conference last week in which she claimed that the government was imposing what she called "green terror" on Chu by dealing with his criminal activities "selectively" for political purposes.
Wu also claimed at the press conference that she has not been in touch with her husband and does not know his whereabouts.
Chu's whereabouts remained unknown as of noon Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA WARY OF AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY EXODUS DUE TO EASED RULES

TEXT.P: In reaction to changes made to a key law regulating exchanges between the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Council of Agriculture (COA) has proposed banning domestic agricultural personnel from working with key Taiwan technology at institutional agencies in mainland China.

In a report submitted to the economic and energy committee under the Legislative Yuan following the amendments to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, the COA proposed a set of measures to curb the negative impact of the opening up of the domestic agricultural sector, including a ban on the export of key agricultural technology to the mainland.

The COA suggested prohibiting Taiwan professionals with key technology and sensitive knowledge from taking any posts at mainland-based institutions in order to secure Taiwan's agricultural progress and competitiveness.

Regarding visits by mainland agricultural professionals to Taiwan, the COA has also put responding measures in place to rule out such visits in sensitive fields in an effort to ward off a leak of critical information, an official said.

At the same time, the COA is in favor of maintaining the existing controls on agricultural and farm imports from the mainland by publishing items permitted for import in a gradual manner and by banning mainland-bound Taiwan investment in areas in which Taiwan still enjoys the upper hand, the official added.

In addition, he pointed out that Taiwan's customs, quarantine and immigration scrutiny must be stepped up to wipe out smuggling and the spread of infections from the mainland should direct transport links be set up between the two sides, especially in view of the fact that the mainland remains an epidemic area for many animal and plant diseases.

One of the revisions to the statute approved in early October by the legislature allows the establishment of direct cross-strait transport, while issues related to the opening of professional exchanges will also have a profound impact on Taiwan's agriculture, the official said.
Direct cross-strait transport services will effectively shorten the travel time for agricultural and farm products between the two sides and could worsen Taiwan's unemployment, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF OFFENSES INVOLVING FOREIGNERS ON RISE

TEXT.P: The number of offenses involving foreigners has been rising steadily in Taipei, city government officials said Wednesday.
According to Taipei city government tallies, the annual number of offenses involving foreign nationals increased from 693 cases in 2000 to 899 in 2002.
In the first nine months of this year, a total of 779 offenses involving foreigners were reported, up 24,64 percent from the same period of last year.

As of the end of September, Taipei had 71,608 foreign expatriates, marking an 11.72 percent decrease from the number recorded at the end of last year. Among them, 77 percent had residence status and the remaining 23 percent were visitors. Altogether, foreign expatriates accounted for 2.73 percent of Taipei's total population.

Meanwhile, the city government said it had discovered 1,236 foreign nationals who had either illegally taken jobs in Taipei or had overstayed their visas between January and September. During the same nine-month period, 1,264 foreigners were repatriated or ordered to leave Taiwan within a specified period of time because they had illegally taken jobs or overstayed their visas.

A total of US$437 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.011 and dipped to a low of NT$33.932.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MONGOLIA TIES IMPROVING: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and Mongolia have become increasingly close, with bilateral exchanges growing remarkably in recent years, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Chen said that since 1991 -- when Taiwan first began promoting civic relations with Mongolia, bilateral ties between the two sides have grown by leaps and bounds, particularly since 1997, when Taipei City and the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator established sisterhood ties.

In addition to facilitating the knotting of sisterhood ties, Chen noted that he, as mayor of Taipei at that time, also traveled to Mongolia in 1999 to further cement bilateral exchanges. Chen made the remarks during an audience with a group of Mongolian officials and civic leaders who have been in Taipei for a one-month training workshop.

The frequent bilateral exchanges have also been evidenced by the establishment of a Taiwan trade center by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) -- Taiwan's major foreign trade promotion arm -- the setting up of a Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Ulan Bator by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 2002, and the ensuing founding of the Mongolian Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei this year, Chen said.
Chen told his Mongolian guests that he was much impressed with the warmth with which the Mongolian people greeted him, as well as their vigor and enthusiasm.

The president offered his greetings to the 26 Mongolian officials -- most of them incumbent deputy governors from various provinces around Mongolia -- who have just completed a one-month civil servant and public-office manager training program sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.
Chen exhorted them to continue to play important and crucial roles in the efforts to further strengthen ties between Taiwan and Mongolia after they return to their country.

Members of the Mongolian official group, led by Sodnom Batmunkh, a senior consultant to the Mongolian national legislature -- known as the State Great Khural -- paid a courtesy call on Chen at the Presidential Office, accompanied by Hsu Chih-hsiung, Chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stocks futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 30 points to close at 6,160 with 28,008 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December rose 43 points to finish at 6,155, with 128 contract transactions, while March futures gained 15 points to close at 6,150, with 9 contracts traded.
June futures increased 88 points to finish at 6,195, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange-listed reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,130 for November, 6,112 for December, 6,135 for March, 6,107 for June, and 6,122 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
November TE futures moved up 2 points to close at 265.8, with 6,069 contract transactions, while December TE futures rose 2 points to finish at 265.5, with 52 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures increased 0.6 points to finish at 911.8, with 11,587 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 1.4 points to close at 910, with 186 contracts traded.
March TF futures lost 4.6 points to finish at 910.6, with 8 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 20.42 points to close at 6,095.87.
The bourse opened at 6,173.85 and then fluctuated between 6,173.85 and 6,080.4 during trading.

A total of 5.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.64 billion (US$3.38 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 5.18 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$114.42 billion (US$3.37 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent. Textile issues remained unchanged.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.6 percent, foodstuff shares and bank and insurance stocks, both at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 479 to 278, with 152 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON REPORTS ABOUT MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILE TEST-FIRING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to make any comments Wednesday on media reports that the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) has test-fired a newly developed medium-range surface-to-surface missile.

According to the media reports, the CIST -- the military's research arm -- conducted the first-ever test-firing of its newly developed ballistic missile with a range of 600 kilometers to 900 kilometers at the maximum-guarded Chiupeng military base in the southernmost county of Pingtung Sept. 25.
The reports said the CIST-developed missile is capable of hitting targets in Hong Kong, Shanghai and other major southeastern mainland coastal cities.

In response to press inquiries about the reports, the MND said it is the military's established policy to refrain from making any comments or giving any briefings on the nation's weaponry development and procurement.
The MND further said the CIST's defense technology development plan is based on the nation's ultimate military buildup goal of establishing an elite deterrent force to safeguard national security.
While the military is stepping up combat preparedness in the face of mainland China's mounting missile threat, the MND said, Taiwan will never provoke a war in the Taiwan Strait.
The MND said the CIST's research and development projects are mainly aimed at satisfying the armed forces' combat demands and at beefing up the nation's overall defense capabilities.

After failing to invite the turbaned wives of the ruling party AK party deputies to the Republic Day reception at the Presidential Palace, President Sezer decides not to invite the turbaned wives of two members of the Constitutional Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: L.H. CHOU TO SAY MASS AT REQUIEM SERVICE FOR LATE MADAME CHIANG
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Pastor Chou Lien-hua said Tuesday that he will give a requiem service for the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek to be held at a church in Manhattan Nov. 5.

Madame Chiang, who had led a peaceful, reclusive life in New York for much of her later life after her husband, the late Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek -- died in 1975, passed away in her sleep at her Manhattan residence Oct. 23 at the age of 106.

The Nov. 5 service will be conducted in Chinese and English, with some 1,000 people expected to attend, said Chou, who was the "court minister" for the Chiang family for 40 years until about a decade ago.

Chou, who was the minister of the Kai-ke Church in the Chiang residence complex in Taipei between 1954 and 1994, is the chairman of World Vision Taiwan and co-founder of Taiwan's Eden Social Welfare Foundation.

Chiang Fang Chih-yi, granddaughter-in-law of Madame Chiang, said Tuesday that after discussions over the preceding several days, members of the Chiang family decided that Madame Chiang's body should be placed temporarily in a mausoleum in New York until she could be buried with her husband -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
Born Soong Mayling, Madame Chiang became widely known in the West, using her Western-education background to lobby for China during its fight against the Japanese in the 1940s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the ROC government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his U.S.-educated wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.
Madame Chiang is also remembered for her dedication to women's rights and charity work throughout her life.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO RECEIVE ILHR HUMAN RIGHTS AWARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will be honored with the International League for Human Rights' (ILHR's) 2003 Human Rights Award on Oct. 31, 2003, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City, the event's organizer announced Tuesday.
The event, to be hosted by the non-profit organization, will be chaired by William S. Cohen, chairman of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, and Thomas Rabaut, president and CEO of United Defense.
The evening will also include a special video tribute by former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.

The ILHR Human Rights Award is being presented to President Chen in recognition of his life-long dedication to the international human rights movement. Moreover, Chen has been chosen for the honor due to the key role he has played in Taiwan's democratization.
Previous ILHR Human Rights Award recipients include Nelson Mandela, Kim Dae-jung, Elie Wiesel, Andrei Sakharov, Mario Soares, Roger Baldwin, George Mitchell, Sadako Ogata and Mary Robinson.

For over 60 years, the International League for Human Rights has helped keep human rights at the forefront of international affairs. The league's special mission is defending individual human rights advocates who have risked their lives to promote the ideals of a just and civil society.

Patrons of the International League for Human Rights have been welcomed to attend the presentation of its 2003 Human Rights Award to President Chen. Patrons can attend the award ceremony and a dinner reception. Media have also been invited to cover the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 29, or the fifth day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA SWINGS TO BLACK WITH US$174 M. PROFIT IN Q2

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) returned to profit in the September quarter after the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) forced the airline into its first-ever loss in the previous three months.
SIA suffered an unprecedented first-quarter net loss of S$312 million as SARS hammered travel demand.
Revenue in the second quarter fell to S$2.5 billion from S$2.7 billion in the previous year, but was sharply higher than the S$1.65 billion in the first quarter.
SIA reported a net profit of S$306 million (US$174 million) for its second quarter, citing a rebound in traffic and cost cuts.
But for the first half, SIA lost S$6.5 million from a S$773.5 million profit on the year.

The SARS outbreak dealt a heavy blow to Asian carriers such as Cathay Pacific Airways and SIA, forcing them to suspend flights, trim costs and to offer heavily discounted air fares to entice people to travel.
SIA cut wages, slashed capacity by a third, and axed nearly 600 staff - the largest lay-offs in its 56-year history.
But along with other Asian carriers, it is seeing travel demand return and has restored flights back to pre-SARS levels.
Separately, two listed SIA units also reported second quarter earnings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LEGISLATURE TO BEGIN BUDGET-APPROVAL PROCESS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Thursday to begin working on the government's general budget plan "for the best interest of the nation."

Yu said he has done his best to explain the process the Executive Yuan went through in preparing the budget and that it would be unfair to accuse him of trying to postpone its passage by rejecting the legislature's request for the Exeutive Yuan to "correct errors" in the budget.

He expressed regret that the budget plan has become bogged down in partisan bickering in the Legislative Yuan two months after it was submitted and with the November deadline for its passage only one month away.

The Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan have locked horns on the budget, with the legislature claiming parts of the budget was not drawn up according to the law and refusing to review it until the Executive Yuan corrects what it claims are "errors." However, the Executive Yuan has denied any abnormalities and has refused to amend it.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY REBUTS U.S. NEWSPAPER COMMENTARY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) rebutted Thursday a commentary in a major U.S. daily and stressed the armed forces' determination to defend Taiwan and the long way the ministry has come in converting itself into a civilian-led organization.

In a written response to criticism carried by the Washington Post, the ministry said there is no question whatsoever about the armed forces' determination to protect the country in the face of increasing military threat from mainland China.

Noting that Beijing has never renounced the threat of force against Taiwan and is targeting the island with some 500 missiles, a number that is increasing at a rate of 75 per year, the ministry said the armed forces have never relaxed their guard against any possible invasion by mainland forces.

Citing a survey conducted by the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies in 2002, the ministry said 75.1 percent of the people interviewed in that survey said they were willing to fight for Taiwan should the country be attacked by the People's Republic of China.
Furthermore, the ministry quoted President Chen Shui-bian as saying that its is completely wrong to think that "we do not have to protect the nation as the United States will come to our rescue."

Based on the general public's strong willingness to protect their country, the government has not dragged its feet in raising funds to procure weapons, as some critics have claimed, the ministry said.

The MND has aggressively prepared budgets for weapons and equipment approved for sale by the United States to Taiwan in 2001, such as Kidd-class destroyers and new amphibious vehicles that were budgeted for fiscal 2003, as well as long-range early warning radar budgeted for 2004, while PAC-3 missile systems and new submarines are listed in a special budget.
As a democracy, the ministry's statement went on, the procurement of military weapons and equipment is subject to the supervision of the legislature.
The ministry also said it has quickened its pace of reorganizing the military to establish an elite and modern force, including putting the ministry itself under the charge of a civilian leader.

As of Oct. 1, 143 civilian officials had been recruited, about 70 percent of the required quota of 204 in the preliminary stage. In fact, the ministry claimed it has done within a few years what it has taken the United States several decades to do after the passage of the 1989 Goldwater-Nichols Act, which mandated similar reforms of the U.S. Department of Defense.
The Washington Post questioned Taiwan's resolve to protect itself, in the signed commentary titled "U.S. Hits Obstacles in Helping Taiwan Guard against Mainland China."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 26 points to close at 6,134, with 26,275 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December lost 21 points to close at 6,134, with 126 contracts traded, while futures for June lost 52 points to close at 6,135, with one contract transaction. September futures slid two points to finish at 6,150, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,160 for November, 6,155 for December, 6,163 for March, 6,187 for June and 6,152 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also closed lower.
November TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 264.5, with 3,971 contracts changing hands, while December TE futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 265.9 points, with 12 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures lost 3.6 points to finish at 908.2, with 7,955 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 2.6 points to finish at 907.4, with 102 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SEMICONDUCTOR FIRM REVEALS PLAN TO OPEN R&D CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Eyeing Taiwan's abundant hi-tech manpower and its market deployment abilities, the United States-based National Semiconductor Corp. (NSC) has decided to set up a research and development (R&D) center in Taiwan, an NSC executive said Thursday.

Hsiao Wen-hsiung, NSC Taiwan general manager, told CNA that the NSC headquarters have been working on the plan for six months and will officially make the announcement after relevant arrangements and preparations have been completed.

According to Hsiao, Taiwan's strength in information technology, its rich resources in hi-tech manpower and its market exploration abilities are the major reasons behind his company's decision to establish a research hub here. He said that the NSC has already sent foreign engineers to Taiwan, who are now stationed in northern Hsinchu City -- a stronghold of Taiwan's hi-tech industries.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., the world's largest chip maker, is also a prime contractor for the NSC. Its clients based in Taiwan include prominent companies such as BenQ and Compal.
The NSC's Taiwan hub plan will bring to 14 the number of foreign-based world-class companies to set up here, such as Microsoft, Intel, HP, IBM, Sony and Phoenix.

The company, based in California, designs, manufactures and markets high performance semiconductors for multiple and market uses. It develops analog chips for wireless handsets, displays, information appliances and information infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEF RANKS TAIWAN FIFTH IN TERMS OF COMPETITIVENESS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked the fifth most competitive economy in the world in the latest Global Competitiveness Report released here by the World Economic Forum (WEF) Thursday.
In the forum's 2003-2004 report, Finland topped the list as the most competitive state in the world, replacing the United States, which moved down one spot to second place.
Following close behind them in descending order were Sweden, Denmark, Taiwan, Singapore, Switzerland, Iceland and Norway.
European states feature prominently on the list, accounting for six out of the top ten.

Finland took the top spot because of its marvelous performance in all economic fields. The United States' competitiveness was blunted by a regression in its overall economic situation and infrastructure, despite its dominance in science and technology.
Taiwan leads the Asian states on the list, with Singapore taking sixth place, Japan in 11th place and South Korea in 18th place.
Taiwan's high ranking comes mainly from its highly developed hi-tech industry, while Singapore owes its competitiveness to its overall favorable economic environment and healthy government system.

Mainland China, which has seen its economy grow rapidly in recent years, moves down from 22nd place last year to 44th this year, mainly because of its deteriorating administrative system and government corruption.
The World Economic Forum has been authoring the global competitiveness report since 1979. The latest report rates the competitiveness of 102 countries, compared to 80 countries rated last year.
Taiwan's relatively high placement on the list gives the government, which is struggling to boost the country's economy, a much-needed shot in the arm.

Lin Chia-lung, a spokesman for the country's Executive Yuan, said in Taipei that the government shares the credit for the ranking, adding that it proves the government's economy-promotion measures have gradually taken effect and that the general public should have confidence in the government's policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The International Herald Tribune: Fallout in Russia over tycoon's arrest. Putin aide reportedly quits in protest.
President Vladimir Putin's powerful chief of staff was reported on Wednesday to have resigned in protest over the arrest of the country's richest businessman, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, even as the investigation into his company widened on other fronts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD OFFICIAL WARNS OF INVESTMENT RISKS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Although mainland China now is the focal point of investors from across the world, Taiwan businesses should try to reduce their investment risks there by shifting operations to other locations, a government official said Thursday.

Chiu Hsiu-chin, a section chief at the Economic Research Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks after the World Economic Forum (WEF) issued its Global Competitiveness Report 2003-2004, in which the rating of the mainland's competitiveness was shown to have dropped to 44th in the world from 33rd last year.
The WEF made the change citing such reasons as corruption and inferior infrastructure in mainland China.
Taiwan ranked at the world's 5th spot but was the most competitive country in Asia, according to the same survey. Taiwan also enjoyed an upper hand in all major categories against the mainland.

Claiming that the mainland has emerged as a world economic power in the wake of the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis and its entry into the World Trade Organization in 2000, Chiu said international enterprises, including those from Europe, Japan and the United States have been cashing in on the mainland market.

However, Chiu pointed out that Taiwan businesses' trade reliance on the mainland market is the world's third-highest, trailing only Hong Kong and Singapore. She acknowledged that the 33 percent ratio will not decrease in the short term because of Taiwan's cultural, language and geographic links with mainland China.

She urged Taiwan businesses to cautiously weigh the possible high investment risks in mainland China given the fact that many uncertainties remain there as a result of the lack of rule of law and order.

Stressing that the government's "go south" policy is aimed at encouraging Taiwan businessmen to invest in Southeast Asian nations against such a backdrop, she said the government has been sparing no efforts to improve the domestic investment climate and upgrade Taiwan's industrial levels to convince local businesses to keep their roots at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF OF SINGAPOREANS AGED 40-59 HAVE NO RETIREMENT PLANS

TEXT.P: Singaporeans have been told they cannot depend on their Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings for retirement, according to a survey.
Still, about half of those aged 40 to 59 have not started building their nest egg.
Analysts said it could become a societal problem as only one in three, aged 40 to 59, say they have enough funds for retirement.
In addition, 60 percent of them said they do not have home insurance and more than half said they do not have medical insurance.
These were the findings from a random survey of more than 1,000 individuals conducted by Ngee Ann Polytechnic in March.
The survey found four out of 10 such Singaporeans going on holiday trips at least once a year.
And traveling is what most want to do, once they retire.
But while they are in Singapore, many prefer to stay home, with shopping their next most preferred activity.
And while they are health conscious, most do not exercise but do watch their diet.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERANS COMMISSION TO TIGHTEN CROSS-STRAIT MARRIAGE SCREENING

TEXT.P: The Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) said Thursday that it will tighten its screening of applications by retired servicemen to have their mainland Chinese spouses or relatives come to Taiwan to live with them.
VAC Chairman Teng Chu-lin made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

During the meeting, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Huang Chien-ting expressed concern about reports that three elderly retired servicemen were given suspended jail sentences for trying to pass themselves off as the grandfathers of three mainland Chinese men who entered Taiwan and then disappeared.

In response, Teng expressed regret over the incident. As a matter of fact, he went on, the VAC has consistently made strenuous efforts to improve welfare services for retired servicemen, particularly elderly ones.

Teng acknowledged that veterans account for 10 percent of the ROC citizens who have married mainland women. He said the VAC has ordered its veteran service centers around the island to strengthen the services they offer to elderly retired servicemen with mainland-born wives.
"We'll assist them in overcoming difficulties in their married lives and prevent them from being tricked into committing crimes, " Teng said.

Moreover, he added, the VAC will cooperate with the Bureau of Immigration and the Mainland Affairs Council to verify marriages between veterans and mainland women to prevent mainland people from entering Taiwan through bogus marriages.
The VAC will also exercise prudence in checking applications by veterans to have their mainland next of kin to come to Taiwan to visit or live, he added.

According to judicial sources, a mainland man known as Xie Xiaoxing, who came to Taiwan a few years ago through marriage with a local woman, offered money to entice the three veterans into saying that they were the three mainland men's maternal grandfathers.
The three mainland men then applied to come to Taiwan to visit their "grandfathers." The trio went missing shortly after their arrival in Taiwan.

Prosecutors indicted Xie and the three veterans, identified as Wang Ping-chuan, Wang Chi and Wang Chung-chu, on charges of document forgery and the Taipei District Court sentenced Xie to one year and 10 months in prison.

Meanwhile, Wang Ping-chuan was given a six-month jail term with a four-year suspension. The two other veterans were each given a four-month jail term with a two-year suspension. The jail terms can be converted into fines.
The court ruled that the defendants' actions threatened Taiwan's security and public order by creating a way for mainland people to enter Taiwan illegally.
The penalties were designed to be harsh, but the court said that because all the defendants repented, they were treated leniently.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CHAIRMAN TOURS TAINAN TO INSPECT AQUACULTURE

TEXT.P: The head of the Council of Agriculture (COA) traveled to Tainan in southern Taiwan Thursday to inspect aquaculture farms and their management.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung's trip is part of the COA's efforts to boost consumers' confidence regarding the safety of fishery products after a recent incident where the European Union rejected 30 tons of Taiwan fishery products exported between August and October because they allegedly contained higher-than-allowed chemical residues such as chloramphemicol and furazolidone, which are used in the treatment of infections caused by bacteria.

Lee, accompanied by Hu Shin-hwa, director of the COA's Fisheries Administration and Legislator Tang Pi-er of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, went to the Chungteh Market first to speak with fishmongers.
Lee was happy to hear that sales had not been affected by the recent incident.
Lee then tasted a bowl of milkfish soup, a famous delicacy in Tainan, at the market, hoping to assuage any possible misgivings of consumers.

Lee then went to an aquaculture farm to learn about the cultivation and management of milkfish, and whether operators had used prohibited drugs in raising the fish. He said that he was satisfied with what he saw during his inspection.

Lee said that the COA will step up its inspection of fishery products. He added that to ensure the safety of fishery products and protect the rights of aquaculture operators, the government will help them conduct tests before transporting their products to market.

Taiwan will adhere to EU standards in inspecting the chemical residues in aquaculture products. In the past the maximum chloramphemicol and furazolidone residue was set at 0.3 parts per billion. In the future, the island will comply with the EU's standard of no more than 0.1 part per billion, a COA official said recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRPORT AT SOUTHERN TIP OF TAIWAN TO BE INAUGURATED IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: An official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday that Wuliting Airport at Hengchun in the southern tip of Taiwan will be inaugurated in January.
He said that construction of the airport will be completed by the end of November, and that Mandarin Airlines, TransAsia Airways and UNI Airways have already moved into the new airport.
The CAA official made the remarks when he visited Pingtung Magistrate Su Chia-chuan, who said the Second Southern Taiwan Highway, which goes through Hengchun, will also be inaugurated in January.
The new airport, highway, and city bus lines will jointly make travel to Kenting and other tourist attractions in southern Taiwan much more convenient than before, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO COMMON DRUGS CAN STEM REPLICATION OF SARS VIRUS: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Two well-established drugs -- promazine and niclosamide -- can effectively keep the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) pathogen from replicating, the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) under the Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday.

Chao Yu-sheng, an NHRI biotechnology division chief, said at an international seminar on prevention and control of SARS outbreaks being held in Taipei that the two drugs can kill all SARS viruses in one day outside the human body in laboratory experiments.
Promazine is a common drug used to treat depression, while niclosamide is an anti-parasite drug whose patent rights have already expired, Chao said.
The new NHRI findings are encouraging, Chao said, adding that both of the two drugs are very cheap.
Chao said the NHRI has filed an application with the U.S. patent office for using these two drugs to treat SARS patients.
Su Yi-jen, director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said it needs clinical tests on humans to determine the effectiveness of the two drugs in treating SARS.
But Su said the two drugs can at first be used to treat critically ill SARS patients.
NHRI researchers said the timing for using these two drugs may need further discussion with clinicians. Use of the two drugs to treat SARS patients will need the DOH's approval.
The SARS pathogen is thought to be the coronavirus.
NHRI researchers tested 700 existing drugs on coronaviruses collected from pigs, which are closely similar to the coronaviruses found in humans.
The researchers discovered only 40 of the drugs had a response. After further screening and testing, they finally found that promazine and niclosamide can stem the replication of the SARS virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT LAW PASSES FIRST READING FOR UNDERCOVER INVESTIGATIONS

TEXT.P: The Judicial Committee of the Legislative Yuan on Thursday passed a draft law to provide a legal basis for investigation by undercover law enforcement agents.

Under the draft law, if undercover policemen, in order to obtain the trust of alleged criminals, carry or transport firearms or prohibited drugs with the prior approval of the State Public Prosecutor General, they will later be absolved of any crimes.

The draft undercover personnel law passed the first reading amid a recent controversy surrounding a policemen who is facing charges for using drugs taken from a suspect and, instead of turning them in, giving them over to an informant as payment for information.

The draft law states that undercover work can only be used when the nature of the situation endangers national security or is a major disturbance of social order, and when there is no alternative method of collecting evidence. The potential crime must also carry a minimum five-year prison term.
However, the criminal activities of undercover police must not kill others or violate the major interests of the nation, according to the draft law.

To protect the safety of the undercover policemen, those who divulge the identities of those involved in such work will be subject to prison terms between one and seven years, and if such a revelation leads to the death of an undercover policeman, the person will be subject to a prison term of between three years and 10 years.

Some legislators also suggested that military servicemen be included in the draft law to help fully probe scandals in the military, but since the National Defense Ministry was adamant that military servicemen would not be appropriate to serve in undercover tasks, the committee decided to keep that issue for later consultations in the second reading of the draft law.
