DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND INDUSTRIAL PROFESSIONALS BASED OVERSEAS MAY ENTER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: To cope with Taiwan's strong need for industrial development, the government has eased rules on the entry of mainland Chinese professionals based overseas to allow them to contribute on a short-term basis in Taiwan.

According to a spokesman for the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior issued revisions Oct. 23 to facilitate the entry of mainland Chinese industrial personnel living overseas into Taiwan, where they are allowed to conduct academic research or take part in industrial development seminars.

Under the terms of the regulations, industrial personnel from mainland China with masters degrees or above who are engaged in long-term scientific research or academic studies in a third country or area with a permanent residence permit are qualified to be invited by Taiwan businesses to conduct activities focusing on industrial research and promotion, the official said.

Those who are allowed to enter Taiwan to serve that purpose will be able to stay in Taiwan for two months each time, while the total residence time will be no longer than four months a year, he added.

Starting from now, both private and state-run enterprises based in Taiwan with a capital or annual business turnover of more than NT$10 million (about US$295,000) as well as domestic industrial groups and associations with an academic research and development unit having operated over one year are allowed to file applications with the Bureau of Immigration under the Interior Ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ISSUES SURVEY REPORT ON BURGLARY AND THEFT PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Policy Committee Thursday issued a survey report, saying that 88 percent of the people surveyed said the problem of burglary and theft in Taiwan is serious.

The report also said that, according to the public opinion poll conducted recently, 72 percent of those surveyed were dissatisfied with police performance in catching thieves and burglars. Seventy-seven percent of the people polled believed that the increase of theft and burglary cases and the current economic doldrums are related.
The survey also found that 83 percent of the people surveyed feared that their properties may be burglarized or stolen.
The KMT Central Policy Committee is conducting a series of surveys on social problems. The problem of burglary and theft is one of those problems.
Meanwhile, Chen Chi-mai, a leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Caucus at the Legislative Yuan, Thursday dismissed the KMT report as "a faked survey."
Chen said at a press conference that "I have gotten tired of reading it." He said the KMT survey is not worthy of any comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices were up on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.26 points to close at 6,108.13.
The bourse opened at 6,110.26 and then fluctuated between 6,119.06 and 6,066.62 during trading.
A total of 4.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.95 billion (US$2.67 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares with 1.6 percent, pulp and paper shares with 0.9 percent, cement stocks with 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares with 0.3 percent.
The prices of electrical shares remained unchanged, while the prices of banking and insurance shares and construction stocks declined 0.6 percent and 0.1 percent respectively.
Gainers outnumbered losers 398 to 334, with 178 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES PRESIDENT OF UNIVERSITY OF NORTHERN COLORADO

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday praised the University of Northern Colorado for turning out talented individuals, including those from Taiwan.
The president made the remarks when he received Kay Norton, president of the University of Northern Colorado, her husband and other school officials at the Presidential Office.

The president noted that the school was inaugurated in 1889 and changed its name to Colorado State College of Education from State Normal School in 1935. It eventually became a university in 1970. The school currently has around 11,000 students, 50 of whom are from Taiwan.
Over the past 20 years, at least 500 Taiwan students have gone to the university for advanced studies, the president said.

In addition, at least 50 professors from the University of Northern Colorado have come to Taiwan to do research or teach since 1983, the president said. The school established sisterhood relations with National Taiwan Normal University and cooperates academically with at least 15 colleges and universities, which the president said has helped upgrade Taiwan's academic level.

The president said that the hope of the nation lies in its talented people, and that although Taiwan has seen some financial difficulties over the past three years, its budgets for culture and education have continued to grow at 3 percent annually, adding that " investment in the future and the next generation is important."
For her part, Norton promised to continue exchanges and cooperation with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SHUI-BIAN TO PAY RESPECTS TO LATE MADAME CHIANG
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang, Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will pay tribute to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek as soon as he arrives in New York on Oct. 31 for a two-day transit stop on his way to Panama for an official visit, the Republic of China's highest liaison official in New York said Wednesday.

Andrew Hsia, director of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said President Chen will travel to the Madame Chiang's apartment in New York to pay respects upon his arrival and express his condolences to the family.
After paying respects, the president will then travel to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City where he will be staying, Hsia said.
Madame Chiang, the widow of late President Chiang Kai-shek, died late last Thursday in her New York home at the age of 106.

The life of the Western-educated former first lady was inextricably linked with the history of modern China and Taiwan. She was most credited with her contribution to winning support from the United States for the Chinese fighting against the Japanese invasion during the 1940s through her lobbying tour in the U.S., as well as her efforts in upgrading the rights of women and her contribution to charity works.

Madame Chiang's family decided to let the public pay tribute to the late former first lady for eight hours starting Wednesday noon. Her coffin is currently in the Franklin E. Campell funeral home in New York City.
ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen first paid tribute on behalf of President Chen, then Director Hsia led New York officials to bow before the picture of Chiang.
Representatives from various overseas Chinese groups in the U.S. as well as the ROC nationals also lined up to pay tribute.
Attendees, including orphans who had studied in schools inaugurated by Madame Chiang after their parents died during the war-ravaged years in China, paid tribute and some were in tears.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 30, or the sixth day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS NOT TO BOW TO BEIJING IN MESSAGE TO OVERSEAS CHINESE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) is an independent state and has the determination to decide its own future, facts that will never change because of any pressure from Beijing, ROC Premier Yu Shyi-kun wrote in a message read to a group of overseas Chinese leaders in Texas.

In his written message to the world conference of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace, which opened in Houston Friday and will run for three days, the premier said Beijing's peremptory approach toward Taiwan is unacceptable to both the people of Taiwan and overseas Chinese, and is the root cause for the tension between the mainland and Taiwan.

The ROC has always tried to develop ties with Beijing pragmatically but the People's Republic of China has never acknowledged the ROC's statehood. Beijing has gone out of its way to shut the ROC out of the international community by short circuiting Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, and by using arm-twisting tactics on other countries to try to persuade them to boycott the new ROC passport which bears the word "Taiwan." These actions betray Beijing's arbitrariness, Yu said in his message.
No matter what pressure Beijing uses against it, the ROC will not be deterred from pursuing democracy, freedom and from claiming that it is a state with sovereignty, yu said.

He urged overseas Chinese to affirm the ROC's achievements in developing its democracy and economy, and appealed to them to support the ROC's efforts to defend the wellbeing and interests of Taiwan's 23 million people and its attempts to break the diplomatic blockades imposed by Beijing.
Calling overseas Chinese a valuable political asset of his country, Yu urged them to work hand in hand with Taiwan to help freedom and democracy take root. (Bu Y. Y. Chen and Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGLIGENCE BY CONTRACTORS AND MILITARY IN AIRPLANE ACCIDENT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Preliminary investigations into a crash of a civilian plane at the Tainan Airport in March point to the culpability of military authorities and the contractor hired to repair parts of the runway, the Aviation Safety Council announced Friday.
The airport is used by both the military and civilian airlines.

The council found that proper measures were not taken to ensure the safety of aircraft landing at the facility, which resulted in a TransAsia Airways plane crashing into construction equipment on the landing strip.
Three construction workers were injured in the mishap, but no one on the plane was hurt.
A final report on the incident will be released on or before June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC TO EASE REGULATIONS ON RECRUITING MAINLAND HI-TECH TALENTS

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) will continue to ease regulations on recruiting people talented in high-technology from mainland China at the appropriate time, an NSC official said Friday.

Speaking at a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait cultural and education exchanges by the private sector, Liu Jin-lung, director of the NSC Central Processing Department, said that the council will uphold the government's "active opening, effective management" policy in handling cross-strait technological exchanges.

The NSC has adopted a series of measures for facilitating personnel from the mainland who are trained in high-technology to visit Taiwan or to conduct research on the island, including increasing the number of technology experts from the mainland to be employed by the private sector, lowering the qualification for their residence in Taiwan, extending the period of residence for technology experts needed by Taiwan to six years and simplifying the process for screening applications for recruiting technology experts from the mainland, Liu noted.
What the NSC is trying to do in the cross-strait exchanges is to create a "win-win" situation for the two sides of the Strait, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON SARS RESURGENCE CONCLUDES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2003 International Conference on Influenza and the Resurgence of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) concluded Friday in Taipei after four days of discussions.

The conference, organized by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, attracted more than 500 government officials, epidemiologists, academics and experts from 15 countries, including the United States, Canada, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, Vietnam and host Taiwan.

The discussions were centered on SARS epidemiology, modeling and transmission; virology, laboratory diagnosis and animal reservoirs; clinical diagnosis and management of SARS; hospital and community SARS infection and control; immunology and immune-response; drug and vaccine development; lower respiratory tract infection by atypical pathogens; and influenza infection in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chou Chih-hau, deputy director-general of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said after the closure of the four-day meeting that participants at the conference reached a consensus to establish a cooperation framework for combating newly detected epidemic diseases.

In the case of SARS, Chou said that the participants agreed to establish an Internet exchange platform through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention of the United States and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to share experiences in diagnosis, treatment, prevention and control.
Taiwan is willing to exchange information and experiences in combating epidemic diseases with other countries around the world, Chou said, affirming that Taiwan will not be alone in this regard.
The development of new test kits on SARS with sensitivity and specificity is a common goal for all countries, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC BIOTECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY BOTTLENECKED DESPITE RECENT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan's biotechnology industry has made considerable progress in recent years, it still faces various key bottlenecks in sustainable development, an industry source said Friday.

Lin Lung-tsan, project planning manager at the Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, pointed to the small scale of the domestic industry and a lack of adequate information about the latest trends in the world market as the reasons.

Despite the fact that the output value of the domestic biotechnology industry grew by 15 percent to NT$113.25 billion (US$3.33 billion) in 2002, it accounted for only 0.5 percent of global production value, Lin said.

During the period from 1997 to Feb. 2002, a total of 108 biotechnology companies were opened in Taiwan in a broad range of areas, from medical and agriculture industries to health foods and environmental protection sectors.

According to Lin, government authorities pumped NT$37.5 billion into life science-related research during the 2000-2002 period, and the figure is expected to increase by 27.9 percent to NT$48 billion for the period from 2003 to 2005.

However, he said that Taiwan's small enterprises and limited resources for collecting capital and recruiting manpower has made it difficult for the domestic industry to gain a bigger slice of the huge international market. For instance, the United States spent more than US$1 trillion in medical care treatment in 2001, he noted.

In addition to the medical and health care fields, he said that biotechnology can be applied in a wide range of sectors, including agriculture, food, environmental protection, energy and chemicals to manufacture a great variety of products.
As the life cycle of life science-related goods is longer, the more the production technology and facilities can be applied, the cheaper the costs will become, he explained.

In the face of Taiwan's limited capital resources and small-sized businesses, he suggested companies, from downstream to upstream, set up comprehensive joint ventures among them to counter foreign competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE BACKS DOWN IN STANDOFF WITH EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan backed down in a standoff with the Executive Yuan Friday by reluctantly assigning the government's overall budget plan to various committees for review.

However, the legislature in the same breath resolved to ask the country's supreme watchdog, the Control Yuan, to look into what it called the "failure of duty" by Liu San-chih, chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and Lin Chia-lung, spokesman for the Executive Yuan.

Liu was referred to the Control Yuan for investigation because he is budget chief of the Executive Yuan, while Lin was referred because he criticized the Legislative Yuan on the premier's behalf and, therefore, became a lightening rod in the quarrel.

The budget plan proposed by the Executive Yuan in August was dismissed by opposition lawmakers as "not consistent with the law" in many places. They voted to ask the Executive Yuan to take it back and revise it before Oct. 20.
The request was rejected by Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who said the budget was prepared according to the law and normal practice.

In a news conference Thursday night, the premier tried to bring the public opinion to bear on the legislature, urging opposition lawmakers to subordinate their partisan bickering to the interests of the nation and do their part dutifully under the law.
As the law requires the legislature to finishing the review of the budget by the end of November, opposition lawmakers were forced to eat crow Friday and began the budget-review process.

This latest twist has only drawn more fire from the Executive Yuan with its spokesman saying at a news conference that the legislative Yuan is contradicting itself by calling the budget illegal in the first place only to began reviewing it later.
Lin took in stride the legislature's resolution to refer him and Liu to the Control Yuan, saying it is a politically motivated move and the legislature has abused its power in making it.
He said the Executive Yuan anticipates and is prepared for more partisan quarrels at the Legislative Yuan in the run-up to the presidential election in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR HAINAN TO ATTEND ECONOMIC FORUM

Siew said the focus of the Boao forum will be discussion on the promotion of development and economic cooperation in Asia, and will not touch on cross-Taiwan Strait economic issues or issues concerning direct trade, postal and transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The Boao Forum, initiated by 26 countries, including Japan, Australia and the Philippines, in 2001, is a non-governmental and non-profit international organization.
More than 1,000 Asian political figures, scholars and businessmen are expected to attend the Boao Forum scheduled from Nov. 1 to Nov. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECIDIVISM RATES AMONG INMATES HIGH: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice Interior Minister Hsu Ing-shen said Friday that the recidivism rate of new prisoners in 2002 was as high as 46.9 percent, highlighting the need to address the problem squarely.

Hsu made the remarks when he attended a seminar on criminal correction, monitoring and protection that was sponsored by the relevant graduate schools of Central Police University, National Chung Cheng University and National Taipei University.
Hsu said that the high recidivism rate shows that the correctional, monitoring and protection system of released inmates has flaws and the government needs to come up with countermeasures.

He said that with the transformation of Taiwan's economy, the crime rate is increasing rapidly. He noted that there are around 480,000 criminal cases reported every year in Taiwan, an average of more than 1,300 cases per day. Larceny accounts for the largest proportion at 70 percent, he added.
He said that larceny induces fear among the public and the National Police Administration should focus on cutting the number of larceny crimes so that the public can be free from fear.
Hsu noted that 378,939 criminal cases were reported in the first nine months of this year, down 1.61 percent from the previous year, although the rate of case-solving is up 1.42 percent.

According to Hsu, Taiwan's crime rate compared with other countries was 2,196 cases per 100,000 people, which is the sixth-lowest behind Turkey, Singapore, Argentina, Chile and Bulgaria. In terms of crime-solving rates, Taiwan is the third-highest at 55.25 percent, only lower than Turkey and South Africa. He did not cite the sources for the figures he offered.

He claimed that this shows that social order in Taiwan is good and that the law enforcement authorities should be recognized. However, he admitted that since a great majority of the people do not agree with this viewpoint, there is still ample room for improvement.

Central Police University President Tsai Teh-huei agreed that the recidivism rate among inmates was too high. He said this "has led to awaste of national resources" and that the government needs to address the overall importance of correctional institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL ALLIANCE FOR DEMOCRACY AND PEACE HOLDING CONFERENCE IN HOUSTON
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Oct. 30 (CNA) (by Y. Y. Chen and EH)

TEXT.P: The Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace is holding a three-day conference in Houston.

President Chen Shui-bian and the presidents of five Yuans have sent congratulatory messages to the global meeting of the alliance, which has more than 80 branches in various parts of the world. Several Taiwan officials and U. S. lawmakers have agreed to attend the meeting.

In the meeting, Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan will deliver a speech on "Democratic Taiwan and Cross-Taiwan Strait Peace." Minister Chang Fu-mei of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission has arrived in Houston to meet with participants in the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO HOLD DIALOGUES AND CONSULTATIONS WITH CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Oct. 30 (CNA) (by Y. Y. Chen and EH)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to hold dialogues and consultations with mainland China in order to increase mutual exchanges, President Chen Shui-bian said in a written message to a conference of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace in Houston.
In the message, President Chen said however that Taiwan will not push for more exchanges and consultations with China at the expense of its national sovereignty, dignity, and security.
Taiwan will continue to actively participate in international affairs through cultural exchanges, humanitarian assistance, and cooperation in economic activities, he said.

He said Beijing is still sticking to such rhetoric as "One China," and "One Country, Two Systems." and trying its best to isolate Taiwan in the international arena. It has even repeatedly obstructed Taiwan's efforts to join the World Health Organization. By doing so, Beijing has badly hurt the feeling of Taiwan people, he said.
President Chen said he has taken several steps to show his goodwill and sincerity to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations since his Presidential inauguration in 2000.
An organization of overseas Chinese with more than 80 branches in various parts of the world, the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace is holding a three-day conference in Houston.
In his message, President Chen expressed the hope that the alliance will be able to help accelerate the peaceful evolution of mainland China into a free and democratic country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSERVATIONISTS WATCHING BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL ARRIVALS

TEXT.P: Conservationists said Friday that the number of black-faced spoonbills arriving at their major wintering habitat in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, has been less than last year's arrivals and they are watching closely to see how many arrive next month.

In view of the botulism poisoning that caused a die-off among the endangered birds at the end of last year and early this year, the conservationists said that if the number of arrivals in November does not match that of last year, they will have to assume that the poisoning has affected the birds' population level.

Bird watchers reported that they had counted 307 black-faced spoonbills at the Chiku wetland sanctuary near the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County as of Friday. The figure is nearly 20 percent lower than the 372 recorded as of Oct. 29, 2002.

Conservationists said that the number of arrivals usually peaks in November. Last year, more than 700 arrived in that month, setting a record high. However, since Dec. 9, the birds began to die from botulism poisoning, eventually causing the death of 73 birds, or 10 percent of the arrivals, despite all-out efforts to save them.

The conservationists said that the reproduction rate of black-faced spoonbills is between 8 percent and 12 percent per year, and that extrapolating from the deaths and the reproduction rate, the maximum number of arrivals this year should be maintained at around 700.
If the number is less than 700, then the conclusion must be that the poisoning has caused an effect on overall numbers, they added.

To avoid any repetition of last year's poisoning, the Tainan County Livestock Disease Control Center has since June been monitoring the Chiku wetlands and has so far found five sites that have tested positive for the botulin bacteria.
Center officials have stepped up the removal of dead fish, shrimp and other shellfish from infected sites and are turning the soil regularly to let the sun kill off the bacteria.

Each year, a large number of black-faced spoonbills migrate from the Korean peninsula and northeastern mainland China to the Chiku wetlands to spend the winter. Last year's die-off was the first of its kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY BUDGET, PROCUREMENT INSTITUTIONALIZED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the country's military budget and procurement systems are institutionalized, transparent and in compliance with existing laws.

Yu made the remarks while answering questions at a legislative interpellation session from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ho Tsai-feng, who argued that it is extremely inappropriate of President Chen Shui-bian to attend a dinner party Friday in New York at which a U.S. arms dealer will also be present as a co-host.

Pointing out that Chen will be only a guest at the dinner banquet hosted by the New York-based International League for Human Rights (ILHR) in his honor, Yu claimed that it will be "impossible" for the president to discuss any relevant issues with the individual, let alone make any promises to him in the public eye.
"The ILHR's decision to present a human rights award to President Chen was also made in line with objective values in a country ruled by law," the premier noted.

Commenting on media speculation that a speech to be given by Chen at the dinner party will have to be screened in advance by the U.S. authorities, Foreign Affairs Vice Minister Kau Ying-mao categorically denied the speculation. He stressed that "two-way contacts are close between Taiwan and the United States, and the government will also stick to its basic principles."
"The dinner banquet has been arranged by the ILHR and President Chen is not in a position to make any comment on the issue, " he further explained.

Traveling at the head of a 100-member delegation, Chen left Taiwan Friday local time for New York for a two-day transit stop en route to Panama, where he will take part in the Central American diplomatic partner's Nov. 3 centenary celebrations.

During his short stay in New York, the non-government ILHR will present its 2003 Human Rights Award to Chen Friday in recognition of his contributions to Taiwan's human rights and democratization, following which the president will give a 20-minute speech.
Chen is slated to proceed to Panama Nov. 1 and to return to Taiwan Nov. 6 via Alaska.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.070 to finish at NT$33.980.
A total of US$424 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.975 and was traded between NT$33.930 and NT$33.980.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIONS WITH CHINA NOT WITHOUT DIFFICULT ISSUES: RICE

TEXT.P: "U.S. relations with China are in good shape, but it's not that we don't have difficult issues," Dr. Condoleezza Rice, assistant to the President for national security affairs, said Thursday at a briefing on U.S. foreign policy for foreign journalists based in New York.

Rice pointed out that the U.S. has concerns about nuclear proliferation, about the progress in China towards human rights and religious freedom, and is concerned that China may not be faithful to its WTO obligations.

The White House national security adviser said that in the recent six-party talks over the Korean peninsula situation, China showed that it was not only a host, but also played a central role in the talks.

"Everybody in that region, Japan, South Korea, Russia, and most of all, China recognizes that a non-nuclear Korean peninsula is essential to peace and security, not only in the Korean sense, but in Northeast Asia and in the world," she said.

Rice began the briefing with a report on the U.S. prospect of building a "just, decent, modern and democratic Iraq." She called on the international community to lend a helping hand in rebuilding Iraq.

Condemning the terrorist attacks on aid workers of international organizations and the Iraqi people, Rice said that the brutal killers have made Red Cross workers and innocent people their victims. The terrorists are blocking the road to Iraq becoming a democratic country, she added.
Referring to the Palestine issue, Rice said that all parties, including Israel, Palestine and the neighboring Mideast countries, should commit themselves to a peaceful resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST AMPHETAMINE MANUFACTURING PLANT IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Police announced Friday that they had busted a large amphetamine manufacturing factory in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, seizing amphetamine with an estimated street value of NT$500 million (US$14.28 million).

Police and investigation agents raided the factory in Taliao, Kaohsiung County, the previous day, seizing 14 kg of amphetamine in solid form and nearly 700 kg in liquid form, as well as a large amount of equipment used to manufacture the drug.
Police arrested chief suspect Lee Wen-cheng and were continuing to track down two other suspects, who were still at large. It was the ninth amphetamine manufacturing plant to be busted this year.
Police were tipped off in October 2002 that Lee was preparing to produce amphetamine and they conducted the raid after an extensive surveillance operation.

Law enforcement authorities noted that drug dealers in the past have tended to manufacture amphetamine in Taiwan for export overseas. Later, they began producing the drug in mainland China, bringing it back to Taiwan for export.
However, recent signs have shown that producers have begun to relocate their overseas manufacturing plants back to Taiwan, hence a recent rise in amphetamine production activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed lower Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 66 points to close at 6,068, with 32,533 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 79 points to close at 6,055, with 414 contracts traded, while futures for March dipped 93 points to finish at 6,060 with 15 contracts traded.
June futures gave up 75 points to close at 6,060, with six contract transactions and September futures slid 90 points to finish at 6,060, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,134 for November, 6,134 for December, 6,153 for March, 6,135 for June and 6,150 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also closed lower.
November TE futures moved down 6.5 points to close at 258, with 5,714 contracts changing hands, while December TE futures lost 7.15 points to finish at 258 points, with 109 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

November TF futures lost six points to finish at 902.2, with 7,681 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 6.2 points to finish at 901.2, with 56 contracts traded and TF futures for March declined 6.4 points to close at 899.6, with 11 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITIES PITCH IN FOR CALIFORNIA WILDFIRE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Tzu Chi Relief Foundation and the Buddha's Light International Association have both pitched in with salvation work in southern California, where wildfires had continued for a 10th day Thursday.
California-based followers of Tzu Chi and Buddha's Light have either established relief centers or begun fund-raising drives in efforts to help exhausted firefighters as well as local residents.

According to Tsai Hsiu-yun, deputy CEO of the Tzu Chi operations in the United States, Tzu Chi voluntary workers have frantically transported relief goods, including bottled water, snack food packages, blankets and masks, to affected areas for distribution to those in need.

Tzu Chi has also presented sums ranging from US$500 to US$1,000 to each of the Californian families whose houses have been destroyed in the blazes or who have lost family members to the wildfires. A total of US$45,000 had been distributed as of Thursday, Tsai said.
Meanwhile, members of the Buddha's Light Association in San Diego have started a fund-raising campaign there, hoping to raise US$30,000 to be used as relief funds.

The death toll from the wildfires roaring through southern California had risen to 22 as of Thursday, including one firefighter, as the infernos chewed up 728,750 acres and destroyed more than 3,000 buildings.
More than 13,000 firefighters have been laboring in 13 different locations, where at least 100,000 people have been evacuated from their homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH TEACHING IN OFFSHORE COUNTIES INADEQUATE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: There is a noticeable gap between Taiwan proper and the smaller islands it controls regarding English teaching resources and learning environments, according to a recent survey conducted by the privately run King Car Education Foundation.

The poll results show that 93.6 percent of school children questioned around the country think it is important to learn English, a stark contrast to just 9 percent who do not think so. However, the poll also revealed that only 34 percent of those polled really enjoy learning English, while 38 percent in Taipei County acknowledged that they learn English only in order to pass examinations.

The results also show that a larger ratio of primary school students on the islands do not like learning English and that there are insufficient English textbooks and language learning activities at their schools. Some 47 percent of them said they have never read any English books, while about 44 percent said they have no confidence in talking with foreigners in English.

Similar surveys carried out in the past mainly focused on the differences between the north and the south, but the King Car investigation reveals that the gap between Taiwan proper and the remoter islands is growing increasingly wide, a foundation official said.

Although the government means well in providing English education to elementary school children, he reminded the education authorities that they need to pay heed to the problem of inadequate teaching resources and facilities on the islands and in remote areas.

The government should pay close attention when allocating budgets and resources in this field, he suggested, adding that the foundation has donated 800 English-language children's books to Kinmen County and has also recruited a group of voluntary foreign teachers to teach English there on a short-term basis.

The survey, carried out earlier this month, collected valid responses from 1,452 fifth- and sixth-graders attending school on Kinmen, Matsu, Penghu, Orchid and Green islands and in remote areas of northern Taipei County, central Nantou County and southern Chiayi County.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Israeli Officer Says Tactics Are Backfiring.
Israel's senior military commander told columnists for three leading newspapers this week that Israel's military tactics against the Palestinian population were too repressive and were fomenting explosive levels of "hatred and terrorism" that might become impossible to control.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CLAIMS INDEPENDENCE ISSUE DOES NOT EXIST

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated the government's stance Friday that the issue regarding whether Taiwan should declare independence is non-existent.
Yu made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan plenary session in which opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chang asked the premier about issues regarding Taiwan's status.
While some people have adopted the viewpoint that Taiwan's status remains problematic, Yu claimed that the issue is actually non-existent.

"Taiwan is an independent sovereign country whose official designation is the Republic of China," Yu said, adding that the ROC's existence has been confirmed through a series of popular elections for the president, legislators and other public officials over the years.
Now that the people elect the president, Yu went on, Taiwan is certainly an independent sovereign state.

Chang, who once served as the ROC minister of foreign affairs during the previous KMT administration, further questioned Yu about the feasibility of Taiwan declaring de jure independence, to which Yu replied that Taiwan need not declare independence since it is already an independent sovereign state.

Yu further said Taiwan's diplomatic plight mainly results from mainland China's suppression. "So long as Beijing continues its diplomatic embargo against us, we'll have a hard time using our official national title in major international organizations, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTROLUX INCREASES DIRECT SOURCING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Electrolux, the largest household electrical appliances dealer in the world, has decided to increase its direct sourcing in Taiwan under a policy of "trimming prices while upgrading quality, " officials from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Friday.

Electrolux, whose big-name household electrical appliances include the Electrolux, Westinghouse, White-Westinghouse, Frigidaire, AEG and CHEF brands -- established an office in Taiwan for direct sourcing earlier this year, after years of minor indirect purchases from Taiwan via its Hong Kong operations office.

Having targeted direct sourcing of finished and semi-finished parts and components worth about US$50 million in its first year of direct sourcing in Taiwan, Electrolux staged a sample showing workshop at the Taipei International Convention Center Friday to brief Taiwan makers and suppliers on Electrolux's direct local sourcing policy and targeted products.
Under its "trimming prices while upgrading quality" policy, Eletrolux -- a Sweden-based company -- plans to increase its direct local sourcing in Asia this year to US$400 million.
About 300 Taiwan household electrical appliances makers and suppliers attended the workshop.

Eletrolux posts an average business turnover of US$14 billion annually. It has more than 100 factories around the world and the company's sourcing of machinery, electrical machines, electronic parts and components, as well as moulding systems, reaches US$10 billion each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK PRICES DECLINE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: The stock prices declined on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted price index moving down 63.01 points to close at 6,045.12.
The bourse opened at 6,110.78, and then fluctuated between 6,117.86 and 6,029.54. A total of 4.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$102.51 billion (US$3.01 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most with 1.9 percent, followed by construction shares with 1.7 percent, plastic and chemical stocks with 1.3 percent, and banking and insurance issues with 0.1 percent.
The prices of electric stocks moved down the most with 2.1 percent, followed by textile issues with 1.1 percent, cement stocks with 0.8 percent, and pulp and paper shares with 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 502 to 283, with 122 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC RESTATES SUBMARINE BUILDING CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: The state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) reiterated Friday that it is capable of building submarines.

CSBC restated its submarine building capabilities in the wake of reports from the Legislative Yuan Friday that an eight-member U.S. group, headed by Gibson G. LeBoeuf, deputy chief of the U.S. Navy International Program Department, expressed its hope that the CSBC not take part in building the submarines given its incapability of developing submarines.

The U.S. officials were quoted by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kao Chung-yuan as saying that CSBC'S ship assembling capability is probably O.K., but its capabilities in developing weapon systems, dynamic systems and electronic instruments -- vital parts of a submarine -- are inadequate.

The U.S. officials expressed their hopes at the Legislative Yuan Thursday that Taiwan's Legislature will pass the budget -- between NT$300 billion and NT$400 billion (US$8.85 billion - US$11.8 billion) for eight diesel-powered submarines -- for the submarine procurement project by July 2004 to pave the way for a speedy implementation of the plan.

Referring to an assessment report filed recently by a German consultant group, CSBC officials said that CSBC is capable of building submarines, given the strength of the CSBC and the Republic of China Navy, as well as the capabilities of the private industrial sector.

The idea of the CSBC building submarines for Taiwan is by no means a fantasy, said members of the German consultant group, who recently completed a one-week assessment tour of Taiwan, mainly visiting CSBC's plants.

By combining the capabilities and resources of the ROC Navy and Taiwan's private industrial sector, the CSBC could produce submarines after upgrading some of its facilities by introducing some cutting-edge technologies and employing younger welders, the German consultants said in a recently-released assessment report.

The Executive Yuan established a cross-division ad hoc committee, headed by Vice Premier Lin Hsin-yi, in January this year to facilitate plans calling for some of the eight diesel-powered submarines that the United States has promised to sell to Taiwan to be built in Taiwan by the CSBC.

CSBC officials said that the CSBC has built a simulated model of a section of pressure hull for a submarine and is now focusing on more advanced research such as building the end plate of a pressure hull.

CSBC officials said that the company's 2,300-plus staff at the Kaohsiung Shipyard should be capable of building the submarines if the company can get the technology from the United States and other countries that have experience in sub-building.

The officials said that there is a lot of follow-up maintenance work on submarines, and that only by building a submarine itself can the CSBC be able to effectively supply follow-up maintenance operations.
The U.S. government announced in 2001 a robust package of arms it had agreed to sell to Taiwan, including the eight diesel-powered submarines.

Taiwan formally filed a request in 1995 for procurement of the subs from the United States in an effort to beef up its deterrence capabilities against possible attempts by mainland China to blockade Taiwan.

According to CSBC officials, it is hoped that a "2-2-2-2" plan will be followed in the building of the eight diesel-powered subs, where the first two subs are built totally in the United States or elsewhere abroad, one-third of the third and fourth subs are built in Taiwan, two-thirds of the fifth and sixth subs are manufactured in Taiwan, and the last two subs are built completely in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR U.S. EN ROUTE TO PANAMA FOR OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian left Taiwan for New York Friday for a two-day transit stop on his way to Panama for an official visit.

The president said that he will attend the centennial celebrations in Panama, one of the staunchest allies of the Republic of China, and exchange notes with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso on a free trade agreement signed by the two leaders in Taipei on Aug. 21.

Chen said that during his transit stop in New York, he will receive an international human rights award as well as pay respects to Madame Chiang Kai-shek, who passed away at her Manhattan home last week.

The president said that "due to the concerted efforts of Taiwan people, and their love of democracy, freedom and human rights" he has the chance to receive the award, adding that the honor belongs to all people on Taiwan.

First lady Wu Shu-chen, Vice President Annette Lu, Democratic Progressive Party Secretary General Chang Chun-hsiung, Presidential Office Secretary General Chiou I-jen, Deputy Secretary General Chen Che-nan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials and the head of the foreign diplomatic corps were on hand to see off President Chen.

Chen said that he had told the presidents of the five Yuans that they have their own duties and need not come to the airport. He added that he hopes this will become a general practice that the presidents of the five Yuans, the Minister of National Defense and the Chief of the General Staff will no longer be present to see the president off from now on.

The president, heading a 100-member entourage, departed CKS International Airport at 11 a.m. via a chartered China Airline plane. This was Chen's fourth overseas trip since assuming office in May 2000.

According to the itinerary announced by the Presidential Office, President Chen will arrive on Oct. 31 at 1 p.m. New York time. He will go directly to the home of the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek to pay respects and express condolences to the family.

Madame Chiang, who had helped her husband -- the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tensions, died at her Manhattan home Oct. 23 at the age of 106.
In the afternoon, President Chen will receive New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, along with the New York State speaker, the New York City speaker and councilmen.
On the evening of Oct. 31, Chen will be honored with the International League for Human Rights' (ILHR's) 2003 Human Rights Award, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City where he will stay.

This will be the first time that the leader of the Republic of China has been bestowed with such an honor. The president will deliver a 20-minute speech on human rights issues after accepting the award.

On Nov. 1 New York time, the president will receive U.S. politicians, visit 911 Ground Zero and attend a dinner aboard a cruise vessel on the Hudson River to be given in his honor by major Taiwanese associations in the greater New York area.

The president will leave New York on the morning of Nov. 2 for Panama. He will meet with accompanying media at a tea party and meet with representatives of overseas Chinese and ROC technical missions in the afternoon before attending a dinner to be given in his honor.

Chen will attend the Central American country's centennial celebration on Nov. 3. Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso will accompany President Chen and leaders from other nations and diplomatic missions to Panama on a walk to the Panamanian city council square to attend a flag-raising ceremony and prayer ceremony for the nation.

President Chen will then attend a centennial celebration ceremony. He will also attend the inauguration ceremony of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Building. Chen will attend a luncheon in his honor given by President Moscoso and other national leaders.
On Nov. 4, Chen will hold talks with President Moscoso and exchange notes on a free trade agreement signed by the two leaders in Taipei Aug. 21.

The president will then take part in a monument unveiling ceremony to commemorate the renovation of a church and national theater and the completion of a children's museum before leaving for Anchorage, Alaska.

On Nov. 5, Alaska time, the president will take a three-and-half hour train ride to view the magnificent scenery of Alaska and attend a luncheon given by Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski, a staunch supporter of Taiwan. He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Nov. 6.

Members of Chen's entourage include National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiung, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary General Joseph Wu, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, leaders of the nation's five largest commerce and industry associations, lawmakers of various political parties and many other senior officials.

Turkish Daily News: [PKK-AI Qaeda link feared]
Both Iraqi Kurds and Turkish intelligence sources agree that bringing the PKK down from the mountains of northern Iraq is mission impossible. They say a PKK-Ai Qaeda link may give bin Laden's people a foothold in the Kandil Mountains and create a nightmare for Turks, Iraqis and the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FORM NEW ASSOCIATION TO PROMOTE TAIWAN-CANADA TIES

TEXT.P: More than 60 lawmakers from across the political spectrum formed a new association Friday to boost parliamentary exchanges between Taiwan and Canada.

Legislator Cheng Kuo-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said he and his colleagues decided to form the ROC (Taiwan)-Canada Parliamentary Friendship Association after their Canadian counterparts took the initiative to establish an amity group last year to promote exchanges with Taiwan's legislative branch.
To the best of his understanding, Cheng said, 109 Canadian parliamentarians have joined the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group.
John MaKay, president of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, extended his congratulations on the establishment of a parallel parliamentary group in Taiwan via a video tribute.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau and Ted Lipman, executive director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, which represents Canadian interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, attended the inaugural ceremony of the new friendship group in the Legislative Yuan.
Addressing the ceremony, Lipman said Canada-Taiwan trade and economic relations have been cordial, with bilateral trade volume growing continually.
Two-way exchanges in other fields have also been growing steadily, Lipman said, adding that three Canadian parliamentary delegations have visited Taiwan over the past year.
Lipman said the establishment of the ROC (Taiwan)-Canada Parliamentary Friendship Association is of great significance in the development of relations between the two countries.
For his part, Kau said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will offer full support for the new parliamentary amity group as it marks an important step in promoting bilateral relations.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Kau said, Taiwan-Canada relations have been close. Taiwan citizens make an average of 150,000 visits to Canada annually, making Taiwan Canada's seventh largest source of tourist arrivals. The number of Taiwan expatriates in Canada, including those doing advanced study there, has also been rising steadily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MELOR EXPECTED TO BRING RAINS TO EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Light typhoon Melor, located 570 kilometers east of Manila at 8 a.m. Friday, is expected to bring rains to eastern Taiwan in the next few days.
According to Central Weather Bureau forecasts, from Friday evening Melor will bring three or four days of rain to eastern Taiwan.
The weather bureau is studying what other impacts Melor may have on the weather of Taiwan.
Another typhoon, Parma, is currently moving in an east-northeast direction from the seas 1,600 kilometers east-northeast of Iwo Jima. The medium typhoon is unlikely to affect the weather of Taiwan.
The weather in most parts of Taiwan is fair and cool on Friday, with temperatures ranging from 20 Celsius to 30 Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PROCUREMENT IS INSTITUTIONALIZED: TANG

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said Friday that the major military procurement plans of the nation have been institutionalized, with decisions made systematically.
"Once the decisions are made, no individuals are supposed to exert personal clout to alter the decisions, " Tang said at the Legislative Yuan.

Tang said that since he assumed office, he has seen to it that all major military and weaponry procurement projects have been implemented systematically, with the Ministry of National Defense (MND) hammering out procurement draft plans first. The drafts are then approved by the Executive Yuan and submitted to the Legislative Yuan for passage before those plans are actually carried out.
Tang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions regarding Taiwan's military purchases from the United States.

During an interpellation session, he was asked about the truth of allegations that President Chen Shui-bian is going to meet with U.S. arms suppliers during his two-day transit stop in New York on his way to Panama for a state visit, and whether his U.S. visit involves a conflict of interests.
Tang declined to make comments on those allegations, and said that the MND has not sent an official as a member of President Chen's entourage.

In a rare visit to the Legislative Yuan Thursday, a group of U.S. Navy officials actively lobbied a submarine sales plan to Taiwan -- a procurement that would cost between NT$300 billion and NT$400 billion (US$8.85 billion - US$11.8 billion) for eight diesel-powered submarines.

The eight-member U.S. group, headed by Gibson G. LeBoeuf, deputy chief of the U.S. Navy International Program Department, expressed its hope at the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan's Legislature will pass the budget for the submarine procurement project by July 2004 to pave the way for aspeedy implementation of the plan.
Since the United States stopped producing diesel submarines long ago, its contractors will have to cooperate with their European counterparts to build the subs for Taiwan.
LeBoeuf and his group members said that the United States will be instrumental in arranging the building of the eight 2,000-ton diesel submarines by either Germany or Spain.
The U.S. officials were apparently not very agreeable to notions that Taiwan's state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) undertake the building of the eight diesel submarines.

They were quoted by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kao Chung-yuan as saying that the CSBC had better not take part in building the submarines. They said that CSBC'S capability to assemble ships is probably O.K., but its capabilities in developing weapon systems, dynamic systems and electronic instruments -- vital parts of a submarine -- are inadequate, according to Kao.

Most of the legislators who have been pushing for plans allowing CSBC to build part of the eight diesel submarines that the United States planned to sell to Taiwan are displeased with the opinions of the U.S. Navy officials.
The U.S. government announced in 2001 a robust package of arms it had agreed to sell to Taiwan, including the eight diesel-powered submarines.

Taiwan formally filed a request in 1995 for procurement of the submarines from the United States in an effort to beef up its deterrence capabilities against possible attempts by mainland China to blockade Taiwan.

Director General Hermogenes E. Ebdane Jr., chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP), placed yesterday on red alert all police units nationwide for the implementation of "Oplan Kaluluwa 2003" for the observance of All Saints' Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS IN SICHUAN ACCIDENT TO BE HOME BY FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Singaporeans caught up in a Sichuan tour bus accident will be heading home on Friday, provided they are well enough to travel.
Forty-two Singaporeans left on a 10-day trip of Southwest China on Saturday.
After arriving at Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province, they moved on to Jiuzhaigou, a popular scenic spot.
But on the fifth day on their way to Mao Xian, the bus they were traveling in toppled over while negotiating a winding road.
A 49-year-old man, who was traveling with his wife, died of a heart attack a short time later.
Singapore's Foreign Ministry said 40 people were admitted to hospitals.
Two Singaporean diplomats have arrived in Chengdu to monitor the condition and treatment of the 40 tourists who were dmitted to hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE IN RACE TO BECOME HERB RESEARCH CENTER

TEXT.P: Singapore and the John Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore, Maryland, have teamed up in an international race to become the first American-sponsored center outside the United States to research medicinal herbs.

The team already has a foot in the door -- it has won a US$274,480 planning grant which gives it two years to convince the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine in Bethesda, Maryland that such a center should be located in Singapore.
If the city is selected, it will be given a US$5 million grant for five years to do research in this area.

But it faces tough competition. Nine other teams, all involving top U.S. medical schools, are also in the running. They are collaborating with researchers from India, China, Japan, South Korea and South Africa.

DOC.TEXT:
New Straits Times: PM: Give full support to Abdullah.
Repeating his earlier recalls, and consistent with his stand on party unity, Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad today advised Umno supreme council members to give their undivided support to his successor, Datuk Seri Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. (noted: Umno-- United Malay National Organization. )

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 31, or the seventh day of the 10th month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two-member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."
